title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Formation Control for Networked Fixed-Wing UAVs: Self-Triggered Observer–Feedforward–Feedback Design and Experiment
authors: Hao Liu, Ziming Ren, Haibin Duan, Michael V. Basin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article studies the robust optimal formation control problem of networked fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) under communication uncertainties and external disturbances. A learning-based observer–feedforward–feedback control framework is constructed. A resilient self-triggered (ST) observer is designed to estimate reference data while enabling intermittent communication under communication uncertainties. By integrating reference estimation with a backstepping technique, the cooperative formation control problem is reformulated as a robust optimal regulation problem. The robust optimal feedforward control law is learned via an off-policy reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm that exploits the collected internal system data and external disturbance inputs. The stability of the constructed closed-loop control system is guaranteed, and Zeno behavior in the ST rule is avoided. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through an experimental study of multiple fixed-wing UAVs.

title: Unleashing the Potential of Multiple WiFi APs in Real-World Localization System
authors: Shuai Yang, Guanzhong Wang, Tianyu Zhang, Xuecheng Xie, Pengfei Yin, Ruiyuan Song, Dongheng Zhang, Yan Chen
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: WiFi indoor localization plays an important role in many real-world applications and has gained widespread attentions from both academia and industry over the past decade. While existing works have already achieved remarkable performance under various practical scenarios, they solely utilize multiple WiFi Access Points (APs) to achieve a higher accuracy and do not deeply explore the intrinsic relationships among them. To further unleash the potential of multiple APs and reach the limits of WiFi indoor localization, in this paper, we propose Qidi, a novel multi-APs collaboration based localization system. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to explicitly reveal three underlying relationships among multiple spatially distributed APs, i.e., consistency, continuity, and non-uniformity. By combining these three basic principles with the unique characteristics of specific tasks, a series of long-lasting practical challenges, such as automatic phase offset calibration, bilateral angle ambiguity, elevation angle estimation with Uniform Linear Array (ULA) and Non-Line-of-Sight (NLoS), can be efficiently resolved. Extensive experiments in various complex environments are provided to demonstrate that Qidi can achieve 2.4°, 3.2° median errors of joint azimuth and elevation angle estimation, and 0.4m localization median error even in 20m×20m exhibition hall. Moreover, a one-month longitudinal evaluation conducted on a real-world deployed WiFi ISAC system further validates the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed localization system.

title: Passive LC Relay Network-Enabled Battery-free Chipless IoT Smart Clothing for Simultaneous Multi-Site Hemodynamic Monitoring_supp4-3647891.mp4
authors: Ting-Wei Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: Smart clothing has emerged as a promising IoT-based healthcare platform by enabling distributed physiological sensing through body sensor networks (BSN). However, most systems rely on embedded chips and batteries, increasing complexity, weight, and cost that limit practicality. We present a battery-free chipless smart clothing that integrates thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU)-encapsulated passive LC relay networks to establish magnetic coupling between an external sensor reader and underlying arteries. Arterial pulsations induce resonant frequency shifts in the coupled system, enabling real-time pulse signal detection. Each sensing coil of passive LC relay networks is positioned at carotid, heart, radial, and femoral arteries, and four pickup coils are routed to a centralized hub on the upper left arm. A lightweight wireless reader with four channels simultaneously acquires multi-site physiological signals. Importantly, passive LC relay networks serve as magnetic field repeaters, enhancing magnetic coupling across extended distances. By matching resonant frequencies of passive LC relay networks and sensor reader at 7.3 MHz, the system achieved a power transfer efficiency (PTE) of 46.56 %, clearly outperforming the capacitor-free configuration, which yielded only 6 %. Notably, a minimum PTE threshold of 0.24 % was established for distinguishable pulse detection. The system showed robustness after water-spray exposure and supported signal acquisition through outer garments up to 21.22 mm thick between sensor reader and centralized hub, confirming resilience to sweat and compatibility with layered clothing. Overall, our battery-free chipless BSN offers lightweight, low-cost, and disposable smart clothing solutions for simultaneous multi-site hemodynamic monitoring, potentially calculating pulse wave velocity for peripheral vascular stiffness assessment.

title: DFT-s-OFDM-Based Linear Frequency Modulated Pulse Waveforms for ISAC Systems
authors: Ruiqi Liu, Yihua Ma, Rongwei Shi, Junpeng Lou, Chuangxin Jiang, Ruyue Yu-Ngok Li
publish: IEEE Communications Standards Magazine
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) has been recognized as a critical usage scenario for the 6th generation (6G) networks, and is expected to cover a variety of emerging use cases benefiting daily users as well as vertical industries. Candidate waveforms for sensing reference signals (RSs) are now being discussed in global standardization organizations considering multiple sensing modes and scenarios. In this article, a discrete Fourier transform spread orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (DFT-s-OFDM) based linear frequency modulated (LFM) pulse waveform is proposed as the ISAC waveform for both uplink and downlink. The generation procedure for this waveform is introduced, and the advantages of it are analyzed and demonstrated by simulation results. The standardization roadmap for ISAC waveforms is also presented.

title: Behavior-Controllable Stable Dynamics Models on Riemannian Configuration Manifolds_supp1-3647763.mp4
authors: Frank Park
publish: N/A
abstract: Due to their stability and robustness properties, Stable Dynamical Systems (SDS) have received considerable attention as a means of representing motions in learning from demonstration tasks. Designing vector fields that fit complex trajectories while ensuring stability still remains a key challenge; although recent deep learning-based methods have shown substantial progress in this direction, their tendency to overfit to demonstration trajectories often leads to undesirable behaviors, particularly as tasks deviate from demonstrations. At a fundamental level, the only reliable way to address this lack of generalization is to provide supervision in out-of-demonstration regions. Focusing on two types of general behaviors, mimicking and contracting, we propose a Behavior-Controllable Stable Dynamics Model (BCSDM), a one-parameter family of SDS that allows users to adjust the system's overall behavior depending on user intent. We show how to extend BCSDM to accommodate demonstrations of multiple tasks, and also propose a Deep Operator Vector Field (DeepOVec) for memory-efficient encoding of multiple dynamical systems. Extensive experiments on tasks that involve mimicking or contracting behaviors demonstrate the advantages of BCSDMs over existing state-of-the-art SDS learning methods.

title: Adaptive Tuning of the Unscented Kalman Filter using Particle Swarm Optimization for Inertial-GPS Sensor Fusion Systems
authors: Psyche T. Malabo, Bobby D. Gerardo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Accurate vehicle positioning requires effective IMU-GPS fusion, yet prior methods-EKF, UKF, ML, GA, and DE-suffer from nonlinearity, instability, or high computational cost. This study introduces a PSO-based adaptive tuning framework for optimizing UKF parameters ($\alpha, \beta, \kappa, Q, R$), evaluated in CARLA 0.9.14 using a Tesla Model 3 under diverse maneuvers and environmental conditions. Within defined parameter bounds, convergence stabilized within 15 generations, achieving an $82.14 \%$ accuracy improvement over manual tuning and reducing IMU drift by up to $\mathbf{2 1, 6 0 6. 5 9 m}$. Multi-trial statistical validation confirmed consistent gains with low confidence intervals. With update times remaining below the 10 ms real-time threshold, the PSO-tuned UKF demonstrates practical localization performance for dynamic, GPS-challenged conditions.

title: Vision-Guided Control of a 3-DoF Robotic Arm for Seaweed Sorting using Faster R-CNN
authors: Adi Kurniawan Saputro, Muhhammad Iyan Putra Pratama, Iqbal Ali Maulana Riyadi, Achmad Fiqhi Ibadillah, Monika Faswia Fahmi, Deni Tri Laksono
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Seaweed is one of the leading commodities in the marine sector. The quality of seaweed significantly affects its price and usability, making sorting an important step. However, manual sorting is inconsistent, time consumption, and reliance on human subjectivity. This research aims to design and develop an automated system using a robotic arm equipped with image processing technology based on the Faster Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (Faster R-CNN) algorithm. The designed system involves capturing seaweed images, extracting features, classifying the quality using deep learning, and controlling the robotic arm to move the seaweed to containers according to its category. Test results showed that the system could classify good quality seaweed with an accuracy of $93.67 \%$ (207 out of 221 samples) and poor-quality seaweed with an accuracy of $81.48 \%$ (176 out of 216 samples). Additionally, the system achieved an operational success rate of $73.33 \%$ for good quality and $60 \%$ for poor-quality seaweed. One obstacle encountered was the gripper’s insufficient strength in gripping the object. This system demonstrates that the application of artificial intelligence and robotics can significantly enhance the efficiency, accuracy, and consistency of the seaweed sorting process, contributing to the advancement of Indonesia’s seaweed industry.

title: Multi-class Classification for Natural Language Processing
authors: Ginka Marinova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Multi-class classification is a current research area within machine learning, aimed at solving problems where input data is categorized into more than two classes. The dataset is in English and includes various news topics, articles and answers collected from the Internet. Efficient multi-class classification algorithms are used, which demonstrate high performance in various tasks. In this report, the problem of multi-class classification of text with the following algorithms was examined, Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Neural Network (NN). Mathematical models are created that classify input data into multiple classes. For the implementation of the empirical study, pre-processing of data, feature extraction, and three algorithms for text classification were selected. A comparative analysis of the results was made. The results of the classification show an accuracy ranging from 0.65 to 0.83, with a maximum of 1. Among the three evaluated classifiers, two of them, Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Neural Network (NN) have an accuracy of 0.83. The results show that the methods are effective for classifying news by topic.

title: Non-programmers Assessing AI-Generated Code: A Case Study of Business Users Analyzing Data
authors: Yuvraj Virk, Dongyu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Non-technical end-users increasingly rely on AI code generation to perform technical tasks like data analysis. However, large language models (LLMs) remain unreliable, and it is unclear whether end-users can effectively identify model errors - especially in realistic and domain-specific scenarios. We surveyed marketing and sales professionals to assess their ability to critically evaluate LLM-generated analyses of marketing data. Participants were shown natural language explanations of the AI’s code, repeatedly informed the AI often makes mistakes, and explicitly prompted to identify them. Yet, participants frequently failed to detect critical flaws that could compromise decisionmaking, many of which required no technical knowledge to recognize. To investigate why, we reformatted AI responses into clearly delineated steps and provided alternative approaches for each decision to support critical evaluation. While these changes had a positive effect, participants often struggled to reason through the AI’s steps and alternatives. Our findings suggest that business professionals cannot reliably verify AIgenerated data analyses on their own and explore reasons why to inform future designs. As non-programmers adopt codegenerating AI for technical tasks, unreliable AI and insufficient human oversight poses risks of unsafe or low-quality decisions.

title: Multigrain Sentiment Analysis on User Reviews in Bulgarian – Comparison Between Stemmed and Non-stemmed Data
authors: Daniela Petrova, Diyan Dinev, Dimitrichka Nikolaeva
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study presents the development of a multiclass sentiment classification model for Bulgarian user reviews, based on a newly constructed and systematically preprocessed dataset. A comprehensive preprocessing pipeline was applied, including duplicate removal, filtering of Latin-script entries, elimination of comments without ratings, stop word removal, and stemming, resulting in a clean corpus of 87,884 unique records distributed across five sentiment categories. To address the substantial class imbalance, under sampling was applied, producing a balanced dataset suitable for robust evaluation. The classification task was performed using a stacked ensemble model that integrates Support Vector Machines (SVM), a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network with lexicon-based features, and a Random Forest meta-classifier. Experimental results demonstrate that while overall accuracy decreases in the balanced setting, class-level performance becomes more consistent, particularly in minority categories. Moreover, preserving original (non-stemmed) word forms consistently outperforms stemming, especially for mid-range sentiment classes, indicating that morphological richness plays a crucial role in Bulgarian sentiment analysis.

title: Effect of the Atmospheric Boundary Layer on a Simplified Truck Model
authors: Nikita Dobin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents a compact, coefficient-based workflow to transfer wind-tunnel data of a truck-like bluff body to realistic atmospheric boundary-layer (ABL) exposure. A neutral log-law wind profile is combined with vehicle motion via rigorous vector composition; integrating the relative-wind kinetic energy over height yields the height-averaged dynamic pressure ${{\bar q}}$ and the effective center-of-pressure height hcp. The operative yaw β is the sensed angle at hcp, not the meteorological azimuth. Using a stationary Uniform reference with identical (U10, βm) enables transparent ABL-to-Uniform comparisons. For a full-scale truck (H = 4.0 m, B = 2.55 m, L = 12.0 m), ABL shear reduces ${{\bar q}}$ for given U10 and raises hcp; for moving vehicles the reduction in ${{\bar q}}$ dominates so roll moments are generally lower under ABL than under Uniform flow at the same external conditions. The method supports engineering assessments, parametric studies, and risk-aware design checks under crosswind.

title: Understanding User and Developer Perceptions of and Responses to Dark Patterns in Online UIs
authors: Huayu Liang, Syeda Afia Zahin Hossain, Chris Brown
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: As dependence on software applications grows, so are the persuasive designs that impact users’ experience and decision-making in online user interfaces (UIs). Dark patterns are UI design choices crafted to manipulate or trick users into actions that are not intended. Scholarship on dark patterns is vastly increasing-however, there is limited work on how dark patterns impact users’ perceptions and interaction with applications. Furthermore, research has yet to investigate dark patterns from the perspective of software engineers who implement UI designs. We explore users’ and developers’ perceptions of dark patterns using a mixed-methods approach, surveying each stakeholder group ($N_{\text {user }}=66$ and $N_{\text {developer }}=38$) and mining GitHub data $(N=2556)$. Our findings reveal that dark patterns encountered online leave users with limited or no options for avoidance. Developers report that external pressures influence their decisions to implement dark patterns, and most recognize their adverse effects on trust and user experiences (UX), often reflecting negative sentiments in software projects. Our findings shed light on mitigating deceptive designs in online interfaces that are increasingly essential in people’s daily lives. title: Digital Twin Framework for Multi-Tank Systems with OPC UA Interoperability and Real-Time Control and Visualization
authors: Galo Guzmán-Guillén, Luis A. Andrade, Luis I. Minchala
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents the design and evaluation of a digital twin framework for a nonlinear multi-tank control system, relying entirely on open-source technologies. A key component of the architecture is a custom-built OPC UA aggregating server, developed with the open62541 library and deployed on a low-cost single-board computer. This server acts as a bridge between the physical system and digital models, republishing real-time measurements and estimating unmeasured functionalities into Godot via GDExtension, which enables an interactive 3D digital twin. Experimental validation showed high agreement between the real system and the digital models, with correlation coefficients above 0.96 and low MAE and RMSE values. These results highlight the effectiveness of the proposed open-source OPC UA-based architecture for real-time monitoring, simulation, and control in cyber-physical systems.

title: Algorithm of Quantum Walk From Energy-Based Bayesian Probabilities
authors: Huber Nieto-Chaupis
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The ordinary problem of quantum walk is studied through Bayesian probabilities. Thus, in according to relevance of individual steps, the energy is calculated. In this manner, main idea consists in the differences between probability respect to previous ones, and how it is harnessed for an optimal quantum walk. Essentially, the walk is associated to those space-time where particle is approaching to some target or being far away of it. Thus, the definition of quantum mechanics evolution operator is exploited in order to orient to particle in a most stable state. Because of this, particle’s energy would vary while particle is passing over the allowed space-time points. When energy is much more than allowed to particle, the trajectory is adjusted and the subsequent steps are efficiently reconfigured to the ones where particle would optimize its total energy. An algorithm is proposed and tested.

title: Weather Data Prediction using the XGBoost Algorithm on a LoRa-Based Weather Station System
authors: Luthfansyah Mohammad, Didi Alfandi, Jidan Humaidi, Lisa’ Yihaa Roodhiyah
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Weather prediction is crucial in sectors such as energy, transportation, and construction, where accurate forecasts can reduce significant economic losses. In Indonesia, diverse topography, uneven GSM/4G coverage, and limited satellite accuracy hinder reliable local predictions. This study proposes the design and implementation of a LoRa-based weather station integrated with a HONDE HD-WSM-U-07 multi-parameter sensor and machine learning prediction using the XGBoost algorithm. The system collects real-time weather data and transmits it through LoRa communication, enabling deployment in remote areas without GSM infrastructure. Historical data from an Automatic Weather Station (AWS) and local sensor measurements are used to train regression models for temperature, humidity, irradiation, and rainfall prediction. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves an $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ of up to 0.9, ensuring reliable performance. The integration of LoRa communication and XGBoost provides an energy-efficient, low-cost, and accurate weather prediction system, supporting local meteorological needs and community resilience in rural Indonesia.

title: System-Wise Reliability Assessment in District Heating Systems: Integrating Technical and Customer-Centric Indices
authors: Amir Rafati, Marayamsadat Tahavori, Hamid Reza Shaker
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: District Heating Systems (DHSs) are integral to the energy infrastructure of urban areas, particularly in cold-climate countries where reliable and efficient heating is essential for both residential and commercial purposes. As these systems evolve with the advent of 4th and 5th-generation district heating, traditional reliability analysis methods must adapt to address the complexities of modern DHSs. Therefore, utilities require effective assessment approaches to evaluate the system’s reliability for planning and optimization applications. In today’s context, customer satisfaction is increasingly prioritized, with utilities striving to enhance the reliability of heating supply systems to meet this demand. While reliability indices are widely employed for analyzing the technical reliability of DHSs, they often fall short in assessing the system’s impact on consumers. This paper examines the characteristics of various reliability indices used in system-wise assessments, highlighting the difference between the reliability of heating systems and other energy sectors. Additionally, it introduces new indices designed to evaluate DHS reliability with a focus on consumer-centric aspects. The indices have been used in an illustrative example. The analysis of results demonstrates that the proposed indices effectively assess the customer-centric reliability in different simulated scenarios compared with other system-wise reliability indices. The proposed indices can be integrated into planning and maintenance strategies, offering a more comprehensive approach to the reliability assessment of modern heating systems.

title: Design of MCU Controlled Universal Motor Driver for Remote Operation
authors: Svetoslav Dimitrov, Seher Kadirova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a universal motor driver controlled by an ESP32 microcontroller. The system is specifically developed for controlling universal motors operating at 230V AC, offering a user interface (UI) for monitoring and controlling motor parameters such as speed and current. The project includes feedback from a tachogenerator for precise speed regulation and employs a phase-control circuit to adjust the AC waveform for speed control. The objective of the study is to design a smart, flexible, and safe control system suitable for laboratory and educational environments.

title: Benchmarking and Teaching Symmetric Cryptography: A Comparative Study of Algorithms and Cryptanalysis Methods with an Educational Simulator
authors: Diyan Dinev, Gergana Spasova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Selecting secure and efficient symmetric cryptographic algorithms requires systematic performance evaluation under realistic conditions. This paper presents an extended comparative study of legacy ciphers (DES, 3DES, RC2, Blowfish, Twofish and Camellia in CBC mode) and modern AES variants (AES-CBC and AES-GCM) conducted with a custom-developed software simulator. In addition to cipher implementations, key-derivation parameters (PBKDF2 iteration counts and salt lengths) and authentication variants (HMAC-SHA-1 versus HMAC-SHA-256) are examined. Experiments with files of varying sizes quantify encryption and decryption time, throughput and metadata overhead. Beyond performance benchmarking, the simulator has been designed as an educational tool, enabling reproducible experiments and visualization of security–performance trade-offs. The resulting dataset provides a comprehensive reference for selecting and teaching symmetric encryption configurations under diverse operational contexts.

title: RemoteCollabEval: An Inspection Method for Interpersonal Dynamics in Remote Tools
authors: Shandler A. Mason
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Remote collaboration software (RCS) tools are widely adopted for global teamwork across professional, educational, and personal contexts. However, no method currently assesses RCS tools for coordination, communication, and collaboration (3C) dynamics regarding cognitive and social complexities that shape user interactions. To address this gap, we developed RemoteCollabEval, a novel inspection method refined through iterative design, combining personas with a specialized walkthrough to identify interface issues hindering effective collaboration, such as differing leadership or communication styles. Unlike user studies, which are costly and time-consuming, our method provides a practical alternative through feedback from interdisciplinary stakeholders during multiple action research phases, including case studies and workshops. Participants found the method thorough and thought-provoking, though some noted the repetitive nature as a potential limitation. This work underscores the need for RCS tools that better support nuanced collaboration dynamics, reinforcing the importance of user-centered design.

title: Leveraging Clinical Text and Class Conditioning for 3D Prostate MRI Generation
authors: Emerson P. Grabke, Babak Taati, Masoom A. Haider
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Objective: Latent diffusion models (LDM) could alleviate data scarcity challenges affecting machine learning development for medical imaging. However, medical LDM strategies typically rely on short-prompt text encoders, nonmedical LDMs, or large data volumes. These strategies can limit performance and scientific accessibility. We propose a novel LDM conditioning approach to address these limitations. Methods: We propose Class-Conditioned Efficient Large Language model Adapter (CCELLA), a novel dual-head conditioning approach that simultaneously conditions the LDM U-Net with free-text clinical reports and radiology classification. We also propose a data-efficient LDM pipeline centered around CCELLA and a proposed joint loss function. We first evaluate our method on 3D prostate MRI against state-of-the-art. We then augment a downstream classifier model training dataset with synthetic images from our method. Results: Our method achieves a 3D FID score of 0.025 on a size-limited 3D prostate MRI dataset, significantly outperforming a recent foundation model with FID 0.070. When training a classifier for prostate cancer prediction, adding synthetic images generated by our method during training improves classifier accuracy from 69% to 74% and outperforms classifiers trained on images generated by prior state-of-the-art. Classifier training solely on our method's synthetic images achieved comparable performance to real image training. Conclusion: We show that our method improved both synthetic image quality and downstream classifier performance using limited data and minimal human annotation. Significance: The proposed CCELLA-centric pipeline enables radiology report and class-conditioned LDM training for high-quality medical image synthesis given limited data volume and human data annotation, improving LDM performance and scientific accessibility.

title: A Flexible High-accuracy Memristor Model Using Varactors
authors: Mahdi Tarkhan, Hui Wu, Fateh Ullah, Mohamad Sawan
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper introduces a novel compact memristor model that encompasses various phenomena such as linear and nonlinear dopant drifts, exponential drifts of dopants in high electric fields, asymmetry in the on and off switching, and threshold effects. This model simplifies its structure by eliminating the window function and integrating its functionality through varactor-based integrators, thus avoiding convergence issues caused by the feedback loop within the conventional models. It demonstrates improved accuracy compared to previously proposed models, achieving more than 10% accuracy improvement compared to other models for some devices (e.g., reducing error from 15.2% to 4.3%). In addition, experimentation was conducted on a commercially procured memristor, where the model was aligned with the obtained test outcomes. Subsequently, a TiO2 device was fabricated, and the model was correspondingly adjusted to align with the outcomes from its tests. Experimental results show that the model achieves 98% accuracy in modeling the commercially available device and 97% in modeling the fabricated device.

title: Sound-to-Vibration Transformation for Sensorless Motor Health Monitoring
authors: Ozer Can Devecioglu, Serkan Kiranyaz, Amir Alhams, Sadok Sassi, Turker Ince, Onur Avci, Mohammad Hesam Soleimani-Babakamali, Ertugrul Taciroglu, Moncef Gabbouj
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Automatic detection of motor failures, such as bearing faults, is essential for predictive maintenance across various industries, as bearing faults alone account for up to 51% of motor failures. While vibration-based diagnostics remain the de-facto standard, acquiring reliable vibration data is costly and sensitive to variations of the sensor model and quality, location, mounting and many other factors. To address this, we propose a novel sound-to-vibration transformation method that eliminates the need for onboard vibration sensors. Using any audio recorder (e.g., a mobile phone) and the proposed machine learning model, realistic vibration signals can be synthesized directly from the acquired sound under diverse operating conditions and fault scenarios. Experimental results on the Qatar University Dual-Machine Bearing Fault Benchmark (QU-DMBF) dataset show that the classification accuracy achieved with synthesized signals differs from real vibration data by less than 0.5%, demonstrating negligible loss in performance. This approach offers a low-cost, practical, and scalable alternative for accurate fault detection. The QU-DMBF benchmark dataset, results, and the optimized PyTorch implementation of the proposed sound-to-vibration transformer are publicly available for further research.

title: A Self-Balancing Bipedal Exoskeleton AutoLEE-G3 With Bioinspired Design and Control
authors: Dingkui Tian, Ziqiang Chen, Sida Du, Li Zhang, Xinyu Wu
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: This article presents the mechanism design, balanced walking control strategy, and experimental implementation of a self-balancing bipedal exoskeleton (SBBE) AutoLEE-G3. Based on the anatomical structures of the lower limbs of human, we developed a bioinspired 12 actuated-joint prototype, AutoLEE-G3, which can assist all lower limb joints of the wearer, with motions including hip abduction/adduction, hip flexion/extension, hip internal/external rotation, knee flexion/extension, ankle inversion/eversion, and ankle dorsi flexion/plantar flexion during walking. Subsequently, a viscoelastic-compliance-based balance controller (VCBC) was proposed to reduce the detrimental influence of impact forces on the SBBE's balance performance. Furthermore, the VCBC is based on centroid dynamics, and its control performance is independent of the distributed mass of the exoskeleton and the wearer, which is highly advantageous for the balance control of SBBEs, as the distributed mass of the exoskeleton, particularly that of the wearer, is difficult to measure accurately. Finally, the validity of the self-balancing and locomotion capabilities of AutoLEE-G3 is successfully confirmed through straight-line and turning walking experiments involving both a dummy subject and two human subjects.

title: On the Performance of an Explicit Generalized Finite Element Method for One-dimensional Elastodynamics Problems with Singularities
authors: A.G. Sanchez-Rivadeneira, C.A. Duarte
publish: Computing in Science & Engineering
abstract: This article reports on a high-order Generalized Finite Element Method (GFEM) that retains the computational efficiency and accuracy of the Spectral Element Method (SEM) while removing its limitations when applied to elastodynamics problems with singular solutions in space. The GFEM basis enables the method to deliver high-order convergence rates for this class of problems while adopting uniform meshes. A variational mass lumping method is used to define block-diagonal mass matrices for the GFEM. This approach is not limited to polynomial shape functions like in the FEM and can be used with any element topology. Numerical experiments show that when applied to problems with singularities, the GFEM provides faster convergence than the SEM with interpolation nodes and quadrature located at Gauss-Legendre-Lobatto points (SEM-GLL). It is also shown that the critical time step of the GFEM is larger than for the SEM-GLL on non-uniform meshes designed to recover the optimal rate of the SEM-GLL.

title: A Bayesian Hybrid Attention Module for Underwater Acoustic Target Recognition
authors: Menghui Lei, Xiangyang Zeng, Mingmin Zeng, Anqi Jin
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: The attention mechanism improves underwater acoustic target recognition (UATR) by suppressing irrelevant features. However, due to the uncertainty and scarcity of underwater acoustic target (UWAT) signals, complicated deterministic attention modules increase the risk of model overfitting, resulting in limited improvement or even degradation in the performance of UATR. This letter proposes a Bayesian Hybrid Attention Module (BHAM) that enhances UATR based on time–frequency (T–F) features. BHAM models attention weights as random variables following Beta and Dirichlet distributions to capture uncertainty of UWAT signals and mitigate overfitting, while strengthening T–F feature representation via Bayesian channel attention and Bayesian T–F attention. By learning attention distributions in a Bayesian manner, BHAM effectively models complex dependencies in UWAT signals. Experiments on the DeepShip dataset demonstrate that BHAM alleviates overfitting and generalizes well across different network backbones.

title: Towards a Holistic Understanding of Digital Innovation: A Multidimensional Approach
authors: G. Cao, Y. Duan, J. Edwards
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: This study develops and empirically validates an integrative model explaining how firms achieve digital innovation through the interplay among digital strategy, absorptive capacity, digital technology deployment, and environmental dynamism. Drawing on the content-context-process-outcome framework, digital strategy provides the guiding content; absorptive capacity and environmental dynamism act as contextual enablers; and digital technology deployment functions as the central process driving innovation outcomes. Survey data from 250 Chinese firms were analyzed using partial least squares structural equation modeling (PLS-SEM) and contextualized and externally validated through cross-case and cross-industry validation. The findings reveal an inverted U-shaped relationship between digital technology deployment and innovation, challenging the linear assumption of prior research. While deployment is essential, overinvestment without strategic alignment leads to diminishing returns, underscoring the need for strategic coherence and absorptive alignment. Digital strategy and absorptive capacity directly and indirectly enhance innovation through digital technology deployment, while environmental dynamism amplifies the strategic-innovation linkage. Theoretically, the study contributes to the engineering management literature by advancing a holistic, dynamic, and nonlinear understanding of digital innovation as an optimization and orchestration process rather than a purely technological one. It offers a generalizable framework that strengthens integrative and system-oriented perspectives in engineering management research.

title: Frame-Channel Model for Microservice Architecture
authors: Nikolai Scerbakov, Vadim Pak, Vladimir Muliukha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce an innovative model for developing complex software projects. The model is based and can be seen as a further development of principles of loose coupling. The model operates with elements called Frames and Channels which depend on each other to the least extent possible. The frame is a self-contained reactive software module that is activated by depending on incoming messages. As the frame is activated, it performs the business logic inside the frame and generates outcoming messages that may activate other frames. The channels are an abstraction for modelling the data exchange mechanism. Each frame may bound to several input channels. The frame is activated/rendered because of receiving the stipulated message from the input channel. Similarly, the frame generates and forward messages into the output channels. One and the same channel can serve as an input channel for a certain frame and the output channel for others. The model has a clear graphical notation that is called the Frame-Channel diagram and therefore facilitates the collaborative development of big software applications.

title: Novel voltage observer for reduced voltage soft-starter torque ramp
authors: Stan R. Simms, Gabriel Braga, Thomas A. Farr
publish: 2023 IEEE-IAS/PCA Cement Industry Conference (IAS/PCA)
abstract: Reduced voltage soft-starters (RVSS) are typically phase angle fired with an open-loop ramping voltage with an alphastop at current limit. The advanced controls for soft-starters for pump control, which in most cases is a closed-loop real power ramping reference, can be configured for a softer shaft speed pull-in resembling a convex s-curve. Another advanced control similar to pump control is a torque ramp. Prior authors have shown a stator flux oriented torque RVSS control using an output motor stator voltage feedback approach. This paper presents a novel voltage observer using a voltage sensorless technique based upon measured motor phase current. The novel control method and results are shown. Torque control is advantageous in certain applications such as belting applications to reduce slippage and squeal.

title: Multi-Robot Formation Control Using a Double Integrator Consensus Scheme: Experimental Validation
authors: Danilo Castañeda, Gabriela M. Andaluz, Paulo Leica, Oscar Camacho
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents the experimental validation of a distributed formation control strategy for mobile robots, based on a double integrator consensus algorithm. The proposed control scheme enables a group of three TurtleBot3 Burger robots to maintain a predefined circular formation by tracking virtual leaders defined through geometric coordination laws. The controller computes desired acceleration references for each follower agent using a Laplacian matrix that captures the inter-agent communication topology. These acceleration commands are then mapped into linear and angular velocities through inverse kinematics to actuate the mobile platforms. Experimental results demonstrate the capability of the proposed strategy to correct initial formation errors, ensure inter-agent stability, and suppress oscillatory behaviors along the trajectory.

title: Intelligent system design to monitor organizational climate at a university using TinyML and emotion detection
authors: Dulce M. Rivero Albarrán, Laura R. Guerra Torrealba, Francklin I. Rivas-Echeverria, Keny A. Mafla Pineda
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper discusses the development of an automatic facial emotion recognition system employing a MiniXception architecture optimized for low-power devices like the Raspberry Pi 5. The primary aim is to analyze faculty emotions at a university and provide insights into the organizational climate. Utilizing facial images from a USB camera, the system classifies seven basic emotions—anger, disgust, fear, happiness, sadness, surprise, and neutrality—with an accuracy of $93.57 \%$. The system incorporates image preprocessing and deep learning techniques for real-time results, displaying emotional feedback through text, emojis, and motivational audio messages. Detected emotions are logged with timestamps for future analysis. Testing with faculty members confirmed the system’s accuracy and usability, suggesting its potential as a non-intrusive tool for continuous emotional monitoring and enhancing institutional well-being.

title: Prediction for Dissolved Gas in Power Transformer Oil Based on Transfer Learning and Mutation Detection
authors: Chunxin Wang, Jun Xie, Yutong Zhang, Chunying Qiao, Qing Xie, Fangchen Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: In order to solve the problem of poor prediction of dissolved gas concentration in transformer oil under a defective state caused by a “small-sample” problem, a prediction method for dissolved gas in power transformer oil based on transfer learning and mutation detection is proposed. First, the domain adversarial-transfer learning method is used to train the prediction models under normal and defective states, respectively. A large number of normal state samples are used to assist in training to solve the problem of inaccurate prediction caused by the “small-sample” characteristics of the defective state. Then, taking the prediction error as the criterion, a transformer state mutation detection method is proposed to determine the transformer state for selecting the required model during online prediction. Finally, the online monitoring data of dissolved gas concentration in transformer oil collected on site is used for testing. The results showed that the proposed method can adapt to the prediction tasks under normal and defective states at the same time. Compared with the comparison method, MAPE is reduced by more than 6.504%, and RMSE is reduced by more than <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$73.295~\mu $ </tex-math></inline-formula>L/L.

title: Simulation of a Two-way Long Line Channel in LTE Mobile Networks
authors: Miroslav Tomov, Michail Malamatoudis, Dimitrios Kazolis, Konstantinos Tramantzas, Stanimir Sadinov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The exploration presents simulation of two way radio communication channel applying a complicated model of long line, amplified and optimized for the standard frequencies used in the mobile networks – 900 MHz, 1800 MHz, 2 GHz and 2.6 GHz.

title: A Compact USB-Based Interface Module for The Verification of ARINC429 Avionics Systems
authors: Fatih Çiçek, İhsan Çiçek
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The ARINC-429 data bus remains a widely adopted communication standard in avionics due to its robustness, simplicity, and long certification history. Verification of ARINC-429 devices typically requires laboratory analyzers, FPGA-based controllers, or SoC-based platforms which, are often costly, non-portable, or demand significant development expertise. This paper presents the design and validation of a compact USB-based ARINC-429 verification module that addresses these limitations. The system integrates a Holt HI-3220 transceiver with an FTDI FT4222HQ USB–SPI bridge, omitting FPGA or SoC devices to minimize cost and complexity. A dedicated C# graphical user interface provides plug-and-play usability, real-time bus monitoring, word configuration, and error detection, making the tool accessible for laboratory testing, field diagnostics, and training environments. Experimental validation confirmed full compliance at both 12.5 kbps and 100 kbps modes, with correct signaling, low-latency response, and 99.6% fault detection accuracy. Compared to commercial analyzers, the module is over ten times cheaper, requires less than two minutes setup time, and offers greater portability. The novelty of this work lies in delivering a low-cost, user-friendly verification platform that bridges the gap between traditional analyzers and complex FPGA / SoC-based implementations, making it suitable for laboratories, field diagnostics, and training environments. Results demonstrate that ARINC-429 compliance testing can be performed efficiently using widely available components and an open, accessible design approach, providing a viable alternative to complex or proprietary solutions.

title: Low-cost unified monitoring platform for enterprise networks based on free software
authors: Abel Roberson Avila Ospina, Devin Fabricio Llerena Ballesteros, Dany Steven Barrera Prado, John Alexander Bustamante Orejuela, Wilson Chango
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The efficient management of modern enterprise networks requires monitoring systems that are both technically robust and economically accessible, especially in small and medium-sized organizations with limited resources. This article presents the design and implementation of a unified, low-cost monitoring platform based entirely on opensource software, which integrates technical monitoring, traffic analysis, anomaly detection, and physical environment monitoring. The proposal is developed using a Design Science Research methodological approach, utilizing open-source tools such as Zabbix, Nagios, and Grafana, deployed in a modular architecture with microservices within a virtualized environment that emulates enterprise networks segmented by VLANs. The central hypothesis is that it is possible to consolidate a comprehensive, flexible, and scalable solution that offers features comparable to commercial platforms, while significantly reducing operating costs. The prototype was evaluated using metrics such as resource consumption, ease of use, response capacity to simulated failures, and estimated financial savings. The results confirm the technical feasibility of the solution, highlighting its ability to represent real-time metrics, generate automatic alerts, and improve cybersecurity through proactive visualization of network behavior. Furthermore, the system was positively evaluated by nonexpert users, supporting its potential for adoption in production environments. The research not only offers a functional and sustainable alternative to commercial solutions but also documents replicable procedures that can be reused by other researchers or network administrators interested in implementing customizable and accessible monitoring platforms.

title: Design and implementation of a meteorological data logging device integrating LoRaWAN and ESP32
authors: Henry D. Maldonado, Juan D. Belesaca, Kevin I. Mogrovejo, Fabian Astudillo-Salinas
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Accurate meteorological monitoring in remote regions is vital for water-resource management, climate research, and natural-hazard preparedness. This paper presents a modular, low-power station based on an ESP32-S3 microcontroller and LoRaWAN connectivity, capable of measuring temperature, humidity, solar irradiance, UV index, rainfall, and wind parameters. Data are packaged using the VMTP protocol and transmitted to a cloud platform for real-time visualization.Field validation with a calibrated reference station showed high agreement on most variables (Pearson’s $\mathbf{r}\gt0.9$), while LoRaWAN testing achieved a packet delivery rate greater than $98 \%$ at line-ofsight distances of up to 450 m with a spreading factor of 10 and 20 dBm transmission power. Energy profiling showed that reducing the ESP32 clock to 20 MHz and employing deep-sleep cycles cuts active-mode consumption by more than $\mathbf{5 0 \%}$. The design’s combination of measurement accuracy, reliable longrange communication, and minimal power draw makes it well suited for sustained deployments in challenging terrains.

title: Enhancing Cybersecurity Resilience: Addressing Emerging Technology Challenges in Developing Countries Using Activity Theory
authors: Dina Moloja
publish: 2025 Cybersecurity4D (C4D)
abstract: This theoretical study contends that strengthening cybersecurity resilience in developing countries necessitates more than merely technological advancements; it requires a comprehensive understanding of the broader socio-technical landscape. The rapid integration of emerging technologies, including blockchain, the Internet of Things, and artificial intelligence, has created substantial opportunities for social and economic progress, particularly in developing regions. However, this digital transformation is accompanied by significant cybersecurity challenges, such as vulnerabilities to data breaches, ransomware attacks, and the exploitation of inadequately secured networks. This research investigates strategies to enhance cybersecurity resilience by addressing the distinct socio-economic and infrastructural constraints that characterize these regions. Utilizing Activity Theory as a conceptual framework, the study examines cybersecurity not as an isolated technological issue but as a systemic challenge shaped by the interactions between technology adoption, human factors, and policy frameworks. This interdisciplinary approach underscores the necessity of cybersecurity strategies that effectively balance innovation with security while accounting for resource limitations, knowledge disparities, and cultural considerations. The primary contribution of this paper is the application of Activity Theory as an analytical lens for understanding and mitigating cybersecurity risks associated with emerging technologies in developing contexts. The findings indicate that prioritizing the development and implementation of scalable, cost-effective, and community-driven security strategies is imperative. Additionally, fostering multi-stakeholder collaboration—encompassing governments, the private sector, and academic institutions—is essential for building a resilient cybersecurity infrastructure. The study advocates for a robust cybersecurity ecosystem that not only mitigates risks but also facilitates sustainable technological growth in developing countries.

title: Web-Based Marketplace to Empowering Local MSMEs: A Policy–Technology Integration using the Waterfall Method
authors: Putri Widya Ardhianti, Meila Purnawati, Karunia Putri Tanjung, Riyan Leandros
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Data on business actors in Karanganyar Regency was manually gathered by Regional Government Organizations (OPD) starting in 2017, which resulted in inaccuracy, delays, and inefficiencies. They also lack sufficient capital to purchase from micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs), and some owners are unwilling to develop the company. The Karanganyar Regency Government, through the Communication and Information Office (Diskominfo), initiated the creation of a centralized web-based marketplace for MSMEs to address these issues. This study proposes merging government-initiated civil servant (ASN) spending programs with an e-commerce platform, a topic seldom discussed in local government digitalization. The System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) and Waterfall approach were applied, incorporating requirements analysis, design, implementation, testing, and evaluation. Three primary user categories are involved: purchasers (ASN and non-ASN), business professionals, and administrators. Key features include product discovery, shopping cart, payment channel, subsidy distribution, and ASN expenditure monitoring. A usability test with 25 participants showed that the core functionality worked well, as all could complete the task. However, the current study remains at the prototype stage and has not yet been implemented. Further research is needed for larger scalability, longer-term sustainability, and engagement with national MSME systems.

title: Robust Null-Space Controller with Sliding Mode for Hierarchical Task Execution in Multi-Robot Formations: Experimental Validation
authors: Zahid Nazate, Gabriela M. Andaluz, Paulo Leica, Oscar Camacho, Pablo Proaño
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents a Robust Null Space (RNS) control strategy for hierarchical task execution in multi-robot formations under reference changes. The controller integrates a task-priority null-space framework with a PI-based Sliding Mode Controller (SMC) to enhance tracking performance during reference changes. The proposed scheme addresses two hierarchical tasks: (i) posture regulation as the primary objective and (ii) shape preservation as the secondary objective. Unlike traditional approaches, the RNS controller employs a PI sliding surface to improve convergence and reduce steady-state errors. A Lyapunovbased analysis guarantees the asymptotic stability of the closed-loop system. Experimental validation with a triangular formation of three Turtlebot3 robots shows that the RNS controller achieves up to $26.10 \%$ improvement in IAE and $4.43 \%$ in ISE over a traditional Null Space controller, demonstrating its robustness and practical effectiveness. These results not only demonstrate the potential of hierarchical control approaches in multi-robot coordination but also provide relevant tools for real-world applications in logistics, cooperative exploration, and collaborative load transportation, where robustness against disturbances and reference changes is critical.

title: Smart manufacturing model to improve sewing line efficiency using TPM, IoT, SMED, and Industry 4.0 Poka-Yoke: A Case Study
authors: Gianella Rebatta-Cazeneuve, Verohuska Tito-Flores, José Velásquez-Costa, Javier Torres-Zavala, Baldomero Méndez-Pallares
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The high competitiveness of the textile industry poses multiple challenges for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), driving the need to optimize processes and innovate continuously. In this context, the studied company faces difficulties in meeting customer orders due to factors that reduce efficiency, such as machine downtime and rework caused by garment defects. This study aims to increase sewing line efficiency by implementing Total Productive Maintenance (TPM) with IoT to reduce mean time between failures, Single Minute Exchange of Die (SMED) to decrease setup times, and IoT-enabled Poka-Yoke systems to minimize rework. The proposed model integrates a real-time monitoring system equipped with sensors and Internet of Things (IoT) services, linking Lean Manufacturing practices with Industry 4.0 technologies. As a result, the model improved efficiency in the sewing area from $\mathbf{7 2. 6 5 \%}$ to $\mathbf{8 1. 9 3 \%} \boldsymbol{(}+\mathbf{9. 2 8 \%)}$). Additionally, mean time between failures increased by $53 \%$, setup time was reduced by $40 \%$, and the rework rate decreased by $35 \%$. These outcomes demonstrate that combining Lean methodologies with IoT-based solutions enables tangible operational improvements, directly enhancing productivity, profitability, and competitiveness in textile SMEs.

title: Clustering and Anomaly Detection for Churn Prediction in POS Payment Systems
authors: José Asitimbay, Felipe Grijalva, Malena Loza, José Vega-Sánchez, Ricardo Flores-Moyano
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work addresses the early identification of businesses at risk of ceasing or limiting their use of point-of-sale (POS) services, resulting in decreased transaction volumes—a key indicator of customer churn. In the highly competitive POS market, customer retention is essential, as acquiring new clients is typically more costly than retaining existing ones. Early detection of potential churners enables targeted retention strategies, enhancing user experience, increasing loyalty, and mitigating revenue loss. To tackle this problem, businesses were first s egmented u sing u nsupervised l earning t echniques, specifically Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) and K-Means, based on transaction volume and average amounts. GMM outperformed K-Means and was selected for clustering. Following segmentation, transactional data were analyzed across card types and network levels. Due to the dataset’s class imbalance—with significantly fewer churners—unsupervised anomaly detection methods were used: One-Class support-vector machine, Isolation Forest, and Local Outlier Factor (LOF). LOF showed the best results, achieving PR-AUC scores of 0.99 and 0.96 for the Micro and Pequeño segments, with recall values of 0.99 and 0.95. For Masivo, Grande, and Mediano segments, lower PR-AUCs (0.71, 0.52, and 0.53) were obtained due to higher false positive rates. Still, their absolute number was small, and they can serve as early warning indicators for proactive retention efforts.

title: Smart Approval of Gaming API Applications Through BERT and MLP Classification Models
authors: Angel-Molina, Felipe Grijalva, José Vega-Sánchez, Roberto Andrade, Malena Loza
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work addresses the challenge of enhancing the user experience within Riot Games’ developer portal by streamlining the process of creating secure and efficient applications that interact with its suite of Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). To accomplish this, a spam detection model was developed using a hybrid deep learning approach that combines Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) for semantic understanding and a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) for classification. T he p roposed m odel a nalyzes t extual metadata submitted with each application to predict whether it should be approved or rejected. Experimental results demonstrate strong classification performance, with an a ccuracy of 91.34%, an F1score of 91.69%, and a Receiver Operating Characteristic - Area Under the Curve (ROC AUC) of $\mathbf{9 1. 3 3 \%}$. These metrics indicate the model’s effectiveness in minimizing both false positives and false negatives. Furthermore, the consistent decrease observed in both training and validation loss across epochs reflects stable convergence and robust generalization capabilities. Specifically, this work lies in the deployment of a lightweight, domainspecific s pam d etection p ipeline t ailored t o t he u nique context of game development APIs. This system not only accelerates the application approval process but also enhances platform integrity by proactively identifying and filtering p otentially m alicious or low-quality submissions. The proposed solution paves the way for more secure, efficient, and developer-friendly gaming ecosystems.

title: Governance in Decentralized Finance: Aligning DAOs with IT Management and Regulatory Compliance in Indonesia
authors: Iswanda F. Satibi, Maureen A. Leksmana, Dini Pasha Ramadhani
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: This paper explores the alignment between DAO governance mechanisms, IT governance frameworks, and Indonesia’s regulatory environment. Using a qualitative document analysis of academic literature, DAO governance documentation, IT governance standards (COBIT, ITIL, ISO/IEC 38500), and Indonesian regulatory texts issued by Bappebti, Bank Indonesia, and the Financial Services Authority (OJK), the study identifies critical areas of convergence and divergence. Findings indicate that DAOs demonstrate strong transparency due to on-chain records, but remain weak in accountability, stakeholder alignment, risk management, and compliance. These weaknesses generate friction with Indonesia’s fragmented regulatory landscape, where crypto assets are classified as commodities, prohibited as payment instruments, and inconsistently taxed. Stakeholder management emerges as a pressing concern, as token-weighted voting privileges large holders while Indonesian retail investors face governance literacy gaps. To address these challenges, the paper proposes a hybrid governance framework that integrates IT governance principles with DAO structures, supplemented by compliance mechanisms tailored to Indonesian regulations. Recommendations include the introduction of accountability representatives, adoption of quadratic voting, adaptation of COBIT-based risk management, and establishment of regulatory sandboxes. The study contributes to the discourse on DeFi governance by offering a conceptual model for reconciling decentralized innovation with national regulatory frameworks in emerging markets such as Indonesia.

title: Multisensory Assistive Systems for English Language Learning through Virtual Reality and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Adriana Guanuche, Cristian Remache, Juan Carlos Molina, Gustavo Caiza
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: English language proficiency has become an essential tool for today’s society due to its preeminent role as a lingua franca in international communication, scientific research, and business. This article aims to create a multisensory immersive application based on virtual reality (VR) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) to support the English language teaching process in the skills of pronunciation and grammar, through audio recognition and navigation in immersive interactive environments. This system, driven by neural networks, can accurately identify the user’s pronunciation, to subsequently generate virtual scenarios where the student can practice and learn the grammar through the representation and interaction with virtual scenarios that were created for interactive and dynamic learning where the culture and representative places of different countries are shown to offer a new experience and greater motivation when learning a new language. Among the results obtained, it was observed that the neural network achieved an effectiveness of $94.45 \%$ in audio recognition, while in an uncontrolled environment, it reached a percentage of $\mathbf{7 5 \%}$ to $\mathbf{9 6. 1 \%}$, which reflects the robustness and accuracy of the system. In addition, students who used this technology showed an acceptance rate of $94 \%$, which evidences its high impact on the acceptance of the use of these technologies to be used in the learning process and its potential to improve different skills through immersive environments. This approach integrates advanced technology with innovative pedagogical methods, promising to transform the way students learn languages and experience cultural diversity in an increasingly connected world.

title: Study of Failover Time in Site-to-Site VPNs Across Leading Firewall Vendors: Fortinet, Check Point, Palo Alto, and Cisco
authors: Hamed Rezaeianfardoue, Mohammad Saedi
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Reliable failover performance is a critical factor in maintaining the availability of site-to-site virtual private networks (VPNs). This study presents a comparative analysis of failover times among four leading firewall vendors: Fortinet, Check Point, Palo Alto Networks, and Cisco. A controlled test environment was designed to evaluate how different configuration parameters and default settings influence the time required for VPN tunnels to recover after a link or device failure. The results highlight significant variations in failover behavior across vendors, with differences attributed to IPsec rekeying mechanisms, detection timers, and session handling strategies. By identifying the configurations that achieve the lowest failover times, this research provides practical guidance for network administrators and security engineers seeking to optimize high-availability VPN deployments. In addition, the study emphasizes the importance of fine-tuning IKE parameters to minimize downtime. The findings suggest that vendor specific optimizations play a greater role than hardware capacity in achieving fast recovery. Future work may extend this analysis by incorporating cloud-based firewalls and hybrid WAN environments for a broader perspective.

title: Design and Analysis of a Combine Hydrostatic Powertrain Drive for All Wheels
authors: Yordan Stoyanov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The objective of the article is to present the hydrostatic drive system of the grain combine is designed to operate in both two-wheel-drive and four-wheel-drive configurations. A single variable-displacement axial-piston pump with a displacement range of 380–750 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/rev supplies the system. The generated flow drives a hydraulic motor responsible for powering the front axle. The system operates at pressures of up to 400 bar, providing the required torque for machine propulsion under varying load conditions. When rear-wheel drive is engaged, the pump output is divided between the rear hydraulic motors according to instantaneous demands for angular velocity, slip compensation, and overall traction requirements. The hydrostatic system is sized to maintain the necessary pressure and flow rates to sustain both field operating speeds and transport speeds, ensuring reliable propulsion across different terrains and working conditions.

title: Investigation of Dual-fuel Diesel Engine Performance with Ammonia and Change of Compression Ratio
authors: Simeon Iliev, Radostin Dimitrov, Velichka Georgieva
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The global pursuit of carbon-free alternative fuels has become a critical endeavor in the effort to mitigate climate change, achieve decarbonization, and meet net-zero emissions targets. As traditional fossil fuels continue to contribute significantly to greenhouse gas emissions, researchers and industry stakeholders are exploring a range of cleaner energy sources to replace or supplement conventional fuels. Among the various alternatives under investigation, ammonia has emerged as a promising candidate due to its carbon-free molecular composition, high hydrogen content, and potential for use in existing combustion systems with certain modifications. In this context, the present study focuses on evaluating the impact of varying compression ratios on the performance and combustion characteristics of a single-cylinder dual-fuel diesel engine operating with ammonia-based fuel. The analysis is carried out through a simulation model developed using AVL Boost software, which allows for detailed examination of engine behavior under different operating conditions.

title: Application of FDM Printing with PEEK for the Development of a Robotic Rehabilitation Device for Children with Musculoskeletal Disorders
authors: Nurtilek Sagynbayev, Nursultan Zhetenbayev, Gani Sergazin, Kassymbek Ozhikenov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper explores the use of Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) 3D printing technology with Poly-Ether-Ether-Ketone (PEEK) material in the development of a robotic rehabilitation device for children with musculoskeletal disorders. The study analyzes the mechanical, thermal, vibrational, and radiation-resistant properties of FDM-printed PEEK based on existing literature. The results demonstrate that PEEK offers excellent strength-to-weight ratio, low thermal conductivity, and high resistance to dynamic and environmental stresses, making it a viable alternative to traditional aluminum alloys in pediatric rehabilitation devices. The integration of FDM technology allows for individual customization of the device structure, ensuring ergonomic compatibility with children's anatomy and enabling the creation of lightweight, durable, and biocompatible solutions for personalized therapy.

title: Reconceptualizing Identity in the Information Age: The Role of Temporal Focus in IT identity Shaping
authors: Ekaterina Zabelina, Marina Lukmanova, AlexandraTelitsyna, Svetlana Kurnosova, Irina Trushina
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In the era of information technology, the issue of the relationship between humans and machines becomes particularly relevant. One of the promising approaches in this field is the concept of IT identity. Despite the potential of the concept, it has not gained wide popularity in Russian science: measurement methods have not been adapted for use on Russian-speaking samples, the term is not integrated into the system of psychological concepts, and the relationship between IT identity and related psychological phenomena has not been identified. This study aims to address this gap by adapting the IT Identity Scale to a Russian sample and exploring the relationship between IT identity and temporal focus. The correlation analysis results $(N=195)$ show moderate positive relationships between IT identity and current focus ($\mathrm{r}=0.195$, $p=0.007$) and future focus ($r=0.191, p=0.008$), but not past focus. Expressed future focus $(\beta=0.307)$ and reduced past focus ($\beta=-$ 0.276) make a more significant contribution to the shaping emotional connection with information technologies as a component of IT identity. The results suggest that IT identity represents a completely new type of identity with fundamentally different properties and functions, connecting individuals not with the past, but with the future, shaping interest and readiness for uncertainty. The adapted IT Identity Scale for the Russianspeaking sample opens up opportunities for international research, including its predictors and effects.

title: Redesigning Mechatronics Education: A First Exploration with 4C/ID
authors: Rebeca Mejía Cepeda, David Loza-Matovelle, Jimmy Zambrano R
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The transformation of engineering education driven by Industry 4.0 and the emerging Industry 5.0 requires instructional models that integrate interdisciplinarity, technological innovation, and authentic problem-solving. Mechatronics, as a transversal field, faces challenges in preparing professionals to design, analyze, and integrate complex systems in dynamic industrial contexts. This paper proposes the Four-Component Instructional Design model ($\mathbf{4 C}$ /ID), complemented by Cognitive Task Analysis, as a framework for redesigning mechatronics curricula. Existing approaches often emphasize fragmented knowledge or narrow technical training, whereas the proposed framework structures whole-task learning sequences that integrate mechanical, electronic, computational, and control-system knowledge. This fosters cognitive integration, transfer of expertise, and readiness for professional practice. Empirical evidence across STEM disciplines demonstrates the effectiveness and efficiency of this model. An instructional blueprint is presented to align mechatronics education with industry demands, while recognizing challenges of resource intensity and curricular adaptation. We argue that can enhance student performance, innovation capacity, and professional readiness for complex engineering environments.

title: Analysing Internet of Things and Cybersecurity Impact in the Namibia Mining Industry
authors: Suama L. Hamunyela, Hiatsita Shipupeni Shinana, Iyaloo Wainganjo, Ambrose A. Azeta
publish: 2025 Cybersecurity4D (C4D)
abstract: Namibia has experienced significant digital advancements in recent years, embracing digital transformation to drive innovation, enhance competitiveness, improve the standard of living and secure the cyberspace. The evolution of the Internet of Things (IoT) has transformed human existence and working conditions, particularly within enterprises, by reducing human intervention, thereby increasing efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Despite these benefits, IoT introduces cybersecurity risks that can be exploited by cybercriminals. This study examines IoT and cybersecurity impact in the Namibian mining industry. A qualitative approach was adopted, with data collected through semi-structured interviews with eight mining personnel. Thematic analysis was used to analyse the findings, and four key themes were revealed as follows: IoT deployment in the mining sector, risks and vulnerabilities of IoT devices, challenges posed by cyber-attacks, and cybersecurity strategies for IoT in mining operations. Findings identified IoT devices such as voice hubs, smart TVs, smartwatches, automation systems, and smart lighting as commonly used in the mining industry. The findings also, highlighted key threats including physical tampering, firmware manipulation, and vulnerability exploitation, with challenges ranging from financial losses to reputational damage and risks to individual safety. The study concluded that there is a need for cohesive strategies to improve IoT cybersecurity which must include education and training, contractual agreements, and adherence to policy standards.

title: Comparative Analysis of a Genetically Engineered E. coli-Based Biosensor and UV-Visible Spectrophotometry for Hexavalent Chromium Detection
authors: Santiago Mafla, Melany Avellaneda, Moraima Mera, Diego Mejía
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of two methodologies for quantifying hexavalent chromium ($\mathbf{C r}^{6+}$) in water samples: a genetically modified biosensor based on Escherichia coli and a conventional UV-visible spectrophotometric technique. The biosensor was developed by transforming E. coli cells with the plasmid pTOP Blunt V2 via electroporation. This plasmid harbors lux A genes, which encode luminescent luciferase enzymes, and chr genes, which confer chromium resistance.Chromium detection was performed using an EPOCH microplate spectrophotometer across a range of $\mathrm{Cr}^{6+}$ concentrations (0.05,0.10,0.20,0.40,0.80, and $1.00 \mathrm{mg} \mathrm{L}^{-1}$), with five replicates per concentration. The biosensor demonstrated high sensitivity, especially at $2 \times 10^{6}$ CFU of E. coli, yielding an error margin of about 1.4%, as determined from the coefficient of determination ($R^{2}$) of absorbance readings. In contrast, the UV-visible method using colorimetric analysis showed a higher error rate of 3.9%.When applied to river water samples, the biosensor method proved to be a rapid, reliable, and cost-effective alternative to conventional spectrophotometric techniques for detecting trace levels of $\mathrm{Cr}^{6+}$, supporting its potential use in environmental monitoring and water safety assessments.
