title: Adaptive PID Control of UAV Variable-Pitch Propellers Based on Lightweight Neural Networks
authors: He Sun, Chuanchao Liu, Songxiang Tang, Tao Suo
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper proposes a novel lightweight neural network-PID composite control method to address the challenges of stability in millimeter-wave (mmWave) and terahertz (THz) wireless communication for UAVs, which are severely affected by nonlinear dynamics and external disturbances in variable-pitch propeller control. On one hand, traditional PID controllers are widely used in variable-pitch systems, but their adaptability to varying flight conditions and external disturbances is limited, leading to suboptimal performance in dynamic environments. On the other hand, existing machine learning approaches, while offering better adaptability, often suffer from high computational complexity, which makes them unsuitable for real-time applications, particularly for UAVs with limited onboard resources. The novelty of the proposed framework lies in the integration of a lightweight backpropagation (BP) neural network with a PID controller. This architecture leverages the self-learning ability of the neural network to dynamically adjust the PID parameters in real-time, thus improving adaptability and robustness without incurring high computational costs. To further enhance efficiency, we introduce a separation strategy for offline training and online inference, significantly reducing the computational load during operation. Additionally, an event-triggered mechanism is employed to optimize the frequency of neural network updates, minimizing unnecessary calculations. By using this proposed system, we achieve better dynamic performance, reduced overshoot, and faster settling times compared to conventional PID controllers. In particular, our method demonstrates superior performance in mitigating speed fluctuations under sudden gust disturbances and adapting to diverse flight conditions. In contrast to traditional methods, which rely on fixed control parameters, the adaptive nature of our approach ensures continuous optimization during flight, guaranteeing improved thrust response precision and communication stability. Experimental validation through simulations and UAV flight tests confirms that the proposed method outperforms traditional PID control in terms of adaptability, robustness, and efficiency.

title: Vascular Reactivity Fingerprints Predict Cardiovascular Risk Via Thermal-Stressed Optical Profiling: A Dual Near-Infrared Spectroscopy and Laser Doppler Flowmetry Approach
authors: Takhellambam Gautam Meitei, Pi-Shan Hsu, Wei-Wen Lin, Yi-Min Wang, Liang-Kung Chen, Chia-Wei Sun
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: This study evaluates the potential of combining Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS) and Laser Doppler Flowmetry (LDF) to classify cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in elderly individuals based on peripheral microvascular function. Signals were acquired during a standardized thermal challenge and processed to extract dynamic physiological features, including time-domain statistics, wavelet-derived spectral components, and engineered indices such as recovery efficiency and vascular coupling. A Random Forest classifier achieved 81.5% cross-validation accuracy (95% CI: [76.2%, 86.8%]) with an area under the ROC curve (AUC) of 0.911 (95% CI: [0.865, 0.950]). Dimensionality reduction via Principal Component Analysis preserved model performance while enabling data visualization. Feature importance analysis highlighted recovery-phase metrics and engineered indicators, such as LDF recovery efficiency, HbO<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> recovery mean, and oxy-flow coupling, as key contributors to classification. These findings support the integration of multimodal optical biosignals and microvascular reactivity profiling as a promising strategy for noninvasive cardiovascular risk stratification in aging populations.

title: The Command Line GUIde: Graphical Interfaces from Man Pages via AI
authors: Saketh Ram Kasibatla, Kiran Medleri Hiremath, Raven Rothkopf, Sorin Lerner, Haijun Xia, Brian Hempel
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Although birthed in the era of teletypes, the command line shell survived the graphical interface revolution of the 1980’s and lives on in modern desktop operating systems. The command line provides access to powerful functionality not otherwise exposed on the computer, but requires users to recall textual syntax and carefully scour documentation. In contrast, graphical interfaces let users organically discover and invoke possible actions through widgets and menus. To better expose the power of the command line, we demonstrate a mechanism for automatically creating graphical interfaces for command line tools by translating their documentation (in the form of man pages) into interface specifications via AI. Using these specifications, our user-facing system, called GUIde, presents the command options to the user graphically. We evaluate the generated interfaces on a corpus of commands to show to what degree GUIDE offers thorough graphical interfaces for users’ real-world command line tasks.

title: Critical Review of Quality Management in HMLV Manufacturing
authors: Kristian Tsvetkov, Pavel Vitliemov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: High Mix Low Volume (HMLV) manufacturing environments present specific challenges to quality management, such as high variability, short cycles, and frequent changes. Despite the established application of Lean Six Sigma, TQM, and ISO 9001 in Low-Mix High Volume (LMHV) settings, their effectiveness in HMLV remains under-explored. An analysis of databases such as ResearchGate and ScienceDirect reveals a lack of sufficient research. The aim of this article is to analyze the limitations and challenges in applying traditional quality management methodologies (Lean Six Sigma, TQM, and ISO 9001) in HMLV manufacturing environments

title: Architecture of Cyber-Physical System for Improving Safety in Public Life "Safety"
authors: Nikolay Gospodinov, Georgi Krastev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper introduces the design and implementation of a cyber-physical system, named Safety, intended to enhance public security through augmented reality technologies. The prototype runs on Epson Moverio BT-300 smart glasses, enabling real-time delivery of contextual information about the user’s environment. The system integrates specialized modules for recognizing traffic signs and detecting aggressive behavior. These components rely on state-of-the-art computer vision and deep learning methods, including YOLOv5 for object recognition and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for temporal pattern analysis. The work provides an in-depth description of the architecture, the functionality of individual modules, and their seamless integration. By offering timely alerts and situational awareness, the Safety system contributes to reducing risks in public spaces and supports safer everyday interactions.

title: Impact of Mixed Reality and Ultrasound Simulation on Medical Student Performance
authors: Leonel Vasquez-Cevallos, Miguel Abad-Rodríguez, Fabian Del-Pino-Bazan, Pedro A. Salazar-Carballo, Paul E.D. Soto-Rodriguez, Rosangela Caicedo-Quiroz, Roberto Tolozano-Benites
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Simulation-based medical education is essential for bridging the gap between theoretical knowledge and clinical practice. This study evaluates the educational effectiveness of advanced ultrasound simulation, including mixed reality (MR), in enhancing medical student performance. A quasiexperimental design was implemented with $\mathbf{6 4}$ participants: 40 third-year students performed thoracic ultrasound using the VIMEDIX simulator, while 24 final-year students engaged in obstetric ultrasound training integrated with MR through HoloLens visualization. Pre- and post-test assessments measured confidence, perceived usefulness, and satisfaction using a five-point Likert scale. In the anatomical ultrasound group, confidence improved from 3.08 to $4.53(\mathrm{p}(\lt)0.01)$, and satisfaction from 3.68 to $4.48(\mathrm{p}(\lt)0.01)$. In the obstetric group, confidence increased from 3.13 to $4.58(p(\lt)0.01)$, while satisfaction improved slightly from 4.83 to 4.96, not statistically significant. Objective video-based assessments showed a mean score of $2.92 / 3$ among trained students versus $1.47 / 3$ in the control group. Sentiment analysis revealed predominantly positive perceptions: 58% positive in obstetric and 55% in anatomical ultrasound, with overall sentiment scores of 3.5/5 and 3.8/5, respectively. These findings underscore the strong potential of combining high-fidelity simulation and immersive technologies to enhance diagnostic training in medical education.

title: Intraclass Data Augmentation Framework for Data-Imbalanced Cross-Domain Face Recognition
authors: Patricio Xavier Moreno-Vallejo, Gisel Katerine Bastidas-Guacho, Angel D. Sappa
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work introduces an intraclass data augmentation framework that leverages Pivotal Tuning Inversion to augment face data by modifying attributes such as pose, expression, age, and hairstyle. The framework also incorporates a crossdomain image translation network to generate thermal infrared images from visible ones, enabling the creation of paired registered visible-infrared augmented datasets. Experimental results show that the proposed framework enhances the quality and fidelity of the generated images, as reflected by metrics such as FID, KID, LPIPS, SSIM, and PSNR. Additionally, the use of the proposed framework to generate visible-thermal infrared augmented datasets enhances the performance of existing computer vision applications, such as heterogeneous face recognition.

title: Participatory Tech-Policy Design: A Methodological Approach Grounded in Regulatory Learning
authors: Maria Isabel Mejía, Pablo Gómez, César Viloria-Núñez, Esteban Fernando Ordóñez Morales, Mateo Meléndez-Villadiego, Christian G. Quintero M
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents a methodological framework for the participatory design of technology public policies, derived from a systematic literature review and grounded in the abstraction of practical experiences from interregional cooperation between Europe and Latin America. The proposed framework integrates key principles from collaborative governance, regulatory learning, and co-creation processes, offering a structured and replicable model for multi-stakeholder policy formulation. The framework is composed of five sequential phases-initial definition, regulatory grounding, collaborative construction, refinement, and finalization-and is designed to guide interdisciplinary working groups in producing actionable Policy Papers. These outputs are intended to inform strategic policy innovation blueprints and support sustained dialogue between diverse institutional actors. By combining theoretical insights with operational clarity, the framework contributes to the broader literature on participatory policy design and provides a useful tool for institutions engaged in digital transformation policy development. The paper concludes with recommendations for adapting the model to other domains and institutional contexts.

title: AI4DVault: A Registry Architecture for Securing the AI4D Supply Chain
authors: Aminata Sabane, Tegawendé F. Bissyande
publish: 2025 Cybersecurity4D (C4D)
abstract: As artificial intelligence for development initiatives expand, ensuring secure and transparent supply chains for AI artifacts has become a critical challenge in emerging countries. Recent incidents of malicious models on repositories like Hugging Face demonstrate that machine learning model platforms are increasingly vulnerable to the same supply chain attacks that have plagued traditional software ecosystems. This paper presents the vision and architectural design for AI4DVault, a comprehensive registry architecture that addresses the unique security, provenance, and integrity requirements of AI4D ecosystems. While implementation remains a work in progress, our proposed architecture defines a cryptographically secure verification protocol that would allow stakeholders to trace model provenance from creation through deployment, protecting against namespace squatting, typosquatting, model confusion attacks, and unsafe serialization formats. The envisioned system would integrate with existing workflows through a standardized command-line interface while providing automated vulnerability scanning and integrity verification to prevent the distribution of compromised models. Our design adapts techniques from established supply chain security frameworks, including SLSA (Supply-chain Levels for Software Artifacts) and Sigstore, extending them to address AI-specific challenges such as dataset provenance tracking and model lineage verification. We present this architectural vision as a foundation for future implementation efforts, with the aim of establishing a roadmap toward more secure and trustworthy AI4D systems, particularly in resource-constrained environments where traditional security infrastructure may be limited.

title: Unsupervised Learning for Fraud Detection in Cooperative Transactions: A Hierarchical Clustering and One-Class SVM Approach
authors: Christian Hernández, Felipe Grijalva, Carla Parra, Daniel Riofrío, José Vega-Sánchez
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Anomaly detection in financial transactions is a critical challenge for mitigating risks associated with fraudulent activities. This work proposes a robust framework tailored to the cooperative financial sector, leveraging unsupervised learning techniques to detect anomalous behavior in transaction data. Hierarchical clustering is first applied to segment users into distinct behavioral groups, enabling the identification of patterns indicative of both normal and suspicious activity. Subsequently, a One-Class Support Vector Machine (SVM) is employed for anomaly detection, achieving Area Under the Curve (AUC) scores of up to 0.90 in clusters with well-defined transactional patterns. Visualization using t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) reveals minimal overlap between normal and anomalous transactions within these clusters, further demonstrating the effectiveness of the model. However, performance decreases in clusters exhibiting higher behavioral variability, highlighting the challenges inherent to diverse financial data. This research underscores the importance of domain-specific anomaly detection strategies and offers practical insights for enhancing fraud prevention in financial systems-particularly within underrepresented sectors such as cooperative banking. Future work will focus on improving scalability and model interpretability to enhance applicability in real-world operational environments.

title: Accessibility and the Right to Information: An Inclusive Digital Dictionary for the Ecuadorian Population with Sensory Disabilities
authors: Verónica Maldonado-Garcés, Elking Araujo, Javier Sánchez, Santiago Andrango, Kerlly Viera, Andrea Abril, Orlando Acosta, Karina Jaramillo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: These dictionaries are resources that directly contribute to strengthening reading skills. As educational tools, access to them should be guaranteed for the entire population. In the case of Ecuador, the public currently lacks a lexical resource of this nature. Moreover, people with visual impairments and deaf individuals have historically been marginalized from access to culture and education in the country. In response to this situation, the PSICO Research Group set out to design a digital dictionary accessible to the entire Ecuadorian population, including people with visual and hearing disabilities. To this end, several working teams were formed: a group of IT professionals, a team of lexicographic writers, and an advisory group composed of people with visual and hearing disabilities. The dictionary was developed in multiple stages and validated by both users without disabilities and individuals with visual and hearing impairments. The main result of this process is a dictionary composed of $\mathbf{5, 0 0 0}$ words, each accompanied by definitions and textual citations, 500 of which include Ecuadorian sign language interpretation through videos embedded in a website designed according to screen reader accessibility standards.

title: Technology-Based Evaluation of User Experience in a Maritime Job Search Application using Questionnaire and Heuristic Methods
authors: Muhammad Rifqi Rabbani, Ardellia Putri Pertiwi, Zahra Zaelani, Meta Amalya Dewi
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: This study evaluates the user experience of REDIKRU, a maritime job search application designed specifically for seafarers, using two established methods: the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ) and Heuristic Evaluation based on Nielsen’s principles. A total of $\mathbf{1 0 0}$ users completed the UEQ, yielding strong scores in efficiency (1.2) and dependability (1.4), while dimensions such as attractiveness (0.9) and stimulation (1.0) scored below benchmark thresholds. In parallel, the heuristic analysis identified 12 usability issues, including unclear job status indicators, inconsistent terminology, and a lack of onboarding guidance. The results suggest that while REDIKRU provides a generally functional and dependable user experience, there is a clear need for improvements in interface clarity, navigation consistency, and user engagement. Based on these findings, a set of design recommendations is proposed-such as enhancing job filtering mechanisms, streamlining the registration process, and optimizing application tracking features-to better align with user expectations in the maritime employment context. Beyond its usability contributions, this study supports SDG 4 (Quality Education) by promoting digital literacy and equitable access to employment platforms for underserved professional communities.

title: Gender Differences in EEG Absolute Power within Alzheimer’s Disease, Frontotemporal Dementia, and Cognitively Normal Individuals
authors: Shahid Iqbal, Humaira Nisar, Kim Ho Yeap
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Dementia affects the structure and function of the brain, which significantly impacts the well-being of older adults. Recent research shows that power spectrum and functional connectivity features can serve as potential biomarkers for diagnosing and classifying dementia. However, there is still limited research on gender-specific changes in the power spectrum in dementia, especially in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD). This paper examines differences in absolute power between male and female participants within each frequency band (delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma). First, the Power Spectral Density (PSD) was estimated using Welch’s method. Absolute power was calculated by integrating the PSD within the frequency bands. The analysis was carried out on a publicly available resting-state (RS) eyesclosed (EC) electroencephalographic (EEG) dataset from 88 age-matched subjects. The dataset includes three groups: 36 (12 male) with AD, 23 (14 male) with FTD, and 29 (18 male) cognitively normal (CN) participants. Statistical comparisons were performed using Welch’s two-sample t-test to find significant differences in group-averaged absolute band power between males and females within each band. The results showed distinct band power patterns between genders in each group. Notably, the average absolute power for females in the AD group was higher across all frequency bands except delta, which was lower compared to males. Furthermore, significant gender differences in absolute power were observed within the AD group in the theta $\left(p=0.02, d=0.59, \eta^{2}=0.17\right)$, alpha $(p= 0.01, d=0.73, \eta^{2}=0.16$), and beta ($p=0.01, d=0.69, \eta^{2}=0.17$) bands, all reflecting large effect sizes. In the CN group, males exhibited higher absolute mean power in the alpha, beta, and gamma bands; however, in the delta and theta bands, the values were lower compared to females. In the FTD group, males consistently showed higher absolute power than females across all frequencies except in the alpha band, where values were comparable. These gender-based changes in overall absolute power revealed a spectral pattern, highlighting the influence of gender on EEG characteristics in AD and FTD.

title: Medium Voltage Drive with Dynamic Power Quality Compensation for High-Harmonic Industrial Environments
authors: Naveen Garg
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: This paper presents a Medium Voltage (MV) Drive integrated with a Dynamic Voltage Restorer (DVR) to address power quality issues in non-linear industrial systems. The system employs active front-end converters, multilevel inverters, and ultracapacitor storage for real-time harmonic and voltage disturbance compensation. Simulation and hardware-in-the-loop testing show a reduction in Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) from $18 \%$ to below $4.5 \%$, with voltage stability maintained within $\pm 5 \%$. The solution meets IEEE 519-2022 standards and enhances operational reliability in harmonic-rich environments.

title: Design for Serviceability in Complex Electromechanical NPI Products: A Comprehensive Survey of Principles, Metrics, and Field Integration Strategies
authors: Makrand Godbole
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Design for Serviceability (DfS) is an increasingly critical consideration in the development of complex electromechanical products, particularly during New Product Introduction (NPI) cycles. While design-for-manufacturing (DfM) and design-for-reliability (DfR) have been extensively explored, DfS remains underrepresented in academic literature—despite its direct impact on Mean Time to Repair (MTTR), technician burden, and product uptime. This survey synthesizes insights from over 15 peer-reviewed academic sources across sectors such as automotive, aerospace, and medical devices to present a comprehensive framework for service-oriented NPI planning. We identify six core DfS principles, introduce a consolidated set of serviceability metrics, and examine enabling technologies including augmented reality (AR), digital twin platforms, and PLM-integrated feedback systems. The paper contributes a Serviceability Integration Matrix that maps design principles to implementation strategies and measurable field outcomes. By bridging fragmented research domains and quantifying downstream service impact, this survey supports NPI teams in embedding DfS principles early in the product development lifecycle to improve scalability, technician efficiency, and customer satisfaction.

title: Secrecy-Energy Efficiency Maximization for Finite Blocklength Aerial Intelligent Reflecting Surfaces assisted RSMA Networks
authors: Habtamu Demeke Mihertie, Zhengqiang Wang, Deepak Kumar Jain, Xingwang Li
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Next-generation wireless networks aim to deliver transformative improvements in data rates, latency, and reliability. Among critical enabling technologies, rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) combined with intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) mounted on unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) has gained considerable attention. In this paper, we address the secrecy energy efficiency (SEE) maximization problem for short-packet communications in UAV-mounted IRS-assisted RSMA networks operating under finite block length (FBL) conditions. Unlike traditional scenarios optimized for long packets, our approach explicitly incorporates the significant impact of decoding errors and strict latency constraints inherent to short-packet transmission. We propose a comprehensive framework that jointly optimizes UAV deployment, IRS phase shifts, transmit precoding vectors, and common rate allocation. The formulated non-convex optimization problem is effectively solved via iterative decomposition and efficient approximation methods. Numerical evaluations demonstrate notable improvements in SEE compared to existing benchmark methods, underscoring the efficacy of UAV-mounted IRS and RSMA integration in addressing practical constraints of short-packet communication.

title: Maximum Electric Field Analysis in a Power Module using Schwarz-Christoffel Transformation
authors: Arindam Sircar, Xiu Yao
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: The increase in operating voltage levels of power modules due to the adoption of wide bandgap semiconductor materials increases the risk of insulation breakdown and partial discharge. Modeling Direct Bonded Copper (DBC) and evaluating its electric field distribution is an important step for power module design. Finite Element Analysis (FEA) solvers, such as Ansys Maxwell and COMSOL Multiphysics, are popular tools to obtain accurate electric field information. However, these solvers are computationally expensive and time intensive. In this paper, a simple and accurate DBC model is developed. Schwarz-Christoffel Transformations are used to obtain an analytical formula to evaluate the electric field in the DBC model. The analytical models are verified against FEA models designed in Ansys Maxwell. The analytical method provides accurate electric field values while significantly reducing computation time.

title: Modified Sparsity Adaptive Matching Pursuit Algorithm for Airborne Forward-looking Imaging
authors: Ruohong Huang, Di Wu, Heng Wei, Shuwen Wang, Yudong Zhang, Daiyin Zhu
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Airborne radar forward-looking imaging (FLI) is a crucial technique with applications in various fields. To enhance imaging performance, super-resolution (SR) methods from array signal processing are introduced, enabling high-resolution forward-looking imaging. Among SR approaches, compressed sensing (CS) combined with array radar offers a promising approach. However, conventional CS reconstruction algorithms require prior knowledge of sparsity, which is often unavailable in practice. Although some algorithms, like the sparsity adaptive matching pursuit (SAMP), do not require sparsity, their performance can be hindered by ineffective stopping criteria. To address this, we propose a modified algorithm based on SAMP, named MSAMP. MSAMP employs a novel stopping criterion and a more suitable reconstruction process tailored for airborne radar FLI without requiring sparsity. Comparing to some existing FLI algorithms, such as orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP) and iterative adaptive approach (IAA), MSAMP demonstrates low time complexity and competitive reconstruction performance.

title: Smart Infrastructure-Based Anomaly Detection Under Cyberattacks
authors: Cong Zhang, Jun Ying, Xiaobo Qu, Yiheng Feng
publish: IEEE Intelligent Transportation Systems Magazine
abstract: Connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) are increasingly exposed to cyberphysical attacks, yet most existing detection methods overlook the potential of infrastructure-based monitoring. In this article, we propose a novel infrastructure-based anomaly detection framework to identify cyberattacks on CAVs under time interference attacks and vehicle-to-everything communication attacks. The optimal attack strategies are generated using a Pareto optimization that jointly maximizes safety risk and stealthiness. To detect the attacks, a transformer-based trajectory prediction model is developed to predict normal driving behaviors. An XGBoost classifier is then developed to detect anomalies by comparing predicted and observed vehicle trajectories. We validate the proposed framework using real-world trajectory data. The results show that the proposed anomaly detection model achieves high accuracy with low false positive and false negative rates in both offline and online settings. These results demonstrate that smart infrastructure can significantly improve the safety of CAVs by enabling timely and accurate detection of cyberattacks.

title: Towards Patch-based Noise Compression for Adversarial Attack against Transformer-based Visual Tracking
authors: Peng Gao, Long Xu, Wen-Jia Tang, Fei Wang, Hamido Fujita, Hanan Aljuaid, Ru-Yue Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: In recent years, with the widespread application of Vision Transformer (ViT) in visual trackers, their robustness has received increasing attention. However, by focusing on global interactions between image patches, ViT reduces sensitivity to local noise, posing new challenges for adversarial attacks. Meanwhile, existing decision-based adversarial attack methods often overlook the differences in noise sensitivity between different patches, further limiting the compression efficiency of adversarial noise, especially in ViT. In visual tracking, existing adversarial attack methods primarily target Siamese network-based trackers, and research on adversarial attacks against Transformer-based trackers, particularly decision-based black-box attacks, is still relatively limited. To implement effective black-box attacks on Transformer-based trackers, this paper innovatively proposes patch-based adversarial noise compression (PANC), a decision-based adversarial attack method. This method effectively compresses adversarial noise patch by patch, significantly improving compression efficiency and attack concealment. PANC also introduces a noise sensitivity matrix that dynamically adds and reduces adversarial noise, optimizing the spatial distribution of noise while decreasing the number of queries. We validated the effectiveness of the proposed PANC attack method on several Transformer-based trackers, including OSTrack, STARK, TransT, and MixformerV2, and three public large-scale benchmark datasets: GOT-10k, TrackingNet, and LaSOT. Experimental results show that compared to the existing state-of-the-art adversarial attack method, the IoU attack, PANC compresses the noise level to 10%, improving the attack effectiveness by 162% with the number of queries of only 45.7%. Furthermore, PANC can serve as an initialization or post-processing optimization strategy for other adversarial attack methods, providing a more flexible and efficient mechanism for adversarial example generation. Our work reveals the vulnerabilities of existing Transformer-based visual trackers and offers new ideas for further improving the efficiency and concealment of adversarial attacks.

title: Integrating Robotics, Remote Sensing, and Machine Learning for Scalable Biodiversity Monitoring in Tropical Rainforests
authors: Igor A. D. Santos, Gilvanio B. De Sousa, Kenny A. Q. Caldas, Robson R. D. Pereira, Leandro J. E. Campos, Paulo H. C. Morais, Edson H. Francelino, Roberto S. Inoue, Marco H. Terra
publish: IEEE Transactions on Field Robotics
abstract: Tropical rainforests are biodiversity hotspots that play a critical role in maintaining global ecological balance. However, the vastness, complexity, and inaccessibility of these ecosystems significantly challenge their monitoring and conservation. This study introduces an innovative approach developed in the XPRIZE Rainforest competition, combining advanced robotics, environmental sensors, and machine learning to enable rapid and non-invasive biodiversity assessments. The proposed solution integrates ground and aerial robotic platforms with Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) sensors, bioacoustic recorders, environmental deoxyribonucleic acid (eDNA) collectors, and high-resolution cameras to collect and analyze data on water resources, the forest floor, and the canopy. The methodologies were validated in a 100-hectare tropical rainforest, where they demonstrated scalability, efficiency, and the ability to deliver real-time insights into biodiversity and ecosystem health. The research outlines pathways for empowering local communities and enhancing conservation policies through the acquisition of high-resolution data. As a testament to its impact, the proposed approach earned the Brazilian Team third place in the XPRIZE Rainforest competition, announced at the G20 meeting in November 2024. These findings highlight the transformative potential of integrating cutting-edge technology with ecological conservation, setting a new benchmark for worldwide biodiversity monitoring in tropical rainforests.

title: Parallel Multi-Attention and Gated Fusion for Visual Question Localized Answering in Surgical Scenes
authors: Zeyu Wang, Ming Wang, Peixi Peng, Wanshu Fan, Zhongbin Han, Xin Yang, Dongsheng Zhou
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Surgical Visual Question Localized Answering (Surgical-VQLA) is an emerging task that supports surgical education by generating accurate answers and localizing relevant anatomical regions based on visual content and textual queries. This task requires precise spatial reasoning and tight semantic alignment across modalities, which remain challenging for current models due to limited spatial sensitivity and insufficient semantic integration. Mitigating these limitations, we propose EndoVisLoc, a dedicated framework that enhances visual-textual interaction through structured attention and gated fusion. Specifically, we design a Parallel Multi Attention Module (PMAM) to capture different visual features, improving the perception of anatomical structures. We further develop a Dynamic Gated Fusion Module (DGFM) to adaptively inject semantic priors into visual features via gated control, facilitating robust cross-modal fusion. Finally, we introduce a Hierarchical Classifier Head (HCH) to refine the fused representations and jointly optimize answer prediction and spatial localization. Extensive experiments on the EndoVis-18-VQLA and EndoVis-17-VQLA datasets demonstrate the superior performance of EndoVisLoc, surpassing the state-of-the-art OTAS model by +5.72% ACC, +5.73% F-score, and +1.82% mIoU on EndoVis-18-VQLA and by +1.59% ACC, +2.48% F-score, and +0.33% mIoU on EndoVis-17-VQLA. These results confirm the consistent advantage of EndoVisLoc in both answer accuracy and precise anatomical localization. title: Optimizing Cell Structure to Improve Cell Characteristics in IGZO Channel-Based 3D NAND Flash With p-Type Gate
authors: Sungho Park, Youngho Jung, Daewoong Kang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: For the first time, a novel IGZO channel-based 3D NAND Flash structure with an embedded p-type poly-Si injection layer is proposed, using integrated structural, material, and operational modifications to address the limitations of the conventional IGZO channel-based 3D NAND Flash with p-type poly-si [23, 24]. First, the round shaped tunneling oxide (TNO) was applied to improve program characteristics by suppressing hole tunneling at the cell center. Second, SiO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>/HfO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>/SiO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> tunneling layers were applied to improve erase characteristics through valence band energy offset to suppress hole back tunneling. The erase characteristics were optimized to improve program characteristics by reducing the top oxide thickness (TTO). As TTO decreases, the ISPP voltage required for V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>= 2 V is reduced due to the thinner electron tunneling barrier. Lastly, the optimization of pass voltage to suppress lateral hole spreading further improved the ISPP characteristics by reducing the ISPP voltage required for V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>= 2 V without the pass disturbance. With these combined modifications, the proposed structure achieved the reduction in the ISPE voltage required for V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>= -2 V by -1.5 V and the ISPP voltage required for V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>= 2 V by -7.7 V, compared with the conventional IGZO channel-based 3D NAND Flash memory with p-type poly-Si [23, 24]. As a result, the program and the erase characteristics of the proposed structure were sufficiently improved with the integration of 1) structural, 2) material and 3) operational optimizations compared to the characteristics of the poly-Si channel structure. These results demonstrate that the proposed structure is promising for next-generation 3D NAND Flash memory with more than 500 layers.

title: MedVisioneer: A Lesion-Aware Deep Vision Framework for Enhanced Diagnostic Assistance in CT Image Recognition and Adaptation
authors: Wang Qian, Zhang Yi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In this study, we introduce MedVisioneer, a lesion-aware deep vision framework designed for enhanced diagnostic assistance in CT image recognition and adaptation, addressing the challenge of identifying clinically significant regions and incidental findings within complex medical imagery. Our approach integrates multi-channel radiological feature representations to effectively characterize scans with intricate anatomical structures. The core contribution is a multi-layer hierarchical model, which simulates radiological search behavior by leveraging lesion-sensitive attention mechanisms. This enables efficient identification of diagnostically relevant regions across varied scales and contexts. Through locality-preserved learning, our model generates clinically plausible scan paths that preserve spatial coherence and prioritize areas aligned with expert visual attention. These attention-guided deep features are incorporated into a probabilistic model for pathological categorization. Extensive empirical validation on our in-house clinical CT dataset and six public medical imaging benchmarks demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach, with significant improvements in lesion classification and image adaptation, as well as superior performance in diagnostic assistance tasks.

title: ContractTrace: Retracing Smart Contract Versions for Security Analyses
authors: Fatou Ndiaye Mbodji, Boladji Vinny Adjibi, Moustapha Awwalou Diouf, Gervais Mendy, Kui Liu, Jacques Klein, Tegawendé F. Bissyandé
publish: 2025 Cybersecurity4D (C4D)
abstract: Due to the inherent immutability of blockchain technology, smart contract updates require their deployment at new addresses rather than modifying existing ones, thus fragmenting version histories and creating critical blind spots for analyses. Indeed, for example, this fragmentation severely hinders security researchers’ ability to track vulnerability lifecycles across contract versions. While platforms like Etherscan provide detailed information about Ethereum smart contracts, they lack crucial functionality to trace predecessor-successor relationships within smart contract lineages, preventing systematic analysis of how vulnerabilities emerge, propagate, and potentially remain unresolved across versions.To address the challenge of tracing smart contract lineages, we adopt a Design Science Research (DSR) approach and introduce ContractTrace, an automated infrastructure that accurately identifies and links versions of smart contracts into coherent lineages. This tool enables the construction of lineageSet, an up-to-date, open-source dataset specifically designed to support security research on vulnerability, defect or any other property’s evolution patterns in smart contracts.Through a security-focused case study we demonstrate how ContractTrace reveals previously obscured vulnerability lifecycles within smart contract lineages, tracking whether critical security flaws persist or get resolved across versions. This capability is essential for understanding vulnerability propagation patterns and evaluating the effectiveness of security patches in blockchain environments. In the evaluation phase of our DSR approach, we validated our lineage detection methodology against an alternative approach using Locality-Sensitive Hashing (LSH) to cluster contract versions, confirming the security relevance and accuracy of our technique.

title: A System Dynamics Model of User Acceptance in Higher Education: Simulating TAM Constructs with Vensim
authors: Siti Mukaromah, Mohammad Idhom, Agung Brastama Putra, Agussalim, Anggraini Puspita Sari, Yisti Vita Via
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The acceptance from the end-user of university information systems is an important factor for successful implementation and long-term use. While the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) has been widely applied to examine this issue. The majority of applications are designed statically, thus failing to account for the shifting relationships between behavioral constructs over time. This paper introduces the use of a system dynamics methodology to represent and simulate the components of TAM within the higher education setting. Using Vensim, a model was developed based on key variables such as perceived usefulness, perceived ease of use, attitude toward use, behavioral intention, and actual use. Two scenarios were simulated: baseline adoption without intervention, and adoption with a training-based intervention aimed at improving perceived ease of use. The simulation highlights that implementing intervention at the right time greatly accelerates adoption rates. Through this study, it is demonstrated that system dynamics serves as a valuable tool for providing insights that support strategic and policy decisions in implementing digital systems in university.

title: Enterprise Architecture Design using Zachman Framework for Research and Community Service Information Systems
authors: Fransiskus Panca Juniawan, Iski Zaliman, Nanang Wahyudin, Hengky Veru Purbolakseto, Dwi Yuny Sylfania
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The management of research and community service in universities is crucial for enhancing social impact and institutional effectiveness. However, many universities face challenges due to fragmented information systems and inadequate integration between these functions, including at the Institution of Research and Community Service (LPPM) of Universitas Bangka Belitung. This paper proposes the design of a unified system for research and community service management using the Zachman Framework. The proposed system aims to address data fragmentation, inefficient resource allocation, and lack of collaboration among departments. By applying Zachman Framework, this proposed system may ensure a structured approach to managing research and community service functions, improving data accessibility, decision-making, and collaboration. This paper discussing all of six Zachman Framework perspective of stakeholders. The methodology outlines the process of framework application, and the results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed architecture in integrating these essential functions. The novelty of this work lies in the adaptation of Zachman Framework to build system that could manage research and community service in the scope university.

title: Digital Transformation in the Textile Sector: ERP, Finance, and E-Commerce
authors: Aracelly Fernanda Núñez-Naranjo, Tania Morales-Molina, Elio Cables-Fernández, Kimberly Alcivar-Loor
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in emerging economies are adopting enterprise software to improve performance, yet rigorous evidence in Ecuador’s textile sector remains scarce. Here we address the gap by examining whether the combined use of Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), digital financial analytics, and E-Commerce is associated with superior firm outcomes. We aim to quantify performance changes and to explain organizational enablers and barriers. We use a concurrent mixed-methods design: a survey of n = 152 textile firms and 12 executive interviews; measurement diagnostics and regression models complement thematic analysis. We find that ERP and digital financial analytics adoption are positively associated with operating margin and inventory turnover; pre/post comparisons suggest higher ROI and lower operating costs in adopters. E-Commerce adoption is associated with higher sales and customer satisfaction, while under-investment in training and cybersecurity persists. We contribute empirical evidence from a Latin American manufacturing context, practical guidance on sequencing investments, and policy-relevant insights for SME digitalization.

title: Voice-Guided User Localization in a Social Robot
authors: Paula Contreras, Andrés Cabrera, Esteban Mora, Daniel Iturralde, Jaime Burbano, Pablo Pintado, David Mejía, José Fajardo, Gabriela Duque
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation and evaluation of a social robot designed to assist university students. The robot locates its interlocutor by identifying the speaker’s voice and turning towards it. The system was implemented on TurtleBot3 and uses a microphone array to perform direction of arrival (DOA) and voice activity detection (VAD), with cliff-detection sensors, and displays to simulate facial expressions. User testing indicates a high level of engagement with the robot and positive user acceptance of it. The robot reliably avoided edges during testing. However, the sound localization was less accurate for high-pitched voices and when the sound source is located directly above the robot.

title: A brief review of robotics and artificial intelligence in education
authors: Sebastián Aucapiña, Manuel Cardona, José Varela-Aldás
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: New technologies are consistently integrated into the educational sector to improve its processes and improve learning outcomes. This paper presents a systematic review of the use of robots and artificial intelligence (AI) in education, with a particular focus on systems that incorporate voice recognition or conversational interaction. Educational robots have increasingly supported learning environments, from primary schools to higher education, enhancing motivation, engagement, and participation. Robots with humanoid features and voice capabilities, such as chatbots or speech recognition modules, are especially effective at capturing student attention and fostering interactive learning experiences. The review includes 30 peer-reviewed articles published in the last decade, identified using a PRISMA-based methodology. Studies were selected based on clear methodologies, measurable outcomes, and relevance to general education, excluding medical or highly specialized STEM applications. Mixedmethod analysis combines quantitative assessments of learning gains with qualitative insights into student perceptions. The findings highlight consistent improvements in motivation and classroom dynamics, although cognitive benefits vary depending on educational level, robot design, and integration with pedagogical goals. Limitations include a high reliance on simulations, a strong geographical bias toward English-speaking countries, and a lack of local data sets. In addition, some studies did not find significant learning improvements, highlighting that these technologies should complement rather than replace human teachers. The review identifies future research needs, such as domain adaptation for real-world applications and more extensive studies in underrepresented regions such as Latin America. In general, voice-enabled educational robots demonstrate great potential as interactive learning assistants when thoughtfully implemented, contributing to more engaging, adaptable, and effective educational environments.

title:
Challenges of Firing H

                    as an Alternative Fuel
authors: Tahir Abbas, Michalis Akritopoulos, Shan Raza, Syed Suhail Akhtar
publish: 2023 IEEE-IAS/PCA Cement Industry Conference (IAS/PCA)
abstract: The future net zero CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emission target requires several stepwise carbon mitigation measures, beyond conventional and already tested and tried technologies. During the last 30 years, cement industry has reported over 30% reduction in CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions (against the 1990 baseline) through energy efficiency and use of alternative fuels and raw materials. The use of calcined clay (by turning natural clays into synthetic pozzolanic materials) may lead to additional 40% reductions in CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions by replacing similar proportion of clinker in the cement mix. For reaching net zero CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions, however, a breakthrough in conventional approaches is required involving non-fossil fuel thermal input and employing ‘green power’.Besides implementing O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> enrichment methodologies (CCSU), among other options, H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> firing is being considered for replacing combustion generated CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> with water vapors (H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O), although it is still a greenhouse gas with similar thermal radiative properties to that of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, but its concentrations within the atmosphere are controlled by the earth’s temperature. Hence, virtually no negative effect on environment is considered when water vapors replace all atmospheric CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions.Therefore, the availability of ‘green’ hydrogen ("green" hydrogen is considered when it has been produced using only renewable energy) may provide an attractive opportunity for the cement plants to adapt H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> as an alternative fuel (AF) although it is expensive and cannot be classified as AF on fuel cost basis. The production of green H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> will reduce consumption of the higher ‘carbon’ content fuels, i.e., petcoke, currently extensively used in the cement industry. The envisaged green H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> supply-chain, has initiated several research and feasibility studies, to identify its thermal substitution ratio (TSR), its firing strategies (kiln/calciner) within current AF utilization scenarios, while handling/storing highly volatile H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, its safety aspects, flammability and its effect on process and control. In this paper, results from both theoretical and plant trials on the use of H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> as an alternative fuel are presented.

title: Measuring Telework Productivity, Key Performance Indicators with a Mixed Approach
authors: Marcela Fernanda Coronel Piduisaca, Irene Marisol Revelo Portilla, Jorge Stalin Chávez Vaca
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents an analysis of labor productivity in a teleworking environment, focusing on the human resources department of one of Ecuador’s leading supermarket chains. It employs a mixed-methodological approach, designing and applying Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) tailored to the context of remote work to measure their impact on staff performance. The study combined structured surveys, semi-structured interviews, and statistical analysis of data collected using digital tools, including SPSS, ATLAS.ti, and Google Forms. The results show an improvement in the perception of productivity, work quality, and job satisfaction, specifically in areas related to autonomy, flexibility, and time management. However, challenges related to connectivity, performance feedback, and clarity in the definition of objectives were identified. As a main contribution, a system of indicators adaptable to the human resources department in similar contexts is presented, including quantitative metrics (task completion, absenteeism rate) and qualitative metrics (wellbeing, communication). It is therefore concluded that the use of digital tools and well-structured indicator systems allows for the monitoring and improvement of productivity in remote environments in the post-COVID era.

title: Visual Servoing of a Manipulator Robot using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Luis Ortiz, Jorge Pomares Baeza, Álvaro Belmonte Baeza, Luis Rivera, José Varela-Aldás
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents the development of a visual control system based on Reinforcement Learning (RL) applied to a UR5 manipulator robot. The main objective is to design and train the robot to perform manipulation tasks in a dynamic environment, using only visual feedback provided by a camera mounted on the end-effector. For the learning process, the Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) algorithm was implemented, achieving an efficient balance between exploration and exploitation in continuous action spaces. The reward function encourages the proximity of the end-effector to the target plane, correct alignment with it, and collision avoidance. The results obtained after 5000 simulation episodes using the MuJoCo physics engine demonstrated that the robot learned a stable and precise control policy, achieving a success rate above $85 \%$ and reducing the distance to the target plane to less than 2 cm. Furthermore, the number of collisions decreased significantly during training, indicating that the robot learned to plan efficient and safe trajectories. The proposed approach enables the robot to adapt to variations in the environment without requiring predefined models, enhancing its ability to perform complex manipulation tasks in unstructured scenarios. The contributions of this work open up new possibilities for applying RL in collaborative robotics, with potential for implementation in real-world environments. Future research could focus on the experimental validation of the system on physical robots and the integration of additional sensors to improve environmental perception.

title: Experimental Determination of the Thermal Properties of Unfired Clay Bricks with Rice Husk Additives
authors: Penka Zlateva, Lubomir Tashkov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study aims to evaluate the effect of rice husk incorporation on the thermal performance of unfired clay bricks, with the goal of developing environmentally sustainable building materials. Four compositions were prepared: a control sample with no additive, and three mixtures containing 16%, 24%, and 32% rice husks by volume. Thermal conductivity (λ), volumetric heat capacity (ρ•c), and thermal diffusivity (a) were measured using a transient heat flow method (Izomet 2114 analyzer) under standardized laboratory conditions. The results show that increasing the rice husk content significantly improves thermal insulation. The 24% composition achieved a 29% reduction in thermal conductivity compared to the control (λ = 0.512 W/(m•K)), while the 32% mix yielded the lowest conductivity value of 0.313 W/(m•K), accompanied by a noticeable decrease in thermal diffusivity. These changes indicate improved thermal inertia and slower heat transfer, contributing to more stable indoor temperatures. The findings confirm the potential of rice husk–modified unfired clay bricks as effective, low-carbon, and thermally efficient materials suitable for energy-conscious construction in warm climate regions. Future research will address the mechanical strength and long-term durability to assess their broader structural applicability.

title: Inverse Modeling of Soil Moisture Dynamics Using Data from an IoT-Based Agrometeorological Sensor Station
authors: Atanas Atanasov, Miglena Koleva, Lubin Vulkov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study focuses on the optimization of Richards’ equation for simulating soil moisture dynamics under real field conditions. The van Genuchten–Mualem formulation was combined with nonlinear optimization and Tikhonov regularization. Six types of agrometeorological and hydrological measurements (air temperature, relative humidity, solar radiation, wind speed, atmospheric pressure, and soil moisture) were incorporated to provide realistic boundary and initial conditions. Case studies from Brestovitsa and Yuper are presented, based on multi-source field observations collected at 30-minute intervals. The numerical simulations demonstrate that the approach reproduces the observed soil moisture dynamics with good consistency in both trend and magnitude.

title: A Transformer Framework for Remaining Useful Life Prediction Using Sensor Attention and Operational Context Embeddings
authors: Jordy Garzón, Ricardo Flores-Moyano, Maria Baldeon-Calisto, José Vega-Sánchez
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents a novel and efficient approach for predicting the Remaining Useful Life (RUL) of turbofan aircraft engines using NASA’s C-MAPSS dataset. A two-phase methodology is introduced: baseline modeling with classical regressors (Ridge, Random Forest, XGBoost), followed by advanced deep learning techniques employing Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and a custom transformer-based architecture. The proposed transformer model integrates dynamic operatingcondition embeddings and a sensor-specific attention mechanism inspired by squeeze-and-excitation (SE) networks. This design enhances the interpretability while capturing complex multivariate temporal dependencies. Comparative experiments across multiple configurations d emonstrated s uperior p erformance in t erms of RMSE and $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$, outperforming both traditional models and recent state-of-the-art deep learning approaches. The proposed method is computationally efficient and can be generalized across diverse degradation patterns. These findings $\mathbf{r}$ einforce $\mathbf{t}$ he $\mathbf{r}$ ole of lean transformer architecture as a scalable, interpretable, and effective tool for predictive maintenance in aerospace applications.

title: Experimental Investigation of Computer Vision Architectures for Object Detection in Mobile Robotics
authors: Perizat Rakhmetova, Aldabergen Bektilevov, Lazzat Kurmangalieva, Baglan Bekbossynova, Beibit Shingissov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In recent years, computer vision has emerged as a key technology for autonomous mobile robots and transportation systems, enabling their ability to perceive the environment and make real-time decisions. One of the most critical and widely demanded tasks is object detection, which is essential for navigation, collision avoidance, and the execution of mission-specific operations. This paper examines experimental studies of computer vision algorithms used for object detection in mobile robots. The focus is on the analysis and comparison of modern methods, including classical image processing algorithms and deep learning-based neural network approaches. The experimental study was conducted in a pipeline system to detect in-pipe defects, which requires high accuracy and robustness of algorithms given the limited computing resources of mobile platforms. Experiments were conducted using various object detector architectures (YOLO, SSD, Faster R-CNN) and lightweight models, such as MobileNet, designed for resource-constrained environments. Algorithm performance was evaluated based on accuracy and processing speed. The results of the study enable the identification of optimal solutions for integrating computer vision systems into mobile robots, ensuring a balance between detection quality and operational efficiency. Furthermore, the study explores the potential adaptation of these architectures for specialized scenarios, such as pipeline inspection, where detecting complex-shaped defects within confined spaces is required.

title: Analysis of the Efficiency of Devices for Reactive Power Compensation in Traction Substations
authors: Vasil Dimitrov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In this paper, a study of the power factor (PF) of Traction Power Substations (TPSs) with installed reactive energy compensators in Bulgarian railway infrastructure for the first half of 2024 was carried out. The applied methods for reactive power compensation and the types of compensating device installed in TPSs were analyzed and relevant conclusions and recommendations are formulated. The main reasons leading to the need to implement reactive power compensators, as well as the criteria for selecting devices, are systematized. In conclusion, dynamic compensation devices are a more correct technical and economic solution, leading to an improvement in the average PF and a reduction in reactive energy costs. For TPSs with suboptimal compensation devices, a detailed study of the electricity consumption should be carried out and options for installing additional modules or replacing the compensation devices with new, more efficient ones should be studied.

title: Optimization of Mechanical and Electrical Parameters of Feeding Devices based on Productivity Requirements and Part Geometry
authors: Penko Mitev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper proposes a practical and theoretical approach for optimizing the parameters of feeding devices based on the required productivity and specific part geometry. In machine and automation design, selecting suitable parameters, such as the length of linear feeders, is often a complex task. Machine designers commonly rely on empirical knowledge due to the absence of reliable predictive algorithms. A major challenge is ensuring the real productivity of the feeding system matches the projected productivity during the design phase. Systems with higher productivity allow for shorter linear feeders, while lower-productivity systems require longer tracks to provide a sufficient buffer. The paper presents a practical method based on experimental trials to determine the mean productivity and the resulting optimal feeder length. Furthermore, it develops a theoretical framework to estimate feeder parameters when experimental data is not available, considering part geometry, the number of stable states, and the probability of correct orientation. Additional recommendations are provided for selecting appropriate types of linear feeding tracks based on part properties and requirements. Key influencing factors such as part symmetry, surface conditions, and gravitational effects on linear tracks are discussed. Practical advice is offered on how to ensure system reliability by introducing safety margins in the design parameters. The study underlines the importance of early practical validation with real parts to avoid costly design errors. The proposed methodology is applicable across a wide range of industrial feeding systems and supports designers in achieving more compact, reliable, and efficient machine solutions.

title: Novel Concept for Drone-Based Situational Driver Assistance System to Improve Visibility in Off-Road Environments
authors: Jörg Kneip, Mario Hirz
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This research project aims at the integration of consumer aerial drones into ground vehicle systems to improve driving in off-road environments by providing optimal external viewpoints for certain driving situations. In this experimental approach the vehicle-drone system uses near vehicle imagery to assess the situation and to decide, which view the drone must provide for the driver to be shown in a vehicle display. In this procedure, the drone is autonomously flying around the car, creating footage and finally moving to the spot of best view. A field study with off-road drivers will investigate selected critical driving situations, optimal viewpoints and other requirements for a seamless operation. The system created will be used to understand operational challenges of drone-based support of ground vehicle drivers in difficult off-road driving situations.

title: Enhance Student Engagement with the Help of Multimedia and Cognitive Computing Tools
authors: Kalliopi Kravari, Athanasia Thomoglou, Maria Roussi, Michail Chalaris, Kalliopi Ladomenou, Anna Thysiadou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In this paper is presented a different way of teaching of the "Water pH" subunit. The aim of this work is the promotion of the integration of computers into the teaching of courses, especially Chemistry, by supporting more fully and more effectively the feasibility and the principles of teaching. It is pursued, with the rotation of methodically selected and targeted activities, to serve as much as possible the entirety of teaching goals defined for the thematic module of "pH". Lastly, the present teaching suggestion can be a reason for active participation during the lesson, in order to get students to learn multiple ways of teaching and present a chemical phenomenon beyond the pages of the schoolbook.

title: Advances in Security Maturity and Architecture Design in Critical Infrastructures
authors: Henry Paul Tigre Avila, Juan Diego Belesaca, Fabian Astudillo-Salinas
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Critical infrastructures such as power grids, water treatment facilities, and gas production plants are increasingly reliant on Industrial Control Systems (ICS). However, these systems are subject to a growing array of sophisticated cyber threats. This paper presents a state-of-the-art review of security maturity frameworks and secure architecture designs tailored for IT/OT environments in critical infrastructure settings. The PRISMA methodology was employed to guide the selection of articles, and the AI-enhanced platform Elicit for peer-reviewed publications in the last 5 years. This yielded 60 pertinent studies. Our analysis identifies a clear preference for modular maturity models, such as the NIST Cybersecurity Framework and DOE’s C2M2, to benchmark and advance security posture. At the architectural level, we emphasize fundamental controls, including network segmentation, access proxies, next-generation firewalls, and Zero Trust implemented via SDN. These are integrated with hierarchical layering and active-deception honeypots. We conclude by recommending continuous, context-aware, multidomain risk management schemes to enhance the resilience and reliability of critical infrastructure operations.

title: A Conceptual Model for the Evolution from Automation to Lights-Out Production
authors: Nina Naydenova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The paper aims to present a conceptual model for the evolution from automation to lights-out manufacturing, by combining engineering principles with organizational-behavioral approaches. It is based on the integration of existing theoretical frameworks, models and empirical data from industrial cases published in peer-reviewed journals and industrial reports. The basic idea is that automation is not a static process. The model describes five sequential and interconnected stages (mechanization, automation, digitalization, intelligent automation and lights-out manufacturing) that are rather spiral-like, as each subsequent phase builds on and refines the previous one through feedback loops. In this sense provides a basis for the analysis of real industrial practices that reflect different stages of this transition. The author aims to compare the model with empirical cases and discuss the critical factors for a successful transformation to autonomous production, and examines the practical experience of FANUC, Siemens Electronics Works and Tesla Gigafactory. The comparison of the developed model with the real industrial cases demonstrates a high degree of correspondence in terms of the phases, also the technological, organizational and human axes and the spiral evolution. However, a systematic discrepancy is observed in the social and ethical integration aspects. Most practices emphasize efficiency at the expense of the human-centric approach which requires additional research in the context of Industry 5.0. The application of the model to real cases confirms its validity and analytical value, while highlighting the areas in which the human factor remains crucial - creativity, interpretation and ethics.

title: From 3D Printing to Automation: Arduino-Controlled Educational Manipulator with Sensor Мodules Integration
authors: Nikolay Komitov, Evelin Shopov, Mariyana Sestrimska, Margarita Terziyska, Veselin Nachev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents the design, fabrication, and autonomous control of a low-cost educational manipulator developed using Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM). The mechanical structure was optimized for rapid prototyping, while the system integrates an embedded control unit based on an Arduino UNO board, four servo motors, and two complementary sensor modules – infrared and ultrasonic – enabling object detection, grip-ping, and positioning in a fully automated work cycle. The study provides a detailed description of the 3D printing process, assembly stages, and structural modifications, including the implementation of a bearing base and an improved gripper. Experimental tests demonstrated an average cycle time of 8.6 s, positioning accuracy of ±2.4 mm, and a 94% success rate in repeated pick-and-place operations. The results confirm the applicability of the system as an affordable and reliable educational platform for robotics, bridging theoretical knowledge with practical skills and providing a foundation for future advanced developments.

title: Embedded Artificial Intelligence System for High Impedance Fault Detection in Distribution Feeders: A Case Study from La Libertad Substation
authors: Patricia Pasmay, Luis Muñoz, Ronald Suarez, Sara Guerrero, Miguel Torres, Edwin Valarezo Anazco
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: High Impedance Faults (HIFs) in medium-voltage distribution networks represent a major challenge for conventional protection systems due to their low fault current magnitude and nonlinear behavior. This paper presents a structured methodology to detect HIF using Multilayer Perceptrons (MLP), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), and Support Vector Machines (SVM). A realistic distribution feeder from the La Libertad substation in Ecuador was modeled in MATLAB/Simulink, and HIF events were simulated under various non-conductive surface conditions using the Emanuel arc model. The CNN-based model achieved the highest detection accuracy of $99.98 \%$, with an inference time of 40 ms on a Raspberry Pi 4 embedded platform. The MLP-based model reached an accuracy of $95.03 \%$, while reducing the inference time to 16.9 ms, making it more suitable for real-time deployment in resource-constrained environments. Also, the implemented algorithms were validated using real oscillographic relay data. The outcomes of this study validate the feasibility of embedding Artificial Intelligence-based HIF detection in edge computing devices, offering a practical and scalable solution to enhance protection capabilities in mediumvoltage distribution networks where traditional schemes often fall short.
