title: AI-Based Lung Disease Classification
authors: Yahya M. Tashtoush, Amani Krieshan, Reem Banihani, Plamen Zahariev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Pneumonia and tuberculosis are two critical diseases posing a severe threat to human health worldwide. Early and accurate diagnosis is necessary for saving patients. In this work, a deep learning system has been presented that could classify chest X-rays into three categories automatically: Normal, Pneumonia, and TB. Transfer learning was implemented using two pre-trained deep networks, ResNet18 and VGG16, with fine-tuning on a publicly available Kaggle dataset. A self-attention mechanism was applied to improve the performance, which captures important regions, and oversampling and undersampling were adopted to address imbalance in the dataset. ResNet18 yielded superior results with a striking accuracy of 99.8% and an F1 score, precision, and recall of 0.9985. The VGG16 model also generated satisfactory results with an overall accuracy of 84%. These observations establish the proposed approach as a potentially efficient and highly accurate supportive tool for diagnosis of prevalent pulmonary diseases.

title: Integration of Melanopic Equivalent Daylight Illuminance and Controlling Color Temperature in Dynamic Lighting Control for Circadian Rhythm Regulation
authors: Ventsislav Vasilev, Aneliya Manukova, Orlin Petrov, Tsvetomir Gotsov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Contemporary research emphasizes the importance of synchronizing artificial lighting with the circadian rhythm and biological processes of humans, especially in educational environments where the concentration, productivity, and health of students are directly dependent on the lighting environment. The spectral composition and timing of light exposure affect both the circadian rhythm and melatonin regulation, as well as the hypothalamic–pituitary– adrenal (HPA) axis, which is responsible for the cortisol response. In this context, this work proposes a new approach to dynamic lighting control that combines two key parameters: maintaining a melanopic equivalent daylight illuminance (mEDI) of approximately 250 lx at eye level (1.2 m, seated position) and controlling the color temperature (CCT) in predefined time windows between 07:00 and 17:00. The system uses sensors to measure spectral characteristics and intensity, integrated into an IoT-based architecture. This ensures not only visual comfort but also biologically effective light exposure, consistent with medical evidence for morning stimulation and subsequent neutrality during the day. This work offers an integrated consideration of mEDI and CCT time profiles as a method for creating a favorable and healthy learning environment that follows the body's circadian rhythm.

title: Electric Potential Calculation in Muscle Tissue: A Method of Moments Approach
authors: Andrijana Kuhar, Blagoja Markovski, Bojan Glushica, Vesna Arnautovski-Toseva
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Accurate estimation of the electric potential and current density in human tissues is essential in biomedical engineering. This process depends on numerical methods since analytical equations are often limited due to the complex properties of tissues. In this paper, the method of moments (MoM) is employed to solve the electric potential distribution within muscle tissue modeled as an isotropic and dispersive medium excited by a point current source placed at the surface. For verification, the numerically calculated results are compared with analytically obtained values for an identical representative system.

title: Risk-Aware Fleet Management in Public Enterprises: A Machine Learning Approach Using Web-Scraped Data
authors: Tania Calle-Jimenez, Flavio Ibujes-Calle, Janio Jadán-Guerrero, Sandra Sanchez-Gordon
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In recent years, technological advancements, particularly in artificial intelligence and machine learning, have enabled the automation of tasks once thought impractical. However, many public sector organizations continue to rely on manual processes, especially in areas like vehicle fleet management, where critical operational data remains underutilized. This study addresses that gap by proposing a machine learning model aimed at improving vehicle fleet management in public enterprises. The model focuses on classifying drivers based on their risk levels, leveraging behavioral data, individual driver characteristics, and patterns of vehicle usage to provide actionable recommendations for fleet optimization. A key innovation of this work is the integration of web scraping techniques to automatically collect and update data related to drivers, vehicles, and fleet operations. This significantly reduces the dependency on manual data entry and supports the automation of processes such as vehicle registration validity control. The proposed system also includes the development of driver risk classification models, with results visualized through an interactive dashboard and geospatial map to facilitate strategic decision-making. This approach enhances the efficiency, transparency, and data-driven decision-making capabilities of public entities managing transportation assets.

title: Automated Detection of Inattentive and Extreme Response Styles in Survey Data
authors: Donika Stoyanova, Hristo Nenov, Stefka Popova, Evgeniya Rakitina, Dimitrichka Nikolaeva, Ivo Rakitin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The study explores an automated approach to detecting problematic response patterns in survey data, focusing on behaviors indicative of insufficient respondent engagement and systematic tendencies toward extreme response styles. A total of 4,432 student surveys containing 12 questions with five-point Likert-type scales are analyzed. Based on nine behavioral indicators, the responses are classified into six categories: regular responding, three types of inattentiveness (midpoint responding, straight-lining, random responding), and two extreme response styles (negative and positive). For classification, Random Forest and XGBoost are applied, evaluated by stratified k-fold cross-validation and balanced with SMOTE. The results indicate high effectiveness of both models, with balanced accuracy exceeding 0.93. Regular responding and extreme response styles are distinguished with the highest accuracy, the inattentive categories also showed reliable classification performance. The methodology demonstrates the potential of machine learning as a tool for improving survey data quality and can be adapted to diverse research contexts.

title: Clothing Product Review System using Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (ABSA) on E-Commerce
authors: Annisaa Sri Indrawanti, Dyas Amorita Radhwa Nashirah, Hafara Firdausi, Henning Titi Ciptaningtyas, Irzal Ahmad Sabilla
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of e-commerce in Indonesia has made it difficult for consumers to determine which products are worth purchasing. To address this issue, a real-time sentiment analysis system based on Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (ABSA) was developed to extract consumer opinions based on product aspects. This system focuses on clothing product reviews with three main aspects: material, stitching, and product conformity, which are considered essential in consumer decision-making. The IndoBERTweet model is used for aspect-based sentiment analysis, achieving an F1-score of 0.88, demonstrating good performance in understanding informal and context-specific language frequently found in online reviews. Furthermore, the Simple Additive Weighting (SAW) method is employed to calculate product recommendation scores based on the combination of aspect weights and normalized differences between positive and negative reviews. The system was designed to operate automatically starting from review crawling, pre-processing, sentiment classification, scoring, up to visualization of ranked product results. The implementation results show that the system is capable of performing sentiment-based reasoning and providing transparent recommendations, thus assisting consumers in making better and more confident purchasing decisions on e-commerce platforms.

title: Evaluation of Low-Cost Water Quality Monitoring Sensors for IoT
authors: Asad Saeed Khan, Rajan Paudyal, Wolfgang Dorner, Thomas Baumann
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents the ongoing research work carried out in the project Smart-Sws (www.smart-sws.de) in the design and deployment of an internet of things (IoT) based, low-cost water quality monitoring system. The system consists of water quality sensors from two manufacturers, Atlas Scientific and DFRobot, which are deployed in the field for continuous and real-time monitoring of key water quality parameters, such as dissolved oxygen (DO), electrical conductivity (EC), potential of hydrogen (pH), and temperature. The waterproof and portable sensor setup uses Long Range Wide Area Network (LoRaWAN) technology for efficient and reliable sensor data transmission in remote areas. The data from low-cost sensors are also compared to the data from commercial multiparameter probes.

title: FSO Transmission Framework Employing F-OFDM for Error Probability and Divergence Loss Evaluation in 5G Networks
authors: Farman Ali, Yasir Ullah, Mardeni Roslee, Irfan Khan, Noorlindawaty Md Jizat, Fardin Kabir
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: This paper presents an end-to-end freespace optical (FSO) transmission framework that employs a filtered-OFDM (F-OFDM) transceiver for $\mathbf{5 G}$ optical wireless backhaul and access. The architecture integrates an optical fiber front haul with an IM/DD FSO link and models the dominant impairments: atmospheric turbulence, pointing-induced misalignment, geometric divergence, front-end nonlinearities, and cochannel interference under multichannel operation. A composite statistical channel is formulated by coupling turbulence, pointing error, and geometric coupling into the received irradiance, from which closed-form expressions for the cumulative distribution function, outage probability, and error performance are obtained. The transmitter leverages subband filtering to suppress out-of-band leakage and reduce peak-to-average power ratio, thereby improving nonlinear tolerance. The framework is validated through coordinated Op-tiSystem-MATLAB co-simulation with forward error correction, QPSK/16-QAM mapping, and FFT-based baseband processing. Performance is evaluated using bit error rate, PAPR complementary CDF, divergence loss, error vector magnitude, and outage as a function of SNR threshold across wavelengths, transmit powers, apertures, and ranges. Compared with conventional OFDM and UFMC under identical link budgets, the proposed transceiver consistently exhibits lower PAPR at fixed exceedance probability, reduced BER at practical transmit powers and ranges, and lower outage under degraded visibility, demonstrating improved robustness to turbulence/misalignment and mitigated divergence penalties for high-capacity 5G optical wireless links.

title: ProDec: Automated Prompt Decomposition
authors: Ebtesam Al Haque, Brittany Johnson
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Current AI-powered programming assistants generate large code blocks through single-shot interactions, violating established human-computer interaction principles and increasing cognitive load while reducing developer understanding and control. We present ProDec, a system that automatically decomposes complex programming prompts into structured subtasks with explicit dependencies, enabling interactive visual exploration and modification of AI reasoning steps. By transforming AIassisted programming from black-box code generation to transparent collaborative problem-solving tool, our approach aims to restore developer agency.

title: Addressing Real-World Domain Shifts in Skin Lesion Diagnosis with Metric-Based Few-Shot Learning
authors: Adeline Charlotte Augustinne, Albert Leonardi, Henry Lucky, Darren Anthony Beltham
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Skin-lesion classification models that are trained on single, well-curated datasets often under-perform when performing on samples exhibiting shifts in age, anatomical location, or skin-tone distribution. This leads to poorer performance on under-represented groups. We aim to explore the effectiveness of few-shot learning approaches to address this cross-domain problem. Four metric-based FSL meta-learners Prototypical, Matching, Siamese and Relation Networks sharing an EfficientNet-V2-S backbone are trained episodically on HAM10000, then compared with a conventional supervised baseline classifier across five domains. After selecting the best FSL model, we test it on the DDI dataset and compare its performance with benchmark metrics from the original study. Unlike prior studies, evaluation also uses imbalance-aware metrics (AUC-PR, F1, precision, and recall) instead of accuracy or AUC-ROC alone. In crossdomain evaluations on both HAM10000 and DDI datasets, the FSL models consistently outperform the conventionally trained benchmark. The Prototypical Network especially demonstrated superior balanced performance compared to all other FSL models. Performance also improved with higher shot counts, yielding more stable results across domains. Our findings suggest that FSL methods particularly those making use of holistic prototype approaches provide a more promising foundation for developing models for cross-domain tasks than the conventional supervised learning method.

title: Pseudo-Temporal Modeling with 2D CNNs for Framewise Surgical Gesture Segmentation in Robot-Assisted Surgery
authors: Daniel Haro-Mendoza, Gustavo Alejandro Castro Vazquez, Angel Leonardo Campos Carreras, Anwar Jair Diaz Urias, Victor J. Gonzalez-Villela, Manuel Cedillo-Hernandez, Rodrigo Eduardo Arevalo-Ancona
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Surgical procedures can be decomposed into elementary units (tasks, surgemes, and dexemes) that represent the building blocks of surgical performance. Segmenting gestures at this level is crucial for objective skill assessment and for understanding how simple movements are concatenated to form complete procedures, ultimately supporting the development of training and evaluation systems. In this work, we present a pseudo-temporal modeling approach for surgical gesture segmentation using a 2D ResNet-50 convolutional network trained exclusively on RGB frames. During training, each video was divided into eight equal segments, which were used to feed the network and generate gesture-level probabilities. To optimize learning, an adaptive Exponential Moving Average (EMA) mechanism was applied to stabilize weight updates and reinforce poorly performing gesture classes. At inference, complete surgical videos were processed with an overlapping sliding window of eight frames, where each frame could be evaluated multiple times in different contexts. Frame-level probabilities were averaged across overlapping windows and refined through a temporal mode filter, producing stable and coherent gesture sequences. The method was validated on the JIGSAWS dataset, which includes the Suturing, Knot Tying, and Needle Passing tasks. Results showed reliable recognition across all procedures: Suturing achieved 82.26%, Knot Tying 91.97%, and Needle Passing 79.35%. Training required approximately one hour, and inference on a complete video of 2950 frames was performed in about 45 seconds, also generating a labeled output video. By relying solely on 2D convolutions and RGB input, the approach achieves accurate and efficient segmentation with low computational cost, making it suitable for surgical training environments with limited resources and applicable in near real-time scenarios.

title: Transforming Mobile User Experience through User-Centered Design and Heuristic Evaluation
authors: M. Imam Ibrahim, Daniel Indra Wijaya, Michael Vincent, Sucianna Ghadati Rabiha
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: A digital news portal faces challenges in delivering a satisfying user experience, particularly on mobile interfaces, which serve as the primary platform for accessing information. This study aims to enhance the user experience of the news portal by employing the User-Centered Design (UCD) methodology and Heuristic Evaluation. The main issues identified include unintuitive navigation, non-responsive design, and suboptimal user experience. The research methodology combines both quantitative and qualitative approaches. Data collection was conducted using the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ) and the System Usability Scale (SUS) during the pre- and post-redesign stages. Heuristic evaluation by experts and user interviews complemented the analysis to identify user pain points and needs. A new design prototype was developed using the Figma application and tested through design iterations involving user feedback. The results showed a significant improvement in user experience. The SUS score increased from 60.75 (Grade D) to 89.25 (Grade B), while UEQ revealed enhancements in both pragmatic quality and hedonic quality. The novelty of this research lies in the comprehensive application of UCD and heuristic evaluation to create a responsive, intuitive, and user-centered interface. This study contributes to the development of mobile-based news portal designs in Indonesia, with practical implications for improving user satisfaction, loyalty, and competitiveness in digital news portals.

title: An Approach for Designing and Deploying a Hybrid Mobile Base Station Power Supply
authors: Ivelin Stoykov, Grigor Mihaylov, Teodora Hristova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: People are used to having coverage on their phones anytime and anywhere and rarely think about how much and what this convenience cost or what innovative and unconventional solutions were needed to provide the existing mobile network coverage. This paper presents the steps needed to be taken in order to design and deploy a hybrid mobile base station power supply. Conclusions are drawn about the benefits of such a power supply, in terms of fuel economy and thus reducing the carbon footprint on the environment.

title: Investigation of the Environmental Performance of a Diesel Engine Operating with Alcohol Additives
authors: Velichka Georgieva, Radostin Dimitrov, Daniel Kostadinov, Simeon Iliev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This research examines the influence of incorporating n-butanol into diesel fuel on the environmental characteristics of a diesel engine. Experiments were performed under varying load conditions to compare the performance of conventional diesel fuel (without a biocomponent) with blends containing 10% (N10), 20% (N20), and 30% (N30) n-butanol by volume. The assessment emphasized the analysis of exhaust emissions, including nitrogen oxides, oxygen concentration, unburned hydrocarbons, and smoke opacity.

title: Energy-Efficient Uplink Resource Allocation via Deep Reinforcement Learning in OFDMA Networks
authors: Arjola Biti, Olimpion Shurdi, Luan Ruci
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In uplink 5G and beyond networks, efficient resource allocation is critical to meeting diverse service demands while reducing energy consumption. Traditional optimization techniques often struggle to handle the high complexity and dynamic nature of resource block (RB) and power allocation in multi-user uplink Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access (OFDMA) systems. This paper proposes a Deep Q-Network (DQN)-based framework to optimize joint RB and discrete power allocation for uplink users. The objective is to maximize the minimum energy efficiency (EE) among all users, ensuring fairness and compliance with per-user power budget constraints. The proposed approach models the allocation problem as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) and leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to learn policies without requiring explicit channel statistics. Simulation results demonstrate that the DQN agent outperforms the baseline while maintaining user Quality of Service (QoS). DQN with constant-time inference yields practical energy savings at the base station, enabling sustained, real-time EE improvements under realistic scheduling budgets.

title: A Review of Clinical and Instrumented Data Collection in Chilren with Cerebral Palsy and its Application in Adaptive Rehabilitation Controller Design
authors: Nursultan Zhetenbayev, Gani Sergazin, Aidos Sultan, Kassymbek Ozhikenov, Yerkebulan Nurgizat, Nurtilek Sagynbayev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This review paper brings together current approaches to collecting and integrating both clinical and instrumental data in children with cerebral palsy (CP), emphasizing their use in developing and refining adaptive rehabilitation controllers. The review discusses several complementary data‑acquisition methods, including electromyography (EMG), force sensing, instrumented insoles, and inertial measurement units (IMU). Particular attention is given to how these multimodal data streams can inform the design and fine‑tuning of control systems such as the P.GEAR controller, enhancing transparency, safety, and personalization in pediatric rehabilitation. The paper outlines current limitations, highlights emerging technological solutions, and explores future perspectives in evidence‑based, data‑driven rehabilitation engineering. In addition, a CAD‑based prototype of a modular hip brace is presented as an example of how sensor‑integrated mechanical design can bridge research concepts with practical clinical applications.

title: Advancing Computer Graphics Learning through Motion Tracking and Machine Learning
authors: Elitsa Ibryamova, Galina Ivanova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study explores how Extended Reality (XR) and artificial intelligence (AI) - supported motion tracking can be integrated into computer graphics education. The approach combines lectures, hands-on exercises, and team projects so that students not only study the theory of transformations, rendering, and animation but also apply it in practice. Using XR headsets together with markerless tracking models—such as CNNs and Transformer-based pose estimators—students worked with 3D content in real time and controlled game engines through gestures. Over two academic years, experiments with undergraduate groups showed clear benefits: students were more motivated, collaborated more effectively, and developed stronger technical skills. The results indicate that XR and AI- supported motion tracking can make abstract topics easier to grasp while preparing learners for professional roles in interactive media, gaming, and virtual design.

title: Self-Supervised Embeddings and UMAP for Discovering Plant Morphological Features
authors: Alyssa Imani, Matthew Martianus Henry, Mahmud Isnan, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Plant identification is fundamental for ecological monitoring and ensuring biodiversity. Conventional identification of plant species, however, is a tedious process. Automatic plant identification using supervised learning also faces limitations in data annotation. In this study, DINOv2 selfsupervised learning is employed alongside Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP) dimensionality reduction methods to examine existing plant patterns in the PlantCLEF 2025 image dataset. DINOv2 embeddings visualization using PCA depicts Bromus Sterilis L. as a vertically elongated cluster, while the other plant embeddings are forming a tight cluster. Conversely, in UMAP visualization, the plant embeddings are more wellseparated, with a higher silhouette score, lower Davies-Bouldin Index (DBI), and higher Calinski-Harabasz Index (CHI) compared to PCA (silhouette score 0.4401 vs 0.0905; DBI 2.9388 vs 3.8379; CHI 7910.6325 vs 3640.4362). Examination of UMAP visualization also uncovers subtle patterns in the PlantCLEF 2025 images, such as phenotypic phases in Hedera helix L., photograph angle variations in Scandosorbus intermedia and Aria edulis, and even mislabeled images, particularly in Scandosorbus intermedia and Aria edulis. This study has proven that unsupervised learning, embedding generation, and visualization can help the taxonomist in classifying plants from images, without the need for annotation labels.

title: A practical framework for fault location in power distribution systems based on artificial intelligence algorithms
authors: Bladimir Gadvay-Damian, Diego Ortiz-Villalba, Jacqueline Llanos, Paul Masache-Almeida, Alex Villamarin-Jacome, Jorge Vega-Herrera
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Accurate fault location is essential for maintaining reliability in a power distribution system. Advances in smart grid technologies, artificial intelligence, and real-time monitoring systems are enhancing the efficiency of fault detection and location, resulting in faster restoration and an improved security level in power distribution systems. This paper presents a methodology for assessing various AI-based algorithms to identify critical features that enhance fault localization, thereby improving system reliability indices such as SAIDI (System Average Interruption Duration Index) and TTIK (Total Time of Interruption per Customer). The proposed methodology is implemented on the IEEE 34-node test feeder, and the results demonstrate appropriate performance in fault allocation using Random Forest and Artificial Neural Networks, utilizing relevant features identified through the proposed methodology.

title: BYTE: Integration of Narrative and Gamification for Teaching Programming in Educational Environments
authors: Dayron Rumbaut-Rangel, Franklin Parrales-Bravo, Peggy Ricaurte-Ulloa, Angel Echeverria-Guzman, Lorenzo Cevallos-Torres, Rene Cardona-Tipan
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In the current educational context, the teaching of programming faces challenges related to low motivation and difficulty of understanding by students without previous experience. This study addresses this problem by evaluating the educational video game BYTE, developed by the Bolivarian University of Ecuador, which integrates interactive narrative and gamification elements. The objective was to analyze its impact on motivation and learning of basic programming concepts. A mixed exploratory-descriptive methodology was used with 145 participants, applying a 27-question questionnaire and qualitative analysis of comments. The results show a high acceptance of the game, with no significant differences between teachers and students. Strong correlations were found between overall satisfaction and aspects such as educational usefulness and narrative design. In conclusion, BYTE is validated as an effective tool that promotes active learning, motivation and conceptual understanding, being applicable in mixed educational environments and adaptable to other disciplines.

title: Four-Phase University-Municipal Technology Transfer Framework: Validated Quadruple Helix Implementation in Developing Countries
authors: Rene Vinicio Sanchez Loja, Mariela Cerrada, Deiver Jiménez-Santín, Mauricio Villacís, Diego Cabrera, Mónica Huerta
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: University-municipal technology transfer in developing countries faces systematic barriers including inadequate financial frameworks, institutional misalignment, and limited risk management protocols. This work presents a validated four-phase collaboration methodology implementing a novel cost-distribution model where municipalities fund physical assets while universities contribute applied research resources without cash expenditure. The methodology integrates Quadruple Helix stakeholder engagement incorporating academia, government, industry, and civil society through systematic democratic validation processes. Implementation through the Universidad Politécnica Salesiana-GAD Cañar Municipality collaboration demonstrates practical application for sewage infrastructure inspection technology. The framework comprises four sequential phases: collaboration structuring with institutional agreements and risk mitigation strategies, collaborative development with multi-stakeholder engagement and technical specification, validation and user integration through controlled testing and operator feedback, and technology transfer with sustainability protocols. Results validate methodology effectiveness through complete milestone achievement within established timelines and budget parameters. The approach addresses critical gaps in developing country contexts by eliminating university cash flow requirements while ensuring municipal asset ownership and comprehensive stakeholder coordination. The methodology provides replicable protocols for similar university-municipal partnerships requiring technological solutions for essential infrastructure challenges in resource-constrained Latin American environments.

title: Performance Evaluation of CubeSat Nanosatellite using LoRa in Low Earth Orbit
authors: Badie Uddin, Lalu Delsi Samsumar, Puput Dani Prasetyo Adi, Henri Septanto, Petrus Dwi Ananto Pamungkas, Anik Hanifatul Azizah
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: LoRa Communication Systems face significant challenges in maintaining Quality of Services (QoS) when LoRaWAN networks must use Nano Cube Satellites that have limited resources and operate in Low Earth Orbit (LEO). This is due to dynamic link conditions, the occurrence of Doppler effects, and also power limitations. This research conducts a specific evaluation of the Non-Terrestrial Network (NTN) network operating robustly. And systematically this research analyzes the relationship between satellite elevation angles and measurements of Receive Signal Strength (RSSI) indicators, Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR), and Packet Error Rate (PER). And also combine the math model for Lik Budget calculation and Orbit propagation. The results of the simulation show RSSI values of $\mathbf{- 1 0 5 ~ d B m}$, SNR of $\mathbf{+ 8 ~ d B}$, and PER of $\mathbf{0. 5 \%}$. These represent critical reference points for reliable data transmission and reception. The findings also provide quantitative guidance for CubeSat constellation design as well as ground station planning that enables LoRa networks to work efficiently.

title: Cosine Similarity-Based Spectral Graph Clustering of ArchiMate Relationships and Metadata for Information System Consolidation
authors: Jovita Tandiana, Samuel Ady Sanjaya
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Realizing that technology keeps changing every day must be terrifying for organizations that want to stay afloat. In the midst of digital transformation, there is one concept standing tall that offers assistance for companies to adapt by creating an Enterprise Architecture (EA). EA is a concept that bridges gaps between business and technology that ensures alignment. One of the main problems during EA drawing is redundancy. When the $\mathbf{E A}$ drawing contains redundancies, it fosters a flawed design destined for poor decision-making. To avoid facing such problems, this research proposes using a model that combines similarity analysis and clustering to help identify relations and its components’ similarities. By using ArchiMate notation relations and its metadata, this study intends to develop a similarity-based algorithm for consolidation recommendation. This research found that using cosine similarity and spectral clustering generated adequate quality clusters with a Silhouette Score of 0.736, a DaviesBouldin Index of 1.061, and an Average Similarity Score of 0.881. Not only that, these combined models managed to reduce $63.28 \%$ of the total initial redundancy. In the end, this study highlights that information system consolidation can be based on cosine similarity and spectral clustering techniques, with notes to explore other similarity analysis metrics for comparison and for practitioners to verify the results.

title: Technical and Economic Analysis of a Photovoltaic Power Plant for a Wastewater Treatment Plant using PVsyst
authors: Cosmin Radu, Corina Boncescu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Considering the provisions of the European Green Deal, as well as Romania's strategic energy objectives, the need to produce green energy represents one of the fundamental objectives of the European energy strategy. This article presents the technical and economic characteristics of a photovoltaic plant with an installed capacity of 4.9 MW for a wastewater treatment plant in Constanta, Romania. For the analysis of the system's performance, the PVsyst software was used. The "single diode" model was chosen for the electrical diagram of the system. Following the modelling and simulations, a requirement of 11888 photovoltaic panels, 10881 storage batteries, and a control system were obtained. The results showed that the obtained system fully covers the necessary energy consumption and the investment payback period of 2.7 years.

title: IMU/UWB Integrated Navigation Based on Nonlinear Error State Definitions
authors: Xiang Yu, Jingqiang Bao, Hongde Qin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: For inertial measurement unit (IMU)/ ultra- wideband (UWB) integrated navigation systems, constructing the dynamics model based on additive errors is a common approach. However, the dependence of the error dynamics on the estimated navigation and bias states requires accurate initial state estimation, which may limit system application. To mitigate this limitation, several geometric navigation approaches have been proposed to decouple error dynamics from state estimation by introducing nonlinear error definitions. In this study, we firstly apply several nonlinear error representations, including two-frame group left- and right-invariant errors as well as tangent group errors to IMU/UWB integrated navigation to develop multiple distinct schemes. Furthermore, a novel left-invariant nonlinear error definition is proposed, wherein the error evolution of the navigation state achieves independent of navigation and bias estimation. The associated error dynamics and the integration scheme for the IMU/UWB-based navigation system are derived. The proposed methods are validated by using simulation data and a public dataset, demonstrating improved accuracy and reliability compared with the state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Synthesis Design of Linear-to-Circular Polarization Converter Based on Bandpass Filter Coupling Matrix Theory
authors: Kai-Ran Xiang, Fu-Chang Chen, Qing-Xin Chu, Quan Xue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: The precise configuration of the axial ratio bandwidth is usually hindered by the structural limitations of linear-to-circular polarization (LP-to-CP) conversion. To overcome this challenge, this article proposes a synthesis method for an LP-to-CP converter based on the filter coupling matrix theory. This method can calculate the topological parameters for arbitrary AR bandwidths using the coupling matrix with a self-coupling offset. Consequently, the design of a converter in accordance with these topological parameters facilitates the realization of the corresponding AR bandwidth. To validate the proposed synthesis design, an LP-to-CP converter based on a fourth-order Chebyshev topology was designed, which can achieve different axial ratio bandwidths. The designed polarization converter is a planar structure consisting of a multilayer dielectric substrate. To obtain radiation beam control capabilities, an LP-to-CP converter with 1-bit phase modulation can be achieved by changing the coupling characteristics in the topology. The designed LP-to-CP converter, when combined with a horn antenna to form a transmitarray, is used to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method. The experimental results indicate that the fabricated transmitarray based on the designed LP-to-CP converter achieves an AR bandwidth of 23.7–28 GHz and maximum gains of 21.66 dBic under RHCP radiation characteristics. The experimental results are in agreement with the synthesis results and the simulated results.

title: SSAA: Secure Semi-Asynchronous Aggregation for Decentralized Federated Learning on Heterogeneous Devices
authors: Ling Li, Cheng Guo, Xinyu Tang, Kim-Kwang Raymond Choo, Yining Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Decentralized federated learning (DFL) has been widely used in edge computing and Internet of Things (IoT) settings with many devices. However, the heterogeneity of devices (e.g., varying computational capacity, stability, security requirements) can impact the performance of DFL applications. Our proposed SSAA, a secure aggregation scheme for DFL on heterogeneous devices, presented in this paper is designed to improve the efficiency of DFL while preserving privacy. Specifically, SSAA accelerates aggregation by synchronously coupling aggregation device-set formation with aggregation computation, and can cope with device availability and performance variability to maintain stable and efficient aggregation. By extending homomorphic encryption to support cross-round ciphertext continuity, SSAA enables reliable and secure decryption under large-scale dropouts in the original aggregation set, making it practical for dynamic DFL environments. In addition, we prove that SSAA is semi-honestly secure and resistant to device collusion attacks – fundamental security requirements for applications involving heterogeneous devices. We also implement SSAA and comprehensively evaluate its performance to demonstrate its practicability.

authors: Mimisha M Menakath
publish: N/A
abstract: Ocean exploration using acoustical 3-D imaging is gaining popularity as it provides information about the 3-D geometry of the targets even under mild turbid conditions. A major challenge in underwater 3-D imaging is the high cost of the planar arrays and the computational complexity of the image reconstruction algorithms. In this work, we introduce the use of a uniform rectangle array placed at the edges of a uniform planar array for underwater 3-D imaging. During reconstruction, an orthogonal combination of two linear arrays which forms an L-shape is used to perform two independent and parallel 2-D delay and sum beamforming and the 3-D image is reconstructed using the product of the resulting beams. Each quadrant in the imaging slice is reconstructed in parallel using different L-shaped arrays. This quadrant-based time domain receive beamforming focuses on achieving relatively low computational complexity for real-time 3-D imaging in underwater environments. The proposed method with 47 hydrophones has reduced the main lobe width by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{2}^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula> with 6 dB increase in the peak side lobe level when compared to the conventional delay and sum beamforming using a uniform planar array of 576 elements. Although there is an increase in the side lobe level, the asymmetric beam pattern of the proposed L array and the quadrant-based beamforming restrict the side lobes within a quadrant. The proposed method achieves a reduction in computation time by a factor of 97 for 3-D imaging compared to the conventional method, while maintaining acceptable image quality. For qualitative analysis, the 3-D images of different underwater targets have been reconstructed and compared in simulation and experiment.

title: Tamper-Proof Quantum Communication Network Enhanced by Machine Learning
authors: Yuan-Bin Cheng, Ze-Zhou Sun, Pei-Jie Chang, Fei-Hao Zhang, Gui-Lu Long
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Quantum cryptography provides a feasible approach to achieving information-theoretic security in point-to-point communication. In contrast to point-to-point protocols, end-to-end secure quantum communication is particularly promising for large-scale quantum networks. Here, we propose a scheme for end-to-end secure communication with private message authentication. For practical purposes, we demonstrate the scheme in a quantum communication network with optical fibers or free-space links that integrate secure repeaters. Furthermore, we present a route proposal model for routing private messages in a quantum network based on the scheme. As messages are routed through a network, malicious nodes may tamper with the messages passing through them with some probability. Based on authentication results, we use machine learning methods to detect malicious nodes, including supervised and unsupervised algorithms. The simulation results in specific networks show that our methods can effectively detect malicious nodes under different tamper probabilities.

title: TERM Model: Tensor Ring Mixture Model for Density Estimation_supp1-3648288.pdf
authors: Yipeng Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: Probabilistic modeling is a core challenge in statistical machine learning. Tensor-based probabilistic graph methods address interpretability and stability concerns encountered in neural network approaches and allow tractable inference (e.g., marginal inference and conditional inference). In this paper, we introduce tensor ring decomposition for density estimation, which reduces the number of permutation candidates compared to existing methods, while simultaneously enhancing expressive power and maintaining tractable inference. Different non-negative strategies for density function results in two variants: Born TRDE offers simpler inference and sampling but with slightly lower accuracy, while Energy TRDE, though more complex, achieves superior performance. Furthermore, a mixture model that incorporates multiple permutation candidates with adaptive weights is designed, resulting in increased expressive flexibility and comprehensiveness. Unlike existing methods that focus on finding a single optimal permutation, our approach, inspired by ensemble learning, demonstrates that combining multiple suboptimal permutations can yield superior results. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach excels in estimating probability density functions and sampling, capturing intricate details with competitive or superior performance compared to existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) tractable density methods.

title: Coherent Transceivers Using SOA–Comb Architectures for Short-Reach Links Beyond 1 Tb/s
authors: Arman Safarnejadian, Wei Shi, Leslie A. Rusch, Ming Zeng
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: We investigate power-efficient multi-wavelength coherent transceivers for short-reach optical interconnects targeting 1.2 Tb/s throughput. A single optical frequency comb can be used for both data modulation and distributed local oscillators. This comb-assisted architecture can be combined with integrated semiconductor optical amplifiers (SOAs) and silicon photonic traveling-wave Mach-Zehnder modulators (TW-MZMs). We analyze two configurations for this combination, placing the SOAs either before or after the modulators. Our results show that positioning SOAs after the modulators enhances overall power efficiency, while longer (4 mm) modulators provide superior power handling due to lower total loss while providing a sufficient bandwidth. Furthermore, by adjusting the power-splitting ratio between the data carrier and the distributed local oscillator, the minimum achievable bit error rate (BER) can be tuned in the post-modulation SOA configuration. These findings offer design insights for optimizing coherent multi-wavelength transceivers based on silicon photonics for next-generation intra-datacenter links.

title: Radar Bistatic Technique for Accurate Characterization of Small Antenna Radiation Patterns
authors: H. Hafdallah Ouslimani, P. Grassin, K. Claver
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: An original method based on the radar bistatic technique (RBTech) is proposed to characterize key antenna parameters, with emphasis on radiation patterns. The bistatic configuration comprises two standard transmit/receive antennas, and the antenna under test. While the transmitting Tx antenna remains fixed, in front of the target (at normal incidence), the receiving Rx antenna rotates around with a bistatic angle. Rx measures the diffracted wave (i.e. backscattered field) as a function of the frequency, the wave polarization and the bistatic angle, for different terminal impedance; namely short-circuit, open circuit, and matched load. First, the antenna mode corresponding to the reradiated wave is recovered in the time domain by removing the structural mode. The structural mode is obtained by measuring the backscattered wave when the antenna is well matched, i.e., with a near-zero reflection coefficient. Second, time-gating and Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) processing are applied to extract the frequency spectrum of the recovered reradiated waves from the time-domain antenna-mode signal. By compiling these results as a function of the bistatic angle, the radiation pattern can be reconstructed in any cut-plane for both co-and cross-polarizations. Experimental measurements conducted in an anechoic chamber, based on an accurate wideband calibration procedure, along with full-wave simulations using the radar bistatic technique, were performed on a triband omnidirectional antenna and patch arrays. Very good agreement was observed between the reconstructed patterns and those obtained via conventional simulation and measurement methods. The developed radar bistatic technique demonstrates accuracy, potential for non-invasive operation, and remote applicability.

title: Ka-Dual-Band Oblique-Incidence Multi-Layer Metasurface for Linear to Circular Polarization Conversion
authors: H. Hafdallah Ouslimani, G. Collignon, V. Mallepeyre
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A dual-band linear-to-circular polarization converter is presented for Ka-band mobile satellite communication antennas operating under variable incidence. The converter operates in transmission mode, providing left-hand circular polarization (LHCP) at 20 GHz for signal reception and right-hand circular polarization (RHCP) at 30 GHz for signal transmission (or vice versa with a mechanical rotation of 90∘). The polarizer consists of three anisotropic metasurfaces separated by two identical dielectric layers, with low-loss impedance transformers on both sides to improve matching and maintain stable performance up to 60∘ incidence. The total thickness of the structure is 8.4 mm. Each metasurface unit cell integrates two distinct metallic inclusions: an electric-LC (ELC) split-ring resonator (SRR) and a meander-line element. The meander-line elements are oriented at 45∘ with respect to the incident linearly polarized electric field. The proposed methodology focuses on optimizing unit cells for oblique incidence, where mode coupling must be considered. The design targets angle-stable susceptances that enable linear-to-circular polarization conversion over two wide frequency bands. Prototypes are fabricated and experimentally characterized through S-parameter measurements over the 18–32 GHz frequency range. Measurement results exhibit excellent agreement with full-wave simulations. The polarizer achieves near-unity transmittance, high polarization conversion efficiency, insertion loss below 2 dB, and an axial ratio below 3 dB over bandwidths exceeding 2 GHz–namely, 19–21 GHz and 29–31 GHz. Furthermore, the structure maintains robust angular stability for incidence angles ranging from 0∘ to 60∘. These results demonstrate the designs suitability for a broad range of commercial and military applications.
