title: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS) Design for 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi Band
authors: Mohammad Ib. Al-Asaslih, Yanal S. Faouri, Hamza A. AbuHamad
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS) has recently been nominated as a key technology and promising solution to enhance 6G wireless networks in the future. One major problem that RIS can mitigate is penetration loss, where the wave is susceptible to losing most of its power while passing through obstacles, especially at high frequencies. RIS can overcome this problem by defining alternative paths for waves with minimal losses by manipulating the electrical properties of its elements, thereby reshaping the pattern of the reflected beam. Moreover, RIS consumes less energy than traditional solutions such as relays and repeaters, which makes it preferable to 6G visions of green solutions. Therefore, this study proposes a design for an RIS array operating in the 2.4 GHz WiFi band as a proof of concept of showing the ability of RIS to enhance network performance in 6G at higher frequencies, and as a suggested practical design to improve users’ experience and satisfy their needs in the 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi band. The proposed single element exhibits a stable phase difference of 180° ± 20° and a loss of less than 2 dB. A 10 × 5 array showed gain improvement at different frequencies under different element configurations.

title: Automation System for Managing Innovation Obsolescence for SME
authors: Petya D. Georgieva, Kostadin Markov, Iliyan Vasilev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper introduces a hybrid intelligence-led web-based Automation system that combines structured human inputs with machine learning–based analysis- to support SME in monitoring and managing innovation obsolescence. The system captures signals of obsolescence across four domains: corporate R&D, startup analysis, policy and foresight, and product lifecycle management. Responses are analyzed through a Random Forest- based framework that identifies key drivers of risk and classifies results into risk bands (low, moderate, high, critical). These results are dynamically linked to tailored managerial strategies, enabling firms to translate diagnostic outcomes into targeted interventions. Stakeholder feedback from SME (managers, traders, and R&D staff) highlights both the tool’s advantages- structured diagnosis, accessibility, actionability- and its limitations, including reliance on self-reported data and the need for sector-specific customization. By integrating human judgment with artificial intelligence, the study contributes a practical and theoretically grounded framework for managing innovation obsolescence and offers insights for firms seeking resilience in dynamic technological environments.

title: Comparative Study between Primary Electrical Energy Storage Devices
authors: Sorin Sintea, Bogdan Hnatiuc, Cornel Panait, Cătălin Pomazan, Mihaela Hnatiuc
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In recent years, the development of storage capacities based on batteries or supercapacitors has gained particular attention in close connection with the use of green energy sources. These storage capacities are widely used in the construction of Internet of Things systems, energy production systems or energy storage systems. There is also an increasing concern for the management and reinsertion of used batteries. This paper proposes a comparative study between 3 elementary energy storage systems: a Li - Ion battery, a sodium battery and a supercapacitor. The aim of this paper is to provide us with an image of how we will be able to use one of the three storage solutions depending on the storage application. The three were subjected to a complete charge - discharge cycle, with monitoring of the corresponding specific parameters: voltage, current, power / energy, as evolution over time. The batteries were similarly charged from a universal charger, and the supercapacitor from a stabilized voltage source with the possibility of voltage regulation. The discharge cycle used a linear load corresponding to a normal use regime of these systems.

title: Benchmarking and Evaluation Framework for Large Language Models in Education
authors: Kalina Nikiforova-Ilieva, Tsvetozar Georgiev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper examines the functional differences and optimal implementation of leading major language models with a focus on their functional capabilities, and performance in the context of learning and analytics tasks. In addition, a relatively new but gaining local popularity language model specialized in Bulgarian is also addressed. Large Language Models (LLMs) have significantly transformed the field of natural language processing, bringing about major changes in various sectors, especially in education and data analytics. Models which can generate human-like text have evolved into multimodal systems that process different types of data like text, images and code. Some models stand out for their personalized learning and learning content creation capabilities, while others are strong in summarizing long and complex texts or in document processing and analytical tasks, and they offer different styles of interaction. The model specialized in Bulgarian language performs more effectively in localized educational tasks. The results show that DeepSeek achieves the highest content accuracy, ChatGPT demonstrates the strongest pedagogical value, and BgGPT excels in localized educational tasks in Bulgarian.

title: ParticipantGuide: Promoting Transparency in Human-Centric User Studies
authors: Minhyuk Ko, Shawal Khalid, Chris Brown
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Human subjects research is fundamental to advancing human-computer interaction (HCI), as it helps researchers understand user behaviors, needs, and experiences to enhance the design of software products [3]. However, conducting such human-centric studies is often hindered by challenges in participant recruitment, including inefficiencies in finding eligible participants and administrative burdens [1]. Participants are hindered from joining research studies due to logistical, eligibility, communication, or personal barriers that make participation impractical, inaccessible, or unappealing. These barriers not only slow down research progress, but also limit the diversity and representativeness of study participants. To address these issues, we propose ParticipantGuide-a structured labelbased approach to enhance participant recruitment through providing key and interpretable information to potential participants. We discuss existing work, present a preliminary design, and provide implications for future research.

title: Diagnosis of User Experience (UX) and Accessibility in Traditional Recruitment Tools: Foundations for the Future Implementation of Gamified Processes
authors: Andrés Caicedo-López, Paulina Guerra-Guerra Psicología
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Traditional personnel selection processes, based on printed tests and face-to-face interviews, present increasing challenges in terms of user experience (UX), usability, and accessibility. Elements such as candidate satisfaction, the learning curve required to understand and complete the processes, and the levels of frustration detected negatively impact fairness and effectiveness in skills assessment. This analysis represents the initial phase of a broader research project, whose ultimate goal is to develop gamified solutions grounded in a user-centered approach. In this initial stage, a qualitative study was conducted through in-depth interviews with six human resources specialists from different organizations, with the aim of identifying the limitations of conventional procedures and examining the perception of gamification as an improvement strategy. The findings indicate that conventional procedures result in a fragmented and unsatisfactory experience, imposing a high cognitive and emotional load on candidates. The specialists highlight persistent obstacles regarding clarity of instructions, limited feedback, unequal accessibility, and the lack of adaptability to diverse profiles. Likewise, they acknowledge the potential of game-based platforms to enhance motivation, reduce frustration, and provide more inclusive experiences. These findings underpin the design of a future quasi-experimental phase that will evaluate, using metrics such as the System Usability Scale (SUS), the comparative effectiveness of traditional versus gamified tools in selection processes.

title: Hybrid Approach for Load Forecasting and Scenario Generation Using SVR and Analog Method
authors: Julio Cuenca Tinitana, Jheremy Quizhpe, Jorge Carrión González, José Benavides Maldonado, Bryan Jiménez Cueva, Jonathan González Espinosa
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents a hybrid approach for modeling demand-side uncertainty in power systems and its application to stochastic economic dispatch. The proposed strategy combines Support Vector Regression (SVR) for short-term load forecasting with analog-based scenario generation. The generated scenario sets effectively capture temporal patterns and variability in load while preserving computational tractability. Numerical evaluations performed on a modified IEEE $\mathbf{4}$-bus system demonstrate that the performance of the stochastic approach is superior to that of the deterministic model, achieving a 6.21% reduction in total operating cost when evaluated with real load data. The results highlight the advantages of incorporating load scenarios in dispatch models, improving operational efficiency and resilience under uncertainty.

title: Cloud-Based Network Monitoring System with Zabbix and WireGuard VPN for Remote SMEs
authors: Fernando Caicedo-Altamirano, Patricio Villacrés-Cevallos, Silvia Alpusig-Cuichan, Alex Ramos-Jinez, Omar Guerra-Pazo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The growing dependence on distributed networks in SMEs poses critical challenges in remote monitoring and service continuity. Existing commercial solutions are costly and difficult t o i ntegrate, l imiting e arly f ault d etection in dispersed corporate environments. This study presents an innovative cloud monitoring architecture that combines Zabbix with WireGuard VPN (Virtual Private Network) tunnels to securely monitor remote corporate networks. Deployed on AWS (Amazon Web Services) EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) with Ubuntu 22.04 LTS, the solution uses SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) to collect metrics on CPU, interface traffic, a nd s torage, while MikroTik routers establish encrypted VPN tunnels, ensuring data integrity and confidentiality. T he i mplementation demonstrated stable performance: CPU between $\mathbf{1 0 - 3 0 \%}$, available memory of $297-408 \mathrm{MB}$, and constant lossless VPN traffic, w ith projected throughput of $\mathbf{5 0 0 ~ k b p s}$ to $\mathbf{1 0 ~ M b p s}$ depending on load. Compared to traditional manual methods, this approach reduced incident detection time thanks to automated alerts via Telegram (the reduction in incident detection times with Telegram reduces latency compared to Gmail by an average of $\mathbf{8 5 - 9 0 \%}$) and improved data visibility thru Zabbix. This architecture offers a secure, costeffective, and scalable solution for telecommunications service providers and SMEs, providing a replicable model of reliable, efficient, and easily implementable remote monitoring in critical networks.

title: Online Professional Development for Southeast Asia Teachers Focusing on Computational Thinking
authors: Burin Asavapibhop, Jason McKenna, Yuhan Lin, Andy Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: This poster evaluated a four-month online professional development program helping seven Southeast Asian teachers from Lao PDR, Thailand, Cambodia and Indonesia embed Computational Thinking (CT) and Universal Design for Learning (UDL) into their lesson plans. Through structured sessions and iterative planning cycles, participants co-created, implemented and revised lessons. Qualitative analysis of their plans, reflections and community discussions showed marked growth: early drafts featured only basic CT and UDL elements, whereas later versions incorporated advanced CT skills (decomposition, data analysis, pseudocoding) and UDL strategies (multiple means of engagement, representation and expression). These results suggest that reflective, collaborative professional development (PD) can boost teachers’ competence and confidence in delivering inclusive, computation-rich instruction.

title: Bringing Probabilistic Reasoning to the IDE
authors: Leo St. Amour, Eli Tilevich
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Exceptional behavior can be harmful to software quality and robustness. Like most modern programming languages, Java offers built-in mechanisms for expressing and handling exceptions. However, despite their languageintegrated design, exception handlers are easy to misuse. Researchers have identified exception-handling anti-patternsrecurring poor coding practices that threaten software quality. One of the most prevalent exception-handling anti-patterns-over-catching-occurs when a handler catches overly broad exception types, potentially obscuring the root cause of a failure. Integrated development environments (IDEs) play a critical role in helping developers identify and address software quality issues. Yet, existing tools can produce an overwhelming number of results, contributing to cognitive overload. To address this problem, we incorporate probabilistic reasoning into IDE-based exception-handling analysis. Exception Shipping & Handling (ESH), our prototype implementation, allows the IDE to present prioritized instances of the over-catch anti-patterns based on their likelihood of being problematic. We evaluate ESH through a user study focused on its usability for helping developers assess over-catching handlers. Our results show that participants found ESH intuitive and provide useful insights into how to integrate probabilistic reasoning into an IDE. Specifically, our study highlights the need for transparency and contextualized UI elements.

title: SnapClass: An AI-Enhanced Classroom Management System for Block-Based Programming
authors: Bahare Riahi, Xiaoyi Tian, Ally Limke, Viktoriia Storozhevykh, Veronica Cateté, Tiffany Barnes, Nicholas Lytle, Khushbu Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Block-Based Programming (BBP) platforms, such as Snap!, have become increasingly prominent in $\mathrm{K}-12$ computer science education due to their ability to simplify programming concepts and foster computational thinking from an early age. While these platforms engage students through visual and gamified interfaces, teachers often face challenges in using them effectively and finding all the necessary features for classroom management. To address these challenges, we introduce SnapClass, a classroom management system integrated within the Snap! programming environment. SnapClass was iteratively developed drawing on established research about the pedagogical and logistical challenges teachers encounter in computing classrooms. Specifically, SnapClass allows educators to create and customize block-based coding assignments based on student skill levels, implement rubric-based auto-grading, and access student code history and recovery features. It also supports monitoring student engagement and idle time, and includes a help dashboard with a “raise hand” feature to assist students in real time. This paper describes the design and key features of SnapClass those are developed and those are under progress.

title: E-Learning Education Modules with Smart Content Delivery
authors: Maria Roussi, Aggeliki Solomanidou, Dimitrios Marmanis, Kalliopi Kravari, Michail Chalaris, Kalliopi Ladomenou, Anna Thysiadou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The conditions of the provided education gradually create inequalities concerning the educational level of the students, which soon create insurmountable difficulties and gradually accumulate the problem. The goal of the present paper is to respond to the need of students who have increased skills and competencies to study autonomously and independently a new e-learning platform (Moodle). The aim of the study was to investigate the use of a computational asynchronous distance learning environment and the correlation between the usage of developed practices and the newly acquired knowledge. An attempt was made to create a complete Moodle course guide without the requirement of any technical pre-existing knowledge. This paper also presents the results of the implemented survey on the feasibility and expediency of using e-learning. The present research validates that the use of educational software in combination with the help of computational teaching and learning contributes significantly to the increase of the effectiveness of education.

title: Detection and Classification of Defects in Photovoltaic Cells from Electroluminescence using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Cristian Tejada-Ardon, Mario Hernandez-Escoto, Hector Barrera-Valencia, Yakdiel Rodriguez-Gallo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The efficiency and durability of photovoltaic modules can be compromised by structural and electrical defects that are difficult to detect through visual inspection. This study proposes an artificial intelligence-based approach for the identification and classification of anomalies in solar cells through electroluminescence images. Machine learning algorithms are implemented, including Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), with image preprocessing techniques such as infrared filters and CLAHE to enhance fault visibility, achieving results of 99.96% for cell type classification using VGG19 and 87.29% for cell condition using WideResnet-50-2, thus it can be concluded that satisfactory results were obtained. This automated system has the potential to optimize the maintenance of photovoltaic plants, increasing the reliability and energy efficiency of solar modules.

title: Path Loss Planning for 5G Networks Applied in Indonesia using the Close-in Model
authors: Achmad Ubaidillah, Muttaqin Hardiwansyah, Puteri Nurul Ma’Rifah, Achmad Zain Nur, Diana Rahmawati, Rahmad Fajar Sidik
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The implementation of $\mathbf{5 G}$ networks in Indonesia is being developed by several major operators, including Telkomsel, Indosat Ooredoo Hutchison, and XL Axiata. The frequency spectrum being developed covers low (700 MHz), mid-band (2.3 GHz and 3.5 GHz), and high ($26 \mathrm{GHz} / \mathrm{mmWave}$). This study aims to evaluate and plan 5 G network path loss using the Close-In (CI) model, chosen because it can realistically evaluate path loss, taking into account distance and operational frequency. The novelty of this study is the comparison of the CI model with empirical data and field measurements of already implemented 5G networks. This research provides a technical foundation for operators in evaluating path loss and serves as a reference in $\mathbf{5 G}$ infrastructure planning, particularly regarding the efficient utilization of the mmWave spectrum. The results show that the CI model is effective in evaluating 5 G network implementation, particularly regarding path loss and shadow fading. The highest path loss values occurred at mmWave (26 GHz), at 21.19 dB LOS and 129.85 dB NLOS. The high values were influenced by scattering, absorption, and low signal penetration at high frequencies. Furthermore, the measured results were higher than the theoretical calculations, particularly under NLOS conditions, due to the complexity of physical barriers.

title: Study of the 30-bus System with Different Degrees of Penetration of Distributed Energy Sources
authors: Todor Todorov, Ivaylo Stoyanov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper studies the impact of distributed energy resources (DERs) penetration on the performance of the standard IEEE 30-bus test network. Power-flow simulations were performed in ETAP 19.0 for DER penetration levels of 10%, 20%, and 30%, applied under two alternative allocation strategies: (1) proportional DER allocation based on the local bus load, and (2) uniform DER allocation based on the average load of the system. The study evaluates the resulting active and reactive power losses, bus loading, branch loading, and system-level power factor. The simulation results demonstrate that DER integration reduces active power losses by up to 53.1% and reactive power losses by up to 49.5%, with corresponding improvements in the system power factor from the baseline value of 91.35% to 94.38% (Scenario 1 at 30% penetration) and 94.51% (Scenario 2 at 30% penetration). Branch-wise and bus-wise analyses further reveal how DER penetration redistributes flows across the network, alleviates loading on critical elements and enhancing overall operational efficiency. The power-flow analysis performed showed that after optimizing the location and power of DERs, the power factor increases from 91.35% (for the baseline) to 94.38% for Scenario 1 with 30%DERs and 94.51% for Scenario 2 with 30% DERs.

title: Synergizing LLMs, Vibes, and Well-Being in Software Development
authors: Fairuz Nawer Meem
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: There is a growing trend of using general-purpose large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT, in software development workflows, often outside traditional IDEs or engineering practices. One emerging phenomenon is vibe coding, which refers to a fluid, intuitive, and emotionally attuned development style shaped by conversational AI tools, music, mood, and ambient factors. I propose research that investigates why software practitioners are drawn to general-purpose LLMs and how these tools fit into and enhance vibe coding experiences. In particular, I aim to understand how these environments affect productivity and well-being, especially for software practitioners with mental health conditions (e.g., ADHD, anxiety, depression). By examining both the technical and psychological aspects of general-purpose LLM use, including but not limited to vibe coding, I intend to facilitate the development of improved tools, settings, and practices that promote a more balanced and adaptable approach to LLM-driven software development.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Trajectory and Handover Optimization in UAV-Assisted 6G HetNets
authors: Yasir Ullah, Mardeni Roslee, Farman Ali, Mohd Azmi Ismail, Idris Olalekan Adeoye, Irfan Khan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: UAV-assisted heterogeneous networks (HetNets) in urban environments face significant challenges in optimizing trajectory, rate, and handover (HO) decisions under dense mobility and interference conditions. Existing approaches often fail to jointly address these factors, leading to inefficient resource allocation, frequent HO failures, and degraded user experience. This paper presents a multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework that enables cooperative UAV agents to optimize trajectory planning, network rate, and HO performance simultaneously. The model integrates signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR), achievable rate, and HO-related parameters into the probability of identification (POI), ensuring accurate user association and sustained connectivity. A reward function is designed to balance rate maximization, HO frequency reduction, and trajectory efficiency, guiding agents toward optimal network performance. Simulation results, validated with ray tracing (RT) in realistic urban scenarios and benchmarked against 3GPP and NYM models, demonstrate that the proposed MARL framework achieves higher rate, lower HO failures, improved POI, and enhanced energy efficiency in complex urban HetNets.

title: Multivariate modeling and value-based segmentation: application to pro-poverty tourism
authors: Harry Vite-Cevallos, Omar Ruiz-Barzola, Purificación Galindo-Villardón, Margarita Palma Samaniego
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study applies advanced multivariate statistical techniques to analyze the intention to engage in ProPoor Tourism (PPT) activities, considering tourists’ axiological and behavioral orientations. A total of 400 participants were surveyed using validated instruments with internal consistency above 0.80, based on the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) and the Value-Belief-Norm (VBN) model. The use of GH-Biplot, CoInertia Analysis (COIA), K-means clustering, and STATICO made it possible to identify latent structures, segment profiles, and model multi-block trajectories. The results revealed that $60.8 \%$ of respondents exhibited a biospheric orientation, strongly associated with financial willingness toward PPT (coinertia coefficient $=0.227; \mathrm{p}\lt 0.01$); 52% showed an altruistic orientation, more strongly linked to non-financial participation, while $27.7 \%$ were classified under egoistic profiles, characterized by indifference toward PPT. Cluster validation through the silhouette index confirmed their internal consistency. This research contributes to the understanding of the axiological determinants of responsible tourist behavior and provides practical implications for the design of social marketing strategies and inclusive, sustainable public policies.

title: Machine Learning Approaches for Predicting Students’ Intentions to Pursue Higher Education: Insights from Multidimensional Survey Data
authors: Dimitrichka Nikolaeva, Diyan Dinev, Daniela Petrova, Maya Todorova, Ivo Rakitin, Evgenia Rakitina
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study investigates the use of machine learning techniques to predict students’ intentions to pursue higher education, based on multidimensional survey data collected from 507 students between 2017 and 2024. The dataset includes variables on educational background, personal attitudes, institutional perceptions, and career expectations. Both classical models (Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Support Vector Machines) and deep learning approaches (LSTM) were employed, alongside ensemble methods such as Voting, Stacking, LightGBM, and CatBoost. Results show that ensemble classifiers, particularly the Voting model, achieved the highest predictive performance, with an accuracy of up to 78% and an ROC AUC of 0.87. Feature importance analysis revealed that career expectations, academic engagement, and perceptions of program quality are the strongest predictors of continuance intentions. The findings provide valuable insights for universities and policymakers, offering evidence-based recommendations to support students’ progression into advanced degrees.

title: Predicting Water Inflows for Power System Operation under Climate Variability: Comparing Long- and Short-Term Data Series via LSTM Networks
authors: Luis Vega-Chuquizan, Alex Villamarín-Jácome, Willian Jiménez-De La Vega, Danny Espín-Sarzosa, Diego Ortiz-Villalba, Jorge Vega-Herrera
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Water inflow is a critical variable for hydropower operation and planning, strongly influenced by climate variability. This work evaluates the impact of using historical versus recent data for inflow prediction under changing hydrological conditions. A long short-term memory (LSTM) neural network was applied to forecast daily river flows using climatic and hydrological time series from the Paute River basin in Ecuador. Two datasets were used for training: a short-term series and a long-term series. Predictions were generated for 2024, a year marked by severe droughts and energy shortages, and used to estimate annual hydropower generation. Results show that the short-term dataset closely matches actual generation ($0.33 \%$ error), while the long-term dataset significantly overestimates output ($+10.13 \%$). Although long records are generally assumed to improve model robustness, they may introduce outdated patterns due to environmental changes such as climate variability or other external influences. Findings highlight the importance of incorporating up-to-date climate signals to strengthen hydropower prediction frameworks and operational reliability.

title: LoRaWAN in the Internet of Things: A Systematic Review of Network Architecture, Security, Business Models, and Real-World Deployments
authors: Santiago Acurio-Maldonado, Erwin J. Sacoto-Cabrera, Edisson Meneses, Mónica Karel Huerta
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Long Range Wide Area Network (LoRaWAN) technology has emerged as a key solution in the Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem due to its energy efficiency, wide reach, and low deployment cost. This paper presents a systematic literature review (SLR) based on Kitchenham’s guidelines and aims to analyze the state of the art of LoRaWAN from four dimensions: architecture, business models, security, and real-world applications. Sixty-three indexed academic publications from 2017 to 2025 were examined, selected through a rigorous searching, filtering, and evaluation protocol. The results identify key trends, technical challenges, and research gaps, highlighting emerging solutions such as blockchain, edge computing, and artificial intelligence. This study offers a comprehensive view that can guide future research and development in urban and industrial IoT environments.

title: Empowering Entrepreneurial Mindsets: A Digital Literacy and E-Commerce Adoption Model using Computational Analysis
authors: Deva Aulianda Permata, Doni Purnama Alamsyah
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The entrepreneurial mindset is the key to facing business challenges and uncertainties, especially in the digital era. The synergy between entrepreneurial mindset and technology adoption plays a crucial role in enhancing competitiveness and sustainability in entrepreneurship. This study aims to examine the support of technology adoption on entrepreneurial mindset. The study was conducted through a survey of students who have experience with social media and ecommerce. 277 students filled out the questionnaire quantitatively and processed the data through SmartPLS. A model test and analysis of the research results were conducted in line with the hypothesis test. The results of the study found that good technology adoption through digital literacy and ecommerce adoption was able to support a positive entrepreneurial mindset. It is directly known that the perceived usefulness of social media and e-commerce can support the improvement of digital literacy and e-commerce adoption by students. Studies on technology adoption are important in supporting student behavior, especially in pinning up and starting a business after graduation. This study provides an empirical understanding of the role of digital technology, especially digital literacy and e-commerce adoption in shaping students’ entrepreneurial mindset.

title: Preparation of an Environmental Impact and Risk Assessment Focusing on Mining Activities in the Sajo/Slana River Basin
authors: Martina Zeleňáková, Pavol Purcz, Timotej Brenkus, Rositsa Velichkova, Iskra Simova, Hany Abd Elhamid
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The Slana watershed, which is divided by the HU-SK border, can be described as a historical mining area. Since the 1990s, mining activities have gradually ceased and the water quality in the Slana River has improved. However, the mine closure was not always carried out professionally, in particular, the disposal and treatment of water flowing from the mine drainage system and the reclamation of tailings ponds were not addressed. As a result, a mining disaster could have occurred, which on February 24, 2022 caused an extraordinary deterioration of the waters in the upper part of the Slana River in southern Slovakia. The aim of the project is to map and preserve the current state of the Slana River and the potential effects of pollution from abandoned mines in the Slana River Basin. The main output of the project will be an Environmental Assessment Study and Risk Assessment. The study will summarise the results of the interconnected measurements and surveys (geophysical measurements, one-year monitoring of groundwater and surface waters, modelling and other studies) carried out within the project, examining the impact of mines and mine tailings on the environment in the Slana River Basin, identifying risks of their magnitude and probability.

title: Incorporating Stratal Dip to Constrain the Integration Range of Marchenko Imaging
authors: Xiaochun Chen, Tianjing Shen, Dong Zhang, Yukai Wo, Haoyang Ou, Xuri Huang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Marchenko imaging provides a powerful framework for reconstructing amplitude-preserved subsurface images while suppressing migration artifacts caused by internal multiples. This capability is achieved by applying an energy-compensated cross-correlation imaging condition to the up- and down-going Green’s functions retrieved through the Marchenko scheme. However, the performance of this approach strongly depends on the choice of the integration range: an excessively large range lowers resolution in shallow areas, whereas an overly small range can degrade the imaging quality of steeply dipping structures. To address this limitation, we propose an adaptive strategy that improves image quality by optimizing the integration range for each imaging point. The integration range is characterized by two parameters—the location of the integration center and the integration radius. Specifically, the radius is determined from the traveltime difference between the up- and down-going Green’s functions together with the depth of the imaging point, while the center location is constrained by stratal dip. The resulting optimal integration range, defined by these two parameters, is then applied to both the retrieval of Marchenko Green’s functions and the subsequent imaging. The proposed method was first tested on synthetic data, where it was shown to outperform fixed integration ranges (either too large or too small) by simultaneously enhancing shallow resolution and preserving the fidelity of steeply dipping structures. It was then further applied to field data from western China, which confirmed the feasibility of the approach.

title: Rapid Generalization of Motion Planning for Robot Manipulator Among Locally Changed Environments_supp1-3637078.mp4
authors: Huashan Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: As is known, the problem of making a trained deep reinforcement learning (DRL) model to adapt to a new environment different from where it trains remains open. In this article, DRL-based techniques are investigated and deployed for the robotic motion planning task in locally changed environments. First, a dynamic-entropy actor-critic is proposed to automatically adjust the coefficient of the entropy cluster to enable the agent to efficiently learn the potentially optimal policy. Second, a tutoring-guiding mechanism is established to heuristically explore and sufficiently exploit valuable experience. Third, a mechanism consisting of progressive planner and inverse kinematics mapper is designed to cope with localized changes in the environment, which enables the robot manipulator to rapidly adapt to the newly changed environment. Finally, experimental results have verified the superior performance of the proposed approaches.

title: Designing an Open-back Enclosure to Mitigate Sound Leakage for Open-ear Headphones
authors: Hironobu Chiba, Tatsuya Kako, Noboru Harada
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Small open-ear headphones are comfortable because they do not block the auricle or ear canal, which eliminates the occlusion effect and enables users to hear ambient sounds naturally and achieve accurate binaural reproduction in principle. However, their significant sound leakage makes them less suitable for use in public spaces. While mitigating sound leakage is desirable, existing near-field reproduction technologies, such as speaker arrays, are costly to use in such compact acoustic devices. Hence, we designed an enclosure with a back air cavity and side-openings for small open-ear headphones that use a single speaker unit. This enclosure design can mitigate sound leakage by emitting opposite-phase sound waves from the back of the speaker unit. The headphone designs that achieve dipole radiation by emitting opposite-phase sound waves are well-suited for near-field reproduction, as the proximity effect enhances the low-frequency response in the near field. Moreover, this enclosure design enables the frequency characteristics of the opposite-phase sound waves to be controlled by altering the volume or the area and position of the openings in the enclosure at the back of the speaker unit. Evaluations were conducted using finite element method (FEM) simulations and measurements with a dummy head wearing headphones. Consequently, we found that the proposed side-opening enclosure design mitigated sound leakage to a greater extent than the studied alternatives, sealed and back-opening enclosures.

title: Auto-Tuning of Speed Controller for PMSM using Nonlinear Dynamic Inversion Control
authors: Cheng-Han Lin, Yaow-Ming Chen
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In this paper, a feedback control technique using nonlinear dynamic inversion control (NDIC) for the speed control of surface permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM) will be introduced. The speed control law using NDIC ensures the stability of the closed-loop control system of PMSMs once the motor parameters are measured properly, and the location of the closed-loop poles can be designed by any linear control method. After that, the linear quadratic regulator (LQR), which is widely used for optimal control design, is employed to determine the closed-loop poles of the control system. Combining the NDIC speed control law with the LQR pole placement method, the new method “NDICLQR” is developed for the speed control law of PMSMs. Since there will be only one parameter to be tuned in the NDICLQR method and a given cost function is minimized, the control system can be auto-tuned, which means that the user does not have to tune the independent control gains manually, as in the conventional field-oriented control (FOC).

title: An Implementation of FEM Simulation for Brain Shift Prediction to Enhance the Neurosurgical Planning
authors: Tanadul Somboonwong, Keita Ono, Sorayouth Chumnanvej, Jackrit Suthakorn, Songpol Ongwattanakul
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In many hospitals, especially in resource-limited settings, neurosurgeons lack access to advanced intraoperative imaging, such as intraoperative MRI or CT. This limitation severely restricts their ability to adapt surgical plans in real-time, especially when anatomical changes occur during the procedure. One of the most critical of these changes is brain shift, a phenomenon where brain tissue deforms during surgery, reducing the accuracy of image-guided interventions. This study addresses that critical gap by introducing a finite element method (FEM)-based simulation that predicts brain shift using only standard preoperative imaging, MRI and CT. Unlike existing approaches that rely on intraoperative imaging or data-driven updates, the proposed method models deformation based on physical factors such as gravity, remaining cerebrospinal fluid, and brain–skull contact, using a static linear elastic formulation. The method is feasible, hardware-efficient, and deployable in typical clinical environments. Validation through phantom experiments confirmed the feasibility and clinical acceptability of the approach, achieving a mean lesion localization error of 1.94±0.59 mm and shift-correction improvement of 46.12±25.84% compared with conventional planning. With a total simulation time of under six minutes, the proposed approach provides a practical and scalable solution to support neurosurgical planning in settings without intraoperative imaging.

title: Analysis of Electromagnetic Characteristics of High Power Low Speed Permanent Magnet Motors with Different Tangential Rotor Structures
authors: Guanghui Du, Hongji Liu, Ruojin Jiang, Na Huang, Wanning Li, Keda Wang, Bowen Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: For high power low speed permanent magnet motors (LSPMMs), which are typically large in size and often subject to installation space constraints, the tangential rotor structure is more favorable than the radial surface-mounted permanent magnet rotor design due to its ability to generate higher output torque within the same volume. An integrated tangential rotor structure that combines flux barriers with silicon steel laminations offers improved manufacturability and is more suitable for mass production. Nevertheless, current research lacks a comprehensive understanding of the design principles governing the integrated tangential rotor structure in LSPMMs. Therefore, this paper focuses on the detailed design rules of the integrated tangential rotor structure for high-power LSPMMs, include different rotor structures, magnetic isolation characteristic, electromagnetic properties, mechanical strength, etc. Firstly, based on a 1200kW 75rpm high power LSPMM, two kinds of integral tangential rotor structures are proposed. On this basis, the influence of different pole-slot combinations and sizes of magnetic isolation bridges on electromagnetic performance is analyzed in detail. Secondly, multi-objective optimization and mechanical strength analysis of two kinds of tangential rotor structures are carried out. Then, the electromagnetic performance and material consumption of two rotor structures are compared. Finally, a full size prototype is manufactured and tested to verify the theoretical analysis.

title: PDWearML: Leveraging Daily Activities for Fast Parkinson's Disease Severity Assessment with Wearable Machine Learning
authors: Xulong Wang, Xiyang Peng, Zheyuan Xu, Mingchang Xu, Yun Yang, Menghui Zhou, Zhong Zhao, Peng Yue, Po Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Objective: Achieving effective and robust free-living PD severity assessment with wearable intelligence technologies requires a deep understanding of clinically relevant features, representative activities, and machine learning algorithms. Methods: We designed a unified analytic framework (PDWearML) to optimise wearable ML approaches with simple daily activities for fast assessment of PD severity. It comprises annotation criteria, feature importance analysis, representative activity combination, and PD severity assessment. We conducted a 12-month study, developing a supervised PD wearable dataset containing 100 PD patients and 35 age-matched healthy controls using Huawei smartwatches and Shimmer. PD severity, assessed by trained physicians using the Hoehn and Yahr (H&Y) scale. Results: The results reveal that through optimising multi-level feature extraction and combining three representative daily activities (WALK, ARISING-FROM-CHAIR, and DRINK), our smartwatch-based machine learning approach can assess PD severity in supervised settings within 2 minutes with an accuracy of up to 84.7%. Significance: This work holds significant clinical value, offering a potential auxiliary tool for faster, more tailored interventions in PD healthcare. Code is availableat code ocean platform and https://github.com/wang-xulong/PDWearML.

title: Lessons Learned from the euROBIN Manipulation Skill Versatility Challenge at IROS 2024_supp1-3648290.mp4
authors: Chaoyang Song
publish: N/A
abstract: Robotic automation in high-mix, low-volume settings often relies on structured workcells where fixtures, workpieces, and procedures are well defined, but tasks must be reconfigured quickly across variants. This paper presents the Design and Learning Research Group's solution to the euROBIN Manipulation Skill Versatility Challenge (MSVC) at IROS 2024, in which a standardized electronic task board is operated through a fixed sequence of subtasks. We deliberately adopt a simple, industry-style implementation: each subtask is taught by recording an open-loop Tool Center Point (TCP) and gripper trajectory in the task-board frame, a wrist-mounted depth camera is used once per run to localize the board and a few key features, and a web dashboard exposes the resulting motion primitives as reusable code blocks that can be reordered and reparameterized. With this pipeline, our system completes the benchmark in 28.2 s in the lab (37.2 s on-site), compared to a human baseline of 16.3 s and an average of 83.5 s for previous teams, closing a large part of the performance gap without advanced learning or feedback control. We further demonstrate limited skill transfer by retargeting the same subtask library to a smoke-detector battery replacement scenario required by the competition. Finally, we release our implementation as open source and discuss how competition design and benchmark structure influence the balance between simple engineered solutions and richer sensing and learning.

title: A Multidisciplinary Approach to the Geometrical Design of Axial Active Magnetic Bearings - Part I: Methodology
authors: Juuso Narsakka, Sadjad Madanzadeh, Tuhin Choudhury, Gyan Ranjan, Niko Nevaranta, Antti Uusitalo, Jussi Sopanen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion
abstract: Approximately 25% of all electricity worldwide is consumed by pumps, compressors, and blowers in industrial applications. High-speed electric machines based on magnetic suspension technology present a significant opportunity to improve the efficiency of these drivelines, thus reducing total energy consumption, costs, and pollution levels. However, a major challenge in adopting the high-speed drivelines in industrial applications lies in their implementation. The design lead time for such machines typically spans years, whereas an ideal time-frame would be mere weeks. This study presents a systematic multidisciplinary design process for thrust active magnetic bearing to accelerate design work. By structuring the design steps in a precise order, automation can be integrated to develop the design space, which can then be directly utilized in the system level design analysis. In practice, when another design area is modified, a thrust bearing design that fulfils the overall design requirements can be automatically updated from the design space. Consequently, non-viable solutions are directly excluded, reducing the iterative nature of high-speed machine system design. Part I of this paper details the methodology of the multidisciplinary design process, while Part II illustrates the application of the proposed design method using a one-megawatt high-speed electric machine for a heat pump compressor.

title: Challenges and Opportunities for Digital Transformation of Organizational Culture in Bulgarian Companies for Telecommunications Services
authors: Gergana Sl. Dimcheva, Ivaylo Ts. Stoyanov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The publication deals with a current problem related to identifying the challenges and opportunities for digital transformation of organizational culture in small and medium-sized telecommunications companies according to the type of services offered in the Republic of Bulgaria. In the conditions of the Bulgarian scientific literature, and also on a global scale, there is a lack of focused studies to identify the challenges and opportunities for digital transformation of companies in the telecommunications services sector. This allows the authors of the publication to conduct an up-to-date study of the nature of these processes in different areas of the telecommunications industry in the Republic of Bulgaria and, based on the data obtained, to derive corresponding results for the dynamics of the process of digital transformation of organizational culture. The study was conducted on the territory of five large cities in the Republic of Bulgaria, using a quantitative approach in the development of an online survey, through which empirical data were generated in the business of small and medium sized telecommunications companies. Based on the data obtained, an analysis of key factors that limit and stimulate the digital transformation of organizational culture was made.

title: Assessing the Capacity and Capability of Law Enforcement in Dealing with Cybercrime: The Case of Nelspruit (Mbombela)
authors: Zenzo Polite Ncube, Nkosana Koos Makhaya, Thembinkosi Mathebula
publish: 2025 Cybersecurity4D (C4D)
abstract: The global escalation of cybercrime, particularly in South Africa, highlights alarming inadequacies in the law enforcement agencies’ capacity to handle such crimes, particularly in resource-limited areas like Nelspruit of the Mpumalanga Province. Offenses including identity theft, financial fraud, cyberbullying, and social media crimes demand specialised skills and an advanced technological infrastructure that is often unavailable at local level. This research analyses the cybercrime preparedness gaps of law enforcement agencies based in Nelspruit, Mpumalanga Province. It focuses on training capacity and the infrastructure technology institutional support.With law enforcement and cybersecurity academic professionals as units of analysis, primary data were collected through interviews. Interviews informed current practices in addition to pinpointing critical knowledge tool coordination gaps within their frameworks. Findings indicate that lack of expertise, outdated forensic tools, and poor inter-agency collaboration hinder local agencies from keeping pace with more sophisticated cyber threats.This paper also focuses on public-private partnership models while highlighting international collaborations for responding to cybercrimes and sharing innovative strategies to overcome the said problems. Moreover, the paper argues that effective measures require dual approaches including proactive technical measures, proactive ethics, and legal frameworks that sustain institutional adjustments.Establishment of dedicated cybercrime training facilities, modern investigative tools and funding, as well as better stakeholder collaboration were proposed in the study. To reinforce Nelspruit’s cybersecurity posture, the local law enforcement agencies need to boost their capacity and capability, which is the main focus area of the study.

title: Stinger - An Asymmetric Multiplayer Serious Game for Dengue Awareness
authors: Nafis Forkan, Md Towhidul Islam Rahat, Yasef Ahnaf Shonon, Rashedur M. Rahman
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Dengue is a global health crisis and is spread by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. This paper presents ‘Stinger’, a 3D asymmetric multiplayer serious game to address dengue awareness gaps in rural Bangladesh through culturally relevant gameplay. The game has interactive mechanics that simulate real-world dengue transmission dynamics, teach players to identify and eliminate mosquito breeding sites and adopt preventive behaviors. Setting in a rural Bangladeshi environment, the game has multiplayer functionality to model community-level disease spread and collective prevention strategies. Early results show significant knowledge retention and behavior adoption among players, so game-based learning works for public health education. The game provides a framework for developing culturally adapted serious games to bridge the gap between awareness and action in disease prevention.

title: Inpainting Detection via Image Segmentation with a Modified U-Net Architecture
authors: Rodrigo Eduardo Arevalo-Ancona, Manuel Cedillo-Hernandez
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The detection of image manipulations is essential to ensure their authenticity. In particular, the identification of inpainting forgery regions for the detection of edits that compromise visual integrity. This paper presents a method for inpainting detection, based on image segmentation using a modified U-Net architecture. The incorporation of the residual layers in the U-Net decoder architecture effectively identifies texture patterns and preserves spatial information, to distinguish forgery regions. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model, achieving an accuracy of 97% and a mean squared error below 0.011 for detecting inpainting areas, even in the presence of certain image distortions.

title: The Evolving Landscape of Artificial Intelligence in Biomedical Imaging
authors: Selahattin Kosunalp, Selma Bulut, Adem Korkmaz
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming biomedical imaging and diagnostics by enabling faster, more accurate, and personalized healthcare solutions. The rise of smart digital ecosystems—integrating cloud computing, the Internet of Things (IoT), and digital twins—has further accelerated the clinical adoption of AI technologies. This study presents a comprehensive bibliometric analysis of AI applications in biomedical imaging and diagnostics from 2019 to 2025, using data retrieved from the Web of Science (WoS) database. Through VOSviewer-Based mapping of 893 publications, key research trends, influential contributors, and international collaboration networks are identified. Dominant research themes include deep learning for medical image segmentation, generative models for synthetic data augmentation, federated learning for privacy-preserving healthcare, and explainable AI (XAI) for enhancing clinical transparency. Temporal evolution analysis reveals a shift from convolutional neural networks (CNNs) toward transformer and diffusion models in recent years. The findings emphasize the field’s increasingly interdisciplinary nature and highlight the need for diverse datasets, ethical frameworks, and interpretable models to ensure trustworthy and scalable AI integration in healthcare. This study provides a systematic and data-driven foundation to guide future research, collaboration, and policy development in the advancement of AI-enabled biomedical imaging.

title: Digital Twin Applications in Industrial Engineering: From Process Optimization to Autonomous Systems
authors: Tsanka Zlateva-Petkova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Digital Twin (DT) technology has emerged as a transformative enabler of Industry 4.0, providing a dynamic link between physical assets and their virtual counterparts. In industrial engineering, DT applications extend beyond traditional process monitoring, offering advanced capabilities in optimization, predictive maintenance, and real-time decision-making. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of Digital Twin applications in industrial engineering, focusing on the transition from process optimization to the development of autonomous systems. A conceptual framework is proposed that integrates physical systems, IoT-enabled data layers, virtual models, and AI-driven analytics to achieve self-optimization and self-healing capabilities. Case studies and simulation scenarios demonstrate the potential of DT for enhancing productivity, reducing downtime, and improving sustainability in industrial environments. The study highlights existing challenges such as data management, cybersecurity, and standardization, while outlining opportunities for future integration with generative AI and extended reality (XR). The findings position Digital Twins as a key enabler for the next generation of smart and autonomous industrial systems.

title: Student and Employer Perspectives on IT Leadership in the Context of AI and IoT
authors: Nikolay Yanev, Iva Kostadinova, Iglika Getova, Yoana Hadzhiyska, Elizabet Mihaylova, Milena Bankovska
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper explores the potential of using empirical and open data to formulate guidelines that support universities as they adapt to the rapidly changing labor market. The analysis draws on the results of four surveys carried out within the TransLeader international project: Research 2 (Study of the labor market for IT leadership competences in the field of AI and IoT), Research 4 (Questionnaire for IT employees), Research 5 (Questionnaire for IT Students, Masters and Alumni in Information Systems and Technologies), and Research 6 (Questionnaire for employers: Specifying leadership competences). The study reviews job postings, analyzes the types of specialists in demand and the skills and competences they are expected to possess, and examines employers’ attitudes and expectations toward universities in preparing the workforce. The resulting analysis is intended for educational institutions, faculty, students, and early career professionals aiming at careers in IT leadership. The proposed recommendations can inform curricular changes and training in AI and IoT.

title: Strategies for ICT integration in secondary education towards socio-professional relevance
authors: Joe Llerena-Izquierdo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The need for a true digital transformation in education requires teachers to develop digital competences that enable them to plan, design, develop and use technological resources in a relevant way. The aim of this work focuses on strengthening pedagogical practices and teachers’ digital competences, while promoting strategies towards the development of socio-professional competences in the classroom. This empirical-analytical study, with a quantitative approach, investigates the socio-professional relevance of training workshops on the integration of ICT in the classroom. Fifty-two secondary school teachers from Guayaquil, Ecuador, voluntarily participated in virtual workshops organised as part of a project to link them with society. The evaluation was carried out by means of a survey applied to the teachers, covering three phases of project work. The results from three dimensions show an average of 98% of having achieved digital teaching skills, 96.17% of having achieved innovation in their teaching strategies and 94.90% of having achieved a real integration of ICT use in the teacher’s classroom activities.

title: JvWiki-Clean: A Language-Specific Cleaning Pipeline for Javanese Wikipedia
authors: Jati Sasongko Wibowo, Eko Sediyono, Hendry
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Javanese (Basa Jawa) is spoken by more than eighty million people yet remains a low-resource language in natural language processing. We introduce JvWiki-Clean version 1.0, a reproducible, language-specific pipeline that converts the Javanese Wikipedia into a cleaner monolingual corpus. The pipeline has six stages: parsing, sentence segmentation, sentence-level language identification, orthographic normalization and code-switch filtering, deduplication, and article-level train-development-test splitting. Applied to the August 2025 dump, the pipeline reduces roughly eight hundred thousand segmented sentences to 13,550 Javanese sentences with improved quality and an average length of 16.5 tokens. We evaluate purity, leakage, deduplication, and sentence distribution, and we audit borderline cases caused by code-switching and disagreement between language identification tools. A sweep over the language-identification confidence threshold (tau) confirms a clear size-purity trade-off; throughout this paper we adopt tau equal to 0.90 as a balanced operating point. Despite the large reduction in size, the resulting corpus is, to our knowledge, among the larger openly available monolingual Javanese resources and is suitable for evaluation and lightweight finetuning. We publicly release the dataset and the associated scripts to support transparent and repeatable research. Future work will establish baselines for classification, part-of-speech tagging, and named-entity recognition, explore data augmentation and cross-lingual transfer with Indonesian, and extend the corpus with curated sources beyond Wikipedia while preserving auditability.

title: Implementation of Least Significant Bit Steganography using the RSA Algorithm in a Telegram Bot
authors: Nila Ardhya Lintang Pramesty, Nia Yulianti, Sri Rosdiana, Nadia Paramitha Retno Adiati, Rheva Anindya Wijayanti
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: In the digital era, instant messaging applications like Telegram have become prevalent communication methods, offering cross-device synchronization and multimedia file transmission. However, threats to message confidentiality and integrity remain significant concerns. This study proposes integrating Least Significant Bit (LSB) steganography with RSA algorithm within a Telegram Bot framework. The approach first encrypts secret messages using RSA for cryptographic security, then embeds them into digital objects using LSB steganography to conceal their existence during transmission. The Telegram Bot facilitates automated, cross-platform communication accessible across different devices. Security performance is evaluated using Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), where higher values indicate better imperceptibility and detection resistance. Experimental results demonstrate that combining RSA with LSB enhances both confidentiality and robustness while maintaining media quality. The main contribution is designing and implementing a secure Telegram Bot that unifies cryptography and steganography, providing a practical solution for safeguarding digital communication through an accessible, user-friendly interface.

title: Lip Reading using Inner Lip Contour Feature with Deep Learning
authors: Muhammad Alwali, Eko Mulyanto Yuniarno, Reza Fuad Rachmadi
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Lip reading is a technology that is becoming increasingly relevant in various fields such as security, inclusive communication, and human-computer interaction. This research proposes a new approach to lip reading by utilizing the inner lip contour features as primary representation of lip movement. Video datasets were collected independently, involving subjects of diverse ages and genders, then processed to extract the inner lip contour area using the Mediapipe framework and the polygon area calculation method (Shoelace formula). The extraction results were used as input for two deep learning architectures: 1D CNN + LSTM and 1D CNN + BiGRU, each model is structured to detect variations in lip movements over time and across different positions. Results from the evaluation indicated that the CNN + Bi-GRU model reached the highest accuracy, recording 88.39%, outperforming the CNN + LSTM model with an accuracy of 84.46%, and demonstrated higher precision, recall, and F1-score values. This Research demonstrates that inner lip contour features can enhance the accuracy of lip-reading systems and make a significant contribution to the development of visual recognition technology based on lip movements.

title: LoRa-Enabled Communication System for Autonomous DJI Tello Drone Operation
authors: Jhonatan P. Cambisaca, Henry M. Castro, Henry D. Maldonado, Pablo Barbecho Bautista
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The Tello drone is widely used in both educational and professional environments for telemetry, control algorithms, and real-time data processing. However, its reliance on Wi-Fi significantly limits its operational range. This paper proposes a LoRa-based communication framework designed to extend the Tello drone’s range and enable applications in long-range telemetry, remote monitoring, and autonomous flight. The system comprises: (i) a LoRa base station for route configuration and flight command transmission; (ii) a hybrid communication architecture leveraging LoRa for long-range signaling and Wi-Fi for close-range drone interaction; and (iii) a custom mounting solution integrating the Heltec V3 microcontroller, LoRa antenna, and lithium battery onto the Tello drone without compromising flight stability. Experimental results validate the successful integration and operation of all components, demonstrating the feasibility of extending the Tello drone’s range by up to four times under non-line-of-sight (NLoS) conditions, with a packet delivery ratio of 99.4%.

title: Deep Learning Approach for Multi-Class Classification of Textual Data via Bi-LSTM
authors: Ahmad Abdul Chamid, R. Rizal Isnanto, Ahmad Jazuli, Wibowo Harry Sugiharto, Albertus Dwiyoga Widiantoro, Sumaji
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The large number of conversations on online platforms is interesting to analyze to produce meaningful information. Textual data analysis requires a special approach, one of which is text classification. Still, the problem is that if the classification is carried out in multiple classes, a balanced data distribution is needed in each class. Existing textual data is generally unbalanced, so a special approach is needed to develop a multi-class classification model. In this study, a model was developed for emotion detection in multi-class using Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM). The research stages include dataset acquisition, preprocessing, pretrained model Global Vectors for Word Representation (Glove), developing model, and model evaluation. The public dataset was obtained under imbalanced conditions, with 422,746 data points. The undersampling approach was used to overcome data imbalance. The Bi-LSTM method was used to develop the model, and the results obtained an accuracy value of 0.87 and outperformed the use of imbalanced data. The resulting model was able to classify multi-class well.

title: An Instructional Method for Designing (15,7) BCH Codes Capable of Correcting Two Errors and its use in University Teaching
authors: Adriana Borodzhieva
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: BCH (Bose-Chaudhuri-Hocquenghem) codes are a versatile family of cyclic error-correcting codes that provide dependable detection and correction of multiple bit errors in digital systems. This manuscript details the synthesis of a binary BCH code with two-error correction capability and presents the main steps of a decoding implementation. Emphasis is placed on a pedagogy tailored to this algebraically dense subject: visualization techniques, simulation-driven exercises, and practical case studies that improve student comprehension, engagement, and outcomes. The work connects theoretical foundations with classroom practice to make modern error-control coding more accessible to learners.

title: Building a logical context for making decisions about cardiovascular diseases using lipoprotein information
authors: Manuel Andrés Ávila Sarmiento, Edgardo Samuel Barraza Verdesoto
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiovascular diseases are among the leading causes of mortality worldwide, and genetic variations in lipoproteins play a crucial role in determining the risk of certain conditions. The primary objective of this study is to introduce a logically based biological model to evaluate the contribution of lipoprotein variants to the risk of cardiovascular disease. METHODS: This study employs a descriptive approach, drawing on mathematical logic, computer science, and empirical research, essential disciplines for the implementation of this approach. Data were collected from the UniProt, Ensemble, and Varsome databases, encompassing 14000 variant alterations associated with conditions such as obesity and hypertension. A cluster analysis was performed that classified t he v ariants i nto t hree g roups: p athogenic, of uncertain significance, a nd b enign. R ESULTS: T he analysis indicated that variants exhibiting a behavior that validates two key axioms about the risk, depending on the type of variant and its change, and proposes a hypothesis that variants of uncertain significance $\mathbf{c}$ ould $\mathbf{b}$ ecome $\mathbf{p}$ athogenic $\mathbf{w}$ hen exposed to detrimental environmental factors, these findings $\mathbf{c}$ an help to build expert and Bayesian systems capable of predicting cardiovasular diseases. CONCLUSIONS: The importance of this study is that it shows the gene-environment interactions with an evolutionary context and provides a predictive model for individualized cardiovascular risk evaluation.

title: School Timetable Optimization Model Using Genetic Algorithms Considering Hard and Soft Constraints
authors: Jair Criollo, Daniel Riofrío, Felipe Grijalva, José Vega-Sánchez, Ricardo Flores-Moyano, Maria Baldeon-Calisto
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents a Hybrid Genetic Al-gorithm (HGA) for automatic school timetable gen-eration at a private institution in Quito, Ecuador. The model incorporates hard constraints (e.g., teacher conflicts, pedagogical continuity) and soft constraints (e.g., part-time staff, maternity leave), representing the complete timetable as a chromosome with 2,832 genes. An eight-phase methodological pipeline was developed, covering data preparation, chromosome generation, fit-ness evaluation, and solution verification. Two experi-ments were conducted: one with random initialization and another using a historical timetable as a heuristic seed. The heuristic-enhanced approach achieved a valid schedule (fitness $=1$) in under 12 hours, reducing plan-ning time from $\mathbf{1 0} \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{1 5}$ days to less than $\mathbf{2 4}$ hours. The system improves schedule coherence, supports yearly reuse, and is adaptable to other institutions through structural adjustments.

title: Catch Me If You Can: Retain High Stealthiness and Durability of Backdoor Attack in Federated Learning_supp1-3639885.pdf
authors: Xinjing Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is vulnerable to backdoor attacks by design since it cannot inspect clients’ local data to protect their privacy. This privacy-preserving feature creates an opportunity for malicious clients to introduce backdoors. However, existing backdoor attacks face two main limitations. First, brute amplification (i.e., uniformly scaling up malicious parameters) can be easily detected, hence compromising attack stealthiness. Second, evasion strategies employed to prevent their backdoors from being overwritten by benign updates are frequently ineffective, reducing the overall attack stability upon model deployment. To address these limitations, we propose an adaptive proactive boosting strategy to enhance both the stealthiness and durability of backdoor attacks in FL. As a concrete example, ReBA introduces a durable importance metric based on stability degrees of parameters as an update mask for malicious attackers, assigning higher weights to backdoor-related parameters during the update process. To ensure stealthiness, ReBA formulates an optimization problem regarding amplification factor by minimizing the distance between malicious and clean updates, thereby correcting malicious updates within a benign distance space. Extensive evaluations on 3 datasets and across 14 defenses demonstrate the efficacy of ReBA, outperforming over 12 baseline backdoor attacks. Our code is available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/ReBA-D82F.
