title: Adaptive and Robust DBSCAN With Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning_supp1-3648017.pdf
authors: Hao Peng
publish: N/A
abstract: Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN), a well-known density-based clustering algorithm, has gained widespread popularity and usage due to its effectiveness in identifying clusters of arbitrary shapes and handling noisy data. However, it encounters challenges in producing satisfactory cluster results when confronted with datasets of varying density scales, a common scenario in real-world applications. In this paper, we propose a novel Adaptive and Robust DBSCAN with Multi-agent Reinforcement Learning cluster framework, namelyAR-DBSCAN. First, we model the initial dataset as a two-level encoding tree and categorize the data vertices into distinct density partitions according to the information uncertainty determined in the encoding tree. Each partition is then assigned to an agent to find the best clustering parameters without manual assistance. The allocation is density-adaptive, enabling AR-DBSCAN to effectively handle diverse density distributions within the dataset by utilizing distinct agents for different partitions. Second, a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning guided automatic parameter searching process is designed. The process of adjusting the parameter search direction by perceiving the clustering environment is modeled as a Markov decision process. Using a weakly-supervised reward training policy network, each agent adaptively learns the optimal clustering parameters by interacting with the clusters. Third, a recursive search mechanism adaptable to the data's scale is presented, enabling efficient and controlled exploration of large parameter spaces. Extensive experiments are conducted on nine artificial datasets and a real-world dataset. The results of offline and online tasks show that AR-DBSCAN not only improves clustering accuracy by up to 144.1% and 175.3% in the Normalized Mutual Information (NMI) and the Adjusted Rand Index (ARI) metrics, respectively, but also is capable of robustly finding dominant parameters.

title: Slack Federated Adversarial Training_supp1-3646649.pdf
authors: Bo Han
publish: N/A
abstract: Security and privacy concerns in real-world applications have led to the development of adversarially robust federated models. Previous works mainly target overcoming the adaptability constraints regarding communication and computation costs. However, the straightforward combination of adversarial training and federated learning might lead to undesired robust accuracy degradation emerging at later training stages. We reveal that the attribution behind this phenomenon is that the generated adversarial data could exacerbate the data heterogeneity among local clients, making the wrapped federated learning perform poorly. To deal with this problem, we introduce an $\alpha$-slack mechanism to relax the original learning objective of federated adversarial training, and propose a novel framework called Slack Federated Adversarial Training (SFAT) to combat the intensified heterogeneity. By assigning the client-wise slack during aggregation, SFAT realizes a weighted aggregation that alleviates the optimization bias induced by the local adversarial generation. We further extend to a more general setting, permitting both clients trained by standard/adversarial training in a unified framework, and propose SFAT* with a hierarchical aggregation schema for this scenario. Theoretically, we analyze the convergence of our method to properly relax the learning objective. Experimentally, we verify the rationality and effectiveness of our methods on various benchmarked and real-world datasets with different adversarial training and federated optimization methods.

title: Measuring the Unmeasurable: Demystifying Silent Data Corruptions in AI Accelerators through Microarchitectural Modeling
authors: Odysseas Chatzopoulos, Maria Trakosa, Harish D. Dixit, Sriram Sankar, Dimitris Gizopoulos
publish: IEEE Micro
abstract: AI accelerators are vital for the efficient execution of data-heavy workloads across various environments, but increased design complexity and shrinking manufacturing processes lead to severe reliability issues (with insidious behavior like silent data corruptions—SDCs). While CPU reliability has been analyzed significantly, AI accelerators require tailored analysis due to their diverse and evolving designs. In this work, we present a comprehensive methodology for the evaluation of the reliability of systolic array-based AI accelerators harnessing the power of microarchitectural modeling. Our approach captures the entire compute stack—from software to gates—across a wide range of design points including dataflows, datatypes, memory hierarchies, and array sizes. We support statistical fault injection on key hardware structures (SRAMs, registers, functional units), supporting a wide range of fault models, and implement speedup techniques that significantly boost the injection throughput (more than 1000×) without sacrificing accuracy. Evaluations on diverse ML models reveal SDC vulnerability trends across accelerator design-points highlighting the effectiveness of our methodology for broad design space exploration.

title: A Review of Partial Discharge in High-Frequency and High-Speed WBG-Based Electric Drives
authors: Kangbeen Lee, Hyunwoo Kim, Junhyuk Im, Suaib Al Sufi, Chanyeop Park, Woongkul Lee
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Industry Applications
abstract: Partial discharge (PD) is a localized insulation failure that occurs without completely bridging the electrodes. While PD in sinusoidal excitations has been extensively studied with conventional detection and analysis methods, wide bandgap (WBG)-based electric drives introduce new challenges due to their high-frequency and high-speed switching. These features give rise to non-uniform voltage and charge distributions, along with voltage overshoot and ringing, governed by a geometry of PD object and drive parameters such as switching frequency and slew rate. Moreover, these fast-switching transients complicate PD detection due to electromagnetic interference (EMI). This paper reviews PD characteristics in WBG-based drives, highlighting the challenges in WBG-based drives. The review explores opportunities to improve PD location prediction through voltage distribution analysis based on the impedance of PD objects, as well as to optimize insulation design by considering charge distribution and methods for reducing the electric field across the insulation. Furthermore, it discusses methods to improve the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of PD detection, including a reduction of common-mode voltage (CMV) and current with active EMI filters, thereby enhancing detection reliability in WBG-based electric drives.

title: Performance Evaluation of Alternative Programming Techniques in PHP
authors: Yordan Kalmukov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Programming is a multivariate activity since most things could be implemented in multiple alternative ways, by using different operators and control structures. In case of applications that process small to medium amount of data, the chosen alternative is not of high importance in respect to performance. However, some subject domains and complex algorithms from the fields of Information Retrieval, Natural Language Processing and Machine Learning usually requires processing large datasets, comprising of millions of instances or elements. In this case, knowing the relative performance of each control structure allows programmers to select the one that will perform best for large amounts of data. The goal of this paper is to conduct a series of experiments and performance evaluation of alternative programming techniques, mostly different type of loop structures, in order to determine the ones that provide higher performance for large datasets.

title: A Modulated Position-Indexed Differential Chaos Shift Keying System With Enhanced BER and Throughput
authors: Lifang He, Yunhan Pei, Gang Zhang, Yongqi Guo
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: To address the issues of low transmission rate and poor bit error rate (BER) performance in traditional Differential Chaos Shift Keying (DCSK) systems, this letter proposes a novel position-index-modulation-based DCSK scheme. Each row of the Walsh code matrix is used to perform a Kronecker product with the initial reference signal to generate multiple orthogonal signals. Each orthogonal signal independently undergoes position index modulation and carries modulated bits to transmit information. Position index modulation labels each time slot of each subcarrier in the system frame structure as a unique position indexed sequentially. According to the rules of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$K$ </tex-math></inline-formula>-combination mapping, one or more active positions are selected from all positions to transmit corresponding orthogonal signals. At the receiver, a sliding average denoising technique is introduced to reduce noise variance and enhance system reliability. Additionally, BER expressions are derived under additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channels and multipath Rayleigh fading channels. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed system achieves higher transmission rates and better BER performance compared with several DCSK-based schemes proposed in recent years.

title: Low Earth Orbit Satellite Network Routing
authors: Ioannis Nakas, Theodoros N.F. Kaifas
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel cross-layer, software defined network-enabled routing framework for LEO mega-constellations that tightly integrates adaptive antenna arrays, real-time physical-layer feedback, and hierarchical control-plane orchestration. By embedding instantaneously measured metrics—signal-to-noise ratio, propagation delay, direction-of-arrival misalignment, and maximum-ratio combining gain—into a unified cost function, our system dynamically selects optimal inter-satellite and ground-station links. A three-tier control architecture leverages GEO satellites as central software defined networking controllers, MEO nodes for regional forwarding, and LEO craft for fine-grained telemetry reporting. Extensive simulations on a Walker-Delta constellation under different array sizes, update intervals, direction of arrival error levels, and interference conditions demonstrate notable reductions in end-to-end latency, significant improvements in throughput, and substantial drops in packet loss compared to snapshot- and signal to noise ratio-only baselines. A comprehensive sensitivity analysis further validates the robustness and onboard feasibility of our hybrid software defined networking–beamforming approach for next-generation non-terrestrial networks.

title: Advancing Prostate Cancer Diagnosis with DCGAN-Generated Synthetic Histopathology Images
authors: Sayedur Rahman, Touhid Alam, Shusmita Anjum Aziz, Md Arifur Rahman, B M Taslimul Haque, Tze Hui Liew
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Deep learning models for prostate cancer diagnosis are often hindered by the scarcity and imbalance of medical imaging datasets. This study addresses this challenge by developing a Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Network (DCGAN) to produce high-fidelity synthetic histopathology images. Leveraging the Cancer-Net PCa dataset, our DCGAN, featuring over 51 million parameters, was trained for 200 epochs to generate realistic images. The model’s performance was rigorously evaluated, demonstrating stable training dynamics with generator and discriminator losses converging at 0.6526 and 0.6953, respectively. A significant improvement in image quality was confirmed by the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) score, which dropped from an initial value of approximately 400 to 211.89. While the model showed high precision, limitations in image diversity were identified, indicating an area for future enhancement. Futhermore, we trained several transfer learning models on the augmented dataset using the proposed DCGAN model where the EfficientNetV2 performed the best at $97.02 \%$ accuracy and an improvement of $\mathbf{5. 4 2 \%}$ over the original dataset, demonstrating a state-of-the-art result among the other established GAN models. The results affirm the potential of DCGANs to effectively augment medical datasets, paving the way for more robust and accurate diagnostic tools in the fight against prostate cancer.

title: Exploring User Plane Function Implementations for Adaptive 6G Networks
authors: Viktor Stoynov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The User Plane Function (UPF) sits at the center of enabling high-performance, scalable, and adaptive data delivery in modern mobile networks. As 6G networks are envisioned to be inherently adaptive—capable of responding to diverse services, user mobility, and dynamic workloads—the architectural flexibility of the UPF becomes increasingly critical. Implementations of the UPF have burgeoned across a wide range of architectural models from centralized designs to distributed, edge-deployed, containerized, and hardware-accelerated configurations. However, existing studies often examine isolated technical facets devoid of a unified framework for comparison. This paper introduces a novel taxonomy with multiple layers that systematically categorizes UPF designs across five independent dimensions: location within the network topology, the computing platform employed, the software engineering approach, the licensing model adopted, and integration capabilities. The proposed framework is then applied to systematically examine and contrast the principal UPF implementation types delineated within the taxonomy, highlighting their respective trade-offs in terms of latency optimization, scalability, orchestration complexity, and deployment maturity. In addition, a comparative simulation-based evaluation is conducted for three representative UPF archetypes, each aligned with a distinct design category. Overall, this study presents a novel and comprehensive analysis of UPF architectures, offering valuable insights for network architects and researchers. It supports the informed selection, optimization, evolution, or replacement of UPF implementations to effectively meet the stringent performance and flexibility requirements of future 6G networks.

title: A Literature Review on Real-Time Crime Detection Using Deep Learning and Edge Computing
authors: Carlos Julio Fierro Silva, Carolina Del-Valle-Soto, José Varela-Aldás
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The growing need for security in urban and commercial environments has driven the development of intelligent surveillance systems capable of detecting criminal activities in real time. While traditional cloud-based solutions offer advanced capabilities, they face limitations in terms of latency, privacy, and bandwidth usage. In this context, Edge Computing has emerged as a promising alternative, enabling local and fast processing of video data through embedded artificial intelligence models. This review article presents a comprehensive analysis of recent advances in real-time detection of thefts and weapons using Edge Artificial Intelligence (Edge AI). A total of 30 scientific articles published between 2018 and 2025 were selected and categorized, taking into account detection models, computing platforms, evaluation metrics, datasets, and real-world applications. The results highlight the predominant use of lightweight convolutional neural networks, especially YOLO-based models, implemented on devices such as Jetson Nano, Raspberry Pi, and Google Coral. Key challenges addressed include detection under lowlight conditions, identification of small or partially concealed weapons, and the reduction of false positives. The review identifies gaps in the current literature, such as the lack of annotated real-world datasets and the need for behavior-based models in retail contexts. Finally, emerging trends and future research directions are discussed, aiming at the development of efficient, accurate, and privacy-respecting Edge AI systems for real-time security surveillance.

title: Design of Indicators for the Logistic Control of Products in a Commercial Company Based on Business Intelligence
authors: Andrés Hidalgo-Valero, Joe Llerena-Izquierdo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In different types of companies and in different parts of the world, the integration of ICT with product logistics management has several advantages. The overall objective of this research study is to design performance indicators to monitor logistics and product distribution in a company based on business intelligence. The methodology used was a review of the literature, observation of other models found in the articles, induction, deduction, modelling and a digital survey technique. Nineteen relevant scientific articles were included that helped answer research questions focused on transport as the most widely used logistics activity, the role of the distributor as the main participant, business intelligence as the most widely used information technology, and service improvement as the main objective pursued by research models. A three-layer model was proposed: Data Source, Processing-Storage, and Presentation, which helps obtain real data and enables decision-making and improved operations. In the survey, an average of 89% of experts agree and strongly agree that the tools, IoT devices, proposed indicators, dimensions mentioned, and table of facts are appropriate elements for the model. Experts also mentioned other indicators, dimensions, and facts that could be added to the model.

title: Business Model and Technical Implementation for the Production of Glued Balsa Blocks in an Ecuadorian Balsa Company
authors: Alejandra Orellana Maldonado
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents the design and evaluation of a business plan for implementing a new technical-industrial process for the production, drying, and gluing of balsa wood blocks in a family owned Ecuadorian enterprise. The objective is to vertically integrate the value chain, improve product quality, and reduce the costs associated with outsourcing critical steps of the process. The business model is analyzed through financial projections and operational diagnostics, showing a significant increase in the profitability and resilience of the company. The proposed investment in drying kilns and gluing systems demonstrates a viable path for sustainable growth and competitive positioning in the global Balsa market. This project impacts multiple aspects of the company, from its culture of innovation to its organizational structure and strategic decision-making, with the goal of positioning the company in a constantly evolving market and presenting management with an alternative to improve its financial results.

title: Thermal Dynamics in Agricultural Soils under Different Vegetative Covers in Coastal Ecuador
authors: Jorge Buele, Ángel Ramón Sabando-García, Rosario Esther Huerta-Vera, Liliana Carolina Argüello-Cedeño
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Global shifts in climate patterns are exerting growing pressure on agricultural systems, particularly in equatorial regions where crop productivity is directly tied to microclimatic conditions. This study investigated the relationship between ambient temperature and soil temperature under three surface conditions—bare soil, dry organic mulch, and live grass cover—using six years of continuous data (2015-2020) from tropical agricultural lands in coastal Ecuador. Soil temperature was measured at 20 cm depth, and the analysis integrated descriptive statistics, linear regression models, and Pearson correlation coefficients to quantify the interaction between air and soil thermal behavior. Additionally, the Mann-Kendall test and Sen’s slope estimator were applied to detect temporal trends. The findings revealed statistically significant correlations between ambient and soil temperatures across all conditions. However, soils with vegetative cover demonstrated greater thermal stability and lower variability, highlighting their moderating role. Notably, a consistent downward trend was detected in both ambient air (-23.22%) and in soils with grass (-32.63%) and mulch (-28.54%) cover. These patterns suggest that vegetative layer’s function as passive thermal regulators, buffering soils against climatic fluctuations. These insights have practical implications for agricultural and agro-industrial management. By promoting soil protection strategies, such as mulching or live cover maintenance, it is possible to mitigate thermal stress, optimize resource use, and enhance system resilience. Continuous soil-climate monitoring is recommended to guide adaptation efforts and ensure sustainability under future climate variability.

title: Web-based entrepreneurship project management platform using RESTful architecture
authors: Leonardo Chamorro-Villota, Christian Fajardo-Sempertegui, Belén Soriano-Cevallos, Lisbeth Molina-Sandoval, Karla Altamirano-Chingay
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Web-based project management platforms have become indispensable for organizing entrepreneurial competitions within academic institutions. Traditional manually coordinated methods typically lead to data duplication, operational inefficiencies, and delays in publishing results, while seldom extending beyond basic event logistics. This paper introduces PUCEmprende, an end-to-end web-based entrepreneurship management platform that automates the full event lifecycle and tracks entrepreneurs’ skill development within the ecosystem. The system adopts a RESTful architecture built with Vue.js and Laravel on a MySQL database, incorporating innovative features such as QR codedriven assessment and dynamic rubric management. Security is enforced through JSON Web Token (JWT) authentication and role-based access control (RBAC) following OWASP guidelines. PUCEmprende reduces event coordination time from weeks to hours, offers real-time monitoring and competency measurement, and automates result reporting and certificate issuance. The findings demonstrate that PUCEmprende transforms traditional entrepreneurship event management by delivering a scalable, secure, and maintainable solution for academic settings.

title: B_Welfare: Design and Modeling of a Web Platform for Labor Welfare
authors: Juan David Durán Garzón, Angel Andrés Boada Salazar, Jalitza Juliana Carrascal Coronel, Maicol Eduardo Robles Salazar, Duvan Andrey Marquez Pinzón, Dewar Rico-Bautista
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The lack of effective mechanisms to guarantee labor welfare continues to impact both workers and organizations, especially in regions where institutional support is limited. In response to this situation in Ocaña, Colombia, B_Welfare was conceived as a web-based platform aimed at improving the physical, emotional, and organizational health of workers. This article describes the design and modeling of the platform based on a mixed methods methodology. Data was collected from fifty local workers through a structured survey whose content validity was verified by expert judgment using Aiken’s V coefficient. A complementary quantitative analysis was conducted using secondary labor statistics. The platform integrates modules addressing key factors such as workplace communication, ergonomics, and emotional stability. The technological implementation was performed using React, TypeScript, PostgreSQL, and Python-based Model View Controller (MVC) architecture. B_Welfare is proposed as a tool for both workers and companies to monitor, support and strengthen occupational health and performance in a total way.

title: Immutable Audit of EV Charging Sessions Using Blockchain and IPFS
authors: Nexhibe Sejfuli - Ramadani, Jelena Gjorgjev, Valentina Angelkoska, Erenis Ramadani, Florim Idrizi, Aleksandar Risteski
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: As electric vehicles (EVs) become more prevalent, ensuring secure and transparent tracking of their charging activities has emerged as a critical challenge. Traditional centralized methods are vulnerable to data integrity issues and lack resilience, raising concerns about trustworthiness. This work presents a blockchain-enhanced architecture for auditing EV charging sessions. It offloads Charging Data Records (CDRs) to the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), while preserving their integrity through cryptographic anchors recorded on an Ethereum-compatible smart contract. This approach strikes a balance between decentralization and system performance. A prototype was developed featuring OCPP-based session simulation and automated verification via smart contracts. Experimental evaluation across thousands of test cases confirmed the system's ability to detect data tampering with minimal processing overhead, especially when integrated with Layer-2 scaling technologies. These results demonstrate the framework's potential to improve transparency and trust in EV charging networks.

title: The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Delivering Electronic Administrative Services
authors: Tsvetanka Dutsova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) plays an important role in the digitalization in Bulgaria. The main objective of this study is to analyze some of the opportunities that AI offers for increasing the efficiency and quality of electronic administrative services at the local level. The study focuses on Bulgarian municipalities and examines practical applications of AI technologies, such as automated document processing, automatic response generation, and improved citizen services. The methodology combines empirical observation of municipal activities with a review of best practices and available AI tools. The analysis identifies several benefits, including faster document processing and reduced administrative workload. It also addresses challenges such as lack of expertise, data integration issues, and the need for regulatory adaptation. The results demonstrate that the use of AI tools can significantly streamline many administrative processes and enhance interaction with citizens. The novelty of the study lies in its specific focus on Bulgarian municipalities and its exploration of AI as a tool for the modernization of local public administration.

title: Real-Time FPGA-Based Wideband Signal Generator for Surface Movement Radar Applications
authors: Osman Büyükkağnıcı, İhsan Çiçek
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Surface Movement Radar plays a vital role in modern airports by enabling the detection of aircraft and ground vehicles with high precision. This paper presents the design and implementation of a real-time FPGA-based wideband signal generator tailored for SMR applications. Unlike conventional methods that rely on pre-generated digital waveforms or expensive RFSoC platforms, the proposed design generates continuous-wave and chirp signals directly within the FPGA, ensuring flexibility, cost efficiency, and portability. A custom hardware architecture composed of Direct Digital Synthesis modules, an SMR chirp generator, and a JESD-compatible high-speed DAC interface was implemented on a ZCU102 FPGA platform. The generator successfully produced 40 ns short CW pulses and 4 μs LFM chirp pulses within a complete PRI structure, achieving up to 50 MHz instantaneous bandwidth at 1 GSPS DAC output with only ~11% LUT, 10% FF, 30% BRAM utilization, and ~3.9 W power consumption. Experimental results confirm the feasibility of real-time SMR waveform generation, providing an accessible alternative to costly RFSoC or SDR-based solutions for both research and operational radar systems.

title: AID-UPF: An AI-Enabled Distributed User Plane Framework for Emotion-Aware 6G Networks
authors: Viktor Stoynov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Sixth-generation (6G) mobile networks are expected to shift from throughput-centric provisioning to human-centric service delivery, where the network continuously adapts to each user’s situation. A promising yet unexplored dimension of this vision is emotion-aware networking—the ability of the infrastructure to sense a user’s emotional state and adjust user plane behavior in real time. This paper introduces the first Artificial-Intelligence-enabled Distributed User Plane Function (AID-UPF) framework that embeds multimodal emotion recognition directly into the 5G/6G user plane. Each edge-deployed UPF hosts a lightweight inference engine that tags active flows with the user’s current emotion, enabling per-packet QoS, dynamic routing, and adaptive scheduling policies that reflect instantaneous user sentiment. An AID-UPF orchestrator coordinates model distribution and state synchronization across a multi-tier UPF mesh while preserving privacy through federated learning and on-device preprocessing. Potential applications—such as emotion-sensitive healthcare, adaptive learning, and stress-aware mobility—suggest how such architectures could personalize service delivery and improve user alignment. By embedding emotional intelligence into distributed packet handling, the AID-UPF framework sets the stage for truly human-centric 6G networks.

title: Model based design methodology using Youla parametrization for fractional order controllers implementation
authors: Hanna Aboukheir
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: One of the main reasons for the difficult $\mathbf{t}$ ask of turning theoretical control algorithms into real controllers is the implementation process. In this paper, it is proposed to build a single-input single-output fractional controller using a modelbased methodology, starting from the design of the controller using Youla parametrization, later, validating the design through simulations with a well-known process and then coding and deploying into an Arduino board, allowing not only the validation of a real controller but also testing the performance against different operating conditions without exposing a real process on costly experiments.

title: Beef Freshness Detection Tool Design using the Support Vector Machine (SVM) Method
authors: Diana Rahmawati, Ahmad Irwandani, Monika Faswia Fahmi, Achmad Zain Nur, Puteri Nurul Ma’Rifah, Dian Neipa Purnamasari
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Beef freshness is a critical determinant of food safety and consumer health. Conventional evaluation methods such as visual inspection and manual handling are subjective and unreliable, while laboratory tests are destructive and timeconsuming. This study proposes a non-destructive beef freshness detection system integrating a webcam, a load cell sensor, and an MQ-137 gas sensor with Support Vector Machine (SVM) classification. Feature extraction employed HSV color values, Local Binary Pattern (LBP) texture features, and ammonia gas concentration. A dataset of 90 samples, divided equally into fresh, not fresh, and rotten classes, was collected from traditional markets under real conditions. Experimental results show that using webcam features alone achieved $84 \%$ accuracy, while combining webcam and MQ-137 sensor data improved accuracy to $87 \%$. A confusion matrix and classification report further validate the model’s performance. This work demonstrates the potential of combining vision and gas sensing with machine learning for low-cost, real-time beef freshness monitoring in practical market environments.

title: Comparative Study of Human Gait Using 2D Video-Based Motion Analysis
authors: Axel A. Balboa, Brayam J. Lazares, Dhiago G. Llanos, Mateo P. Muñoz, Keila S. Villavicencio, Victoria E. Abarca, Ana C. Villa-Parra
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study analyzes lower-limb joint kinematics during gait in five university students, using video-based motion capture with Kinovea. Reflective markers were placed on anatomical landmarks, and joint angles of the hip, knee, and ankle were extracted across the gait cycle. Spatiotemporal parameters and anthropometric measurements were also collected. Results revealed that morphological differences-such as limb length, pelvic width, and body mass-directly influenced gait strategies. The findings highlight the feasibility of low-cost tools for biomechanical assessment in diverse populations.

title: Comparative study of hand-gesture recognition (HGR) models using EMG signals with a focus on intrapersonal variation
authors: Luis Gabriel Macías Santillán, Jhonattan Steven Amagua Taco, Christian Gabriel Nazate Tapia, Lorena Isabel Barona López, Marco E. Benalcázar, Ángel Leonardo Valdivieso Caraguay
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Human intrapersonal variation in hand gesture recognition (HGR) using electromyography (EMG) signals raises concerns about the recognition accuracy of HGR machine learning models. This article presents the results obtained after the evaluation of five machine learning models: SVM, KNN, ANN, CNN, and CNN-LSTM using EMG signal data corresponding to five hand gestures performed by 20 participants over a period of four consecutive months. The models were trained with data from the first month and subsequently tested with data from the following months to analyze the impact of intrapersonal variation on the performance of these models.

title: Electronic Control Unit Design for BLDC and EPS Motor Control
authors: Riza Alfita, Achmad Tegar Lukmantiar, Deni Tri Laksono, Muhhammad Iyan Putra Pratama, Achmad Fiqhi Ibadillah, Puteri Nurul Ma’Rifah
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: In electric cars, the prime mover uses a 10 KW Golden Motor HPM BLDC motor controlled by an EZ motor controller. This research focuses on the prime mover and the Electric Power Steering (EPS) motor system. The input for controlling the $\mathbf{1 0 ~ K W}$ HPM BLDC motor comes from the gas throttle signal, while the EPS motor receives input data from the torque sensor. The STM32H723VGT6TR functions as the central processing unit in the ECU, which is responsible for processing all control data. The motor controller processes data originating from the BLDC motor and then forwards it to the ECU. At the same time, the EPS module processes data from the EPS motor, and the entire system is monitored via CAN bus communication. Speed testing was carried out with variations in throttle pressure of $30 \%, 50 \%$, and 100%. The test results showed that the maximum speeds without load and with 30% throttle pressure were $2.49 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$ and $17.52 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$, respectively. At 50% throttle, the maximum speed without a load is $11.35 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$, while with a load it reaches $24.62 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. At 100% throttle, the maximum speed without a load is recorded at $28.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$, and with a load, it remains at $24.62 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. The PID parameter settings on the EPS that provide the best response, both under no-load and loaded conditions, are with values of $\mathrm{P}=0.5, \mathrm{I}=0.02$, and $\mathrm{D}=0.1$.

title: Delay Effects in Stability Augmentation System of Aircraft Longitudinal Dynamics: A Case Study on Boeing 747
authors: S. Mert Özer
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study investigates the delay effects in the stability augmentation system (SAS) of an aircraft longitudinal dynamics using the Boeing 747 as a representative case. The SAS plays a crucial role in enhancing the inherent dynamic stability and handling qualities of the aircraft by providing automatic feedback that improves damping and response characteristics. It effectively suppresses oscillatory motion, particularly the short-period and phugoid modes, ensuring smooth pitch attitude control, and improved overall flight performance, efficiency, and passenger comfort. In practical flight control systems, however, feedback delay is unavoidable and may arise from multiple sources, including sensor dynamics, signal transmission, actuator lag, and digital computation time. Even small delays can significantly affect closed-loop stability and degrade flying qualities. To investigate this effect, a linearized state-space model of the Boeing 747 is developed, and a SAS is designed under nominal, delay-free conditions. The stability of the delayed system is then examined by analyzing the variation in the real and imaginary parts of the dominant roots with respect to the feedback delay. For the first time, it is shown that the feedback delay has a pronounced effect on the short-period mode, causing reduced damping and slower transient response, whereas the phugoid mode remains almost insensitive to delay variations. These observations are confirmed through detailed numerical simulations conducted on the Boeing 747 longitudinal model, which validate the analytical findings and quantify the extent of delay-induced degradation. The results highlight the importance of incorporating delay-aware stability analysis into the design and certification process of modern flight control systems. The findings provide new insight into the sensitivity of longitudinal dynamics to delay, offering a foundation for the development of robust and delay-tolerant augmentation systems.

title: Analysis of EM Side-Channel Leakage on an RO-PUF and Proposed Countermeasures
authors: Alejandro Casado-Galán, Santiago Sánchez-Solano, Erica Tena-Sánchez, Luis F. Rojas-Muñoz, Francisco Eugenio Potestad-Ordóñez, Macarena C. Martínez-Rodríguez, Antonio J. Acosta-Jiménez
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) are a very useful resource in cryptography with many applications ranging from system authentication to secret key generation. Side-channel attacks (SCAs) are a major concern in any physical implementation of a cryptographic module, and PUFs are no exception. Electromagnetic (EM) leakage from the implementation of a ring-oscillator-based PUF (RO-PUF) can be exploited to retrieve sensitive information that compromises the security of the cryptographic scheme incorporating the PUF. In this paper, we analyse the EM leakage of an RO-PUF implemented on FPGA, highlight its main vulnerabilities, and propose alternative countermeasures and architectures to mitigate the threat of this type of attack. Furthermore, we evaluate the cost in terms of area overhead of the proposed implementations compared to the original design.

title: Towards Secure BPF Kernel Extension with Hardware-enhanced Memory Isolation
authors: Lijian Huang, Hongyi Lu, Shuai Wang, Fengwei Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: The Linux kernel extensively uses the Berkeley Packet Filter (BPF) to allow user-written BPF applications to execute in the kernel space. The BPF employs a verifier to check the security of user-supplied BPF code statically. Recent attacks show that BPF programs can evade security checks and gain unauthorized access to kernel memory, indicating that the verification process is not flawless. In this paper, we present MOAT, a novel hardware-assisted, cross-platform isolation framework designed to protect the kernel from malicious BPF programs. MOAT introduces a two-layer memory isolation scheme that leverages hardware features such as Intel MPK and Arm Stage-2 translation to enforce isolation. Our design overcomes several key challenges, including the limited scalability of available hardware isolation mechanisms and the risk of helper function abuse. We implement MOAT for Intel x86 and Arm on Linux (ver. 6.1.38), and our evaluation shows that MOAT delivers low-cost isolation of BPF programs under mainstream use cases, such as isolating a BPF packet filter with only 3% throughput loss.

title: Multi-UAV Cooperative Navigation Based on Multi-Source Information Fusion: A Review
authors: Fujun Song, Qinghua Zeng, Rui Zhang, Xiaohu Zhu, Xiaoyu Ye, Zongyu Zhang
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarms are increasingly deployed in both civilian and military domains, where high-precision navigation in GNSS-denied environments remains a critical challenge. Cooperative navigation has emerged as a promising paradigm by leveraging inter-vehicle information exchange and multi-source information fusion to enhance swarm navigation performance. Although numerous surveys have summarized multi-sensor integration and state estimation methods for single-platform UAVs, comprehensive reviews dedicated to cooperative navigation remain limited. This paper presents a structured framework for cooperative navigation that integrates multi-source information acquisition, cooperative localization techniques in GNSS-denied environments, and multi-source fusion algorithms. On this basis, we provide a systematic review of cooperative navigation from three perspectives: relative measurement information, cooperative navigation architectures, and swarm cooperative optimization algorithms. Furthermore, fusion algorithms are categorized into four classes, namely mathematically derived, graph-based, filtering-based, and learning-based approaches, with their development trends systematically analyzed. The synergistic features of multi-source information are then discussed, with emphasis on information selection, fault tolerance, and resilient fusion. Finally, the hierarchical structure of multi-source information fusion is highlighted, revealing the evolutionary trend from feature-level toward decision-level strategies. This survey aims to present a holistic understanding of UAV cooperative navigation, outline key technical challenges, and shed light on future research directions in this rapidly evolving field.

title: Improper Gaussian Signaling for Uplink NOMA Systems With Finite Blocklength Codes Under Imperfect SIC
authors: Ding Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: The ultra-low latency requirements of emerging Internet of Things (IoT) applications necessitate data transmission in the finite blocklength (FBL) regime, while non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) enables massive connectivity. However, the practical imperfection of successive interference cancellation (SIC), a key component of NOMA, can significantly degrade system performance. This paper proposes the use of improper Gaussian signaling (IGS) to mitigate interference caused by imperfect SIC in an uplink NOMA system operating in the FBL regime. Specifically, users are grouped into pairs to form NOMA groups, where IGS is applied at the strong user in each pair to suppress residual interference. A minimum effective-throughput maximization problem is formulated by jointly optimizing user grouping, blocklength allocation, power allocation, IGS circularity coefficient, and decoding error probability. To address the resulting non-convex and mixed-integer nonlinear programming problem, we develop an efficient algorithm that achieves a high-quality suboptimal solution. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme with IGS-FBL outperforms various benchmark schemes, especially under severe imperfect SIC and stringent decoding error probability requirement conditions. Particularly, at a maximum decoding error probability of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−4</sup>, the proposed scheme with IGS-FBL achieves the minimum effective-throughput that is 14.1×, 38.0×, and 98.8× greater than the benchmark schemes employing IGS-infinite blocklength (IGS-IFBL), proper Gaussian signaling-FBL (PGS-FBL), and PGS-IFBL, respectively.

title: UAV-Enabled Aerial Monitoring Aided by STAR-RIS: A Stochastic Optimization Framework
authors: Cheng Zhan, Lu Hu, Kaifeng Song, Rongfei Fan, Han Hu, Jie Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: This paper studies the unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-enabled aerial monitoring assisted by simultaneous transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (STAR-RISs), in which one UAV aims to monitor a number of moving targets, and one STAR-RIS is installed on a building for assisting the UAV to broadcast the monitored information to both indoor and outdoor users. Due to the randomness of target movements over time, the UAV needs to adaptively adjust its flight trajectory to track them. This thus results in highly dynamic channel conditions and uncertain UAV energy consumption, which accordingly make the efficient aerial monitoring a challenging task. To address these challenges, we propose a STAR-RIS-aided UAV-enabled aerial monitoring framework, which aims to maximize the long-term average throughput for all users, through joint optimization of transmit beamforming, UAV trajectory, and STAR-RIS configuration, while ensuring the monitoring requirements under strict energy constraints. The formulated problem is a multi-stage stochastic optimization problem, due to the randomness of various system parameters. To handle this problem, we apply the Lyapunov optimization technique and introduce a virtual energy queue to transform it into a series of single-slot optimization subproblems that are solvable online. For each subproblem, we develop efficient algorithms to obtain a near-optimal solution, in which a penalty dual decomposition (PDD) approach is used for the transmit beamforming and STAR-RIS configuration optimization, and a sequential parametric convex approximation (SPCA) method is used for UAV trajectory optimization. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly outperforms benchmark schemes, effectively maximizing the throughput and energy efficiency under dynamic operational conditions.

title: Dual-Polarized Antenna with Flexible Pattern Steering Based on Digital Meta-surface for Satellite-Assisted Mobile Communication
authors: Guangwei Yang, Gang Jiang, Yiwei Zhang, Yihan Ma, Lei Wang, Zijian Xing, Dimitra Psychogiou, Ling Wang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: To address the practical challenges of satellite-assisted mobile communication for Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices—such as the needs for low-profile antennas, wide-angle beam steering under strict size and power constraints, and the limited tuning flexibility of conventional reconfigurable structures—this work proposes a compact dual-polarized antenna with digitally controlled pattern steering. The method combines mirror-image theory with transmission-optics-based phase regulation, enabling beam steering through a reconfigurable digital meta-surface that replaces the conventional ground plane. A planar dual-polarized dipole is positioned above the meta-surface, and beam steering is achieved by digitally switching the PIN-diode states to alter the discrete reflection-phase distribution. The prototype, fabricated and characterized at 12–14 GHz, demonstrates wide-angle beam steering with stable gain, low cross-polarization, and FPGA-based real-time digital control. The proposed approach provides a compact and energy-efficient solution for next-generation satellite-assisted IoT terminals requiring flexible and robust beam steering.

title: Video Face Super-Resolution with High-Precision Identity Preservation
authors: Chaoliang Wu, Ting Zhang, Xianbin Zhang, Nian He, Yiwen Xu
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: As an emerging technology, Video Face Super-Resolution (VFSR) aims to reconstruct high-resolution facial images from low-quality video sequences while maintaining identity consistency, which makes it applicable to scenarios such as surveillance, video conferencing, and film restoration. Compared with image-based face restoration and general video super-resolution, VFSR is more challenging because it requires accurate facial detail reconstruction, strict identity preservation, and computational efficiency under varying poses and expressions. To address these challenges, we propose a High-Precision Identity Preserving VFSR framework (HPIP), which integrates a Multi-Scale Prediction Module (MPM) and an Identity Preservation Module (IPM). The MPM focuses on identity-critical facial regions (e.g., eyes, nose, and mouth) and leverages multi-scale feature prediction to improve reconstruction accuracy and robustness while maintaining computational efficiency. The IPM further projects features into a latent representation space, generating temporally consistent dictionary features and enhancing temporal coherence. Extensive experiments demonstrate that HPIP achieves superior performance in both qualitative and quantitative evaluations, producing visually pleasing facial details while maintaining an efficient and lightweight design.

title: Applicability Analysis of InSAR Tropospheric Delay Correction for Landslide Monitoring Considering Periodicity Characteristics-Case Study on Southwest Mountainous Region
authors: Li Zhang, Daqing Ge, Jie Dong, Xiangxing Wan, Bin Liu, Lu Zhang, Yangyang Chen, Yu Wang, Gaoyun Shen
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Tropospheric delay is a major limitation in Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) for measuring landslide deformation. It exhibits complex spatial-temporal variability, stochastic behavior, and is particularly difficult to model in the mountainous areas of southwest China, where terrain is highly heterogeneous. Accurate estimation of tropospheric delay is therefore critical for improving the precision of InSAR-based landslide monitoring. In this study, we propose a tropospheric delay correction method that explicitly accounts for its periodic characteristics and evaluate its applicability in landslide monitoring across the mountainous regions of southwest China. By analyzing the temporal characteristics of tropospheric delay, we examine its periodic properties and construct a model that combines periodic and stochastic properties to estimate the delay. The method is applied to Sentinel-1 time-series InSAR data in southwestern mountainous study areas, with performance assessed at the levels of interferograms, linear deformation rates, and time-series. Results show that, in both study areas, more than 98% of single-master interferograms exhibit a reduced standard deviation (std), with average reductions exceeding 40% and maximum improvements surpassing 80% in interferometric phase std. These findings demonstrates that the proposed temporal tropospheric delay correction method effectively accounts for both time-related and stochastic components of tropospheric delay, substantially mitigating its impact spatially and temporally. Consequently, this approach significantly enhances the accuracy and reliability of InSAR-based landslide monitoring.

title: Federated Blockchain-Based Resilient Identity Management for Securing Consumer Vehicular Networks
authors: Sandeep Srivastava, Deepshikha Agarwal, Brijesh Kumar Chaurasia, Vishal Krishna Singh, Rajkumar Singh Rathore, Weiwei Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Connected vehicles rely heavily on mobile vehicular networks and centralized cloud infrastructures for data handling. These networks contain not only environmental information but also sensitive data such as passenger identities, routes, origins, and destinations, making them prone to various cyber threats. Existing authentication mechanisms are predominantly centralized and cloud-based, which introduces significant vulnerabilities, including high latency, single points of failure, and exposure to denial-of-service attacks, man-in-the-middle intrusions, and data breaches. Moreover, the real-time nature of vehicular data sharing exacerbates these risks. Conventional centralized architectures typically depend on a single trusted authority for vehicle authentication and data integrity validation, which further increases susceptibility to unauthorized access, data tampering, and system disruption. To address these limitations, this work proposes a novel distributed blockchain-based authentication mechanism for Internet of Vehicles and autonomous vehicles. The proposed approach leverages decentralized identifiers and verifiable credentials to securely authenticate vehicles within a decentralized network. Extensive experimental evaluations assess the system’s performance across multiple parameters, including latency, trust, and resilience to attacks. Comparative analysis demonstrates a significant improvement in trustworthiness and authenticity, validating the effectiveness of the proposed method.
