title: Assessing the Feasibility of Robotic Systems for Measuring Internal Corrosion Using SWOT Analysis
authors: Petar Todorov, Teodora Hristova, Grigor Mihaylov, Luchezar Georgiev, Martin Boyadjiev, Katerina Gabrovska-Evstatieva
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The problem of internal corrosion in underground pipelines and the problems that cause their failures are considered. It has been established that timely monitoring of their condition is part of the measures to ensure trouble-free operation. The article provides a detailed analysis of the methods of measuring internal corrosion. With the development of technology, it is seen that the use of robots with ultrasonic, magnetoelectric, eddy currents, Lidar, and others offers a profitable alternative. Mechanisms for movement, power supply, control, and data processing are also being developed. To facilitate the analysis for the selection of a suitable robot by non-technical persons, a SWOT analysis is proposed. It can be applied to select a suitable measurement method according to criteria such as the pipeline design, expected narrowings, bends, legal basis, level of personnel competence, and others).

title: Methods of Industrial Control Applied in a Door Lock Assembling Machine
authors: Iliyan Iliev, Desislava Mihaylova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The paper presents the design and structural features of an automated lock assembly machine using a PLC control unit, robotic arms and PC-based supervision system. The implementation of advanced techniques in manufacturing processes is observed in the aspect of combining novel technical means and approaches. The main goal to increase the quality of the assembled details is achieved through the application of modern industrial equipment and modeling concepts.

title: Towards Trustworthy AI-Assisted Software Development
authors: Ebtesam Al Haque
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: AI assistants have become ubiquitous in software development, yet there are several challenges that remain to be addressed, undermining trust in these tools, thereby hindering effective human-AI collaboration. Using the PICSE framework, I identify areas of concern and propose addressing them through automated prompt decomposition to improve interaction paradigms and dynamic benchmarking to systematically evaluate AI-generated code reliability.

title: Evaluation of Mechanical Properties of Asphalt Mixtures Using Walnut Shell Ash and Recycled Asphalt Pavement
authors: Michelle Viteri, Diego Chérrez, AlexLópez, Jorge Guevara
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The growing demand for sustainable road infrastructure has driven the search for alternative materials and innovative techniques in road construction. This study evaluates the mechanical properties of asphalt mixtures modified with walnut shell ash (WSA) and recycled asphalt pavement (RAP). Laboratory tests were conducted to determine resistance, durability, and behavior under different loading conditions using the Marshall method. Three different percentages of WSA $(7 \%, 10 \%$, and $13 \%)$ and RAP ($10 \%, 20 \%$, and 30%) were incorporated into conventional asphalt mixtures with asphalt cement contents of $5.5 \%, 6.0 \%$, and $6.5 \%$. The results show that the addition of these alternative materials can improve certain asphalt properties, contributing to sustainability in road construction despite a marginal cost increase of ${\$} 16.79$ per $\mathbf{m}^3$. The modified mixture with $7 \%$ WSA and $10 \%$ RAP at $6.5 \%$ asphalt content achieved the best performance with a stability of 3803 lb and flow of 13.87 hundredths of an inch, meeting Marshall criteria. The implementation cost analysis shows an increase of ${\$} 16.79$ per $\mathbf{m}^{\mathbf{3}}$ compared to conventional mixtures, offset by environmental benefits and waste utilization. This work demonstrates the technical feasibility of incorporating agricultural waste and recycled materials in asphalt mixtures, promoting sustainable road construction practices.

title: Improving Reliability and Latency in FANETs Using Machine Learning
authors: Patricio J. Mendoza-N´u˜Nez, Leticia Lemus-Cárdenas, Juan Pablo Astudillo-León
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Ensuring reliable and low-latency communication in Flying Ad Hoc Networks (FANETs) is crucial for smart mobility applications and critical operations in smart cities, where communication failures can have severe consequences. This paper presents a machine learning approach to enhance FANET performance by predicting network conditions and optimizing packet delivery. We constructed a comprehensive dataset using BonnMotion to simulate UAV mobility and ns-3 to emulate network communications, capturing features such as channel busy ratio and queue lengths. Addressing class imbalance with SMOTE and conducting exploratory data analysis, we trained a CatBoost model and integrated it into ns-3 via ns3-ai for real-time operation. Compared to baseline and traditional EDCA methods, our approach increased the Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR) from below $15 \%$ to approximately $80 \%$, while reducing end-to-end delay from over 0.45 s to around 0.19 s. These substantial gains demonstrate that integrating machine learning into FANETs can significantly i mprove $\mathbf{r}$ eliability a nd $\mathbf{r}$ esponsiveness, supporting the stringent requirements of smart mobility and smart city infrastructures.

title: Opportunities for using Combined Energy Production from Livestock Manure and Running Water Energy in Bulgaria
authors: Rositsa Velichkova, Iskra Simova, Angel Aleksandrov, Rangel Sharkov, Aleksandar Stanilov, Milka Uzunova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study presents the design and performance evaluation of a hybrid renewable energy system integrating biomass and hydro turbine technologies for sustainable power generation. The integrated system aims to utilize the continuous water flow of hydro turbines together with the controllable and dispatchable nature of biomass energy to provide a reliable and balanced energy supply, especially in rural or off-grid areas. Results from the theoretical assessment of the proposed combined system demonstrate improved energy reliability, reduced carbon emissions, and enhanced system efficiency compared to standalone renewable sources. The hybrid approach emphasizes the potential of multi-source renewable systems in addressing energy security and environmental sustainability challenges.

title: Tomato Leaf Disease Detection: A Comparative Study using Deep Convolutional Networks and Vision Transformer
authors: Mayté Brusil, Roberto Andrade, Felipe Grijalva
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The detection of plant diseases is crucial for mitigating economic losses and enhancing agricultural productivity. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have proven highly effective in automating plant disease identification from images of leaves, fruits, and stems. Traditional CNN architectures, such as AlexNet, Inception, ResNet, DenseNet, and EfficientNet, have demonstrated high accuracy in plant disease classification tasks. Recent advancements, including Vision Transformers and lightweight architectures for IoT applications, have further expanded classification capabilities. In this study, we e valuate the performance of three deep CNN architectures, EfficientNet B0, InceptionV3, and ViT b16 in classifying plant diseases. We employ transfer learning to leverage pre-trained models, optimizing computational efficiency while p reserving l earned f eatures. Our evaluation focuses on identifying the trade-off between model size and classification accuracy, aiming to determine the most suitable architecture for mobile and resource-constrained environments. Results indicate that EfficientNet B0 offers a more compact and efficient solution while maintaining high accuracy, making it a promising choice for real-world agricultural applications.

title: Study of Total Cost of Ownership of Variable Frequency Drives
authors: Navid Binesh, Samantha Grosz, Ryan Romney, Jose Simpson
publish: 2023 IEEE-IAS/PCA Cement Industry Conference (IAS/PCA)
abstract: Nowadays, variable frequency drives (VFDs) are ubiquitous in every heavy industry. The cement industry was one of the pioneering industries to adopt variable frequency drives and realize efficiency and productivity gains from their use. Advanced and complex equipment including fans, conveyors, crushers, and kilns benefit from the addition of VFDs inside the modernized concrete plant.The total cost of ownership (TCO) of a variable frequency drive depends on several factors. While the initial cost of equipment (capital expense) may play a key role in selecting the equipment, neglecting the life-cycle cost (operating expense) may result in netfinancial loss. The TCO of a drive is determined by factors including, but not limited to, the initial cost of equipment, installation cost, cost of cabling, initial cost of cooling system, energy costs, operating cost of cooling system, and cost of maintenance. Additionally, the financial savings associated with drives must be accounted for in the complete TCO analysis. Topics such as energy savings, reduction of emissions, reduction in repair/maintenance costs of mechanical systems, motor reliability improvements, process enhancements, electrical system impacts, and reliability improvements will be discussed.Finally, this paper details the several types of maintenance (reactive vs. proactive) and investigates the impact of utilization of condition monitoring systems on reduction of downtime and total cost of ownership.

title: The Challenge of Deploying Fixed Broadband Infrastructure in Ecuador: Regulation and Operational Costs
authors: Miguel Veliz, C. D. Altamirano, Fernando Lara
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In Ecuador, the development of fixed broadband networks is driven by the expansion of physical infrastructure such as fiber optics, which requires the support of poles for aerial deployment and ducts for underground installations. This paper analyzes Ecuadorian regulations that govern and determine leasing fees for the use of passive infrastructure, through a review and analysis of applicable legislation related to ducts and poles, including norms issued by relevant governmental entities. The analysis identifies the existence of two regulatory frameworks-one from the electricity sector and another from the telecommunications sector-which assign different rates to the use of poles. This duality creates ambiguity for telecommunications service providers and affects the provision of fixed broadband services. The current situation also reflects Ecuador’s relatively low position in international indices concerning regulatory environment and quality.

title: Application of machine learning methods for the prediction level of development in supply chain
authors: Douglas Andrés Verduga-Alcívar, Emanuel Guillermo Muñoz-Muñoz, Neyfe Sablón-Cossío, Ana Julia Acevedo-Urquiaga, Víctor Ernesto Márquez-Pérez, José Arturo Garza-Reyes
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study seeks to apply three machine learning methods to predict the level of development in supply chains, using case studies in Ecuador. The three machine learning techniques used in this research are support vector regression, neural networks, and Bayesian networks. The study data are obtained from the application of a reference model for supply chains, consisting of 15 variables and 120 items. Based on these results, and based on a quantitative analysis and a procedure for applying three machine learning methods, the data analysis was correlated, the importance of the variables was identified, the most relevant ones were selected, the level of development was predicted, and the performance of the methods was evaluated. The study’s findings imply that these machine learning methods could be valuable tools for decision-making and optimization in supply chain management. By implementing the models, it was demonstrated that the optimization function of each allows parameters to be adjusted to improve their predictive capacity. As a result, a high regression coefficient was obtained with all three methods.

title: Noise level analysis using I-SIMPA Simulation: A case study in the Hotel Operations Laboratory, Universitas Multimedia Nusantara, Indonesia
authors: Fahmy Rinanda Saputri, Nicholas Robert, Vanesa Lorent, Muhammad Salehuddin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: This study investigates noise levels in the laboratory of the Hotel Operations Department at Universitas Multimedia Nusantara, Indonesia, using on-site measurements and I-SIMPA software simulations. The primary objective is to address noise disturbances that impact activities in the laboratory and propose effective solutions. Noise level measurements revealed that several areas exceeded the Indonesian Minister of Environment Decree No. 48 of 1996 standard of 55 dB for educational facilities. Simulations identified the highest noise level, 72 dB, in the pastry room near a pipe system, the main noise source. Other affected areas included the bakery room, kitchen, storage spaces, and serving areas, with levels ranging from 58 dB to 68 dB. To mitigate these issues, the study recommends installing sound-absorbing barriers, using noise-dampening covers for equipment, and providing ear protection for personnel. These findings provide actionable insights to enhance acoustic comfort and create a conducive learning environment within educational laboratories.

title: Pedestrian Wind Environment in Urban Fabrics: Field Measurements, CFD Modeling, and Mitigation Measures
authors: Nikita Dobin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper integrates two complementary studies of the pedestrian wind environment in cities: (a) field measurements and CFD modeling to evaluate conditions at pedestrian height in a typical high-rise district and on a university campus; (b) a critical review and verification of the effectiveness of architectural, landscape and engineering mitigation measures for adverse wind effects. The modeling was carried out in ANSYS Fluent using steady-state RANS (SIMPLE, second-order spatial discretization) with the k–ω SST turbulence model and a consistent atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) implementation: a logarithmic inflow velocity profile and compatible turbulence quantities (u*, z0, k, ω) were generated via a user.prof file. Preservation of the ABL was verified in an “empty” domain of the same height. Comparison with field data (mean velocities at ≈1.75–1.8 m above ground) shows that proper ABL specification is critical for credible near-ground speeds; without ABL, pronounced systematic errors occur. In the mitigation part, we investigate rounded/chamfered high-rise edges (reducing mean speeds in the leeward near-ground zone by roughly 20%) and evergreen tree belts modeled as porous media (achieving a twofold reduction of the mean speed at a control point). The results are interpreted through mechanism-based reasoning (downwash, corner acceleration, channeling) and the frameworks of Lawson’s criteria and the Dutch standard NEN 8100. A practical workflow is proposed for municipal wind microclimate screening at early design stages.

title: A Review of Deep Metric Learning Methods in Disease Detection on Medical Images
authors: M. Aldiki Febriantono, Mahmud Isnan, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Deep learning has various algorithms that can be used for disease diagnosis, where each algorithm has its own advantages and disadvantages. The main challenge is to determine the most appropriate algorithm to produce an accurate diagnosis. One approach that can improve diagnostic accuracy is deep metric learning, which is applied to analyze medical images efficiently. This review aims to analyze various deep learning algorithms and deep metric learning methods in detecting disease in medical images. This methodology uses PRISMA as a framework for the systematic study search and selection process. Literature obtained from the Scopus and IEEE Xplore databases, includes papers published between 2019 and 2024, with a focus on medical image classification using a deep metric learning approach. From the search results, 442 studies were found, and 12 of them met the inclusion criteria for further review. This research not only focuses on algorithm selection, but also analyzes classification metrics used to evaluate model performance in various diagnosis tasks. The study reveals that dice scores and contrastive learning are popular learning metrics to improve model performance. Additionally, instead of just using accuracy, the model is evaluated using specificity and sensitivity metrics, providing a deeper understanding of its effectiveness.

title: Near Field Focusing to Assist Emerging Networking, Tracking and Sensing Technologies
authors: Nikolaos Karkanis, Andreas Giannakoulas, George Kyriacou, Theodoros Kaifas
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Emerging networking, tracking and sensing technologies via wireless communications near or across media boundaries, such as the water-air interface, presents profound challenges due to wave refraction, reflection, and impedance mismatch. This paper investigates the feasibility of direct electromagnetic (EM) links for cross-medium communication, leveraging Unmanned Aerial and Underwater Vehicles (UA(U)Vs) as mobile nodes. We present a simulation study focusing on optimizing the excitation of antenna arrays to enhance signal strength at a receiver located near or across a medium boundary. The performance is evaluated using the Rayleigh Quotient method to maximize the signal at the target receiver by controlling the amplitude and phase of array elements. Scenarios include arrays above and below a dielectric half-space (modeling land/sea) and the water-air interface. The results demonstrate that strategic array excitation can significantly enhance cross-medium link reliability by focusing energy across and/ or through the boundary. These findings underscore the potential of optimized EM systems, rather than traditional acoustics, for short-range, high-data-rate cross-medium links, with UAVs and UUVs acting as intelligent, adaptive transceivers.

title: The Agentic Brand: How Autonomous AI is Reshaping Sentiment, Strategy, and Consumer Engagement
authors: Sriram Panyam, Ram Joshi, Praveen Gujar, Gunjan Paliwal
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper examines the transformative impact of autonomous Artificial Intelligence (AI) agents on contemporary brand management. Moving beyond traditional automation, these agents introduce a paradigm shift from retrospective analysis to prospective, simulation-based strategy. We first analyze the evolution of sentiment analysis, detailing how psychographically-grounded AI agents enable predictive modeling of consumer sentiment with high fidelity, allowing brands to pre-emptively manage perception. Second, we explore how these real-time insights facilitate dynamic brand messaging and agile strategy adaptation. Third, the paper investigates the application of AI agents in driving hyper-personalized consumer engagement and conversion, analyzing their quantifiable impact on marketing ROI and customer loyalty. Fourth, we provide a concise overview of the modular architecture that underpins these intelligent systems. Finally, we conduct a critical analysis of the profound ethical challenges, including algorithmic bias, data privacy, and the need for new governance frameworks. We conclude that while AI agents offer unprecedented capabilities for brand optimization, their effective and responsible deployment requires a renewed focus on human-centric strategy, ethical oversight, and brand authenticity.

title: The teaching of physics from cinema: an epistemological proposal with the film Interstellar
authors: Cristián Londoño Proaño
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This article explores the potential of science fiction cinema, specifically Christopher Nolan’s film Interstellar, as a didactic resource for the teaching of physics and the development of scientific thinking. The main objective is to design a theoretically based didactic proposal that allows teaching both specific content and the epistemological dimension of scientific knowledge. It has a qualitative methodology, based on a content analysis, focused on selected scenes from the film, organized into three categories: representation of scientific knowledge, relationship between science and society, and implicit epistemology. The results show that Interstellar allows complex concepts to be represented in an accessible and critical way, as well as to generate spaces for reflection on the nature and limits of scientific knowledge. It is concluded that the systematic use of cinema in the classroom favors interdisciplinary learning, fosters critical scientific literacy and opens new possibilities for a more contextualized, reflective and formative teaching of physics. Keywords-science fiction, technologies, science, picture, engineering education, movies.

title: A Battery Swapping Scheduling System for Electric Motorcycle Ride-Hailing Drivers using Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search
authors: Iskandar Muda Rizky Parlambang, I Gusti Bagus Baskara Nugraha, Arry Akhmad Arman
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Electric vehicles have emerged as an environmentally friendly solution and have begun to be adopted by motorcycle ride-hailing services. However, the operation of electric motorcycle ride-hailing services often faces challenges such as long queues at battery swap stations during peak hours, lengthy charging times, uncertainty in battery availability, and inconsistent battery quality. These conditions directly impact the operational profit of drivers. This study proposes a battery swapping scheduling system based on a Problem-Solving Agent to address these issues. The system is designed using a design thinking approach and the Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search (ALNS) algorithm to generate schedules based on operational conditions. The evaluation is conducted using a simulation based on SimPy with realistic configurations in the DKI Jakarta area. The results show that the system can effectively increase driver operational profit, reduce driver waiting time, and reduce the number of drivers waiting, compared to the case without the system.

title: Comparative Evaluation and Deployment of Machine Learning Models for Predicting Student Academic Performance
authors: Misia Callista Abdipatra, Rezki Yunanda
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: This study aims to improve the quality of education by building a machine learning model enhanced through hyperparameter tuning. The use of this hyperparameter tuning method is expected to increase the accuracy and f1-score value for each model, so the prediction results of student academic performance become more accurate and reliable but the prediction system does not only rely on the evaluation of classification metrics, but also provides an implementation approach through the integration on a web interface that practical for end user. The study also includes experiments comparing default and tuned SVM configurations, which show a significant performance improvement of 12.65% through hyperparameter optimization. The model with the best performance is used as the basis for a student academic performance prediction system that will be developed into a website interface using Streamlit. Through this combination of technical improvement and practical implementation, this study demonstrates how machine learning can be applied to improve educational insight in a way that is both effective and accessible.

title: Machine Learning-based Measurement Models: A novel methodology for GUM-based uncertainty evaluation
authors: Leopoldo Angrisani, Pasquale Arpaia, Sabatina Criscuolo, Mauro D’Arco, Egidio De Benedetto, Luigi Duraccio, Annarita Tedesco
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The continuous advancement of computational technologies has accelerated the use of data-driven methods across various domains, including metrology. Machine Learning (ML) models, in particular, have demonstrated significant potential to enhance measurement processes, establishing themselves as fully-fledged elements of modern metrology. However, in such ML-based measurements, the evaluation of measurement uncertainty requires additional considerations compared with the conventional approaches to measurement. The most widely adopted framework in metrology, i.e., the Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement (GUM), is based on the assumption that the measurand must be defined in such a way that definitional uncertainty is negligible compared to the other components of measurement uncertainty. In conventional practice, this is achieved by selecting an appropriate relationship between the measurand and a set of input quantities, referred to as the measurement model. In contrast, in ML-based measurements, this relationship is not explicitly chosen by the practitioner but rather inferred from data. Consequently, should adherence to the GUM framework be intended, it is necessary to verify the validity of the GUM assumption and take corrective actions where appropriate. Based on these considerations, this paper proposes a novel methodology that enables GUM-based uncertainty evaluation in ML-based measurements. The primary focus is on ML deterministic regression models, whose structure can be readily assimilated to measurement operations. The proposed methodology is applied to two representative case studies. The first case study involves an electric circuit for resistance measurement, where a comparison between ML-based approaches and a consolidated measurement model is provided to ensure consistency. The second case study concerns the estimation of the output power of a power plant, where no conventional measurement model is available. Overall, the proposed methodology enables proper integration of ML practices into the GUM framework, thus broadening the application domain of measurement processes.

title: Toward Unified Expertise: Learning a Single Vision Model from Diverse Perception_supp1-3647880.pdf
authors: Zitian Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Multi-task learning (MTL) presents greater optimization challenges than single-task learning (STL) due to conflicting gradients across tasks. While parameter sharing promotes cooperation among related tasks, many tasks require specialized representations. To balance cooperation and specialization, we propose Mod-Squad [1], a modular transformer-based model composed of a “squad” of experts. Each task activates a sparse subset of experts through a differentiable matching process, guided by a novel mutual information-based loss. This modular structure avoids full backbone sharing and scales effectively with the number of tasks and dataset size. In this extended version, we generalize Mod-Squad to support multi-dataset pre-training, enabling joint learning across disjoint, single-task datasets (e.g., ImageNet, COCO, ADE20K). This is achieved via a new formulation of the mutual information loss that unifies learning across heterogeneous sources. More importantly, while most prior work in large models has focused on efficiency, few have explored adjustable efficiency. In this study, we further evaluate the model's generalization to downstream tasks and introduce a set of efficient adaptation techniques that leverage Mod-Squad's modularity for flexible finetuning-enabling dynamic adjustment of model size, parameter count, and computational cost. Additionally, we present a hybrid adaptation scheme that combines these techniques to achieve favorable performance-efficiency trade-offs. In summary, Mod-Squad provides a robust foundation for sparse modular models that can learn from diverse supervision and datasets. Its emergent modularity enables strong generalization, decomposition into high-performing components, and rapid, resource-efficient adaptation for downstream applications.

title: Temperature Cycling Life Prediction of Low-Voltage Transportation Electric Machines Winding: From Lifetime Model Proposal to Applications
authors: Xuanming Zhou, Yatai Ji, Paolo Giangrande, Weiduo Zhao, Michael Galea
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: The rapid electrification of transportation demands compact, high-power-density low-voltage electric machines (EMs), whose winding insulation life limits safety and uptime. Conventional Arrhenius models consider only thermal–chemical aging and often neglect thermal–mechanical (T-M) fatigue resulting from frequent temperature cycling in vehicle duty cycles. Based on mathematical derivation and previous physical models, this paper proposed a unified temperature-cycling life model that couples Arrhenius T-C terms with a phenomenological T-M fatigue term driven by cycle amplitude and mean temperature. The life model’s parameters are tuned using experimental data collected during accelerated temperature profiles (TPs) cycling tests performed on motorette specimens, while the life model is validated across different TPs. The predicted life outcomes demonstrate higher computational efficiency and yield more conservative results compared to the physical model simulations. As proof of concept, the proposed model is employed at the design stage of an EM meant for automotive application, in order to achieve a mission profile-based reliability-oriented design. Meanwhile, a real-time life consumption methodology, employing online cycle counting, is implemented to facilitate continuous reliability assessment and monitoring. This integrated approach establishes a systematic framework for evaluating and managing the reliability of EM insulation systems, thereby enhancing the methodological foundation for life prediction under realistic and dynamically varying operating conditions.

title: State-of-the-Art Technologies and Emerging Trends in Radar-Based vital signs Sensing: A Review
authors: Tongyang Yuan, Youyu Kuo, Aifeng Ren, Runqi Huo, Qing Sun, Adnan Zahid
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Radar-based non-contact vital signs sensing has emerged as a pivotal research direction in biomedical engineering and beyond, providing a privacy-preserving and unobtrusive alternative to conventional contact sensors and vision-based systems. This review systematically introduces the physiological underpinnings of respiratory and cardiac activities together with their mathematical representations, and elucidates the engineering foundations of radar sensing across different modalities. Furthermore, signal processing pipelines and algorithms are critically examined, covering both traditional frameworks and machine learning–driven approaches, with emphasis on their strengths, limitations, and biomedical performance metrics. Application domains are comprehensively surveyed, spanning bedside clinical monitoring, home healthcare, human–computer interaction, security surveillance, and emerging Internet-of-Things–enabled environments. By integrating current advances, this review highlights the major challenges and outlines prospective research directions, aiming to facilitate the translation of radar-based vital signs sensing into diverse real-world applications.

title: Adaptive Robust Fusion of MIMU Array for Dynamic Scenarios
authors: Rui Liu, Pin Lyu, Jizhou Lai, Xin Sun, Junqing Lu, Huafeng Hu
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Conventional noise estimation methods for arrayed MEMS inertial measurement units (MIMU) exhibit reduced effectiveness in dynamic scenarios, leading to degraded measurement accuracy and stability. To address this problem, this paper proposes an adaptive robust fusion method for MIMU array designed for dynamic applications. The performance enhancement mechanism of MIMU array is analyzed and the theoretical basis of the reduced effectiveness of traditional noise estimation methods under dynamic conditions is investigated. A second-order redundant observation mechanism is introduced to enable reliable online noise estimation of MIMU array in dynamic environments. Building upon this estimation, a fading-memory factor and a similarity evaluation strategy are incorporated to achieve adaptive and robust fusion of multiple MIMU measurements. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively estimate the noise level of MIMU array in dynamic scenarios, while vehicle experiments further verify its capability to enhance both accuracy and robustness in practical dynamic applications.

title: A Five-Level Integrated Common-Ground-Type Inverter With Dynamic Voltage-Gain
authors: Anil Jakhar, N. Sandeep
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: This article proposes a five-level (5L) inverter that combines the benefits of the DC-DC boost converter and the common-ground-type (CGT) inverter in a single-stage conversion. On contrary to the majority of the established CGT inverters, the proposed topology features continuous input current (non-zero) with dynamic voltage-boosting gain. Additionally, the proposed inverter eliminates ground leakage current caused by photovoltaic parasitic capacitance because of the common ground feature. It requires lower voltage rating capacitors, i.e., half of the inverter’s peak output voltage, and is self-voltage-balanced, and reduced control complexity. It will be demonstrated that the voltage stress of semiconductor devices, the number of conducting switches, and switching transitions are the least, resulting in lower power losses. The circuit description and its operation are explained in detail. A comparative assessment is carried out to highlight the salient features of the proposed topology against its counterparts. From the comparative analysis, the above-mentioned salient features of the proposed topology will be established. The experiment results for grid-connected operation demonstrate the proposed inverter’s viability and feasibility. Furthermore, the proposed 5L CGT inverter has fault-tolerant capability unlike other recent CGT inverters; it can sustain the inverter operation in post-fault operation and is capable of supplying partial/full load power.

title: Increasing the Digital Capacity of Organizations by Using Digital Wallets in the European Blockchain Services Infrastructure
authors: Rusen Gigov, Ivan Dimitrov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The present study aims to analyse attitudes towards Blockchain technology with a view to increasing the digital capacity of organizations in the field of education through the use of digital wallets in the European Blockchain Services Infrastructure (EBSI). The study focuses on the attitudes of decision-makers in their efforts to increase the digital adaptability of the organization they lead, which in turn verifies the readiness for positioning in the new digital era influenced by blockchain and artificial intelligence. The data reflected in the current study also take into account subjective limiters, which are often a major obstacle to the adoption of a given innovation. By their nature, blockchain technology and the EBSI infrastructure are recognizable as digital agents, but the understanding of blockchain is still associated with the cryptocurrency Bitcoin, which in turn creates additional boundaries when making a management decision related to the potential implementation of the technology. This analysis examines organizations operating in the field of education, but also includes companies from various industries to test the level of awareness and readiness to maintain their competitive advantages.

title: Centralised Orchestration and Strategic Alignment in AI-Agent-Enabled Supply Chains
authors: Petya Popova, Veselin Popov, Mariana Petrova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: AI-agent-based supply chains promise faster, more resilient, and sustainable operations, but outcomes depend on how autonomous agents are aligned with the business strategy of the company. In this research, centralised orchestration is considered as the governance layer that converts strategy into distributed agent behaviour. We consider decision-making rights and governance routines, shared planning calendars, and contracts tied to KPIs based on a literature review from 2020 to 2025, as well as a five-stage orchestration maturity model starting with isolated pilots and synchronisation to achieve ecosystem synchronisation. Three KPI bundles connect maturity with strategic performance: resilience (time-replan/recovery), agility (latency of decision), and sustainability (e.g., CO₂ intensity). Results show that organisations on the maturity path improve more consistently on these KPIs if orchestration includes shared data, synchronised horizons and contractual accountability. Meanwhile, locally optimised or misaligned agent deployments lead to performance compromises. Contributions include (i) an integrative framework, where orchestration mechanisms are connected to strategic-alignment pathways, and (ii) a diagnostic and roadmap maturity model. (iii) managerial guidelines for orchestration charters, integrated business planning cadences and KPI contracts. The study also sets out guidelines for exploring thresholds for "human interaction", data sharing/consent and designing incentives for autonomous execution aligned with strategy.

title: Towards Practical Software Discrimination Testing
authors: Sadia Afrin Mim
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Technological advancements over the years have led to increasingly complex software systems. The recent surge in artificial intelligence (AI) has, while reducing human effort, further contributed to this complexity. Among the growing concerns in this domain are the ethical implications of developing and using such systems. Regardless of whether a system explicitly incorporates AI, underlying software infrastructures have demonstrated instances of discriminatory behavior, resulting in undesired outcomes. To address this challenge, my research focuses on discrimination testing as a means to ensure equitable behavior in software systems. As part of this effort, I plan to build on insights from my earlier work, which involved compiling a list of existing tools and user studies on their effectiveness. My goal is to design a more explainable and generalizable discrimination testing tool that can be applied across various systems.

title: Multicriteria Approach to Selecting Sites for Pumped-Storage Hydropower Plants
authors: Andrei Pisică, Eliza-Isabela Tică, Angela Neagoe, Bogdan Popa
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper applies an integrated Geographic Information Systems (GIS) – Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) framework to the site selection of pumped-storage hydropower plants (PSHP). After outlining the role of PSHP in ensuring energy flexibility and system stability, the study introduces the main principles of multicriteria analysis, including methods, steps and criteria relevant to an alternative for the selected site. To illustrate the method, Tarnița– Lăpuștești PSHP, a proposed pumped-storage project on the Someșul Cald River in Cluj County, Romania, is analyzed by combining GIS-based spatial analysis with engineering assessments applied as a MCDA. The results confirm the validity of previous decisions while providing a transparent and replicable framework for objectively comparing alternative sites. The study highlights that GIS–MCDA offers a robust decision-support tool for the planning and development of future pumped-storage hydropower facilities.

title: Data Cleaning: Methods, Challenges, and Practices for Improving Data Quality
authors: Irena Valova, Tsvetelina Kaneva, Tsvetana Halacheva, Gabriel Kanev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Data cleaning is a fundamental step in the data preprocessing pipeline, significantly affecting the accuracy and reliability of downstream analytics and machine learning models. This paper explores the application of various tools and techniques for cleaning data originating from heterogeneous sources, including IoT devices and structured datasets. The study focuses on common data quality issues such as missing values, duplicates, noise, outliers, inconsistent formats, and incorrect or biased data. We present an experimental comparison of three widely used tools—Pandas (Python library), Open-Refine (GUI-based desktop application), and Trifacta (now part of Google Cloud Dataprep)—evaluating them across several dimensions: usability, automation, scalability, supported data types, and functional capabilities. In addition, a conceptual model for a data cleaning pipeline is proposed, comprising modules for edge processing, real-time stream ingestion, semantic and syntactic data transformation, and integration with time-series databases and visualization platforms. The results highlight the strengths and limitations of each tool in specific contexts, guiding data professionals when selecting appropriate solutions based on project requirements, data volume, and technical expertise. This paper aims to bridge the gap between theoretical approaches and practical implementations of data cleaning in modern, data-intensive environments.

title: Bandwidth-Enhanced Ultra Low-Profile Electroplated 3D-Printed Microstrip Patch Antennas
authors: Carlos E. Andrade, Francisco Pizarro, Javier L. Araque, Julio Soriano, Daniel Jaramillo Chamba, Washington Torres
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents two realistically modeled, simulation-based ultra-low-profile microstrip patch antennas for LTE Band $5(869-894 \mathrm{MHz})$, designed for dual-extruder 3D printing with low-conductivity filaments, followed by post-print copper electroplating to overcome the filaments’ limited conductivity. Both 3D-printed antennas were analyzed through full-wave simulations. The first antenna used a 5 mm monolithic substrate, achieving a $2.83 \%$ impedance bandwidth, a peak realized gain of 5.18 dBi, and stable broadside radiation patterns, offering greater mechanical simplicity than a conventional four-layer FR4 microstrip stack $(6 \mathrm{~mm})$. The second antenna reduced the profile to 3 mm via a sandwich-style stacked patch, introducing an additional resonance that maintained bandwidth while limiting the peak gain to 2.9 dBi and preserving stable radiation patterns. Simulations confirmed that both antennas maintain stable hemispherical radiation patterns with effective impedance matching and low RF losses across the operational band. These results demonstrate that electroplated 3D-printed antennas provide ultra-low-profile, low-complexity alternatives to conventional multilayer microstrip designs for sub-GHz applications requiring moderate bandwidth enhancement.

title: Application of Intelligent Algorithms for Energy Demand Estimation in Urban Electric Mobility
authors: A.H Yánez, Mónica Mite León, E.R Yánez, Julio Barzola-Monteses
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This research assessed machine learning and deep learning methodologies for predicting hourly energy demand in electric vehicle charging stations within urban settings. Utilizing a comprehensive dataset from Shenzhen, China, encompassing over 17,500 connectors at 1,300 public stations with 5-minute intervals, the methodology involved data preprocessing, feature engineering, model training, and validation through visualization. Four predictive models were evaluated: Random Forest, XGBoost, LSTM, and LSTM Encoder-Decoder. The forecast dataset covered February 1, 2023, to April 14, 2023, encompassing 1,772 hourly observations. Findings revealed that XGBoost outperformed others, exhibiting a commendable balance of accuracy, adaptability, and computational efficiency. Random Forest also showed satisfactory performance. Conversely, LSTM models demonstrated poorer results, marked by smooth predictions and inadequate responsiveness to demand fluctuations. This research highlights the necessity of integrating RMSE and MAE metrics with visual validation for a thorough performance assessment. In summary, XGBoost holds considerable promise for integration into urban energy-planning frameworks, enhancing electric mobility efficiency.

title: Integration of IoT and Network Technologies for the Design of Escape Rooms
authors: Fatima Sapundzhi, Metodi Popstoilov, Teodora Bakardjieva, Slavi Georgiev, Ivan Georgiev, Antonina Ivanova, Georgi Georgiev, Meglena Lazarova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Escape rooms are interactive real-time games that are becoming increasingly popular for entertainment, education, corporate training, and team building. With the rapid development of Internet of Things (IoT), numerous opportunities are emerging for integrating automation, smart lighting, multimedia, and safety systems to create more immersive and secure escape room environments. This study presents a design of an IoT infrastructure for escape rooms located in Southwestern Bulgaria, combining architectural modeling and network engineering. The system integrates a network with switches, routers, servers, and IoT controllers to coordinate lighting, video surveillance, and multimedia. The results show that IoT integration improves interactivity and ensures safety in emergency scenarios. Using the proposed methodology, IoT-based infrastructures can be systematically modeled and validated before deployment.

title: Generative AI for Glucose Level Prediction Using Wearable Devices
authors: Zdenek Snajdr, Martin Brun, Corin Otesteanu, Carlo Menon
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Reliable continuous glucose monitoring is crucial for diabetes management, yet current invasive techniques hinder patient adherence and quality of life. This research explores the application of generative artificial intelligence models for non-invasive blood glucose prediction using data from wearable devices, thereby reducing patients’ discomfort and complications. We benchmarked several machine learning models, including discriminative models (XGBoost) and generative models (variational autoencoders, sequence-to-sequence models), for signal-to-glucose translation, alongside time-series forecasting approaches such as autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA), exponential smoothing (ETS), and LSTM models for forecasting future glucose trajectories. Analyses were conducted on the BIG IDEAs Lab dataset comprising 16 participants, using leave-one-person-out cross-validation and personalized modeling strategies. In low-data personalized settings, XGBoost achieved superior accuracy (RMSE: 4.04 mg/dL), whereas generative models outperformed in the generalized leave-one-patient-out setting, achieving RMSE values down to 17.45 mg/dL. An integrated translation– forecasting pipeline combining a VAE encoder with an LSTM forecaster further attained an RMSE of 12.9 mg/dL in personalized evaluations. These findings demonstrate the promise of generative AI for clinical glucose monitoring while revealing important performance trade-offs between personalized and generalized approaches that must be addressed for real-world deployment.

title: Simple Quantum Probability Amplitude Modulation Test on an IBM Quantum Computer
authors: Darin Peev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Quantum Probability Amplitude Modulation (QPAM) was implemented on a real quantum computer, ibm_brisbane, one of IBM’s 127-qubit devices from the Eagle r3 family. To evaluate the errors, advantages, and limitations of such a real-world implementation, four experiments were conducted. Three of them encoded different signals: a ramp signal, a jagged signal, and a custom signal constructed from a sequence of five quantum gates. The first two signals were prepared using a built-in function from IBM’s Qiskit library, which includes an optimization step. Despite the relatively high root-mean-square errors normalized to the signal range (RMSEN) observed in the measurements, the encoding of N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</inf> analog samples with only log<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</inf> qubits was successfully demonstrated for N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</inf> = 8 using three qubits. The maximum RMSEN error obtained from the real quantum hardware was 8.7%. However, the need for a disproportionately large number of measurement shots to extract classical information significantly limits the practical applicability of the QPAM method, unless further quantum signal processing is performed within the quantum system.

title: Integration of Artificial Intelligence in the Student Training of Engineering Programmes
authors: Marlena Daneva, Vanyo Donev, Monika Simeonova-Ingilizova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study explores the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into the training of. The research examines how engineering students, who receive parallel pedagogical preparation, develop readiness to apply intelligent technologies both in industrial practice and in vocational teaching. Conducted over two academic years (2023/2024 and 2024/2025) through a mixed-methods approach combining surveys and semi-structured interviews, the study provides empirical evidence on the evolution of AI-related competences. The findings reveal that while engineering students demonstrate growing digital literacy and motivation to experiment with AI tools, their methodological capacity to apply these technologies in educational settings remains limited. The participants demonstrate predominantly positive perceptions of artificial intelligence, although some express reservations concerning the ethical management of data and the influence of automation on human reasoning.

title: Intervention against school bullying through emerging technologies: a literature review
authors: Paúl Bladimir Acosta-Pérez, Carlos Alberto Espinosa-Pinos, Fernando David Saá-Tapia, Francisco Sebastián Vaca-Pinto
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: School bullying remains a persistent issue that negatively affects students’ well-being and academic performance. Private educational institutions face unique challenges in addressing this problem due to limited resources and teacher training. This literature review explores the use of emerging technologies—such as virtual reality (VR), mobile applications, and artificial intelligence (AI)—as innovative tools to prevent and mitigate school bullying. Recent studies that implement these technologies in educational settings were analyzed to assess their effectiveness and applicability. The findings suggest that such tools can foster empathy, facilitate anonymous reporting, and enable early detection of incidents, contributing to the development of safer and more supportive school environments.

title: Evaluating Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) Performance for Autonomous Vehicle Navigation in Urban Environments
authors: Svetozar Stefanov, Valentina Markova, Miroslav Markov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Precise and reliable localization is paramount for the safe and efficient operation of autonomous vehicles (AVs) in complex urban environments. This study rigorously evaluates the real-world performance of consumer-grade Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) receivers under diverse urban conditions, including varying speeds, travel directions, and environmental factors within an urban canyon in Varna, Bulgaria. Our experimental findings reveal substantial and spatially consistent deviations from actual trajectories (mean error: 9.87 m; RMSE: 12.43 m for 3.6 km/h), coupled with frequent signal outages, particularly in areas characterized by dense infrastructure and tunnels. We demonstrate that GNSS accuracy is significantly degraded by multipath effects and signal blockages, with challenging zones exhibiting substantial spatial superposition. Furthermore, the study highlights distinct directional discrepancies in accuracy and nuanced impacts of speed. Critically, even advanced consumer sensors did not consistently outperform basic counterparts in these severely compromised conditions. GNSS positioning alone is unreliable in urban areas. Complementary technologies are essential for safe autonomous navigation.

title: Large Language Models and Multi-Agent Systems for Customer Support Ticket Automation
authors: Claudia Moncada, Leticia Lemus-Cárdenas, Fabricio Crespo, Juan Pablo Astudillo-León
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Customer service operations increasingly struggle to handle the rising volume and complexity of support tickets, exposing the limitations of traditional rule-based workflows and static machine learning models that often lack contextual adaptability. This paper presents a modular architecture that integrates multi-agent systems orchestrated by large language models (LLMs), specifically G PT-4-mini, implemented through the CrewAI framework. The proposed system leverages specialized agents for data ingestion, ticket classification into categories such as incident, request, change, and problem, and the generation of contextually appropriate responses. Experimental evaluations conducted on a dataset of technical support tickets demonstrate an average classification accuracy of 85% and a mean cosine similarity of $\mathbf{7 5 \%}$—capturing semantic alignment beyond lexical overlap. These results highlight the effectiveness of combining LLM-driven reasoning with multi-agent coordination to automate customer support workflows, offering a scalable foundation for deploying intelligent systems across diverse operational environments.

title: Development of a Prosthetic Hand Simulator
authors: Kleber Saavedra, Marco E. Benalcázar, Ángel Leonardo Valdivieso Caraguay, Lorena Isabel Barona López
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents the development of a digital twin based on a dynamic simulation platform of a prosthetic hand, aimed at testing and analyzing control strategies, addressing some of the limitations of current approaches. The proposed architecture integrates MATLAB for real-time dynamic computation and Autodesk Inventor through the implementation of IPC with a custom messaging protocol. The dynamics of the fingers are modeled using the Newton-Euler formulation. A fourth-order Runge-Kutta numerical scheme with fifth-order local error estimation is employed to ensure temporal accuracy. The model includes mechanical constraints (angular stops) and inertial parameters obtained directly from the 3D geometry. The results show a consistent correspondence with the expected physical behavior, validating the simulation approach.

title: AI-Driven Diagnostics and Predictive Maintenance in NPI Service Engineering: A Comprehensive Survey of Methods, Applications, and Future Directions
authors: Makrand Godbole, Adwaita Jadhav
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) are increasingly transforming how complex electromechanical products are diagnosed, serviced, and maintained. However, their integration within the New Product Introduction (NPI) phase remains fragmented across design, manufacturing, and service domains. This survey provides a comprehensive overview of AI-driven diagnostics and predictive maintenance frameworks specifically applied in NPI Service Engineering. The study systematically reviews recent literature and industrial implementations to identify core techniques such as data-driven fault detection, digital twins, and physics-informed models, along with their roles in improving fault triage accuracy, mean time to repair (MTTR), and first-time fix rates (FTF). A structured taxonomy is developed to classify methods based on learning paradigms, data sources, and system hierarchy levels. Comparative analysis reveals that hybrid AI models-combining physical modeling with deep learning-offer the highest potential for early anomaly detection and cross-domain integration. Finally, the paper highlights research gaps in dataset standardization, model interpretability, and real-time deployment within field environments, offering a roadmap for future AI-augmented NPI ecosystems.

title: Experimental Validation of a Kinematic Control Strategy for Trajectory Tracking in Quadruped Robots
authors: Christian P. Carvajal, José Varela-Aldás, Víctor H. Andaluz, Fernando A. Chicaiza, Manuel Ayala-Chauvin
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents a high-level control architecture for trajectory tracking in quadruped robots. The proposed controller is based on the motion kinematics of the robot’s center of mass (CoM). The proposed strategy transforms planned trajectories in Cartesian space into motion velocity commands for the robot, using a differential kinematic model that relates the velocity of the robot’s operational point to its velocity in the XY-plane. The control scheme is organized hierarchically, where the kinematic controller operates independently from the system dynamics, which are handled by low-level controllers. The proposed control architecture is experimentally validated using the Unitree Go2 quadruped robot, employing MATLAB and ROS2 tools. The results confirm the feasibility of using purely kinematic models for high-level locomotion task control under real-world operating conditions.

title: Topic Analysis of #IndonesiaGelap Discourse Communities using BERTopic
authors: Sebastianus Adi Santoso Mola, Matthew Martianus Henry, Tamar Dian Ina Dappa Ole, Zypora Ray Putri Blegur, Jusuf Ezra Rudolf Fransz, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Following Indonesia 2024 presidential election, the hashtag #IndonesiaGelap emerged as a symbol of distrust of the new government on social media. Such a campaign can cause instability in Indonesia’s growth. In this study, social network analysis is employed to identify key opinion leaders (KOLs) and communities within #IndonesiaGelap discourses on Twitter. Semantic coherence within each detected community is further examined using BERTopic. This study identifies political figures, government institutions, news outlet, and communitybased accounts as KOLs. However, none of the political figures and government institutions emerged as central or broker accounts. This study also detects $\mathbf{6 4 5}$ communities with weak intra-connections. Analysis of the Top-10 most populated communities finds nine communities form no coherent topics. The one community with coherent topics is dominated by brokers with distilled narratives from the sub-community. This community exhibits a mesh network structure, suggesting interactions among them. However, the cosine coherence score of 0.6491 and NPMI coherence score of -0.599 suggest that more topics exist in the broker community. UMAP and HDSBCAN hyperparameter tuning in BERTopic are needed to reveal more coherent topics. As for the new government, this study reveals a communication gap that needs to be bridged to prevent further spread of #IndonesiaGelap discourse.

title: Improving Apple Fruit Disease Classification using InceptionV3 and Adam Optimizer
authors: Brian Marcellino, Nasywa Hilmi Cahyono, M. Aldiki Febriantono
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Accurate identification of diseases is essential for achieving successful apple cultivation. However, manual inspection remains a time-consuming process and is highly susceptible to human error. Although deep learning has demonstrated significant potential in plant disease identification, most existing studies have concentrated on leaf based analysis, leaving a research gap in fruit specific identification. This study proposes and evaluates a deep learning framework for the identification of apple fruit diseases using the InceptionV3 architecture optimized with the Adam algorithm. A dataset comprising 3,360 images was collected from apple orchards, representing five categories: Black Pox, Black Rot, Fruit Moth, Green Fruit Caterpillar, and Healthy. Data augmentation techniques were employed to mitigate class imbalance prior to training. The proposed InceptionV3 model was compared with EfficientNetB0, ResNet50, and MobileNetV2. Experimental results indicated that InceptionV3 achieved superior performance, attaining 97.15% testing accuracy with balanced Precision, Recall, and F1-Score values of 0.97. Despite its slower inference time, the model demonstrated high reliability for automated apple disease identification in practical agricultural applications.

title: Public Investment in Higher Education and QS Performance in Ecuador (2023–2026): A Longitudinal Analysis
authors: Geovanny Solano, Jorge Albuja-Sánchez, Jenny Vinueza, Andres Basantes, Susana Masapanta, Mauricio Cely
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Global university rankings are having an increasing effect on how higher education is planned, especially in developing countries. This study examines how the performance of Ecuadorian universities in the QS World University Rankings from 2023 to 2026 is related to how significantly the government spends on higher education. The analysis examines at whether more public spending leads to better rankings by comparing national funding data from 2021 to 2025 with QS outcomes and taking into account methodological lag. Findings reveal that while investment peaks coincide with moderate gains in research related and sustainability indicators, broader improvements such as employer reputation or internationalization remain limited. Several public institutions exited the rankings in 2026 despite previous upward trends, suggesting structural or strategic misalignments. The results indicate that public funding, though essential, is insufficient in isolation. It is crucial for institutions to be in line with changing ranking metrics, such as sustainability and international research networks. The study indicates that national policies need to connect money spent with clear performance goals so that investments lead to long-term global visibility.

title: Phytoremediation of Cadmium-contaminated agricultural soil using Zea mays L, effective microorganisms and silicon
authors: Jhosseph Dario Muñoz Astuhuamán, Rubén Munive Cerrón, Andres Alberto Azabache Leytón, Lorgio Valdiviezo-Gonzales
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study aims to evaluate the effect of effective microorganisms (EM) and silicon on cadmium-contaminated agricultural soil using Zea mays L. as a bioindicator. Soil samples were collected from the El Mantaro Agricultural Experimental Station in Jauja, Peru. Experiments were conducted in pots under cover using a completely randomized design in a $3 \times 3$ factorial arrangement, plus one additional treatment. Effective microorganisms were applied at concentrations of 2%, 4%, and 6%, in combination with liquid, hydrated, and organic forms of silicon. Cadmium (Cd) content was measured in both leaves and root tissues of $\mathbf{Z}$. mays $\mathbf{L}$., as well as in post-treatment soil. Plant height, leaf area, and root length were also assessed. The results indicated a higher presence of Cd in the roots $(3.5-5 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{kg})$ than in the leaves (up to $0.2-0.45 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{kg}$), while Cd in the soil reached minimum values of up to $2.3 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{kg}$. The application of EM 2 and 4% resulted in the highest $\mathbf{C d}$ absorption values in the root and the lowest Cd concentration in the soil. Meanwhile, organic silicon allowed for the highest accumulation of $\mathbf{C d}$ in the root. The results show a synergy between corn, EM, and Si, which allows Cd to be extracted from the soil to the plant’s roots, limiting the translocation of this element to the aerial parts of the plant.

title: Surface charge-driven selectivity of greensynthesized silver nanoparticles for anionic dye removal: Implications for environmental nanotechnology
authors: Cintya Gordon-Falconí, María Florencia Iannone, María Daniela Groppa
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The selective removal of ionic pollutants from wastewater represents a significant challenge in the advancement of scalable and efficient water purification technologies. This study explores the adsorption behavior of green-synthesized silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) toward anionic dyes, with particular emphasis on the role of the surface charge imparted by plant-derived capping agents. The AgNPs were synthesized using discarded yerba mate extract, which is rich in phenolic compounds and other oxygen-containing functional groups (e.g., aldehydes, ketones, and carboxylic acids) that act as both reducing and capping agents, conferring a predominantly negative surface charge to the nanoparticles. Experimental results revealed minimal interaction with anionic dyes, such as bromocresol green and congo red. In contrast, prior studies have shown that these AgNPs exhibit high adsorption efficiency towards cationic dyes, including crystal violet, methylene blue, and safranin. This selective adsorption behavior was attributed to electrostatic repulsion between the negatively charged nanoparticle surfaces and the anionic dye molecules. These findings demonstrate the critical influence of synthesis conditions and surface functionalization on the adsorption performance of nanoparticles. Moreover, they highlight the importance of tailoring nanoparticles surface properties to enhance selectivity and broaden the range of target pollutants. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the physicochemical characteristics that govern pollutantnanomaterial interactions, contributing to the advancement of sustainable and cost-effective nanotechnology-based solutions for environmental remediation

title: Predicting the level of artificial intelligence in engineering students using machine learning techniques
authors: Douglas Andrés Verduga-Alcívar, Eldis Roman-Cao, Alexander López-Padrón, Liliana Sarduy-Pereira, Neyfe Sablón-Cossío
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The objective of this work is to predict the level of artificial intelligence literacy in engineering students at the Technical University of Manabí using machine learning techniques. The research methodology includes training a neural network and support vector machines to predict the level of artificial intelligence literacy in university engineering students. The novelty of this work lies in the possibility of defining in advance the needs of engineering students regarding AI literacy, which will allow for early and personalized interventions in the learning process. Historical data on artificial intelligence literacy levels are compared with those predicted by neural networks and support vector machines. The selection of these models was carried out by cross-validation (k = 5) on 75% of the data, using the mean RMSE as the primary criterion and Spearman/MAE as complementary metrics.

title: Research on generative AI within university teaching contexts a methodological analysis
authors: Ximena Coronado-Otavalo, Viviana Galarza Ligña, José Marcelino Romero-Gutiérrez, Abel Romero
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This article presents the results of a systematic literature review aimed at identifying methodological trends in empirical and review studies concerning generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) within higher education institutions. The review was conducted in accordance with PRISMA guidelines, by using a corpus of peer-reviewed articles indexed in Scopus and Web of Science, published between 2021 and early 2024. Most studies are conducted within undergraduate and teacher education settings, with a primary focus on assessment processes and academic performance. A qualitative matrix was applied to 30 selected studies, considering variables such as type of research, methodological approach, educational level, data collection techniques, and ethical-pedagogical approach. The findings show the predominance of quantitative, cross-sectional designs based on surveys with limited validation procedures. The study concludes with an insight: the need to enhance methodological rigor and ethical alignment in future research on generative artificial intelligence within the university context.

title: Bayesian Approach to RF Fingerprinting Localization Using Directional Antennas
authors: David Mendoza, E René Játiva, Nicolas Yanchapaxi
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work explores the use of Bayesian estimation as a mechanism to determine an optimal set of receiver orientations, aiming to maximize spatial diversity and, consequently, enhance the generation of radio frequency patterns that contain accurate information about the position of a deployed transmitter anywhere within a virtualized university campus. The environment is modeled using OpenStreetMap (OSM), while the communication system, emulating a 5G-NR mobile network operating at 3.7 GHz, is implemented in MATLAB ${ }^{\circledR}$. The positioning method relies on RF Pattern Matching (RFPM), using a K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) approach to match the received Received Signal Strength (RSS) fingerprint to the transmitter’s location. Results validate Bayesian Optimization as a suitable method to steer directional antennas to maximize positioning accuracy.

title: Exploring Digital Diary Journals to Enhance Emotional Growth in Elementary Students
authors: Mujahidil Mustaqim, Freddy Widya Ariesta, Salma Nabila Putri
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Diaries have been a medium for channeling feelings for hundreds of years. Many studies have revealed that diaries, in addition to overcoming various dynamics of unstable social emotional competence problems, can also improve students’ academic performance. Researchers try to transform the usual diary with book and pen media into digital diary journals (DDJs). For this reason, this study is the basis for the development of application-based diaries. There are 117 elementary school students who are respondents in the study. Data were collected using a questionnaire, then processed and analyzed using the Pearson correlation test statistical method. This study presents a number of important statistical evidences in the development of DDJs including students being quite interested in writing digital-based diaries. Interestingly, students have not seen the application design directly, but students are already interested at a moderate level. In addition, there is a significant correlation between students’ perceptions and interests in the benefits of the DDJs application with the development of social emotional learning (SEL). In addition, students describe themselves as not very good at SEL, which indicates that the development of DDJs can be tried as a new strategy in improving students’ SEL.

title: Interface Design for Autism in an Ever-Updating World
authors: Lewis D Sawyer, Ramaswamy Palaniappan
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: It is well-known that people diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder experience difficulty coping with change. However, the extent to which this applies to small changes in user interface design is not known. Through exposing autistic (n=11) and control (n=10) users to seven controlled, cumulative design changes within an e-calendar appointment creation interface, and systematically recording usability scores, a bespoke comfortability score and qualitative responses, we confirm that the autistic discomfort around change extends to small changes in user interface design, negatively impacting system usability and comfortability scores consistently in the autistic group for some tests. To widen the applicability of our findings for industry use and promote further research in this under-explored yet critical area, we also transform our results into preliminary non-exhaustive design heuristics for reducing negative impacts of interface design changes in autistic users.

title: From Legacy to Leadership: Intelligent Radio Network Planning Framework for Cell-Free Massive MIMO in B5G/6G Era
authors: Valdemar Farré, David Vega, Juan Estrada, Juan A. Vásquez Peralvo, Symeon Chatzinotas
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The proliferation of cell-free Massive MIMO represents a transformative shift in wireless network architecture, addressing critical limitations of conventional distributed Massive MIMO systems. This paper presents an intelligent radio network planning framework that bridges legacy $\mathbf{5 G}$ infrastructures with future $\mathbf{B 5 G} / \mathbf{6 G}$ networks through cell-free architectures. By leveraging operational insights from existing $\mathbf{5 G}$ deployments, we systematically address coverage optimization, and capacity enhancement. Our scalable framework enables seamless evolution from legacy designs to next-generation cell-free systems. Through extensive simulations in dense urban environments, we demonstrate substantial improvements: 45% spectral efficiency gains, 30% interference reduction, and significantly enhanced uniform coverage. The proposed framework provides network operators with a practical roadmap for transitioning from traditional cellular architectures to demanding B5G/6G requirements while maximizing existing infrastructure investments.

title: Energy Systems in Agriculture: Synergies and Perspectives
authors: Mantas Švažas, Valdemaras Makutėnas
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The agricultural sector is characterized by a high level of pollution, determined by the lack of alternatives. Tractors used in agriculture are characterized by pollution, but biomethane and electric tractors are today considered conceptual, but not mass solutions. The perspective of farms to reduce pollution is related both to the optimization of the livestock sector and to additional activities in generating electricity. In the latter case, the emphasis is on the transformation of storage, drying, and production areas through the use of solar collectors and batteries. The article proposes solutions that allow for the cost-effective development of renewable energy activities on farms, reducing costs and environmental pollution. In addition, synergies are presented that allow for the improvement of the main activities carried out by farms, making them safer and generating higher income. The main idea of the article is the necessary integration between different technologies in order to minimize farm pollution while achieving maximum operational efficiency.

title: Investigating the Impact of AI-Assisted Tools on Software Practitioner Well-Being
authors: Fairuz Nawer Meem, Brittany Johnson
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: The rapid integration of AI-assisted tools such as ChatGPT, GitHub Copilot, and Gemini into software development has reshaped how practitioners perform tasks, collaborate, and manage their workloads. While these tools offer productivity gains, they also introduce new job demands, such as cognitive overload, emotional stress, and blurred work-life boundaries that can affect practitioners’ well-being. We designed a research study to investigate the short and long-term well-being impacts of AIassisted tools on software practitioners, using the Job DemandsResources (JD-R) model as a guiding framework. Through a mixed-methods study combining survey and interview data, we aim to identify both beneficial and harmful patterns emerging from use of AI-assisted tools. Our findings thus far suggest both positive and negative impacts of AI-Assisted tools on software practitioner well-being. We also found significant differences in impact between practitioners with and without neurocognitive conditions, underscoring the need for inclusive tool design and thoughtful organizational policies. This research contributes theoretical insights into the evolving human-tool relationship in software development and aims to inform the ethical and sustainable integration of AI into developer workflows.
