title: Multi-Technology Wireless Communication for Internet of Things Applications Enhancing Robustness and Redundancy
authors: Ondřej Šolc, Tomáš Martinec
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper focuses on the efficient use of wireless communication technologies within Internet of Things (IoT) systems, with an emphasis on increasing the robustness and adaptability of data transmission. The crucial parameters of several different transmission technologies are considered and evaluated. Each technology offers specific advantages but also limitations depending on the application environment. To address this, a custom multi-technology platform was designed and implemented. The following section deals with the design of a multi-technology device that is equipped with several different communication modules and employs control approaches to dynamically select the appropriate available transmission technology based on current conditions. A unique aspect of the platform is the inclusion of a satellite communication module, enabling data transmission even in remote or terrestrial coverage infrastructure-limited areas.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Electric Vehicle Integration on University Campus Energy Demand
authors: Onur Elma, Murat Kuzlu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The accelerating adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) presents both challenges and opportunities for electricity grids, particularly in urban and campus-scale environments where charging demand may create localized peaks. This study investigates the impact of EV integration on a university campus located in the Hampton Roads region of Virginia, serving as a micro-scale case study within the Dominion Energy service territory. Using recently reported EV registration data, coupled with available campus parking and charging infrastructure information, baseline uncontrolled charging was compared with smart charging (V1G) and bidirectional vehicle-to-grid (V2G) strategies. The results demonstrate that uncontrolled charging could significantly exacerbate evening peak demand, while controlled charging strategies substantially mitigate these peaks and reduce ramping requirements. Furthermore, V2G integration, particularly through emerging electric school bus fleets in Virginia, has the potential to provide critical support during summer peak events and emergency outage conditions, thereby enhancing campus resilience. This study contributes to the literature on EV–grid interactions by presenting one of the first campus-level case studies in the Hampton Roads region. The findings highlight both the technical feasibility and the policy relevance of EV-based flexibility solutions, offering practical insights for universities, utilities, and policymakers in Virginia. Additionally, scaling analytics to the regional level provides a foundation for aligning campus-level insights with statewide clean energy and decarbonization goals.

title: Understanding User Perceptions of Automated Dark Pattern Detection Online
authors: Ryan Wood, Chris Brown
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Dark patterns are software designs that manipulate and mislead users of applications or services. These patterns range from making it harder to end a subscription service, adding additional charges to a purchase, or having the user give out data or personal information. Prior work has explored perceptions of dark patterns, yet there is limited research exploring the effects of tooling to detect dark patterns on users. In this study, we introduce Dark Pattern Detector, a Chrome extension that would help users detect and understand dark patterns online. We conducted a technology probe study where participants $(n=40)$ were tasked with installing the extension and completing a series of tasks on different websites based on real-world Internet browsing. We leveraged mixed-methods surveys to collect feedback on dark pattern detection tools in practice. We found the majority of participants gave positive feedback, claiming they found the extension useful, interesting, and a good idea. Many participants also gave useful feedback about what changes or additions they would like to see in future systems. With our results, we provide implications to help users better understand dark patterns and motivate future tools for enhancing dark pattern detection in online environments.

title: Sidelink Communication for Unmanned Platforms' (UxU) Swarms in Challenging Scenarios
authors: Andreas Giannakoulas, Nikolaos Karkanis, Stylianos Markou, George Kyriacou, Theodoros Kaifas
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Unmanned platforms are increasingly employed in swarm configurations for various applications, including surveillance, disaster response, logistics, and environmental monitoring. Reliable communication is essential for maintaining coordination and ensuring mission success. Traditional channel modeling techniques often utilize statistical representations, such as Rayleigh or Rician fading, which may fail to adequately characterize the highly dynamic and environment-specific conditions encountered in real-world swarm operations. This study explores unmanned platform communication through a deterministic, site-specific modeling approach that does not rely on statistical channel assumptions. We present our approach on studying UxU device to device communications on extremely challenging channel environments that dictate full-wave analysis and the computation of Sommerfeld integrals. Specifically, to the best of our knowledge for the first time, the over-sea water to under-sea water drone communication scenario is studied under 5G Sidelink. Indicative results are presented and commented on validating the merit of our method that should have possible practical applications on various two - channel cases such as potential applications in maritime rescue, surveillance, or hybrid UAV-UUV networks.

title: Lowering the Barriers to Designing and Creating Electronics-Based Tangibles for Learning Programming
authors: David Wong-Aitken
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Tangible interfaces are a powerful medium for learning, yet their creation requires technical expertise in coding and electronics. My first research addressed this with TangiBooks, a system using sensor-augmented paper to simplify learning programming concepts. My subsequent research tried to lower the barrier to authoring tangible lessons using modular hardware and a web-based lesson editor, revealing a strong user demand for more flexible and capable tangible authoring tools, especially for creating novel interactions. This insight motivates my current research: investigate the tangible creation made radically simple by leveraging the opportunities that naturallanguage programming offers, especially for general audiences. Through an electronics toolkit with a natural language interface, users will be able to program interactive objects by describing their desired behavior effortlessly and learn from the generated code. The findings will contribute to understanding key HCI issues in lowering the barrier to tangibles for large audiences and let them create interactive experiences, free from technical constraints.

title: APICANVAS: Graphically Designing Web APIs
authors: Griffin Tomaszewski, Souhaila Serbout, Wesley K. G. Assunção
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Web APIs are essential in modern software systems, with OpenAPI as the standard specification for describing RESTful APIs. Despite widespread adoption, OpenAPI specifications are mainly textual documents that become verbose, deeply nested, and difficult to navigate at scale. Current tools like Swagger Editor lack graphical design capabilities, impeding effective prototyping for large teams and non-technical users. To address this gap, we present APICAnvas, a visual design tool enabling users to interact with OpenAPI specifications through both editable YAML and graphical interfaces with bidirectional synchronization. We evaluated the tool with 13 participants across two tasks: creating new APIs and modifying existing ones. Results show 83% successfully created APIs from scratch and 75% correctly updated existing APIs, demonstrating the tool’s effectiveness across diverse experience levels.

title: Modeling Code Navigation in Collaborative Software Engineering Tasks
authors: Shahnewaz Leon
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: As software development becomes increasingly collaborative and remote, understanding how developers seek and share information as a team is essential. How can we model the influence of team interactions on individual code navigation behavior? In my research, I propose PFIS-VT, an extension of Information Foraging Theory (IFT) designed to capture how developers in virtual teams navigate codebases using both environmental cues and social signals. PFIS-VT integrates team navigation history, shared attention, and social cues into a foraging-based predictive model. This work aims to improve our ability to simulate, predict, and support collaborative navigation in modern software engineering environments.

title: Temporal Response Comparison Following Digital Filter Application on EEG Signals
authors: Alberto M. Peralta-Orellana, Efrén L. Lema-Condo, Freddy L. Bueno-Palomeque
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study focused on analyzing the response of electroencephalographic (EEG) signals to the application of different digital filters. EEG signals (14 electrodes) were recorded at rest, with no external stimuli present. The EEG recordings were subdivided into four sub-bands: Delta, Theta, Alpha, and Beta. The analysis was performed in the time domain, focusing on signal amplitude, frequency, and morphology.The EEG signals were represented through their frequency distribution and modeled as curves with a normal probability distribution. Convolution operations were performed between pairs of digital filters over these distributions to identify which filters exhibited lower temporal variability.The results of the comparative analysis revealed that the filters induced variable responses. In the Delta band, the sym9 filter showed greater selectivity and stronger presence across electrodes. For the Theta band, the db1 filter presented the lowest variability across all electrodes. In the Alpha and Beta bands, the db2 filter showed both lower variability and stronger signal presence.This study demonstrates that the response of EEG signals to different digital filters can lead to variations in the resulting signal characteristics. Although the differences are subtle, taking them into account could contribute to more objective results in EEG signal processing.

title: Advantages of Smart Protective Relaying
authors: Anuneet Krishna, Richard W. Miller, Alan Simmons
publish: 2023 IEEE-IAS/PCA Cement Industry Conference (IAS/PCA)
abstract: Protective relaying is the backbone of electrical power distribution systems. As compared to traditional electromechanical relays, modern microprocessor-based relays can perform a multitude of protective functions. Recently, a Southern California cement plant discovered the benefits of implementing virtual main protection on the secondary of a 1 MVA 4.16kV/480V transformer to greatly reduce arc flash (AF) incident energy (IE) levels at the associated downstream low voltage Motor Control Center (MCC).Another benefit of modern relaying is the ability to replace hard-wired tripping signals from switchgear in isolated unit substations to the lockout relays located in the associated upstream switchgear feeder breakers using Generic Object Oriented Substation Event (GOOSE) messaging between the relays. This integrates the old and the new electrical infrastructures and makes the overall protection more robust and reliable.This paper will discuss the benefits of implementing smart relaying, specifically for the above-mentioned applications within cement plants.

title: River water collection system using embedded systems for the analysis of basic characteristics in real time
authors: Jean Paul Mata Quevedo, Diego Efraín Verdugo Ormaza, Jaime Eduardo Rojas Coronel, Carlos Mauricio Orellana Uguña, Santiago Arturo Moscoso, Luis J. Serpa Andrade
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Numerous initiatives have emerged worldwide to improve water quality monitoring and management in global context where water treatment and preservation are critical. This project, grounded in an extensive literature review, aims to enable the efficient acquisition of key water quality parameters, including $\mathbf{p H}$, conductivity, turbidity, temperature, and dissolved oxygen. The collected data is accessible through a mobile application and a desktop platform, supporting real-time monitoring and analysis. This article presents a comprehensive overview of the project, from its conceptual design to final implementation, detailing the methodology adopted throughout each phase-planning, data acquisition, storage, and visualization. The proposed solution contributes to environmental protection by facilitating continuous monitoring of one of the planet’s most vital resources: water.

title: Federated Learning over Wireless Ad Hoc Networks: Comparative Evaluation of Aggregation Methods on Non-IID Data
authors: Fernando Patricio Carranco-Avila, Leticia Lemus-Cáardenas, Juan Pablo Astudillo-Le´n, Wilman Roberto Su´Arez Zambrano, Ahmad Mohamad Mezher
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Unlike traditional centralized learning-which requires aggregating all raw data in a single repository-federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across distributed devices while preserving data privacy by exchanging only model parameters. This paper presents a privacy-preserving FL framework deployed on a wireless ad hoc edge network of lowcost Raspberry Pi devices. A minimal Bash script automates the configuration of the MANET topology, ensuring scalability and resilience across embedded nodes. We implemented a lightweight TCP message protocol to transmit model parameters and control signals, keeping local datasets private throughout. To validate the framework, we employed the IBM Telco Customer Churn dataset-chosen for its complexity and imbalance-though the approach generalizes to other tabular problems. We systematically evaluated four aggregation methods (FedAvg, FedProx, FedNova, and FedAvgM) under both IID and non-IID partitions, and compared them to a centralized baseline trained on the entire combined dataset collected from all clients in one place. Results show that while FedNova excelled under balanced conditions, FedAvgM was more robust to heterogeneous client distributions. These findings highlight the practicality of deploying federated neural networks on infrastructure-free edge environments, achieving competitive performance without sharing sensitive raw data.

title: Evaluating Clustering Metrics for Time-Series Data: A Power Test Approach
authors: Mohammad Idhom, Amri Muhaimin, Aviolla Terza Damaliana, Trimono, Muhammad Nasrudin, Shindi Shella May Wara
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Unsupervised learning is a machine learning method that identifies patterns in unlabeled data by grouping similar observations. The primary goal is to map data based on inherent characteristics using clustering techniques. To determine the optimal number of clusters, evaluation metrics such as the Silhouette Score, Davies-Bouldin Index (DBI), and Calinski-Harabasz Index (CHI) are commonly used. A good clustering result is achieved when within-group variation is minimal and between-group variation is large. However, these metrics often yield inconsistent results, leading to potential bias in deciding the ideal cluster number. This study aims to evaluate which metric performs best using a power test. The dataset used is time-series data with 38 observations and 487 features, clustered across six datasets with identical dimensions. Clustering experiments were conducted with 2 to 10 clusters, and metrics were calculated for each configuration. Analysis revealed discrepancies among the three indices, where Silhouette suggested 2 clusters, DBI 10 clusters, and CHI 8 clusters. A power test on this case showed that the DBI achieved a 90% performance rate, outperforming the Silhouette and CHI metrics in determining the optimal number of clusters.

title: Incremental Learning for Drought Prediction with CatBoost on Time-Series Data
authors: Andri Fauzan Adziima, Amri Muhaimin, Aviolla Terza Damaliana, Alfan Rizaldy Pratama, Kartika Maulida Hindrayani, Dwi Arman Prasetya
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: This research explores the application of continual learning within non-neural network models, specifically focusing on the CatBoost algorithm for time-series classification tasks. The study uses a drought dataset sourced from Kaggle, spanning from 2000 to 2016, to predict drought conditions across U.S. counties. Unlike traditional static learning, where models are retrained from scratch, continual learning allows the model to update incrementally with new data, preserving prior knowledge and adapting to evolving data distributions. The performance of the continual learning approach is evaluated using ROC AUC, which measures the model’s ability to differentiate between drought and nondrought conditions. The results show that continual learning outperforms static learning in $71 \%$ of the iterations, with an average ROC AUC score of $65.0 \%$, compared to $60.5 \%$ for static learning. Additionally, continual learning demonstrates significant advantages in terms of memory consumption and training time, processing only new data while avoiding the need for full retraining. This study highlights the potential of continual learning as a more efficient and scalable solution for real-time predictions in dynamic environments, such as drought forecasting. The findings suggest that continual learning, even without deep learning models, can provide a viable alternative for time-series forecasting tasks that require model adaptation over time.

title: A Spatial Investigation of Motor Vehicle Theft in East Java using the Geographically Weighted Regression Approach
authors: I Gede Susrama Mas Diyasa, Affa Lelira Ibrahim, Irma Dwi Kusuma, Vinza Hedi Satria, Amri Muhaimin, Ani Dijah Rahajoe
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: This study investigates the spatial distribution and underlying factors influencing the number of motor vehicle theft cases across East Java Province by employing the Geographically Weighted Regression (GWR) model, creating some insights through the data. The analysis reveals that incidents are not evenly distributed and are closely linked to the local socio-economic conditions. Unlike conventional global regression models, GWR effectively captures spatial heterogeneity in the relationship between predictor variables and crime occurrences. The number of police posts demonstrates a consistently positive impact across most regions, whereas the open unemployment rate shows significant effects only in selected districts. The model exhibits strong performance, indicated by an R -squared value of 0.806 and a relatively low Residual Sum of Squares (RSS) compare to others. Additionally, the lower Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) value suggests better model efficiency. These findings highlight the importance of incorporating local characteristics when designing more targeted and effective public safety policies.

title: Implementation IoT and Firebase for Oncom Fermentation Process Monitoring System
authors: Yogi Aldi Saputra, Ibrahim Lammada, Emny Harna Yossy, Ulinnuha Latifa
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The traditional fermentation of oncom in Indonesia is still conducted manually without adequate monitoring of key environmental parameters such as temperature and humidity. This condition often leads to inconsistent product quality, delayed detection of ripeness, and potential microbial contamination. To address these challenges, this study designed and implemented an Internet of Things (IoT)-based monitoring system using Raspberry Pi 4 Model B, DHT22 sensor, and Firebase integration, enabling real-time data acquisition through a Human Machine Interface (HMI) and a mobile application. Experimental results showed that the temperature sensor achieved an average deviation of $0.47^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ with $93.33 \%$ accuracy, while the humidity sensor had a $0.55 \%$ RH deviation with the same accuracy, confirming their reliability. Data transmission trials succeeded in 30 attempts, demonstrating stable communication among devices, network, and cloud for temperature, humidity, and image data. Network Quality of Service analysis revealed that one provider consistently delivered superior performance (3.09 Mbps throughput, $0.0119 \%$ packet loss, 0.37 ms delay/jitter). Furthermore, blackbox and whitebox testing verified that all mobile application features worked correctly with clean logic and responsive performance. These results confirm the system’s feasibility for efficient, stable, and automated monitoring of oncom fermentation.

title: Optimizing Leukemia Classification with FineTuned SENet Variants: A Comparative Study on Binary and Multi-Class Tasks
authors: Humaira Nisar, Kye-Fung Lee, Siti Atiyah Ali
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Leukemia, a blood cancer diagnosed primarily through microscopic examination of blood smears, poses challenges due to the cost, time, and labor-intensive nature of the process. This paper proposes an automated deep learningbased approach for leukemia classification, addressing two tasks: (i) binary classification between acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) and healthy cells (HTL), and (ii) five-class classification involving ALL, acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), and HTL. Microscopic images were obtained from the ALL Image Database (ALL-IDB1) and the American Society of Hematology (ASH) Image Bank. Transfer learning was applied using three state-of-the-art models: Inception-V3, ResNeXt, and SENet. Results demonstrate that SENet consistently outperforms the other models. To further enhance performance, three SENet variants were developed by integrating support vector machine (SVM) classifiers, additional hidden layers with diverse feature vectors, and dropout regularization. The best-performing variant (SENet-D), combining feature selection with dropout regularization, achieved testing accuracies of $99.84 \%$ for binary classification and $\mathbf{8 4. 4 8 \%}$ for five-class classification, establishing its robustness and effectiveness for automated leukemia detection.

title: Multiclass Prediction of Bug Resolution Time Using Context-Aware Machine Learning Models
authors: Maritza Vaca, Ricardo Flores-Moyano, Maria Baldeon-Calisto
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Accurately predicting bug resolution time is a persistent challenge in software development and is often complicated by subjective factors and noisy data. This work proposes a robust machine learning pipeline that classifies bug resolution time into four ordinal categories (Immediate, Fast, Normal, and Long) by leveraging project metadata from large-scale repositories, such as GitHub and Jira. The methodology includes comprehensive exploratory data analysis, statistical outlier removal, and advanced feature engineering to derive contextual variables that encapsulate historical projects and component-level behavior. Three machine learning classifiers (Random Forest, XGBoost, and MLPClassifier) were evaluated under various data balancing strategies. While tree-based models showed signs of overfitting, the MLP Classifier achieved superior generalization when enhanced with engineered features, which was validated through cross-validated learning curves and hyperparameter optimization. Our findings underscore the importance of contextual feature design and advance state-of-the-art bug resolution modeling by integrating multiclass classification, temporal context, and model interpretability.

title: Implementation of a Secure Communication Solution for small and medium-sized companies under the Hub and Spoke Model using GRE Tunnels over IPsec using FortiGate in a Simulated Environment with GNS3
authors: Chamorro-Quijije Adrian Alejandro, Salazar-Jácome Martha Elizabeth, De La Torre-Guzmán José Javier, Salazar-Achig Edgar Roberto
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents a secure communication solution based on the Hub and Spoke model. The proposal uses GRE tunnels over IPsec and FortiGate firewalls in a simulation environment with GNS3, with the aim of evaluating its technical feasibility, efficiency in the use of resources and scalability. A virtual laboratory was designed that simulates a distributed business network. In this scenario, a central node manages encrypted traffic between branch offices, leveraging the encapsulation and security features offered by GRE and IPsec protocols. It was necessary to establish static and dynamic routes, security policies, authentication mechanisms and AES256 encryption, to demonstrate that this type of architecture guarantees the confidentiality and integrity of data, with optimal performance and easy management, becoming an optimal alternative to be implemented in small and mediumsized companies that have limited resources. The use of GNS3 made it possible to recreate real scenarios without the need to invest in expensive infrastructure, this makes it a secure solution, easily scalable for companies that are developing and that want to protect their communication and keep it fluid in all the offices they have.

title: Blockchain-Based Model for Monitoring Employees Vital Signs
authors: Venelin Maleshkov, Veneta Aleksieva, Hristo Valchanov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The rapid adoption of wearable devices for monitoring employees’ vital signs in industrial and high-risk environments raises new challenges regarding data security, privacy and trust. Traditional centralized monitoring systems are prone to vulnerabilities, lack transparency and often fail to guarantee meaningful employee consent. This paper proposes a blockchain-based model that integrates wearable devices, Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) communication and HyperLedger Fabric to ensure secure, transparent and auditable management of physiological data. The model leverages BLE to provide energy-efficient, real-time data transmission, while HyperLedger Fabric enables immutable and permissioned storage, smart contract-based automation and controlled data access for stakeholders such as safety managers, medical staff and insurers. A two-channel topology is introduced to optimize data handling by separating early-warning threshold events from detailed emergency medical records, thereby reducing unnecessary storage of sensitive information. Through this architecture, the proposed system addresses major barriers such as data reliability and minimizes the risks of arbitrary usage and misuse of personal information.

title: FPGA-Based RISC-V SoC with Intra-Frame H.264 Encoder
authors: Minh-Phat Le Tang, Anh-Khoi Nguyen, Phuoc-Tai Dao, Hoai-Nhan Nguyen, Thanh-Khiet Cao, Hieu-Truong Ngo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study presents the design and implementation of a System-on-Chip (SoC) on the Xilinx Virtex-7 VC707 field-programmable gate array platform. The system integrates a custom 32-bit RISC-V processor with an H.264 intra-frame video encoder, forming a tightly coupled architecture for efficient and scalable embedded video processing. The processor adopts a five-stage pipeline with mechanisms for handling data and control hazards and communicates with the encoder through an AXI-Lite interface. Video data in YUV 4:2:0 format is stored in external memory and transferred using a direct memory access unit to maintain continuous throughput. Operating with separate clock domains for the processor and encoder, the system ensures synchronized performance. Experimental results show correct RISC-V instruction execution and standard-compliant H.264 bitstream generation. The combination achieves a peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) above 35 decibels at full high-definition resolution and 30 frames per second, confirming the effectiveness of integrating RISC-V with H.264 for high-quality, real-time video compression.

title: Efficient FPGA-Based Implementation of YOLOv3-Tiny for Real-Time Traffic Sign Detection
authors: Xuan-Dung Nguyen, Tri Gia-Bao Do, Minh-Bao Nguyen, Thanh-Phat Nguyen, Hieu-Truong Ngo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: With the increasing prevalence of artificial intelligence across diverse domains, the demand for real-time object detection has become critical, particularly in intelligent surveillance and advanced driver-assistance systems. However, deploying deep learning models on resource-constrained hardware such as FPGAs remains challenging due to limited resources and computational complexity. This study focuses on optimizing and implementing the YOLOv3-Tiny model on the Xilinx Kria KV260 FPGA platform equipped with a dedicated Deep Processing Unit (DPU). Post-training quantization (PTQ), network pruning, and architectural refinements are employed to reduce computational cost, accelerate inference, and optimize hardware resource utilization. Experimental results demonstrate that the system achieves 60 FPS on single images and 30 FPS on video streams, while maintaining a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 96% compared to 97.75% of the original model, and successfully recognizing 43 types of traffic signs. These findings not only validate the feasibility of deploying deep learning on FPGAs but also highlight the trade-offs among performance, accuracy, and resource utilization, thereby underscoring their potential in real-time embedded systems requiring high efficiency and low power consumption.

title: Mechatronic coupling design proposal for integrating milling and drilling tools on the KUKA KR 16 robot
authors: Josué D. Trujillo-Terán, Amelia N. Suárez-Jadán, Angel E. Cárdenas-Cadme, Paúl A. Chasi-Pesántez, Josué P. Romero-Verdugo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The manufacturing of components with complex geometries necessitates the adoption of advanced technologies, as conventional methods often fall short in achieving such intricate shapes. In this context, robotic machining has emerged as a leading alternative due to its flexibility, adaptability, and precision. This study presents the mechatronic design of a tool coupling system for milling and drilling applications using the KUKA KR 16 robot. The proposed design compares two coupling configurations: one mounted perpendicularly to the robot’s flange, and the other inclined at 45 degrees. The evaluation includes an analysis of cutting forces during the machining of expanded polystyrene (EPS), along with the corresponding bending moments and structural deformations. Additionally, a kinematic analysis of various machining processes is conducted to assess the standard deviation and angular variation range of the robot’s joints during operation. The results demonstrate that the deformations and bending moments experienced by both couplings do not compromise the structural integrity of the robotic system. Furthermore, the analysis indicates that the perpendicular coupling offers superior performance for horizontal surface machining, while the 45-degree inclined design is better suited for inclined surface operations.

title: Quantum-Inspired Strategies: Bridging Classical and Quantum Computing for Enhanced Optimization in Structural Engineering and Feature Selection
authors: Alejandra Ospina, Daniel Riofrío, Felipe Grijalva, José Vega-Sánchez, Pablo Torres, Diego Benítez, Noel Pérez-Pérez, Maria Baldeon-Calisto
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper explores a quantum-inspired approach to optimization by incorporating quantum random numbers (QRNs) into classical bio-inspired algorithms. Specifically, it applies Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) and Genetic Algorithms (GAs) to two tasks: parameter fitting of the Extended Base Plate-Embedded Anchor Bolts (EBP-EAB) seismic model and feature selection from high-dimensional seismic datasets. Experiments compare QRNs with pseudorandom numbers (PRNs), showing that although the final metrics are similar, QRNs consistently yield faster convergence. In the EBP-EAB model, QRNs reduced the number of iterations needed to reach the optimal error. In feature selection, QRNs reduced the generations required to achieve high-quality subsets without compromising accuracy. These results suggest that QRNs enhance convergence efficiency, positioning hybrid quantum-classical computing as a practical strategy for complex optimization in structural engineering and machine learning.

title: Polar-Coded Alamouti MIMO Transmission over Rayleigh Channels
authors: Ana-Maria Grigoras Oanca, Mihaela Andrei, Daniela Tarniceriu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Polar codes are known as a great coding scheme used in several of the latest communication technologies, alongside other coding schemes, such as the Alamouti code. In this paper, we propose a Polar-Coded Alamouti MIMO system, and we evaluate its performance achieved over additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channels with Rayleigh fading. We analyzed the proposed system under different types of modulation and for various values of the polar code parameters: block-length N and dimension K. The simulation results show that if the rate R of the polar code has a value that is closer to 0, the Alamouti-polar configuration exhibits a lower bit error rate (BER), in comparison to the standalone Alamouti and polar code. The system is more robust in the case of binary phase shift keying (BPSK), and the worst scenario is found with 16 quadrature amplitude modulation (16-QAM).

title: User Interface/User Experience Design of a Voice of Customer Application using Design Thinking Method
authors: Muhammad Naufal Rinaldi, Dinda Rizki Pangesti, Daffa Damas Yoridho, Sucianna Ghadati Rabiha
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The rapid development of digital technology encourages the banking sector to continuously innovate in improving service quality. However, manual evaluation systems such as suggestion boxes are considered less effective. Service innovation is needed to provide customer satisfaction through a web-based voice of customer (VoC) application design. This study aims to optimize service innovation through a web-based VoC application at PT Bank Pembangunan Daerah Jawa Timur Tbk Syariah Branch Sidoarjo. This research employs a quantitative method utilizing a Likert scale for measurement. The study measures customer satisfaction with existing services and analyzes the potential impact of the proposed VoC application on enhancing service innovation. The findings indicate that such an application can effectively accommodate customer feedback flexibly and in real-time, a key evaluation tool to improve the quality of bank services and facilities, thereby increasing overall customer satisfaction. This research contributes to the practical application of Design Thinking in developing user-centric banking solutions.

title: Efficiency of Immobilized Chlorella sp in Sodium Alginate and Luffa Matrices for the Bioremediation of Shrimp Farm Effluents
authors: Santiago Mafla, Cristina Stephanía Ponce, Moraima Mera
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Bioremediation with microalgae has been limited due to the difficulty of separating the substrates on which they are cultured, owing to their small size and high cost. The main objective of this study was to evaluate the actual efficiency of immobilized microalgal cultures for the bioremediation of effluents from a shrimp farm, and to assess their growth within a sodium alginate polymer matrix or luffa support.In the first experimental phase, a halotolerance test was conducted over two weeks to verify the adaptability of the Chlorella sp. strain to the experimental conditions used in later stages. A final cell density of $4.8 \times 10^{6}$ cells $\mathbf{~ m L}^{-1}$ was obtained.Batch experiments were conducted for ten days under photoperiod conditions $(12 / 12 \mathrm{~h})$ and constant aeration $(43 \mathrm{~mL}$ min $^{-1}$), using the following treatments: Chlorella sp. immobilized in sodium alginate spheres, Chlorella sp. immobilized in luffa, Chlorella sp. in suspension, and untreated wastewater as a control. The sodium alginate treatment proved to be the most effective in nutrient removal, achieving removal efficiencies of $\mathbf{8 4 \%} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{7 1 \%} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{7 7 \%}$, and $\mathbf{6 1 \%}$ for ammonium, nitrites, nitrates, and phosphates, respectively. This treatment also reached a final cell density of $18.2 \times 10^{6}$ cells $\mathbf{~ m L}^{-1}$. In the case of luffa, removal efficiencies of $\mathbf{4 0 \%}, \mathbf{9 5 \%}, \mathbf{5 4 \%}$, and $\mathbf{4 2 \%}$ were observed for the same parameters, consistent with previous reports. The final cell density reached $32.6 \times 10^{6}$ cells $\mathbf{~ m L}^{-1}$. In contrast, the suspended algae treatment showed an increase in nutrient concentrations and a decrease in cell density, demonstrating that the immobilization matrix acts as a physical barrier that protects the microalgae from hostile environmental conditions while allowing the passage of nutrientsIn the adsorption-based immobilization process using luffa, a final cell density of $\mathbf{2 4. 5} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{1 0}^{\mathbf{6}}$ cells $\mathbf{~ m L}^{\mathbf{- 1}}$ was obtained.

title: Significant Increase in China's Mangrove Cover Fraction during 1990 to 2023
authors: Xinzhi Wang, Huiying Li, Mingming Jia, Rong Zhang, Chuanpeng Zhao, Chunyan Lu, Zongming Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Mangrove forests are critical ecosystems for global climate mitigation and coastal resilience. However, global and regional assessments of their health and recovery are often based on binary metrics of areal extent (presence/absence). This approach can be misleading, as it overlooks crucial structural changes, such as canopy densification, which are fundamental to ecosystem function. Consequently, the true efficacy of large-scale conservation efforts and the actual recovery of ecosystem services may be significantly misjudged. To address this limitation, we developed a novel framework integrating time-series Landsat (1990-2023), very-high-resolution, and UAV imagery to generate the first national-scale, 30 m resolution China Mangrove Cover Fraction (CMCF) dataset. Our analysis reveals a profound structural transformation: the national mean mangrove cover fraction (MCF) increased from 47% in 1990 to 70% in 2023. This structural enhancement, not just areal expansion, was a primary driver for a marked improvement in ecosystem services, with the national average coastal defense capacity increasing to 2.38 times its 1990 level by 2023. Furthermore, we document a significant northward migration of the MCF-weighted centroid, signaling large-scale biogeographical shifts in response to intensive management and environmental change. By moving beyond binary classifications, we provide robust, quantitative evidence that structural densification is a key determinant of the functional recovery of a major coastal ecosystem. These findings provide a more nuanced and accurate framework for evaluating large-scale conservation initiatives, offering critical evidence to advance the quantification of ecosystem services and guide more effective coastal environmental management.

title: Achieving Linear-Scaling Throughput in Covert Ambient Backscatter Communication via Non-Colluding Replay
authors: Qianyun Zhang, Jiting Shi, Bi-Yi Wu, Guan Gui, Marco Di Renzo, Dusit Niyato, Hikmet Sari
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Traditional covert ambient backscatter communication (AmBC) systems suffer from a fundamental throughput limitation governed by the square root law (SRL), restricting reliable covert transmission to O(√n) bits over n channel uses. To overcome this limitation, we introduce a non-colluding replay node that retransmits ambient radio frequency (RF) signals with randomized power, significantly increasing channel uncertainty faced by an adversarial warden (Willie) while preserving compatibility with low-power AmBC architectures. Through rigorous theoretical analysis, we demonstrate that this approach enables linear scaling of covert throughput without necessitating power reduction or prior knowledge of ambient RF signal characteristics. Furthermore, it guarantees that Willie’s total detection error probability can be driven arbitrarily close to 1, specifically PFA + PMD = 1 − ϵ for any ϵ > 0, simultaneously achieving an arbitrarily low decoding error probability at the legitimate receiver (Bob). Unlike conventional jamming-based solutions requiring stringent synchronization or complex multi-antenna configurations, our replay mechanism operates independently from covert communication participants, substantially simplifying the decoding architecture for the legitimate receiver and reducing synchronization overhead. By increasing the ambient signal power uncertainty, the proposed architecture provides a robust, scalable framework suitable for high-rate covert communication scenarios in IoT and privacy-sensitive applications, achieving an effective balance among covertness, energy efficiency, and system robustness.

title: Automated Cross-Level Verification for Heterogeneous Systems Using Attribute Recursive Hypergraph and Fault-Tolerant Bus Resolver
authors: Keli Long, Fangfa Fu, Defu Hu, Liangquan Qiao, Jinghan Zhou, Jinxiang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: In the post-Moore era, heterogeneous integrated systems—such as chiplet-based designs—exhibit increasingly complex functional interface interconnections, demanding scalable and accurate verification methods. Traditional manual approaches are time-consuming and error-prone, while mainstream EDA tools lack standardized cross-level models and comprehensive multi-level rule checking. To address these limitations, we propose an automated verification mechanism based on an Attribute Recursive Hypergraph (ARH). The method constructs a five-layer hierarchical mapping network (component → interface → signal cluster → signal → pad) to represent architecture-to-schematic relationships. Verification proceeds in two stages. First, a Fault-Tolerant Bus Resolver (FT-Bus Resolver) applies matrix operations to extract interface structures from pad-netlists and generates a multi-level hypergraph. These structures are compared with system architecture for consistency. Second, a hierarchical rule base, executed by a Rule Executor, validates electrical compatibility and bus-topology constraints across abstraction levels. The implementation integrates a reusable component model library, recursive hypergraph representations, and a rule execution framework, which bridges semantic gaps and supports complex constraint checking. Experiments demonstrate full coverage and 100% correctness for 54 interface-level rules, compared with only one rule supported by commercial EDA tools. Across 7,350 connections and 6,500 injected errors, the framework eliminates all false positives, reduces missed errors by 63%, achieves 1,125×/1,034× speedups for consistency and rule checking, and exhibits near-linear memory growth for scalable deployment. Together, these results demonstrate that the proposed mechanism offers a scalable, robust, and high-coverage solution for cross-level verification in emerging heterogeneous and chiplet-based systems.

title: Equivalent Measurement and Removal of Primary Field Effect Using a cm-Level Coil in Time-Domain Electromagnetic Surveys
authors: Yanju Ji, Weiyi Wang, Shilin Qiu, Yibing Yu, Huaishi Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The superposition of the primary field in time-domain electromagnetic (TDEM) surveys can severely degrade data quality, especially during the early stage after the transmitting current is turned off, resulting in shallow detection blind spots. To address this problem, this paper proposes a cm-level coil–based method for equivalent measurement and removal of the primary field. By driving the cm-level coil with a proportionally reduced current, an equivalent primary field is generated while the induced secondary field remains negligible. The receiving system directly measures this equivalent primary field, enabling its subtraction from the observational data. The method was validated through field experiments using 4 m × 4 m and 50 m × 50 m transmitting coils, where residual primary fields from the bucking device and the complete primary field of the large loop were effectively removed. Consequently, the effective observation window was extended by 150 μs and 278 μs, respectively. The method significantly enhances shallow detection capability and exhibits broad applicability across TDEM system scales.

title: Hierarchical Optimization-Based Multi-UAV Cooperative Trajectory Planning and Integration of Sensing and Communication
authors: Peng Hou, Sen Liu, Hongbin Zhu, Jin Wang, Zhihui Lu, Shin-Chia Huang, Yang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: With the rapid development of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) technology, UAV-aided integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems have become one of the core technologies for next-generation wireless networks. However, in multi-UAV collaborative scenarios, the problem of jointly optimizing trajectory planning and resource allocation for energy management, makespan minimization, and load balancing is inherently a complex mixed- integer nonlinear programming problem. Existing methods fail to strike an effective balance between solution quality, computational efficiency, and scalability. To tackle this challenge, we propose a hierarchical optimization-based multi-UAV collaborative ISAC framework (HO-ISAC), which facilitates efficient multi-UAV collaboration via a two-stage mechanism: offline global trajectory planning and online flight control integrated with resource allocation. In the offline trajectory planning phase, multi-UAV trajectory coordination optimization is achieved through the integration of k-means clustering, simulated annealing, 2-OPT local optimization, and adaptive large neighborhood search techniques. In the online phase, dynamic adjustment of sensing and communication resources is realized through discretized parameter space search. Experimental results demonstrate that HO-ISAC significantly outperforms baseline algorithms in key metrics such as makespan, total energy consumption, and service fairness, while exhibiting excellent scalability and high solving efficiency.

title: Advanced Optical Design and Evaluation of a Plenoptic Microscope for Extended 3D Imaging Capabilities
authors: Chihoon Kim, Myungjoo Kang, Munseob Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Plenoptic systems represent a significant advancement in imaging technology, enabling sophisticated three-dimensional image capture with a single exposure. This study presents the development of a microscope system for microscale applications, based on plenoptic principles. The proposed system incorporates a microlens array designed and fabricated with minimal errors through optical simulation and a custom-designed lens jig. Precise optical alignment was performed to optimize the system performance, ensuring improved spatial resolution and depth of field by matching the numerical apertures of the microlens array and the tube lens. The system achieved a spatial resolution of 12.4 μm, with contrast ratios of 90% and 97% in the horizontal and vertical directions, respectively. Additionally, the depth of field was enhanced by 1.6 times, increasing from the theoretical value of 630 μm to 1000 μm. The analysis revealed that high-frequency components were more sensitive to variations in the depth of field relative to the spatial frequency, whereas low-frequency components maintained high clarity over an extended range.

title: Joint Beamforming Design in Multi-STAR-RISs Aided Cell-free Massive MIMO Networks
authors: Zhichao Gao, Ruikang Zhong, Xidong Mu, Zhengfeng Du, Ju Liu, Yuanwei Liu
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Multiple simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (STAR-RISs) aided cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF mMIMO) network is investigated. A long-term sum-rate maximization problem is formulated to jointly optimize the active beamforming at each access point (AP) and the passive beamforming at each STAR-RIS while satisfying the quality of service (QoS) requirements. To address this non-convex problem with challenges caused by user mobility and high-dimensional optimization variables, two deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based beamforming algorithms are proposed. Firstly, a soft actor-critic (SAC)-based centralized joint beamforming algorithm is proposed, which adds maximum entropy term to the objective function and provides an exceptional exploration-exploitation trade-off. However, since the centralized scheme might suffer from high communication loads and latency, we generalize the proposed approach into a distributed control. A multi-agent SAC (MASAC)-based distributed beamforming algorithm is further proposed, which employs the centralized training and decentralized execution (CTDE) framework, where each AP plays a role of an agent and makes decisions based on local observations. Simulation results demonstrate that: 1) The multiple STAR-RISs can effectively improve the performance of the CF mMIMO networks compared to other baseline schemes; 2) Both SAC-based and MASAC-based beamforming algorithms can maximize the sum-rate and guarantee the QoS of users in the long term; and 3) The MASAC-based beamforming algorithm performs better and converges faster than the SAC-based beamforming algorithm as it reduces the overall complexity and alleviates pressure on the fronthaul link transmission by making decentralized decisions.

title: Sequential Inference for Non-Gaussian Additive Processes
authors: Zixin Liu, Simon Godsill
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing
abstract: In this paper, we introduce dynamical models based on Stochastic Differential Equations (SDE)s driven by additive processes. Additive processes are intuitively obtained as time-varying versions of Lévy processes, and we adopt this formalism to model properties that may change over time, for example the skewness of the process. While the framework is quite general, we take an $\alpha$-stable process with time-varying skew as a concrete example, demonstrating the effect of time-varying skew on the expected direction of motion of an object. The framework is constructed based on a generalised shot-noise representation of an additive process. We show how to perform joint inference about states and skew of the model, based on a marginalised particle filter framework. Finally, performance is demonstrated on both simulated and real data and improved performance is observed compared with competitor models.

title: Cybersecurity Enhancement in Digital Substations: Hidden Markov Model-Based Smart Cyber Switching and Threat Response
authors: Mansi Girdhar, Kuchan Park, Wencong Su, Junho Hong, Chen-Ching Liu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The rising incidence of cyber-attacks on critical infrastructure and power grids poses significant threats to the stability and reliability of electrical substations, with potentially devastating consequences such as extended blackouts. This paper introduces an advanced cybersecurity framework aimed at safeguarding IEC 61850-based substations through the integration of software-defined networking (SDN) and digital twin (DT) technologies. The proposed DT-based framework employs smart cyber switching (SCS) for proactive threat mitigation and concurrent intelligent electronic device (CIED) for swift system restoration, thereby maintaining continuous operational integrity and robust cybersecurity defenses. Central to this framework is the adaptive port controller (APC), which enables dynamic port management to adapt to evolving threats, and an intrusion detection system (IDS) designed to detect and neutralize malicious attacks on IEC 61850-based sampled value (SV) and generic object-oriented substation event (GOOSE) messages within the substation’s communication network. Further, novel predictive intrusion detection and response (PIDR) algorithm is implemented on a digital substation (DS) to predict the best route to be taken by the attacker. The efficacy of these comprehensive cybersecurity frameworks is validated through rigorous simulations and a hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) testbed, showcasing the system’s ability to sustain substation operations amidst cyber-attacks.

title: Edge Feature Extraction Medical Image Segmentation Network Based on Frequency Domain Data Enhancement
authors: Chaofan Li, Qiong Liu, Jinnan Teng
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Accurate boundary segmentation of anatomically complex structures such as organs and tumors remains a major challenge in medical image analysis. Traditional segmentation methods often overlook the extraction of high-frequency information such as texture and boundary details, despite their critical importance in guiding clinical surgical planning. To address this issue, we proposed a hierarchical frequency-domain enhancement strategy in the encoder, which performs effective separation and reconstruction of high- and low-frequency features via Fourier transform combined with a low-pass masking operation. This design enhances the model’s sensitivity to high-frequency texture and fine-grained boundary signals. Furthermore, in the decoder, we introduce a boundary refinement mechanism that dynamically combines Scharr operators with Laplacian-based sharpening to enhance structural clarity. This effectively alleviates segmentation discontinuities and boundary fragmentation issues commonly observed in regions with blurred edges using conventional methods. We conduct extensive experiments on both the BraTS 2020 MRI dataset and the Synapse CT dataset. Our method achieves an average Dice score of 86.79% on BraTS 2020 and 84.23% on Synapse, representing relative improvements of 0.99% and 0.90%, respectively, over strong state-of-the-art baselines. In terms of boundary precision, our approach reduces the 95% Hausdorff Distance (HD) by 13.2% on BraTS 2020 and 30.1% on Synapse, demonstrating superior boundary segmentation capability. Ablation studies further validate the effectiveness of each proposed component.

title: Stochastic Sparse Sampling: A Variable-Length Time Series Classification Framework for Seizure Onset Zone Localization
authors: Xavier Mootoo, Alan A. Díaz-Montiel, Milad Lankarany, Hina Tabassum
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Variable-length time series classification (VTSC) problems are prevalent in healthcare applications, such as heart rate monitoring and electrophysiological recordings, where sequence length varies among patients and events. VTSC is challenging as finite-context models such as Transformers require padding, truncation, or interpolation, leading to distortion in the input data, higher computational costs, and overfitting, while infinite-context models including recurrent neural networks struggle with overcompression and unstable gradients over long sequences. In this paper, we develop a novel VTSC framework based on Stochastic Sparse Sampling (SSS) for seizure onset zone (SOZ) localization, a critical VTSC problem requiring identification of seizure-inducing brain regions from variable-length electrophysiological time series. The proposed framework sparsely samples time series windows to compute local predictions, which are then aggregated and calibrated to form a global prediction. SSS provides post-hoc insights into local signal characteristics related to the SOZ, by visualizing temporally averaged local predictions throughout the signal. We evaluate our method on the Epilepsy intracranial electroencephalography (iEEG) Multicenter Dataset, a heterogeneous collection of iEEG recordings obtained from four independent medical centers. The proposed solution outperforms state-of-the-art (SOTA) baselines across most medical centers, and superior performance on all out-of-distribution (OOD) unseen medical centers.
