title: Let’s Talk About It: Making Scientific Computational Reproducibility Easier
authors: Lázaro Costa, Susana Barbosa, Jácome Cunha
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Computational reproducibility-the ability to reexecute a scientific experiment using the same code, data, and configuration-should be straightforward. However, researchers often struggle with inconsistencies in documentation, missing dependencies, and environment setup, which undermines the credibility of scientific results. To address this, we propose a conversational, text-based tool that aids researchers in reproducing and packaging computational experiments into a single file. This file can be re-executed with a double-click on any machine, requiring only a single tool. SciConv is designed to support two key scenarios: (i) enabling researchers to prepare their own experiments in a reproducible, shareable format, and (ii) helping other researchers reproduce existing experiments from shared code repositories. In both cases, the tool reduces technical overhead and simplifies environment configuration through conversational interaction. We evaluated the tool through two studies. In the first, we reproduced 15 of 18 published experiments, with most requiring little or no user interaction. In the second, we conducted a user study comparing our tool with a professional platform, using the System Usability Scale (SUS) and NASA Task Load Index (TLX). The results show a statistically significant advantage for our tool in both usability and workload, demonstrating its effectiveness in supporting reproducibility.

title: Enhancing Issue Labeling in Open-source Projects
authors: Amir Hossain Raj, Sadia Afrin Mim, Fairuz Nawer Meem
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: GitHub serves as the primary platform for software maintenance within the open-source community. Developers frequently report issues, ranging from bug reports to feature requests, on GitHub. The presence of well-maintained labels on these issues significantly enhances the problem-solving process by providing immediate context and facilitating the assignment of appropriate personnel, thereby expediting development. However, a substantial number of open-source repositories on GitHub lack consistent and comprehensive issue labeling. This paper addresses this challenge by proposing a classification framework for GitHub issues using ML, DNN & Transformer models. We conducted an extensive analysis of prominent GitHub opensource repositories and classified issues into common categories (e.g.,Documentation, Bug). Our empirical study demonstrates that DNN models consistently outperform ML & Transformer models in this classification task, achieving an accuracy of up to 83.75%. This work contributes to improving the efficiency of open-source software development by automating a crucial aspect of issue management.

title: Comparative Analysis of GARCH-Family and LSTM-Based Models for Volatility Forecasting: Evidence from the Borsa İstanbul (BIST 100) Index
authors: Selahattin Kosunalp, Adem Korkmaz
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study presents a comparative evaluation of traditional econometric and deep learning approaches for modeling and forecasting financial market volatility. Using daily closing prices of the Borsa İstanbul (BIST 100) index spanning January 2015 to September 2024, the study investigates the predictive performance of GARCH(1,1), EGARCH(1,1,1), GJR-GARCH(1,1,1), and LSTM-based architectures. Volatility was proxied by the squared logarithmic return, and all models were assessed using multiple error metrics, including RMSE, MAE and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The empirical results indicate that the GJR-GARCH (1,1,1) approach achieved the best overall forecasting accuracy, exhibiting the lowest RMSE and MAE values and the highest explanatory power (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.205). Among the deep learning models, the LSTM and BiLSTM architectures produced comparable absolute error magnitudes but exhibited weaker variance explanation, reflected in negative R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values. Descriptive statistics revealed heavy tails, negative skewness, and strong volatility clustering in the BIST 100 return series, validating the use of ARCH-type models. Overall, the findings suggest that while GARCH-family models remain superior for capturing asymmetric and time-varying volatility in emerging markets, deep learning models provide a flexible, data-driven complement. Future research may benefit from hybrid frameworks that combine the interpretability of econometric models with the representational strength of neural architectures to enhance volatility prediction and risk assessment in financial markets.

title: Estimation of a Mobility Matrix for the City of Cuenca Based on Human Flow Data
authors: Santiago Torres, Pedro Perez, Jorge Fajardo, Nestor Rivera, Hernan Avila, Johnny Montenegro
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents a novel methodology to estimate an origin-destination (OD) mobility matrix for the city of Cuenca, Ecuador, using geospatial data obtained via the GPS Logger mobile application and machine learning techniques. From a sample of 380 individuals, urban travel patterns were identified through the analysis of trip micro-cycles. Travel routes were classified using a decision tree model, achieving an accuracy of 95.7 %, and indicating that the most frequented zones correspond to educational and commercial areas. The findings reveal that only 22 % of trips involve public transportation, while 78 % rely on private vehicles, emphasizing the urgent need to promote sustainable transport systems. The proposed methodology demonstrates significant potential for urban planning and data-informed policies.

title: Epileptic Seizure Detection in EEG using Machine Learning Approaches: A Systematic Review
authors: Arif Albastomi, Handayani Tjandrasa, Shintami Chusnul Hidayati
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Epilepsy is a complex neurological condition characterized by recurrent seizures resulting from abnormal electrical discharges in the brain. Electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings, which capture temporal and spatial changes in brain activity, serve as essential tools for the diagnosis and continuous monitoring of epilepsy. In recent developments, computational methods have shown substantial progress in automated seizure detection systems. This review focuses on four core components in EEG based seizure detection. Traditional machine learning approaches are outlined, emphasizing the role of statistical patterns and engineered features. Third, hybrid deep learning approaches are described that combine multiple model types to improve detection accuracy and generalization among diverse patient populations. Finally, advanced models such as Transformers and Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) are highlighted for their ability to model complex temporal and spatial EEG signal dynamics. This review offers a systematic and critical overview of current methodologies, with the aim of supporting future research efforts in EEG-based seizure detection systems and clinical deployment strategies.

title: Residue Number System-Driven DNA Cryptography for Telecommunication Security Education: Algorithm Design and Its Implementation Using Computer-Based Tools
authors: Adriana Borodzhieva
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents a novel DNA-based cryptographic algorithm underpinned by the Residue Number System (RNS), tailored for integration into the Telecommunication Security curriculum. By mapping plaintext integers into coprime residue classes, the RNS pre-processor efficiently converts numerical data into DNA base-pair representations, enabling lightweight yet secure encryption. We detail both the encryption and decryption workflows step-by-step, illustrating with a fully worked example that highlights the interplay between modular arithmetic and nucleotide encoding. To demonstrate practical viability and foster hands-on learning, we provide two complementary implementations: one realized entirely in Microsoft Excel using formulae and conditional formatting, and another scripted in MATLAB for performance analysis and visualization. Comparative results showcase the method’s robustness against brute-force and statistical attacks, while the spreadsheet version offers an intuitive platform for students to experiment with cryptographic concepts. This dual-tool approach bridges theory and practice, empowering educators and learners to explore DNA cryptography through familiar software environments.

title: Condition Monitoring and Fault Diagnosis of Synchronous Machines: Short Review
authors: Abdellah Belhaouzi, Mohammed Ouassaid, Hamza Sabir
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Synchronous machines (SMs) are key components of power systems, playing an important role in securing the continuity of the electrical power supply. To maintain optimal performance of these machines, it is essential to monitor their condition to recognize faults at an early stage and prevent serious damage. In this way, minor repairs can be done at the appropriate time, avoiding expensive repairs, and minimizing the loss of revenue due to production downtime. This paper outlines the most common failure mechanisms affecting the various components of SMs, identifying their root causes and their impact on machine performance. On this basis, it presents the main conventional diagnostic tests commonly used for assessing the condition of these machines, while discussing their applicability and restrictions. It further provides a critical analysis of the main approaches related in the scientific literature for condition monitoring and fault detection, highlighting their areas of application, comparative advantages and main limitations.

title: Performance Comparisons between Smart Antenna and MIMO Radar in Interference Environments
authors: Hyeon-Cheol Lee, Sang Gyu Lee, Sang Burm Ryu, Eun Su Kang, Myung Jin Baek, Jinhyuck Kim
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In this paper, the weights of element of the Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) radar with the number of N receiver elements and with the number of M transmitter elements are calculated on the method of the Minimum Variance (MV), then the performance on the beampattern to the Direction of Arrival (DoA) is compared between the smart antenna and the MIMO radar. Simulation results show that as the number of interfering signals increases, the smart antenna's beampattern fails to accurately point to the target's Direction of Arrival (DoA), but the MIMO radar leverages the expanded degrees of freedom provided by its M x N virtual antenna array effect to effectively track the target's DoA, even with numerous interfering signals. This study demonstrates that MIMO technology can significantly enhance the robustness of radar systems in highly interfered environments.

title: Engineering Inclusive: Head-Controlled Electronic Device for Human-Computer Interaction
authors: Caridad Gonzalez-Maldonado, Verónica Maldonado-Garcés, Jose Gerardo Acosta Arias, Elking Araujo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Interaction with the digital world is a recurrent barrier for people with physical disabilities, especially those with reduced or no upper limb mobility. Although peripheral human-computer interaction devices controlled by other limbs (lower limbs or head) exist, many are inaccessible due to their cost, complexity or lack of usability for the task. This study presents a working prototype of an electronic assistive humancomputer interaction device controlled by head movements, designed for users in low-resource environments. Based on Arduino Pro Micro and MPU-6050 IMU, the device translates head movements into on-screen pointer interaction control, with an automatic click function that is activated after 5 seconds of cursor fixation. The hardware is housed in a customized structure 3D printed using recycled PET-G and optimized for comfort and ease of use. The process was structured following a Human Centered Design (HCD) methodology, which iterated the development of the prototype with a group of real users with multiple disabilities served by a foundation whose activity is focused on the care of people with disabilities and motor problems. After calibration and parameter adjustment, users demonstrated improved interaction capabilities, with increased efficiency in the execution of key tasks such as on-screen pointer addressing and positioning and basic navigation, and user acceptance scores were established for usability. The device is portable, low-cost, and replicable, making it a promising option for initial testing and potential application in educational institutions, rehabilitation centers, and home environments. By removing interaction barriers, this solution contributes to social inclusion and contributes from a concrete application of biomedical engineering to assistive technologies. It is expected that future phases of the research will add assessments tailored to various usage scenarios and more complex tasks.

title: Engineering Framework for Integration of AI Technologies in Research and Academic Library Infrastructures
authors: Viktoriya Ivanova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Rapid introduction of multiple artificial intelligence (AI) instruments in all spheres of life has been observed during the last few years. Technological development widens human possibilities and humanity has the opportunity before to support changes in natural processes, to make unprecedented progress in medical sciences, and to foresee a real connection between human mind and technology. AI tools change how information is gathered, processed, and distributed. Historically library infrastructures have proven their crucial role in the management of knowledge. It is inevitable that today's libraries, and especially research and academic libraries, face changes in their technological equipment, expertize organization, and services. A structured and well-planned engineering framework for the introduction of AI in academic and research library infrastructures leads to automation of everyday tasks, precise data analysis and better accessibility and visibility.

title: Automation of Energy-Efficient Motorized Valves in Clean Product Storage Terminals Using ISA-101 Recommendations and PlantPAx Architecture
authors: Luis Chuquimarca-Jiménez, Kleber Lalaleo-Saltos, Óscar Gómez-Morales
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Remote valve operation in fuel terminals poses a critical challenge in industrial automation, often resulting in delays, excessive energy consumption, and safety hazards due to manual intervention. Existing systems frequently lack standardized interfaces and integration protocols, which limits operational efficiency and process reliability. This work presents the design and implementation of an automated system for the remote control of motorized valves in product storage tanks, developed in accordance with the ANSI/ISA-101.01-2015 standard. The proposed architecture integrates Rockwell Automation’s Logix Designer for PLC programming, FactoryTalk View HMI with PlantPAx standards, and Modbus TCP/IP communication via the Prosoft MVI56E-MNETR module. The system was validated through simulation using Factory I/O, replicating the operating conditions of a clean product terminal. The results indicate significant improvements: energy savings of 849.79 kWh in filling operations and 567.22 kWh in discharge, along with maintenance cycle reductions from five to two filter changes per year. These findings demonstrate enhanced operational reliability, reduced human risk, and increased sustainability. Moreover, the proposed approach is adaptable to similar industrial contexts, providing a replicable model aligned with current automation standards and energy-efficiency objectives.

title: Mentalization-Based Therapy Worldwide: A Bibliometric Mapping of Growth, Collaboration and Expansion Across Diagnoses
authors: Johanna Salazar-Pantusin, Jorge Galán-Mena, Daniel Pulla-Sánchez, Martín López-Nores, Juan Pablo Salgado-Guerrero
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In just one decade, Mentalization-Based Therapy (MBT) has progressed from the gold-standard intervention for borderline personality disorder (BPD) to an increasingly consolidated transdiagnostic framework. To chart this trajectory, we analysed 405 publications indexed in Scopus and Web of Science (2015-2024). Bibliometric processing with Bibliometrix and VOSviewer revealed an uninterrupted growth curve-compound annual growth rate $\approx 8 \%$-driven by a collaborative network dominated by the United Kingdom, the United States and Nordic hubs. Eight core investigators, spearheaded by Fonagy and Bateman, account for $33 \%$ of the literature, while openaccess journals publish one-third of the output, accelerating clinical translation. Thematically, MBT research still gravitates around BPD; however, keyword co-occurrence networks signal a decisive migration toward eating disorders, forensic contexts and early psychosis. This bibliometric mapping shows that MBT is expanding in synchrony with health-service demands for scalable, cost-efficient psychological interventions and underscores the need for multicentre trials to validate its effectiveness across diverse cultural and service settings.

title: Feature Relationship Graph with Transformer Vision for Face Anti-Spoofing
authors: Riko Arlando Saragih, Tio Dewantho Sunoto, Maria Christine Sutandi, Judea Janoto Jarden, Kartika Suhada, Bryant Alexander Dwi Nugroho
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Face recognition is one example of an authentication system that uses the face of a person to gain access to. With the rapid growth of technology, there’s a lot more variety of attack that targets face recognition. These attacks are called Presentation Attack (PA). PA include the likes of print attack, video replay, and 3D masks. For that reason, a system to identify those kinds of attacks are made called Face Anti-Spoofing (FAS). In this paper, the FAS system is created using public datasets and are converted into a graph data structure. To make the graph data, we use algorithms like Simple Linear Iterative Clustering (SLIC) and Gray-Level Cooccurrence Matrix (GLCM) to make it. After the graph data has been created, we use a deep learning model called Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) to classify between a real or fake face.The result that is obtained from testing the model, is tested in a variety of conditions such as different learning rate, optimizer, and batch size. Based on those conditions, the best result we obtained is using a learning rate of 0.001, Adam optimizer, and 32 batch size because the value of APCER, BPCER, and ACER is lower than the other conditions.

title: Fault-Tolerant Control for Finite/Fixed-Time Synchronization of Delayed Inertial Memristive NNs With Time-Varying Actuator Faults
authors: Yuxin Jiang, Song Zhu, Mouquan Shen, Shiping Wen, Chaoxu Mu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article investigates finite/fixed-time synchronization (FTS/FXTS) for delayed inertial memristive neural networks (IMNNs) with time-varying actuator faults, a more practical scenario compared to the widely studied constant-fault case. Novel fault-tolerant controllers, including state-feedback and event-triggered schemes, are proposed to achieve synchronization under mixed delays. By establishing algebraic criteria via a nonreduced-order approach, explicit settling time estimates are derived while excluding Zeno behavior. The theoretical results are verified through simulations, and the proposed method is further applied to secure communication using synchronized IMNNs for image encryption.

title: Robust Soft Fault Diagnosis of Capacitor Degradation in DC–DC Converters Using Statistical Optimal Measurement Point and RaDR-WCNN
authors: Yuanyuan Jiang, Miao Zhou
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Soft faults caused by capacitor degradation lead to performance drift and reliability loss in dc-dc converters, while measurement noise further destabilizes diagnosis. This work addresses both single and combined degradation of input and output capacitors, aiming for robust diagnosis under noisy conditions with minimal measurement points. A framework is proposed that integrates Statistical Multi-Metric Ranking (SM²R) with a lightweight deep classifier, Residual and Dilated Residual Wide CNN (RaDR-WCNN). RaDR-WCNN directly processes raw voltage waveforms using wide first-layer kernels and multi-scale dilated residual blocks to improve feature robustness in noisy conditions. S-M²R quantitatively evaluates candidate measurement points based on distribution separability, feature redundancy, noise resilience, and distribution alignment, identifies the optimal two-point and three-point subsets for classification. These subsets are validated under additive white Gaussian noise, and broader noise robustness is evaluated on the four-point baseline across both white and colored noise. Results confirm that the proposed framework enables accurate and noise resilient diagnosis of capacitor degradation while minimizing measurement points, showing promise for practical deployment in converter systems.

title: FLCLA: Four-Level Crowdsourced Label Aggregation
authors: Himanshu Suyal, Avtar Singh, Shiv Naresh Shivhare
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Crowdsourcing is a fast and cost-efficient way to collect large-scale labelled data for supervised machine learning. However, crowdsourcing leads to noisy labels due to the variability of crowd workers’ expertise. Conventional label aggregation techniques address noisy labels but ignore their inter-relationships among the different instances. This paper proposes FLCLA (Four-Level Crowdsourced Label Aggregation), a hierarchical framework that dynamically adapts to data quality by partitioning instances into four context-aware subsets: confidence, positive, boundary, and noisy. FLCLA first evaluates label reliability by considering both individual instances and their neighborhood structures, leveraging proximity (k-nearest neighbors) and dissimilarity (k-farthest neighbours) to capture instance interdependence. For confidence sets, Majority Voting (MV) is used, whereas the positive subset employs weighted Majority Voting (WMV) based on k-nearest neighbors. For boundary instances, WMV is extended to incorporate both nearest and farthest neighbors. Finally, noisy instances are resolved using supervised classifiers trained on the combined confidence, positive, and boundary subsets. Extensive experiments conducted on 20 benchmark crowdsourced datasets demonstrate that FLCLA consistently outperforms state-of-the-art label aggregation methods in terms of accuracy.

title: Human spatial dynamics for electricity demand forecasting
authors: Nathan Douméche, Yannig Goude, Stefania Rubrichi, Yann Allioux
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: Accurate electricity demand forecasting is crucial for energy security and efficiency. In 2023, massive savings have been observed in Europe following an unprecedented global energy crisis. However, assessing the impact of such a crisis on electricity consumption behaviour is challenging. Moreover, standard statistical models based on meteorological and seasonal data have difficulty dealing with such sudden changes. Here, we show that mobility indices based on mobile network data reporting daily presence data significantly improve the performance of state-of-the-art models in electricity demand forecasting during France's government-pushed energy sobriety period. We start by introducing our mobility dataset, comparing it to others, and showing that adding mobility indices to models outperforms the state-of-the-art during winter 2022-2023. Then, we develop interpretable insights by characterizing how winter of 2022-2023 was atypical in terms of electricity demand and by showing how our mobile network data captures work dynamics. In effect, our results characterise the effect of employment-related behaviour patterns on electricity demand.

title: Modeling and Analysis of Voltage Imbalance in Series-Connected FS-IGBTs Based on Physical Description of Tail Current Dynamics
authors: Xianzhe Bao, Chushan Li, Yunfei Xu, Guoliang Zhao, Wuhua Li, Weijiang Chen, Xiangning He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: The series-connected insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs) always endure a secondary voltage imbalance introduced by the difference of tail current. The state-of-the-art models often oversimplify or neglect key physical processes like carrier transport and recombination, leading to inaccurate descriptions of the tail current and complicating the characterization of secondary voltage imbalance. To address this issue, a physics-based model of IGBT is analytically established, which could accurately describe the tail current characteristics. First, this paper introduces an improved carrier transport formulation that incorporates the description of space charge generation current and the characterization of non-linear carrier distribution. Furthermore, an equivalent carrier lifetime expression is developed to describe the recombination effect more comprehensively by incorporating the recombination mechanism under the low carrier concentration conditions. Based on this IGBT model, a circuit composed of series-connected IGBTs is constructed to investigate the mechanism of secondary voltage imbalance. Finally, the accuracy and superiority of the proposed model were validated through comparative experiments and simulations. Compared to conventional models, the proposed model achieves a 42.66% improvement in accuracy in describing the voltage imbalance between series-connected IGBTs. Furthermore, the proposed model provides valuable references and theoretical support for the design of voltage balancing strategies and circuit parameters in series-connected IGBT equipment.

publish: IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems

title: Soft 3D-Printed Endoskeleton for Precise Tendon Routing in Soft Robotics
authors: Emanuele Solfiti, Alessio Mondini, Emanuela Del Dottore, Barbara Mazzolai, Alberto Parmiggiani
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: This paper presents the design, development, and testing of a soft 3D-printed endoskeleton for arbitrary cable routing in tendon-driven soft actuators. The endoskeleton is embedded in a silicone body, and it is fixed to the mold prior to the casting process. It enables tendons to be placed through predefined eyelets, ensuring accurate positioning within the soft body. To minimize its impact on the overall stiffness of the soft body, the endoskeleton was designed with a slim profile, flexible connections, and 3D-printed with elastic material (Shore A hardness 50), selected to roughly match the mechanical properties of the surrounding silicone matrix (typically with Shore 00 hardness 20–30). Key features of the proposed solution include a 3D-printable guide for tendon routing that is (1) fully soft, (2) easy to place, (3) rapidly reconfigurable for arbitrary tendon paths, (4) adaptable to variable soft body geometries, and (5) easy to fabricate with single-step casting. The current work describes the design, manufacturing, simulation, and testing of a simplified case study in which the endoskeleton is employed to reproduce a target pose predicted by FE analysis with good matching, demonstrating the effectiveness of the approach.

title: PWaveSense: DAS-Based Knowledge-Driven Seismic Signal Processing and Ensemble Learning Framework for REST API-Enabled Real-Time Earthquake Early Warning System
authors: Deepika Sasi, Thomas Joseph
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Effective earthquake early warning (EEW) relies on accurate and rapid signal detection. This letter presents PWaveSense- a real-time earthquake detection framework using distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) data. The pipeline combines advanced signal processing, probabilistic feature relevance, and a stacked ensemble classifier. Using extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost)-based feature selection, synthetic minority oversampling technique (SMOTE), and second-order polynomial feature expansion, the model generalizes well across domains. PWaveSense achieved 100% accuracy after a post-hoc threshold-sweep calibration that optimized performance. However, the results are limited to binary classification on two real-world DAS datasets. An ablation study highlights each pipeline component’s contribution. Real-time deployment via a Flask-based REST API yields sub-150 ms inference latency, making PWaveSense a scalable and robust solution for real-time EEW in diverse seismic environments.

title: A Neural Network-Based ADC Calibration Framework via Quantization Code Reconstruction
authors: Jiashen Li, Honghui Deng, Muqi Li, Luotian Wu, Xiao Yang, Yuhao Luo, Xiaoting Lu, Yongsheng Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: This article proposes a neural network (NN)-based calibration framework via quantization code reconstruction to address the critical limitation of multidimensional NNs (MDNNs) in analog-to-digital converter (ADC) calibration, where performance degrades drastically under varying input frequencies or sampling rates. Conventional MDNN methods suffer from distribution shifts caused by dynamic oversampling ratio (OSR) variations, necessitating repeated retraining. Our innovation lies in a data reconstruction mechanism: for lower OSR scenarios, a third-order cascaded integrator-comb (CIC) filter inserts pseudo-data points between quantization code to match the NN’s input dimension. For higher OSR scenarios, cyclic downsampling decomposes the original sequence into parallel subsequences processed independently by the same network. For multitone signals, a reconstruction–calibration–summation flow hierarchically handles spectral components. Implemented on an FPGA and covalidated with a commercial 14-bit/1 GSPS pipeline ADC, the framework demonstrates robust performance without retraining. Experimental results show: bandwidth expansion from 16.3% to 84.7% of the Nyquist bandwidth. SFDR improvement of 13.8–27.7 dB and ENOB gain of 2.3–4.6 bits across 10.3–160.3 MHz inputs. This work enables consistent high-precision ADC calibration in dynamic signal environments, facilitating deployment in complex application scenarios.

title: Short-Term Energy Demand Forecasting in a University Campus Using Machine Learning
authors: Georgios N. Perakis, Evangelos K. Markakis, Yiannis A. Katsigiannis, Emmanouel S. Karapidakis, Marios Nikologiannis
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The accurate forecasting of energy consumption is a cornerstone of efficient energy management, particularly within complex entities such as university campuses. These environments are characterized by non-stationary demand patterns susceptible to abrupt changes, a phenomenon known as Concept Drift, which poses a substantial challenge to conventional forecasting models. This paper introduces and validates a holistic, three-phase methodological framework designed to address these challenges. We conduct a rigorous comparative analysis of three machine learning algorithms— Random Forest (RF), LightGBM, and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)—using high-resolution temporal data from a university building. The framework's initial phase establishes a baseline and diagnoses the severe impact of Concept Drift. The second phase implements a dynamic sliding window retraining protocol, demonstrating its necessity for model adaptation. The final, decisive phase integrates advanced feature engineering, which proves to be the most critical component for achieving high-fidelity predictions. Our results indicate that this final optimization stage reduces the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) for all models to a convergence point of approximately 1.1 kWh. Notably, this enhancement elevates the performance of the LightGBM model to a level commensurate with the specialized LSTM network. The study concludes that the development of a robust methodological framework, encompassing drift adaptation and sophisticated feature engineering, is of greater importance than the selection of a specific algorithm in isolation.

title: Digitalization of Logistics Processes through AI: Economic Effects and Levels of Implementation in Bulgaria and the EU
authors: Siyka Demirova, Svetlana Dimitrakieva, Nikolay Sharaliev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study examines the impact of digitalization on logistics processes in Bulgaria and the European Union through the use of artificial intelligence and related technologies. The aim is to assess the degree of digital transformation of small and medium-sized enterprises in the logistics sector and to analyze the relationship between the level of digitalization and the reduction of logistics costs. A linear model was used, in which every 1% increase in digitalization leads to a reduction in costs by approximately 0.5%. The results are compared between Bulgaria and the EU average for the period 2020-2024, and a BG/EU ratio index was introduced, which measures the relative lag of the country.

title: A New Approach to High-Performance Image Compression on FPGA
authors: Xuan-Dung Nguyen, Duc-Thanh Mai, Duoc-Van Nguyen, Quoc-Tuan Bui, Hieu-Truong Ngo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents a study on the implementation of a color image compression system of various sizes by combining different compression methods on an FPGA to optimize storage space. The image compression system applies standard techniques in many image compression architectures, including converting images to the YCbCr color space, reducing the number of samples on CbCr channels through the Downsampling step, and then applying 3-level DWT to decompose the image into LL, LH, HL, and HH components. In which, LL3, containing much important information, will continue to be processed by DCT and quantized; HH1, LH1, HL1 components will be removed; the remaining components are quantized. Finally, all data is encoded using the Arithmetic coding algorithm for efficient compression. The entire image compression process is performed directly on the FPGA using Verilog language, while MATLAB is used to decode the output data and calculate the image quality evaluation parameters. The results show that the system achieves a compression ratio nearly equivalent to that of the software, while maintaining good image quality. The operating frequency reaches 113.6 MHz for image sizes of 512×512, 1024×768, 1024×1024, and slightly decreases to 111.11 MHz for image sizes of 960×960 and 1280×1000.

title: An Evaluation of Hybrid and Electric Vehicles Training Needs for Developing VR/AR Supported Digital Training Materials
authors: Ridvan Arslan, Abdil Kus, Dorian Gorgan, Vladislav Ivanov, Lubomir Dimitrov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Electric and hybrid vehicles are widely spread in the world nowadays. This requires training at all levels: design, production and maintenance. This paper is devoted to the assessment of the training needs in vocational education in the field of electric and hybrid vehicle design. It justifies the application of modern VR/AR technology in education and the development of digital training materials. In order to evaluate the training needs in vocational education, an original questionnaire has been developed. It consists of 25 questions and a 5-point Likert scale has been used. The questionnaire is structured in the following sections: perception, knowledge, skills and expectations. Totally 440 stakeholder representatives of manufacture and service sector, students, teachers in vocational schools, academics and administrators (employees) participated in the surveys made in three countries: Turkey, Bulgaria, and Romania. It is noteworthy that all three countries provided similar answers to all questions in the questionnaires and thus indicated the exact needs. It can be said that the training programs that will be developed in accordance with these results will meet the priorities and needs of all stakeholders regarding the training needs for electric and hybrid vehicles.

title: Optimization of the YOLOv4 Algorithm with MFNMS for Defect Detection in Arabica Coffee Beans
authors: Muhammad Fadli Kasman, N.R.A. Novy Mokobombang
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Coffee is one of Indonesia’s leading commodities with high economic value, especially the Arabica variety because it contains higher levels of natural sugars and acids, compared to other coffee varieties. However, the quality of Arabica beans is greatly influenced by their physical and visual conditions, especially the presence of defects. Defect detection in coffee beans is crucial for maintaining the quality and efficiency of postharvest processing in the coffee industry. YOLOv4 is a fast object detection algorithm, but its performance decreases when detecting small objects that are close together. To improve defect detection in Arabica coffee beans, this study proposes an improvement in YOLOv4 using the proposed More Focused Non Maximum Suppression (MF-NMS) method, which normalizes the coordinates of the lower left and upper right corners of the predicted bounding box and the ground truth bounding box. This is done to reduce the impact of small errors in object position prediction. The data used in this study consists of green Arabica coffee beans categorized as normal, hollow, broken, and black. The results show that the proposed model achieves a 7.50% increase in $\mathbf{m A P} \text{@} \mathbf{0. 5}$ compared to the baseline model.

title: DeckFlow: Specification Decomposition on a Multimodal Generative Canvas
authors: Gregory Croisdale, Emily Huang, John Joon Young Chung, Anhong Guo, Xu Wang, Austin Z. Henley, Cyrus Omar
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Generative AI promises to allow people to create high-quality personalized media. Although powerful, we identify two fundamental design problems with existing tooling through a literature review. We introduce a multimodal generative AI tool, DeckFlow, to address these problems. DeckFlow supports a specification decomposition workflow where an initial goal is iteratively decomposed into smaller parts and combined using feature labels and clusters. DeckFlow supports generative space exploration by generating multiple prompt and output variations, presented in a grid, that can feed back recursively into the next design iteration. We evaluate DeckFlow for text-to-image generation against a state-of-practice conversational AI baseline for image generation tasks. We then add audio generation and investigate user behaviors in a more open-ended creative setting with text, image, and audio outputs.

title: Achieving Full Bearing Design Life in Demanding Mining Applications
authors: Matt Adams, Steven Soetjiandi
publish: 2023 IEEE-IAS/PCA Cement Industry Conference (IAS/PCA)
abstract: Bearings in mining equipment are often subjected to exceptionally harsh and dirty environments which prevent them from reaching their full design life. Premature failures are often the result of damage to the bearing raceways due to contaminant ingress, poor lubrication, or a combination of both. Two essential strategies can have a profound impact on extending bearing service life: adequate protection against contamination and proper lubrication.This paper will discuss how spherical roller bearings with integral seals are an ideal solution for applications in heavily contaminated environments. Proven benefits include improved worker safety, reduction in environmental impact, extended lubrication intervals, and increased equipment runtime. Sealed spherical roller bearings are available in a variety of sizes and can often be substituted in place of an open bearing with little to no equipment modifications.

title: The Impact of Deepfakes in Face Recognition Systems
authors: Daniel P. Benalcazar, Eddy Arias, Pamela Zurita, Andreina Jimenez
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Nowadays, there is a proliferation of generative AI methods accessible to the masses. Both open source and paid algorithms are capable of creating deepfake images with the likelihood of a person. This is problematic since those deepfakes can be created with social-media images without consent, and used to spoof Face Recognition engines. That is why, in this research, we test the vulnerabilities of common Face Recognition methods to deepfake presentations. First, we gathered a dataset of 12 volunteers and created deepfake images of each one. We explored Stable Diffusion’s LoRA and ControlNet methods for deepfake generation. Then, we contrasted biometric indices before and after including the deepfakes in the dataset. The results indicate that EER and FRR increase in average by $1.28 \%$ and $3.40 \%$, respectively, when introducing deepfakes in the dataset. This indicates that the tested face recognition engines encountered problems discerning a person from their deepfake, and that Presentation Attack Detection systems are imperative.

title: Deep Learning-Based Architectures for UAV Network Attack Detection
authors: Rashed M. H. Almarri, Plamen Zahariev, Mahar Khashim, Ahmed F. N. Obeidat, Yahya M. Tashtoush
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This research aims to develop and compare deep learning approaches to detect cyberattacks on Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) networks, including Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs). We applied Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) on the ECU-IoFT dataset to investigate feature distributions and relationships, prepared it for training, applied the SMOTE technique to balance the data, and compared the DL architectures' results. The dataset contains 54,492 samples representing various attacks on UAV Wi-Fi communications, which were carefully preprocessed. The models achieved high performance, with the ANN achieving an average accuracy of 96%, the RNN achieving 96%, and the CNN achieving a lower average accuracy of 81%. We also applied additional evaluation metrics, including precision, recall, F1-score, and confusion matrices, which confirmed the models' effectiveness in accurately detecting UAV network attacks. This reflects the ability of the DL models to recognize patterns associated with UAV security threats, enhancing the efficiency of UAV networks in the face of cyberattacks.

title: 1.5 GHz Accurate Signal Frequency Meter Design
authors: George A. Adamidis, Manolis G. Tampouratzis
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents an automated measurements in a wide range using an 8-bit PIC18F2620-I/SP microcontroller with the help of frequency meter. The device measures signals with frequencies from actually DC to 1.5 GHz and has a feature to display on a 2x16 character LCD display. It offers frequency resolution up to 0.1Hz for frequencies in the 0.1Hz to 100MHz operating range (Channel A) and up to 4Hz for 70MHz to 1.5GHz (Channel B), respectively. Minimum and Maximum hold functions, selection of frequency units, and gate time adjustment are also supported, making it ideal for laboratory measurement equipment, comparing to other high-complexity and high-cost FPGA’s commercial implementations.

title: The Hidden Burden: Insights Into Women’s Lived Experiences In Computing
authors: Shandler A. Mason, Sandeep Kaur Kuttal
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Women researchers in computing face persistent, career-longchallenges that contribute to broader gender disparities in the field. While prior work has examined barriers faced by women in computing, little is known about the lived experiences of women researchers, specifically those navigating careers across academia and industry. To address this gap, we conducted in-depth, semi-structured interviews with ten novice and experienced women researchers across three continents. Using inductive analysis and open coding of transcribed interviews, we identified thirteen career-related challenges, organized into three overarching themes: absence of belonging, experiences of implicit bias, and increased emotional burden. Participants described heightened gender awareness in computing environments, which contributed to feelings of isolation and hindered professional growth. Our findings highlight the need for targeted interventions to support the career trajectories of women researchers, foster inclusive research communities, and ultimately reduce the gender gap in computing.

title: Application of the Tití App Technological Tool in Reading and Writing Comprehension
authors: Paulina Pérez Pérez, Andrés Caicedo López
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Education at its various levels seeks to foster social change among all stakeholders, particularly students and teachers. In primary school, persistent learning difficulties have been identified, most of which are linked to mastering literacy skills—an essential foundation for educational progress. The interactive tool TitíApp, designed to correct errors such as omissions, substitutions, and rotations, has proved effective in enhancing children’s reading abilities. This application not only supports the teaching—learning process but also helps narrow the digital divide across different sectors. The aim of this study was to compare children’s reading competencies before and after using TitíApp. A pre and post-assessment methodology was employed with the Toro and Cervera Reading-Writing Analysis Test, applied in accordance with ethical standards for minors. The sample comprised 234 students from public and private schools in Pichincha Province. Findings revealed a reduction in errors when reading letters, syllables, and words, as well as an overall improvement in reading comprehension. The discussion highlights the growing positive impact of technological tools in education, noting that Tití App was particularly effective in improving students’ reading fluency and comprehension. Ultimately, the use of this tool offers an engaging and effective means of restoring reading skills while reflecting a culturally grounded approach within the Ecuadorian context.

title: Virtualization and Control of an Industrial Process of a Water Tube Steam Generator
authors: Luis Vargas, Karina Montaluisa, Jaqueline Llanos, Paola Velasco
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This research proposes a control algorithm based on the inverse behavior of a virtualized water-tube steam generator, taking into account its nonlinear model. In addition, the immersive virtualization of the process is presented, which allows for the analysis of its operation and the evaluation of different control strategies.The virtual process incorporates an avatar that simulates the operator in a realistic industrial environment, together with a nonlinear model, enabling the visualization of the evolution of controlled variables and control actions. 3D design and animation software, including Unity3D, is used to create the interactive virtual environment, providing an audiovisual experience similar to the operation of a real steam generator.Furthermore, the results of the process industrial virtualization allow the user to interact with the environment through an avatar and verify performance using graphs of the dynamic variables, which are stabilized to industry-standard values by means of the control algorithm.The proposed control algorithm demonstrates good performance in transient states and even enables economic savings by reducing fuel flow consumption. Steam pressure, excess oxygen, and steam flow are effectively controlled; when one of them changes, the others are disturbed.

title: Risk-Based Security Hardening in IoT Systems Using OWASP and Cyberattack Simulations
authors: Aarón Echeverría López, Mercedes Amor Pinilla, Henry Ramiro Carvajal Mora
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a transformative technology, yet its adoption remains hindered by persistent security vulnerabilities. This paper presents a threat modeling framework to reduce the attack surface associated with the OWASP IoT Top 10. To validate the approach, we developed a controlled experimental environment using real IoT devices (Arduino Mega 2560 and Raspberry Pi 3B+), identifying key threats such as denial-of-service, brute force, and ARP poisoning. Security measures-including encrypted protocols (e.g., MQTT over TLS, HTTPS), non-standard ports, and access control rules-were implemented. A comparative risk assessment was conducted between a baseline system with default settings and a hardened system applying the proposed mitigations. Results show a substantial risk reduction: OWASP-related scores dropped from 10.2 to 2.4, and cyberattack risks from 16.0 to 2.0, shifting the system from critical to low-risk. This study provides a replicable methodology for IoT risk analysis, demonstrates the effectiveness of lightweight countermeasures, and underscores the importance of integrating security early in the design phase.

title: Optimized Deep Learning Models for Robust Splicing-Based Image Forgery Detection Using CASIA Mixed Dataset
authors: Irmawati, Nur Hayati
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Digital image manipulation has emerged as a significant challenge in maintaining the reliability of visual information. This paper focuses on passive forgery detection, specifically splicing-based tampering. We compare an optimized Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and ResNet50 using three datasets CASIA-v1, CASIA-v2, and a newly formed combined dataset referred to as Splicing-Mix. The optimized CNN achieved accuracies of $62.99 \%$ on CASIA-v1, $78.12 \%$ on CASIA-v2, and $83.59 \%$ on Splicing-Mix, while ResNet-50 obtained 59.05%, 76.91%, and 84.81% on the same datasets. These findings highlight that ResNet-50 offers stable performance across datasets, whereas the optimized CNN excels in smaller-scale data. The major contributions of this study are: 1) the design of Splicing-Mix as a combined dataset to enhance robustness, 2) the development of an optimized CNN evaluated against ResNet-50, and 3) an empirical examination of dataset composition on model transferability and performance.

title: Forecasting of Clinical Program Gross Growth over Revenue through Outcomes and Workforce Metrics using LSTM-XGBoost
authors: Fiorenza Irene Christabelle Suryanto, Samuel Ady Sanjaya
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Health awareness and healthcare sectors have grown in recent years, yet hospitals face challenges in maintaining high service quality while ensuring financial stability. In a private hospital, challenges arise from revenue fluctuations of around $25 \%$ to $30 \%$ per year. Clinical program monitoring serves as a key strategy to support both service quality and financial management, as suboptimal performance can destabilize revenue growth. Studies explored time-series forecasting with hybrid models but were limited by hyperparameter sensitivity and exogenous variables. Recognizing the relevance of clinical achievement and workforce metrics to the gross growth over revenue (GGOR), this research leverages time-series clinical data (2021 to 2024) and applies a hybrid Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) approach. The hybrid approach demonstrated strong forecast performance, achieving RMSE of 0.04, MAE of 0.02, MAPE of $47 \%$, and R-squared of 0.79. A counterfactual analysis and trajectory plotting were conducted, providing actionable insights for hospital financial planning. Quantitatively, the model establishes a baseline hybrid time-series forecast for clinical program revenue, offering evidence of the interplay between clinical outcomes and workforce metrics in driving GGOR. Future research is recommended to incorporate clinical variables to strengthen time-series forecasting in healthcare financial management.

title: Detecting Tiny Performance Regressions at Hyperscale
authors: Yang Wang, Mike Chow, Dong Young Yoon, Rohan Bopardikar, Sherry Chen, Zoltan Farkas, Caner Gocmen, Kapil Goenka, Ayichew Hailu, Daniel Hodges, Elvis Huang, Ivor Huang, Zhihui Huang, Juan Jones, Osman Kocas, Jocelyn Kong, Abhinay Kukkadapu, Yanjun Lin, Matt McNally, David Meisner, Rodrigo Paim, Dhruv Patel, Jialiang Qu, Santosh Sonawane, William Wang, Mack Ward, Jonathan Wiepert, Miao Yu, Bin Zhang, Yunqi Zhang, Chunqiang Tang
publish: ACM Transactions on Computer Systems
abstract: None

title: Development of Insulin Bolus Calculators in Type 1 Diabetes using A Framework Based on Real-world Data, Digital Twins and Machine Learning
authors: Elisa Pellizzari, Giacomo Cappon, Giulia Nicolis, Giovanni Sparacino, Andrea Facchinetti
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Objective: Precise mealtime insulin bolus (MIB) dosing is essential in type 1 diabetes (T1D) to minimize glucose excursions from carbohydrate intake. Traditional MIB formulas, based on glucose concentration at mealtime, are suboptimal and do not exploit real-time data from continuous glucose monitoring (CGM). Existing methods that incorporate CGM data often rely on empirical rules or are developed in-silico, limiting their applicability to real-world conditions. This work investigates a framework combining machine learning (ML) algorithms, digital twins (DTs) and real-world data, to improve the assessment, tuning, and development of MIB dosing algorithms. Methods: We utilized ReplayBG, a DT for T1D, to: i) evaluate a published linear ML model (Noaro et al.), originally developed in-silico, on real-world data from 30 free-living subjects; ii) recalibrate this model to fit the real-world dataset; and iii) train and test nonlinear gradient-boosting models (XGBoost, LightGBM) developed entirely on real data through DT simulations. Results: Progressing to DT-enhanced models, we observed improvements in glucose control. The recalibrated linear and nonlinear models increased time-in-range (up to 80.6% with LightGBM vs. 75.6% for Noaro et al.) and reduced time-above-range. Risk metrics reflecting hypo/hyperglycemia also improved. Conclusions: These findings demonstrate that a DT-based framework grounded in real-world data supports both the refinement and development of bolus calculators, achieving performance gains beyond the original in-silico model. Significance: DTs allow the use real-world data to develop, validate and extend the domain of validity of new MIB formulas, paving the way to practical applications of ML tailored solutions for T1D.

title: Coordinated Optimization of Wind-Solar-Storage Systems in Microgrids for Enhanced Economic Performance
authors: Chenran Zhai, Haiyan Zheng, Man Wang, Hui Zhang, Youhan Deng, Weiwei Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Predictive Control of Electrical Drives and Power Electronics (PRECEDE)
abstract: This paper addresses the coordinated optimization of wind-solar-storage systems in microgrids to enhance their operational economy. Recognizing that the inherent instability of wind and photovoltaic (PV) power generation and their temporal mismatch with load demand can lead to energy waste and reduced economic benefits, the study focuses on optimizing both the configuration and operational strategies of renewable generation and energy storage devices. The research includes an analysis of the economic performance of microgrids without energy storage, and investigates optimal operation strategies and electricity purchase plans when a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \text{kW} / 100 \text{kWh}$</tex> energy storage system is integrated. Utilizing linear and quadratic programming models, the study further optimizes the power and capacity configurations of energy storage to identify the most effective coordinated scheme. It also explores optimal energy storage strategies in the joint operation of multiple parks versus independent operation, and considers future scenarios with load growth and time-of-use pricing. The findings reveal that while high storage costs often outweigh benefits in most parks, optimized configurations can improve economic performance in some cases. Additionally, joint operation significantly reduces wasted wind and solar energy, lowers operational costs, and enhances economic efficiency. This study innovatively integrates joint microgrid operation with dynamic storage allocation under real-world constraints, such as load growth and time-of-use pricing, providing a scalable framework for practical applications.

title: An Efficient Communication Scheme for Satellite Aerial Networks With Location Privacy
authors: Jiahao Ma, Lin Bai, Rui Han, Xin Xie, Jiaxing Wang, Jinho Choi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Since satellites can provide stable communication services to uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs), satellite aerial networks become an important part of the sixth generation (6 G) networks. The service of satellites relies on UAVs' location information, while actively real-time location information reporting of UAVs incurs large communication overhead and poses substantial security risks. Specifically, UAVs may be threatened by global navigation satellite system (GNSS) spoofing attacks, which is carried out by obtaining UAVs' location information. To meet these challenges, in this paper, we propose an overhead-efficient communication scheme for satellite aerial networks without requiring UAVs' location information reporting, which not only saves communication resources, but also offers resilience against GNSS attacks. The total average communication rate of the system is analyzed, and its analytical expression, based on the point beam radius and frequency modulation interval, is derived. Finally, simulation results demonstrate the sum of the transmission rates for multiple high-dynamic UAVs served by the satellite in various scenarios, as well as a performance comparison between the proposed and traditional methods under GNSS attack scenarios.

title: Robust Weakly-Supervised Bearing Fault Diagnosis via Dual Learning and Curriculum Strategies
authors: Yifei Ding, Qiuhua Miao, Xiaoli Zhao, Xiaoan Yan, Chi-Guhn Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Deep transfer learning (DTL), especially domain adaptation (DA) based techniques, has broadly extended the scope of practical fault diagnosis which struggles with generalization under variable operating conditions. However, real-world applications often involve noisy source domains with significant label and feature corruption, posing severe challenges to existing DTL approaches. In this work, we introduce the weakly-supervised domain adaptation network (WSDAN), a novel framework designed to tackle these issues through transfer curriculum learning (TCL) and dual learning strategies. WSDAN prioritizes informative samples from noisy source domains and enhances cross-domain generalization by utilizing inherent supervision in unlabeled target domain data. Our extensive experiments demonstrate that WSDAN outperforms current DTL and DA methods, particularly in high noise and significant domain discrepancy scenarios. This study highlights WSDAN’s robust performance and practical utility, paving the way for more reliable fault diagnosis in complex, real-world conditions.

title: Passive LC Relay Network-Enabled Battery-free Chipless IoT Smart Clothing for Simultaneous Multi-Site Hemodynamic Monitoring_supp2-3647891.mp4
authors: Ting-Wei Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: Smart clothing has emerged as a promising IoT-based healthcare platform by enabling distributed physiological sensing through body sensor networks (BSN). However, most systems rely on embedded chips and batteries, increasing complexity, weight, and cost that limit practicality. We present a battery-free chipless smart clothing that integrates thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU)-encapsulated passive LC relay networks to establish magnetic coupling between an external sensor reader and underlying arteries. Arterial pulsations induce resonant frequency shifts in the coupled system, enabling real-time pulse signal detection. Each sensing coil of passive LC relay networks is positioned at carotid, heart, radial, and femoral arteries, and four pickup coils are routed to a centralized hub on the upper left arm. A lightweight wireless reader with four channels simultaneously acquires multi-site physiological signals. Importantly, passive LC relay networks serve as magnetic field repeaters, enhancing magnetic coupling across extended distances. By matching resonant frequencies of passive LC relay networks and sensor reader at 7.3 MHz, the system achieved a power transfer efficiency (PTE) of 46.56 %, clearly outperforming the capacitor-free configuration, which yielded only 6 %. Notably, a minimum PTE threshold of 0.24 % was established for distinguishable pulse detection. The system showed robustness after water-spray exposure and supported signal acquisition through outer garments up to 21.22 mm thick between sensor reader and centralized hub, confirming resilience to sweat and compatibility with layered clothing. Overall, our battery-free chipless BSN offers lightweight, low-cost, and disposable smart clothing solutions for simultaneous multi-site hemodynamic monitoring, potentially calculating pulse wave velocity for peripheral vascular stiffness assessment.

title: IGZO/IGMO phototransistor based on photogating effect for high-performance solar-blind ultraviolet detection
authors: Jichun Yao, Wenbo Li, Kuangkuang Li, Xingzhao Liu
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: The solar-blind ultraviolet photodetectors are alternative for confidential communications and missile track due to its low false alarm rate. Amorphous multi-component oxide semiconductors have become excellent choices for solar-blind ultraviolet detectors due to their tunable bandgap and large-area uniformity. In this work, we fabricated amorphous In0.2Ga1.8ZnO4/In0.2Ga1.8MgO4 (IGZO/IGMO) heterojunction. The band alignment reveals the effective separation and transport of photogenerated carriers at the interface, which makes recombination more challenging. As expected, IGZO/IGMO phototransistor shows a high responsivity of 499.3 A/W, a high external quantum efficiency of 2.4 × 105%, a high detectivity of 3.7 × 1014 Jones, which demonstrates a significant ultraviolet sensitivity improvement compared to single-layer-film phototransistor. Furthermore, a rise/decay time of 1.4/2.7 ms, linear photoresponse characteristic and high visible-blind rejection ratio R255nm/R400nm of 1.5 × 104 show the superiority of IGZO/IGMO phototransistor in high-performance solar-blind ultraviolet detection. We believe that the IGZO/IGMO phototransistor demonstrates great potential for next-generation advanced optoelectronic devices.
