title: Correspondence-Free, Function-Based Sim-to-Real Learning for Deformable Surface Control_supp1-3647769.mp4
authors: Charlie C.L. Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: This paper presents a correspondence-free, function-based sim-to-real learning method for controlling deformable freeform surfaces. Unlike traditional sim-to-real transfer methods that strongly rely on marker points with full correspondences, our approach simultaneously learns a deformation function space and a confidence map – both parameterized by a neural network – to map simulated shapes to their real-world counterparts. As a result, the sim-to-real learning can be conducted by input from either a 3D scanner as point clouds (without correspondences) or a motion capture system as marker points (tolerating missed markers). The resultant sim-to-real transfer can be seamlessly integrated into a neural network-based computational pipeline for inverse kinematics and shape control. We demonstrate the versatility and adaptability of our method on two vision devices and across four pneumatically actuated soft robots: a deformable membrane, a robotic mannequin, and two soft manipulators.

title: TSAI: A Novel Temporal and Spatial Anomaly Index for Forest Fire Detection
authors: Mingxiu Tang, Xiufang Zhu, Junying Song, Jie Chen
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Efficient fire detection is crucial for minimizing wildfire potential impact. In this study, a new index, TSAI (Temporal and Spatial Anomaly Index), is proposed for fire detection. For a given pixel, it is calculated in terms of the difference in Sentinel-2 B12 reflectance of the pixel between during and before a fire, as well as the difference in Sentinel-2 B12 reflectance between the pixel and the surrounding non-fire pixels. The fire detection method based on the TSAI threshold was developed and tested in 19 study areas across different continents worldwide, encompassing various climatic and vegetation types. The results show TSAI exhibited remarkable accuracy in detecting fire, achieving an average commission error ratio (CE) of 11.43% and an average omission error ratio (OE) of 5.47% across all study areas. The TSAI-based detection method has a high degree of automation and shows great potential for large-scale fire monitoring. In addition, the TSAI construction method in this study can also serve as a reference for the development of other new disaster detection indices.

title: Evaluating Privacy Attacks Protection through Malware Family Classifiers: A Semi-Supervised Learning Approach
authors: David Cevallos-Salas, José Estrada-Jiménez, Danny S. Guamán
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Modern malware has garnered significant attention due to its devastating impact, driving the implementation of classifiers trained on datasets that aim to detect its type or family at runtime. While this approach is valuable for incident response and containment, it does not provide an evaluation of the protection against attacks that malware can carry out, which is essential for estimating its potential impact and performing a risk assessment. In addition to the lack of datasets labeled with attacks, modern malware has a dynamic, complex, polymorphic, and multi-attack behavior, making this evaluation more challenging. In this paper, we present a method based on a semi-supervised learning approach that allows the evaluation of the attacks protection achieved by a malware family classifier. Unsupervised learning is used to identify the clusters on a dataset that define possible attacks. Supervised learning, on the other hand, is used to train a malware family classifier with the original labels of the dataset. Then, both outcomes are interpreted and mapped. We present the results of applying this method to the CIC-MalMem-2022 dataset, evaluating the level of protection against privacy attacks achieved by seven malware family classifiers. Our method achieves comparable results to alternative approaches without requiring dataset relabeling or training additional classifiers.

title: Applied Predictive Model for Clinical Referral of COVID-19 Patients: A KDD-Based Approach Using Supervised Classification
authors: Lorenzo Cevallos-Torres, Franklin Parrales-Bravo, Rosangela Caicedo-Quiroz, Dayron Rumbaut -Rangel Universidad, Julio Barzola-Monteses
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic has underscored the necessity for digital solutions that can forecast the severity of infected patients. This paper proposes the deployment of a predictive care model to facilitate clinical referrals (inpatient or outpatient) for patients with COVID-19, utilizing supervised learning techniques such as Naive Bayes and Random Forest. The procedure adheres to the Knowledge Discovery Database (KDD) paradigm, consisting of six stages: import, data quality assessment, transformation, modeling, evaluation, and implementation. A primary objective was to create a refined dataset from the medical histories of diagnosed patients, selecting pertinent clinical factors for model development and assessment. This prototype serves as an essential instrument to facilitate medical decision-making in critical situations, namely with the referral of patients with COVID-19 for inpatient or outpatient care. The principal beneficiaries are medical professionals, who will have access to a resource that expedites and clinically substantiates their decision-making process, promoting more efficient and data-informed treatment.

title: Low-Power Motion Event Detection in Maritime Environments
authors: Mohamad Omran, Tim Brockmann, Benjamin Rother, Frank Golatowski, Christian Haubelt
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Efficient motion monitoring on cargo ships is essential for ensuring cargo safety and enabling predictive maintenance. This paper presents a low-power, event-driven sensing approach designed for maritime environments with limited energy availability and constrained communication infrastructure. The proposed node integrates a Bosch BMI160 inertial sensor with a Heltec Wi-Fi LoRa 32 board and operates over LoRaWAN using a hybrid transmission model that combines periodic updates with event-triggered messages based on two motion thresholds. Light-motion events are logged locally for later retrieval, while high-impact events are transmitted on detection. Laboratory and shipboard trials indicate reliable detection with low energy usage. The results support the feasibility of event-driven LoRaWAN sensing for long-term maritime monitoring and lay the groundwork for future improvements such as adaptive thresholds and lightweight machine-learning-based analytics.

title: Statistical Analysis of the Peaks in the Price of Electrical Energy on the Bulgarian Energy Market
authors: Kamen Simeonov, Boris Evstatiev, Atanas Atanasov, Teodora Hristova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study performs a statistical analysis of the peak hourly energy price on the Bulgarian energy market for 2024. Four specific situations are of interest – the morning high peak value, the evening high peak value, the nightly low peak value, and the daily low peak value. Different hourly statistical measures were estimated on a monthly basis for each one of them, such as the average value, minimum value, maximum value, standard deviation, and 95% confidence interval. Furthermore, all data was analyzed and divided depending on the type of the day – weekday or weekend, as in most situations, there is a noticeable difference between them. The obtained results show that there isn’t a clear pattern, which forms the peak values (low and high) of the electrical energy price, though some similarities can be observed between certain months. This indicates that statistical analysis is not enough if the optimal times for charging and discharging energy storage should be estimated. More advanced models should be used, based on machine learning and deep learning, if precise forecasting is to be done, which is an objective for future studies.

title: Adaptive Multi-Vector Model Predictive Control for Three-Phase PWM Rectifier
authors: Ningfan Zhong, Ruihao Zhao, Kaixun He
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Predictive Control of Electrical Drives and Power Electronics (PRECEDE)
abstract: In order to improve the dynamic response of the three-phase PWM rectifier when the load changes and reduce the AC current harmonics, an adaptive multi-vector model predictive control (MV-MPC) strategy for the three-phase PWM rectifier is proposed in this paper. The controller consists of a DC side voltage controller and an AC side current controller, and has a nested closed-loop structure. The DC side voltage controller estimates the change of the DC side load and adjusts the reference current of the AC side current controller in real time, so that the rectifier DC side voltage can make a fast dynamic response to the change of load and return to the set value. A multi-vector model predictive current controller was designed to reduce the harmonic spectrum dispersion of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{A C}$</tex> side current caused by the switching frequency variation. Simulation experiments show that compared with the FCSMPC strategy, the control strategy proposed in this paper can effectively shorten the startup process of the three-phase PWM rectifier, quickly respond to load changes, and improve the power quality on the AC side.

title: DevTales: A Tool for Providing Narrative Code Histories into Developer Workflows
authors: John Allen, Somin Park, Caitlin Kelleher
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Understanding unfamiliar code often requires insight into the original developer’s intentions, design rationale, and on-the-fly problem-solving strategies. Traditional version-control systems capture only coarse commits, leaving web foraging and developer notes disconnected. We present DevTales, a VSCode extension that integrates fine-grained subgoal labels, captured web-foraging activity, and LLM-generated narrative summaries directly with code in the IDE. We evaluated DevTales in three mixed-methods user studies spanning debugging, understanding rationale, and code reuse. Results show that subgoal labels and “See in Code” links enable rapid top-down navigation and code localization, while embedded web resources clarify unfamiliar artifacts. Narrative summaries proved valuable for answering deep “why” questions by explicitly linking causal relationships among history items, but were avoided during quick sensemaking contexts due to their verbosity. We discuss design implications for history-aware code search, adaptive narrative summarization, and inference transparency in LLM-generated stories.

title: AutoSIGHT: Automatic Eye Tracking-based System for Immediate Grading of Human experTise
authors: Byron Dowling, Jozef Porubcin, Adam Czajka
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Can we teach machines to assess the expertise of humans solving visual tasks automatically based on eye tracking features? This paper proposes AutoSIGHT, Automatic System for Immediate Grading of Human experTise, that classifies expert and non-expert performers, and builds upon an ensemble of features extracted from eye tracking data while the performers were solving a visual task. Results on the task of iris Presentation Attack Detection (PAD) used for this study show that with a small evaluation window of just 5 seconds, AutoSIGHT achieves an average average Area Under the ROC curve performance of 0.751 in subject-disjoint train-test regime, indicating that such detection is viable. Furthermore, when a larger evaluation window of up to 30 seconds is available, the Area Under the ROC curve (AUROC) increases to 0.8306, indicating the model is effectively leveraging more information at a cost of slightly delayed decisions. This work opens new areas of research on how to incorporate the automatic weighing of human and machine expertise into human-AI pairing setups, which need to react dynamically to nonstationary expertise distribution between the human and AI players (e.g., when the experts need to be replaced, or the task at hand changes rapidly). Along with this paper, we offer the eye tracking data used in this study collected from 6 experts and 53 non-experts solving iris PAD visual task.

title: Calibration-Based Pixel Non-Uniformity Correction Method for Medical Endoscopic Cameras
authors: Plamen Dikulakov, Aneliya Manukova, Deyan Levski, Georgi Bochev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents a calibration-based pixel non-uniformity correction method for image processing in medical endoscopic cameras, with particular focus on fixed-pattern noise (FPN) observed in Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS) image sensors. A calibration procedure is proposed and integrated directly into the manufacturing process of disposable endoscopic devices. Correction coefficients are extracted from controlled calibration frames and applied in the raw image domain in real time. The method extends traditional flat-field correction by incorporating a localized sliding-window averaging approach, thereby adapting to non-uniform illumination and pixel-level imperfections. Experimental results demonstrate improved image uniformity without introducing computational latency, making the method suitable for real-time medical endoscopy applications.

title: Green Synthesis of Carbon dot Sensors from Citrus Waste for Rapid Polarity Detection in Solvents
authors: Charikleia Malerou, Evangelia Kyriazi, Vasiliki Rammou, Kalliopi Ladomenou, Kalliopi Kravari, Maria Roussi, Anna Thysiadou, Michail Chalaris
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: A major challenge faced by researchers today is the fast and precise monitoring of solvent polarity, as it strongly influences reaction kinetics, solubility and molecular conformation during chemical processes. To address this issue and pursue a more environmentally sustainable approach, this study focused on synthesizing carbon dots (CDs) as fluorescent sensors derived solely from orange peels and orange juice, using a hydrothermal method at 180 °C for 8 h and 2.5 h, respectively. The choice of biomass-based carbon sources over small molecules was motivated by cost-effectiveness, environmental sustainability and widespread availability. Furthermore, green CDs have potential applications in sensing solvent polarity, metal ions, organic molecules and in vitro/in vivo imaging of plant and animal cells. The CDs were characterized by UV-Vis, FT-IR, and SEM techniques and subsequently evaluated as polarity sensors in ethanol–water mixtures under UV irradiation. Additionally, an agar–agar gel incorporating CDs was prepared to examine photoluminescence under UV exposure, demonstrating potential for qualitative determination of moisture content in liquids.

title: Design and Development of an Autonomous Thermal and Water Management System for Vertical Farming with Energy Optimization under Power Shortage Conditions
authors: Carlos Salazar L, Marcos Cevallos J, Abraham Plua E, Adriana Aguirre A
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The current global energy crisis poses a critical challenge for sustainable agriculture, particularly in environments with limited access to a stable power supply, as is the case in Ecuador. This work presents the design, modeling, and prototyping of an automated vertical farming system for medicinal plants, optimized for efficient energy use. The proposed solution minimizes the need for human intervention and active climate control, eliminating dependence on continuous energy supply. By operating only when environmental conditions demand, the system can function intermittently using battery backup or low-voltage sources, making it suitable for settings with restricted energy access. Ginger cultivation (Zingiber officinale) was evaluated in the prototype, yielding favorable results in environmental stability and achieving a 35% reduction in energy consumption compared to conventional greenhouses.

title: Design Concept of an Automated Laboratory Platform for Capturing Hyperspectral Images
authors: Georgi Manchev, Stanislav Penchev, Plamen Daskalov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Laboratory hyperspectral imaging is a widely used approach for the quantitative determination of macroelements in soils, where the use of precise measurement systems is essential. This work presents a conceptual design for a complete upgrade of an existing hyperspectral system based on the SPECIM N17E pushbroom spectrograph, where the main purpose is to capture soil samples, but the proposed design is not limited to this and can be successfully used with a wider application. The initial configuration suffers from some shortcomings, such as lack of optical isolation, non-standardized illumination and absence of synchronization between mechanical motion control and data acquisition, which compromises the quality and repeatability of measurements. The proposed design addresses these problems by introducing a light-isolated chamber with an internal coating to suppress stray light, standardized illumination geometry with quartz-tungsten-halogen (QTH) sources and a precise focusing mechanism. The main innovation of the concept is the integration of an additional networked module based on Raspberry Pi (RPI), which provides centralized user control, data collection and management, and most importantly, synchronization between the software processes for controlling the mechanical mobile table and for collecting data from the camera. This architecture is expected to transform the existing system into a robust platform capable of generating high-quality data required for the development of advanced models for soil nitrogen analysis and other agrochemical applications.

title: Dynamic Ensemble Voting for Water Extraction: Optimizing Sentinel-2 Water Indices for Enhanced Accuracy and Optimal Processing Time
authors: Nikolay Dimitrov, Valentina Markova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In this paper a novel Dynamic Ensemble Voting for Water Extraction method for two-class water-land classification, optimized for mapping regions with high heterogeneity is proposed. It also presents a comparative analysis of different ensemble voting methods among the following eight water indices (NDWI, MNDWI, AWEI_nsh, AWEI_sh, NDMI, WRI, EWI and TCW) for extracting water surfaces from Sentinel-2 data, in a region with high geomorphological heterogeneity (Lake Varna). The analysis performed in Google Earth Engine highlights the advantages of dynamic ensemble preprocessing, especially in complex pipelines with subsequent classifications, regressions and other processing. The DEVWE method offers an optimal balance between accuracy, adaptability, and processing efficiency. It provides a fast, precise, and fully automated solution suitable for integration into operational water resource monitoring systems

title: IoT-based LPG Management and Control System for Domestic Consumption Monitoring
authors: Stalin Marcelo Arciniegas Aguirre, Cristopher Joel Sánchez Perugachi, Dulce Milagro Rivero Albarrán, Francklin Iván Rivas Echeverría, Franklin Hipólito Sánchez Espinosa
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents the development of an IoT-based system for domestic liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) consumption management and control. The system integrates ultrasonic sensors and ESP32 microcontrollers to enable real-time monitoring of gas levels in residential cylinders through a mobile application. The proposed solution addresses the critical need for efficient LPG management in residential environments, where approximately 70.4% of total consumption occurs. Using Design Science methodology, the research encompasses three phases: relevance (user needs analysis), design (IoT prototype development), and rigor (validation through unit testing and IEEE compliance). The system architecture incorporates MQTT communication protocol, NestJS backend, and Flutter mobile application, ensuring bidirectional communication and real-time data synchronization. Validation results demonstrate accurate gas level measurements with response times under 15 seconds and successful integration between hardware and software components. The system provides automatic alerts for critical levels, optimizing distribution logistics and enhancing user safety.

title: Analysis of the Influence of Gamification on Students’ Interest in Cultural Learning
authors: Luluk Uljannah, Yulyani Arifin
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Gamification has emerged as an innovative strategy to enhance student engagement in education, including the introduction of cultural knowledge. This study investigates the influence of a gamification-based learning application on students’ interest in cultural learning. The research involved 30 eighth-grade students at SMP Muhammadiyah 12 GKB Gresik using a quantitative approach with adapted instruments from the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) combined with intrinsic interest constructs. Data were collected through Likert-scale questionnaires and analyzed to examine the relationship between gamification and cultural learning interest. The results demonstrate that the integration of gamification elements such as points, badges, leaderboards, and challenges fosters a more interactive and enjoyable learning environment, increasing students’ curiosity and motivation to explore cultural subjects. The findings provide both theoretical and practical implications by validating gamification as an effective educational innovation. This study contributes to the growing body of research on gamification in cultural education and offers recommendations for educators and policymakers to adopt gamified strategies to strengthen cultural awareness among students.

title: Perceptions of South African Farmers towards Cybersecurity in Smart Farming Technologies: A Quantitative Analysis
authors: Alfred Thaga Kgopa
publish: 2025 Cybersecurity4D (C4D)
abstract: This study investigates South African farmers’ perceptions of cybersecurity in smart farming technologies through a quantitative approach. As farming methods increasingly adopt advanced technologies like IoT, cloud computing, and AI systems, the agricultural industry faces rising risks from cybersecurity threats. Using a 15-item questionnaire administered to 312 farmers, The study examined awareness levels, perceived threats, implementation of protective measures, trust in technology providers, and adoption barriers. The exploratory factor analysis underscored the identification of five separate dimensions regarding cybersecurity perceptions, reflecting substantial reliability coefficients (Cronbach’ s α = 0.81–0.87). ANOVA results demonstrated significant differences across farm sizes, with larger operations showing better cybersecurity readiness. The findings highlight the need for targeted educational interventions, affordable security solutions, and policy support to strengthen cybersecurity practices in South African smart farming.

title: Covert Data Exfiltration via Electromagnetic Side-Channel Emissions from Computer Memory
authors: Oladapo A. Ajike, Toya Acharya, Mohamed Chouikha, Annamalai Annamalai, Akshay Kulkarni, Sheikh Tareq Ahmed
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Due to the lack of publicly available datasets to develop a machine learning model for detecting electromagnetic data exfiltration via RAM-based Radio Frequency attack in an air-gap system, we established a lab using low-cost and readily available hardware. This paper presents a proof-ofconcept for a covert data transmission system that exploits electromagnetic side-channel emissions from computer memory access patterns, distinguishing it from previous CPU, SATA, or USB-based approaches. Unlike existing electromagnetic covert channels that rely on peripheral components, our RAM-based approach directly manipulates memory access patterns to generate detectable radio frequency signals at $\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ M H z}$, offering superior stealth characteristics and broader applicability across diverse hardware configurations. We achieved successful electromagnetic signal transmission using a C++ developed transmitter program that modulates CPU and memory-intensive operations, and a Python-based receiver integrated with RTL-SDR on the receiver system. A dataset that captured the anomaly in the transmitter system was generated. The features included in the resulting dataset were the timestamped process metrics with binary classification for the anomaly, which offers valuable input for machine learning model development. Although complete file reconstruction remains challenging due to bit-level alignment issues, weak signal emission, and noise interference, the research proves the fundamental vulnerability of electromagnetic emissions from computer memory. With the implementation of our enhanced synchronization protocol that incorporates error correction and adaptive noise filtering, we achieved quantifiable improvements, resulting in a $68 \%$ file reconstruction success rate compared to the initial $\mathbf{4 2 \%}$. Also, the signal detection increased to $\mathbf{7 3 \%}$ accuracy, $\mathbf{1 0 0 0}$ bps effective transmission rate with $\mathbf{1 5 \%}$ error rate, and $\mathbf{0. 5}$-meter operational range. The findings and generated dataset have significant implications for cybersecurity, particularly for securing air-gapped networks and sensitive computing environments.

title: Atrous Spatial Pyramid Pooling(ASPP)-Enhanced U-Net with Squeeze-and-Excitation(SE) Channel Recalibration for Early Smoke Classification
authors: Lola Naomi Enzelin, Samuel Ady Sanjaya, Suyoto, Jansen Wiratama, Santo Fernandi Wijaya, Rudi Sutomo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Early smoke detection is critical for wildfire prevention and industrial safety, yet image-level classification under UAV conditions remains challenging due to low contrast, thin and transient plumes, cluttered backgrounds, and variable illumination. The Flame and Smoke Detection Dataset (FASDD) has expanded benchmarking beyond narrow scenes, but much of the literature emphasizes object detection or few-shot classification. Reported results on FASDD show that Fireformer achieves 87.3% accuracy, ConvNeXt 88.6%, and EfficientNetV2 $82.69 \%$, while FireCLIP, leveraging multimodal pretraining, reaches $98.56 \%$. To balance accuracy and deployability for UAV platforms, we propose an ASPP-Enhanced U-Net with Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) channel recalibration, a compact encoder-decoder repurposed for image-level classification via global pooling of decoder features. The design combines batchnormalized residual blocks for stable optimization, attention-gated skip connections to suppress irrelevant context, an SE mechanism to emphasize subtle smoke cues, and an Atrous Spatial Pyramid Pooling (ASPP) bottleneck to aggregate multiscale features for both faint wisps and broader plumes. On the FASDD_RS subset, the proposed model attains a best validation accuracy of $97.29 \%$, substantially outperforming Fireformer, ConvNeXt, and EfficientNetV2, while remaining within $\boldsymbol{\sim} \mathbf{1 \%}$ of FireCLIP. Pixel-level evaluation further demonstrates strong background suppression (overall accuracy 0.955, precision 0.80, recall 0.81, IoU 0.68, Dice 0.81). These results highlight that a UNet backbone, augmented with ASPP and SE attention, delivers high accuracy in a single end-to-end model that is compact and well-suited for UAV-based early smoke detection.
