title: Semi-Supervised Learning for Volcanic Seismic Event Classification: A Comparative Study of Self-Training and Label Spreading
authors: Pavel Estrella, Felipe Grijalva, Diego S. Benítez, José Vega-Sánchez, Noel Pérez-Pérez
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the impact of the proportion of labeled data on the performance of semi-supervised learning models for the classification of volcanic micro-seismic events. This work utilizes a dataset of over 22,000 micro-earthquake records from the Cotopaxi Volcano, with extracted features from time, frequency, and scale domains. Two semi-supervised approaches are implemented: Self-Training, using Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and Naive Bayes (NB) as base classifiers; and L abel Spreading, based on graph-based label propagation. Model performance is evaluated using two primary metrics: the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUC-ROC) and F1-score. The SVM Self-Training model achieved the highest results, with an AUC of 0.9575 and an F1-score of 0.9472 when trained with 90% of labeled data. The RF model also performed robustly, particularly in noisy or imbalanced scenarios, reaching an AUC of 0.9505 and an F1-score of 0.9436. In contrast, NB showed limited gains, and the Label Spreading model failed to improve with more labeled data, stabilizing at an AUC around 0.88. These findings highlight the effectiveness of SVM and RF in leveraging unlabeled data for seismic event classification under varying label scarcity conditions.

title: Designing and Implementing a Hand Orthosis for Rheumatoid Arthritis Rehabilitation
authors: Kevin J. Morocho-Guevara, Mateo J. Illescas-Siavichay, Mónica A. Romero-Sacoto, Alan I. Rodriguez-Velecela
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This article addresses the implementation of a hand orthosis for rehabilitation focused on people suffering from rheumatoid arthritis, considered a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the functionality of the joints and limits the mobility of the fingers. Using computer-aided design (CAD) tools, a device was developed to emulate the anatomical movements of the fingers based on a system of rigid joints interconnected by a 4bar mechanism. To validate the constructed orthosis, tests were carried out in controlled environments, obtaining a mechanical design that can be adapted to the morphology of the hand. The orthosis also has a control system that guarantees the precision of the programmed movements. This research provides a solid basis for the design of adaptive medical devices and paves the way for the development of similar technologies in the field of rehabilitation.

title: Implementation and performance evaluation of Zimbra 9.0.0 OSE integrated with Proxmox Mail Gateway and Active Directory in an institutional environment
authors: Fabricio Marcillo Vera, Pamela Fajardo Vanegas, Pedro Mosquera Domínguez, Andrés Altamirano Espinosa, Mario Fajardo Vanegas, Milton Altamirano Pazmiño
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents the design, implementation, and evaluation of an institutional email architecture based entirely on open-source technologies, aimed at ensuring secure, efficient, and autonomous communication within a public sector environment. The system was deployed on an enterprise-grade server and integrated Zimbra 9.0.0 Open-Source Edition (OSE), Proxmox Mail Gateway (PMG), and Active Directory (AD) for centralized authentication and access control. The analysis focused on key performance indicators, including spam filtering effectiveness, false positive rates, and system behavior under real-world operational load. Results revealed high detection performance, with blocked spam percentages ranging from 88.42 % to 96.29 > %, while false positive rates remained low, between 0.53% and 1.98%, indicating accurate calibration of filtering policies. System monitoring showed stable performance, with CPU and memory usage remaining within optimal thresholds, and average webmail response times below 0.7 seconds. The integration with AD facilitated streamlined identity management and improved traceability. These outcomes confirmed the viability of open-source platforms in delivering secure and reliable messaging services, particularly in institutional environments that demand budget efficiency, operational resilience, and data sovereignty. The study contributes empirical evidence supporting the strategic adoption of open-source technologies in public infrastructure.

title: Vision Transformer for Multiclass Animal Image Recognition
authors: Assel Mukasheva, Dina Koishiyeva, Jeong Won Kang, Alibek Bisembayev, Teodor Iliev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Automated recognition of animal species from images remains a central challenge in computer vision with applications in ecological monitoring, veterinary diagnostics, and livestock management. Conventional convolutional architectures exhibit limited robustness when confronted with heterogeneous data and visually similar classes, resulting in reduced inter-class separability. To address this limitation, three representative deep learning models were examined: a custom convolutional network, a deep residual network, ResNet50, and a transformer-based ViT-B16. All models were trained under identical conditions with standardized normalization, extensive augmentation, and uniform optimization. Comparative evaluation established a clear stratification of performance. The custom network achieved only moderate accuracy with pronounced misclassification between similar categories. ResNet50 demonstrated substantial improvements and more stable generalization, though residual ambiguities persisted. ViT-B16 consistently outperformed both convolutional models, achieving class-wise F1-scores above 0.90 and true positive rates exceeding 0.95 for most categories. The findings provide rigorous evidence of the superiority of transformer-based architectures for fine-grained image recognition.

title: Electromechanical Setup for Measuring Viscoelastic Interactions of a Brain Phantom
authors: Hristo I. Hristov, Plamen Pekov, Teodor Minev, Dimiter Prodanov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Quantifying biomechanical properties of the brain is important for understanding mechanisms of traumatic brain injury and the biocompatibility of implanted electrodes. The aim of the present work is to demonstrate an experimental setup for precision measurements of the viscoelastic interactions between a long immersed probe, mimicking an implanted electrode and the brain phantom tissue. The setup measures simultaneously pressure, tissue displacement and probe tip displacement. The conducted experiment proves the functionality of the electromechanical experimental setup for studying viscoelastic interactions. High precision of the measurements has been demonstrated, which creates opportunities for future studies of the biomechanical properties of brain tissue.

title: Compressed Sensing of ECG Signal Implemented on FPGA Processor
authors: Miroslav Jusko, Peter Lukacs, Ondrej Kovac, Jan Saliga
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents an FPGA-based signal processing platform for electrocardiogram (ECG) signal compression using a multiwavelet-based compressed sensing (CS) approach. The platform was designed to investigate trade-offs between compression efficiency and reconstruction accuracy when deploying CS on resource-constrained embedded hardware. The algorithm was developed in LabVIEW and implemented on an NI myRIO device, with multiwavelet filtration, differential compressed sensing, and quantization performed on the FPGA, while lightweight arithmetic encoding was executed on the real-time processor. ECG signals from the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Database were segmented into frames of 2048 samples and processed under different parameter configurations, including threshold values and encoding schemes.

title: USSF: A Unified Framework for Screen Standardization in Software Systems
authors: Hristo Hristov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper introduces the Unified Screen Standardization Framework (USSF), a methodological model that consolidates the heterogeneous principles (such as Nielsen’s heuristics, ISO 9241 principles, WCAG accessibility recommendations, Shneiderman’s Eight Golden Rules, Norman’s design principles, etc.) into a coherent, hierarchical structure. USSF employs two novel mechanisms: (1) artifact-based indexing (APP, SCR, DIA, FRM, CMP, WID) to represent application elements in hierarchical form and (2) inheritance with override rules for systematically applying and adapting standards across different levels of user interface elements. The framework enables traceability, scalability and methodological clarity, supporting both usability evaluation and future integration with automated design tools. The USSF could acts as a composite high-level standard that integrates existing standards, principle, heuristics, established usability and accessibility guidelines into a unified model. An illustrative example demonstrates the framework’s applicability, while a discussion highlights its benefits, limitations and potential for empirical validation. The USSF thus provides a novel contribution to human-computer interaction by bridging established guidelines and enabling standardized, traceable and adaptable screen design.

title: Spark: Real-Time Monitoring of Multi-Faceted Programming Exercises
authors: Yinuo Yang, Ashley Ge Zhang, Steve Oney, April Yi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Monitoring in-class programming exercises can help instructors identify struggling students and common challenges. However, understanding students’ progress can be prohibitively difficult, particularly for multi-faceted problems that include multiple steps with complex interdependencies, have no predictable completion order, or involve evaluation criteria that are difficult to summarize across many students (e.g., exercises building interactive web-based user interfaces). We introduce Spark, a coding exercise monitoring dashboard designed to address these challenges. Spark allows instructors to flexibly group substeps into checkpoints based on exercise requirements, suggests automated tests for these checkpoints, and generates visualizations to track progress across steps. Spark also allows instructors to inspect intermediate outputs, providing deeper insights into solution variations. We also construct a dataset of 40 -minute keystroke coding data from $\mathrm{N}=22$ learners solving two web programming exercises and provide empirical insights into the perceived usefulness of Spark through a within-subjects evaluation with $\mathbf{1 6}$ programming instructors. Index Terms-programming education

title: Faces Under Pressure: A web-based emotion recognition system to assess workplace stress, using AI
authors: Paola Salinas-Aguilar, Gustavo Eduardo Fernández Villacrés, Freddy Patricio Baño Naranjo, José Luis Vásconez, Tania Elizabeth Huertas López
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Facial expressions have been studied by professionals in psychology, medicine, law, marketing, art, and sociology. and thanks to technological advances in robotics and artificial intelligence, a facial emotion recognition system has been developed to determine the effectiveness of predicting whether a worker is experiencing work-related stress, by comparing the results with the Maslach Burnout Inventory (MBI), which measures work-related stress in its three main dimensions: emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and low personal fulfillment. Free tools were used and Amazon web services routines designed exclusively for facial emotion recognition were integrated, and an XP methodology was applied for software development. With a population of 25 people who initially assessed their levels of work-related stress, using software that automates MBI, samples were taken over 20 working days using the facial emotion recognition system. Participants were free to determine the number of samples they took during this period, with the instruction that it should be done during the working day, obtaining a total of 260 samples. A Pearson correlation coefficient was applied to the results, obtaining an $\mathrm{r}=0.25$, which indicates a low linear relationship between the MBI and the indices derived from AI; This leads to the conclusion that the facial recognition system shows that technology alone cannot capture the complexity of work-related stress, confirming that numbers and objects or pure technological measurements, even with artificial intelligence and algorithms, are insufficient for diagnosing mental health if the cognitive, affective, interactional, and contextual spheres are not considered in order to understand the complexity of human beings.

title: A Review of Quadruped Robot Control and Perception Based on Augmented Reality
authors: Erick Criollo-Rodríguez, William Oñate, Gustavo Caiza, Erick Pule-Ponce, Jonathan Maldonado-Mejía, Jose Varela-Aldás
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This article presents a systematic literature review on the control and perception of quadruped robots using augmented reality (AR), focusing on current approaches that enable the implementation of teleoperation systems and the limitations encountered during their development. The main objective is to evaluate the architectures and methods currently in use, as well as the solutions offered by AR when applied specifically to quadruped platforms. The review also addresses the shortcomings of conventional control methods in unstructured environments. Methodologically, the study was conducted following the PRISMA guidelines, covering indexed publications between 2018 and 2024. The findings indicate that AR integration significantly enhances operator immersion, facilitates teleoperation, and enables real-time feedback through spatial mapping and sensor visualization. Furthermore, the review highlights current challenges such as latency, co-localization errors, and cognitive overload, emphasizing the need for more ergonomic, adaptive, and intelligent interface designs in future implementations.

title: Mechanical characterization of FCAW welding with combinations of flux cored wires and shielding gases on ASTM A588 steel for bridges
authors: Oscar Analuiza, Santiago Bonilla, Cesar Arroba
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The construction of steel bridges requires welded joints with high mechanical strength, durability, and efficiency. In Ecuador, the application of flux-cored arc welding (FCAW) has increased; however, limited technical guidance exists regarding optimal consumable combinations that meet AWS D1.5 requirements. In this study, butt joints of ASTM A588 Grade A steel were fabricated using FCAW with varying proportions of E71T1 and E81T1Ni2 flux-cored wires and two shielding gases: CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and Indurmig $\left(20 \% \mathrm{CO}_{2}+\mathrm{Ar}\right)$. A total of six experimental groups were produced and tested. Mechanical characterization included tensile, Charpy impact, guided bend, and macrographic tests, conducted in accordance with AWS D1.5 acceptance criteria. Statistical analysis included an ANOVA with a 95% confidence level ($\mathbf{p}{\lt}0.05$), confirming significant differences in the properties. The combination P3 (80% E71T1 - 20% E81T1Ni2) exhibited superior performance, achieving increases of 23.9% in ultimate tensile strength, 40.5% in yield strength, 20.1% in elongation, and 48.4% in impact energy relative to the reference values. Based on these results, a Welding Procedure Specification (WPS) was developed and validated for implementation in bridge superstructure fabrication. The proposed procedure enhances weld quality, consistency, and cost-efficiency, offering a standardized solution for code-compliant structural applications.

title: Structural Causal Modeling with Double Machine Learning for Robust Policy Evaluation
authors: T.Dwiati Wismarini, S. Yulianto J. Prasetyo, Bambang Susanto, Yessica Nataliani
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Urban land-use conflicts often arise from overlapping ecological, demographic, and economic pressures, making them difficult to resolve through conventional statistical approaches. These methods struggle to separate the causal impacts of policy interventions from confounding socioeconomic factors. This paper proposes a methodological framework that integrates Structural Causal Models (SCM) with Double Machine Learning (DML) to estimate the causal effects of land-use policies on urban land dynamics. The framework employs directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) to formalize causal assumptions and applies back-door adjustment with DML to achieve robust effect estimation under complex confounding. Empirical results show that land tenure types substantially influence the probability of conflict, and these effects are further moderated by demographic and ecological heterogeneity. Beyond the empirical findings, the study illustrates how SCM+DML functions as a form of computational intelligence, combining adaptive learning with causal reasoning to strengthen policy evaluation. The contribution is twofold: (1) methodologically, it advances causal inference approaches in high-dimensional urban policy settings, and (2) practically, it provides actionable insights for policymakers to design more adaptive, transparent, and evidence-based land-use regulations

title: Performance Analysis of Combined Feature Extraction Method on Chili Quality Classification using XGBoost
authors: Yisti Vita Via, Eva Yulia Puspaningrum, Zain Muzadid Zamzani, Salamun Rohman Nudin, Siti Mukaromah, Afina Lina Nurlaili
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Chili pepper (Capsicum frutescens L.) is a highvalue horticultural commodity whose quality determines its market price and consumer acceptance. Manual quality assessment remains subjective and inefficient, highlighting the need for an automated system. This study proposes a digital image processing approach for classifying chili pepper quality using the eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) algorithm. Three feature types were extracted from chili pepper images: texture features using Local Binary Pattern (LBP) and Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM), and color features using Hue Saturation Value (HSV). A dataset of 1,200 primary images representing six quality categories (raw, half-ripe, ripe, dry, rotten, and anthracnose) was used. The images underwent preprocessing including background removal, resizing, and augmentation. Experimental results show that the combination of LBP, GLCM, and HSV features achieved the best performance, with an accuracy of $95.83 \%$, precision of 0.9586, recall of 0.9583, and $\mathbf{F 1}$-score of 0.9581. The optimal XGBoost parameters were a learning rate of $0.1,100$ estimators, and a maximum depth of 12. These findings demonstrate that integrating color and texture features effectively enhances chili pepper quality classification accuracy.

title: An Integrated Approach to Evaluating E-Commerce Platforms using Postman and Selenium
authors: Fatima Sapundzhi, Elizabeta Jovanova, Metodi Popstoilov, Slavi Georgiev, Ivan Georgiev, Tsvetelina Stefanova, Venelin Todorov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The successful operation of e-commerce platforms depends on the reliability of key business processes such as registration, login, adding products and finalizing an order. This study presents an integrated approach to automated testing by combining the use of Postman for Application Programming Interfaces testing and Selenium for User Interactions testing. The approach applied Page Object Model and TestNG to ensure modularity, consistency and reusability of the test code. Experiments were conducted that included scenarios for successful and unsuccessful transactions, and response times and stability were measured. The results show that the combination of Postman and Selenium provides a comprehensive view of quality - from the reliability and performance of backend services to the usability of the interface and error response.

title: Multiprocessor Based Architecture for Optimum Control of Reconfigurable and Multifunctional Next Generation Antenna Systems
authors: Ioannis Gavriilidis, Dimitrios Karamanlis, Theodoros Kaifas
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The evolution of wireless communications requires antennas that can adapt to multiple requirements of dynamic environments and support high data rates. Reconfigurable antennas (RAs) provide this potential by changing their properties. At the same time, the integration of microcontrollers Units (MCUs), Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs), and software platforms offers real time control, automation and a sub-optimal solution in certain conditions in telecommunications applications. This paper presents the antennas for the next telecommunications generations and highlights the role of microcontrollers.

title: Investigation of the Impact of Photovoltaic Systems on Medium Voltage Grids
authors: Dimitrios Kazolis
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In recent years, with the rapid development of numerous photovoltaic systems, attention has been drawn to the potential impact these may have on the stability of voltage in electricity distribution networks. This is the focus of the present study, which aims to examine the relationship that may exist between voltage fluctuations in electricity transmission networks and the variation in the photovoltaic system production. To this end, two separate databases of a specific geographical area are processed and combined. These relate respectively to the output of photovoltaic parks in amperes and the grid voltage in kilovolts, for a period of one year. The above databases were merged into a single file, and then analyzed using various approaches, such as correlation analysis, the use of a scatter plot, time series analysis and regression analysis, specifically linear regression. All the above was done in Python programming language. Finally, the research findings were summarized and presented to contribute to improved knowledge of this subject.

title: Evaluate Road Depressions with Deep Learning and Mobile Application
authors: Wei-Fun Chan, Ee-Mae Ang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Road damage such as potholes and cracks potentially poses significant safety challenges, economic outlays, ecological impact, and governance concerns. This study presents an integrated approach using deep learning and mobile technology to automate the detection and severity classification of road depressions. The system compares three YOLO models, which are the YOLOv5s, YOLOv8s, and YOLOv11s, trained on the RDD2022 dataset to identify the optimal model for deployment. YOLOv8 is selected based on its balanced performance, achieving 65 percent precision, 59 percent recall, and 62 percent $\mathbf{F 1}$-score. A React Native mobile app enables users to upload images and receive feedback, while a Django backend handles prediction and status updates. This solution improves road maintenance efficiency and promotes public participation in infrastructure reporting.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Object Detection Models for Identifying Fruit Flies in Snake Fruit Cultivation
authors: Indah Desri Wahyuni, Nabila Husna Shabrina, Suputa, Riya Fatma Sari
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: The snake fruit export farming community in Sleman, Yogyakarta, experienced a decline in production in 2023 due to fruit fly infestations. Control efforts were carried out using the Area-Wide Integrated Pest Management (AWIPM) approach by installing methyl eugenol-based pheromone traps, with effectiveness measured using the Flies per Trap per Day (FTD) indicator. Since the fruit fly-counting process is still performed manually and is time-consuming, this study proposes an image-based automatic counting system to improve monitoring efficiency and accuracy. A comparative analysis was conducted on five deep-learning-based object detection models, YOLOv3, YOLOv5, YOLOv7, YOLOv8, and Fast R-CNN, using a public fruit fly dataset. Six different training schemes were applied to the YOLO models, whereas Fast R-CNN was trained using an iterative approach. Based on the evaluation results, YOLOv5 demonstrated the best and most balanced performance, achieving a precision of 0.944, recall of 0.947, and mAP of 0.946. Its architecture, which incorporates Leaky ReLU and Sigmoid activation functions along with the CSPDarknet backbone, enables efficient feature extraction and real-time object detection. Therefore, YOLOv5 was selected as the primary model for developing an accurate and lightweight fruit fly detection and counting system to support farmers and regulatory reporting.

title: Radio Frequency Fingerprint Identification With Fusion of Domain Knowledge and Simplified Residual Network
authors: Shaoying Guo, Liang Li, Xiaohui Li, Jiajia Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: As the number of wireless devices has grown exponentially, there is a great challenge for identifying large quantities of transmitters with high accuracy. Radio frequency (RF) fingerprint identification is a powerful tool for wireless device identification, also called as specific emitter identification (SEI). There is nearly no research about the sufficient integration of domain knowledge with deep networks among the existing SEI methods, limiting the accurate identification of large amount of transmitters quickly. A novel deep fusion SEI approach with domain knowledge and improved residual network is proposed. The domain knowledge is integrated to highlight the differences among emitters. An improved residual network with simplified layers and attention mechanism is proposed to further characterize the subtle and deep fingerprints with high efficiency. The real-world large datasets are utilized and the proposed method has superior performance of identifying large number of emitters with high accuracy of 96.63% for 60 emitters and 94.46% for 139 emitters. Through numerous of comparative experiments, it is demonstrated that the proposed method has higher accuracy, fewer parameters, less running time comparing to the State-of-Art studies.

title: Multi-stage Group Interaction and Cross-domain Fusion Network for Real-time Smoke Segmentation
authors: Kang Li, Feiniu Yuan, Chunmei Wang, Chunli Meng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Lightweight smoke image segmentation is essential for fire warning systems, particularly on mobile devices. In recent years, although numerous high-precision, large-scale smoke segmentation models have been developed, there are few lightweight solutions specifically designed for mobile applications. Therefore, we propose a Multi-stage Group Interaction and Cross-domain Fusion Network (MGICFN) with low computational complexity for real-time smoke segmentation. To improve the model’s ability to effectively analyze smoke features, we incorporate a Cross-domain Interaction Attention Module (CIAM) to merge spatial and frequency domain features for creating a lightweight smoke encoder. To alleviate the loss of critical information from small smoke objects during downsampling, we design a Multi-stage Group Interaction Module (MGIM). The MGIM calibrates the information discrepancies between high and low-dimensional features. To enhance the boundary information of smoke targets, we introduce an Edge Enhancement Module (EEM), which utilizes predicted target boundaries as advanced guidance to refine lower-level smoke features. Furthermore, we implement a Group Convolutional Block Attention Module (GCBAM) and a Group Fusion Module (GFM) to connect the encoder and decoder efficiently. Experimental results demonstrate that MGICFN achieves an 88.70% Dice coefficient (Dice), an 81.16% mean Intersection over Union (mIoU), and a 91.93% accuracy (Acc) on the SFS3K dataset. It also achieves an 87.30% Dice, a 78.68% mIoU, and a 92.95% Acc on the SYN70K test dataset. Our MGICFN model has 0.73M parameters and requires 0.3G FLOPs.

title: HySpeFAS: A Hyperspectral Face Anti-spoofing Dataset based on Snapshot Compressive Imaging_supp1-3648158.pdf
authors: Yali Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Face anti-spoofing, which aims to prevent the attacks of widely-used face recognition systems, is highly related to personal privacy and property security. However, existing benchmarks on face anti-spoofing mainly focus on RGB images, further challenged by consistently developed 3D high-fidelity (HiFi) masks. To facilitate the research on multimodal face anti-spoofing, we construct the HyperSpectral Face Anti-Spoofing (HySpeFAS) dataset. We introduce the newly-developed snapshot spectral imaging (SSI) technology to capture real and spoof faces, as well as identify unknown HiFi masks. Specifically, hyperspectral images (HSIs) acquired by SSI sensor contain rich information about the chemical composition of the targets, which can be used to effectively distinguish live human skin and various spoof materials. The HySpeFAS dataset contains 22,368 multimodal images (i.e., RGB, SSI, HSI) of 17 live subjects and 60 spoof subjects. Moreover, extensive experiments with baseline deep learning models validate the special features of the SSI images and the potential of SSI in FAS. By publishing the dataset as well as the baseline models, we encourage the community to foster the algorithm study associated with hyperspectral images and the development of SSI-equipped intelligent systems.

title: Lessons Learned from the euROBIN Manipulation Skill Versatility Challenge at IROS 2024_supp5-3648290.mp4
authors: Chaoyang Song
publish: N/A
abstract: Robotic automation in high-mix, low-volume settings often relies on structured workcells where fixtures, workpieces, and procedures are well defined, but tasks must be reconfigured quickly across variants. This paper presents the Design and Learning Research Group's solution to the euROBIN Manipulation Skill Versatility Challenge (MSVC) at IROS 2024, in which a standardized electronic task board is operated through a fixed sequence of subtasks. We deliberately adopt a simple, industry-style implementation: each subtask is taught by recording an open-loop Tool Center Point (TCP) and gripper trajectory in the task-board frame, a wrist-mounted depth camera is used once per run to localize the board and a few key features, and a web dashboard exposes the resulting motion primitives as reusable code blocks that can be reordered and reparameterized. With this pipeline, our system completes the benchmark in 28.2 s in the lab (37.2 s on-site), compared to a human baseline of 16.3 s and an average of 83.5 s for previous teams, closing a large part of the performance gap without advanced learning or feedback control. We further demonstrate limited skill transfer by retargeting the same subtask library to a smoke-detector battery replacement scenario required by the competition. Finally, we release our implementation as open source and discuss how competition design and benchmark structure influence the balance between simple engineered solutions and richer sensing and learning.

title: Design Optimization of Hybrid-Laminated Fast-Scanning Magnets for the Carbon-Ion Radiotherapy
authors: Ben Fan, Bin Tang, Chenyang Gong, Guo Peng, Pai Xiang, Geng Wei, Yuan Chen, Xianhu Zeng, Rong Zhou, Ruicheng Yan, Pengshan Chang, Wanglin Wang, Junjie Yao, Renming Zhong, Yuehu Pu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: Scanning magnets are devices responsible for deflecting particles to specific locations in particle therapy utilizing spot-scanning techniques. To maintain scanned beam-spot distortion at the isocenter plane within an acceptable threshold, sufficient field-integral homogeneity must be guaranteed in both transverse dimensions across the good field region. Typically, this is accomplished by adding shims on both sides of magnet poles. In this study, we innovatively proposed a method for multi-objective optimization of shim parameters and excitation currents using the state-of-the-art evolutionary algorithm, Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm-III (NSGA-III), to facilitate an efficient optimization process. After that, beam tracking has been employed to assess the beam-spot distortion. By implementing these methods, we successfully developed an optimal Y-axis scanning magnet (SMY) using hybrid-laminated silicon steels. Designed for a fast scanning speed of up to 80 mm/ms, this magnet can deliver a 400 MeV/u carbon-ion beam to cover a 20 cm × 20 cm irradiation field at a source-to-axis distance (SAD) of 255 cm. Compared to the manually tuned SMY configuration, the automated optimization process achieved a 78.80% homogeneity enhancement in the good field region at the midplane. This advanced high-performance magnet, designed for integration with the next-generation lightweight superconducting rotating gantry, is a pioneering accelerator magnet developed through intelligent algorithm-driven optimization. Static magnetic field measurements conclusively demonstrate the manufacturability of this genetically optimized magnet within existing CNC machining frameworks, and show good agreement with simulation results. Furthermore, the development of the X-axis scanning magnet (SMX) is also discussed.

title: Designing Spatial Architectures for Sparse Attention: STAR Accelerator via Cross-Stage Tiling_supp1-3648055.pdf
authors: Yang Hu
publish: N/A
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) rely on self–attention for contextual understanding, demanding high-throughput inference and large–scale token parallelism (LTPP). Existing dynamic sparsity accelerators falter under LTPP scenarios due to stage-isolated optimizations. Revisiting the end-to-end sparsity acceleration flow, we identify an overlooked opportunity: crossstage coordination can substantially reduce redundant computation and memory access. We propose STAR, a cross-stage computetation and memory–efficient algorithm–hardware co-design tailored for Transformer inference under LTPP. STAR introduces a leading-zero-based sparsity prediction using log-domain add only operations to minimize prediction overhead. It further employs distributed sorting and a sorted updating FlashAttention mechanism, guided by a coordinated tiling strategy that enables fine-grained stage interaction for improved memory efficiency and latency. These optimizations are supported by a dedicated STAR accelerator architecture, achieving up to 9.2× speedup and 71.2× energy efficiency over A100, and surpassing SOTA accelerators by up to 16.1× energy and 27.1× area efficiency gains. Further, we deploy STAR onto a multi-core spatial architecture, optimizing dataflow and execution orchestration for ultra-long sequence processing. Architectural evaluation shows that, compared to the baseline design, Spatial-STAR achieves a 20.1× throughput improvement.
