title: Pathologic Voice Recordings Databases: Generalizability and Data Availability
authors: Monika Danilovaitė, Gintautas Tamulevičius
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Computer-assisted voice assessment remains preclinical due to limited training data and poor generalizability. Combining multiple available voice databases could address these limitations, but the differences between databases are poorly understood. In this work, differences across pathological voice databases are analysed using Linear Mixed Models and Mutual Information scores. Results reveal significant differences between databases. These differences are caused by inconsistent recording protocols and population sampling, leading to differing lengths of recordings, values of features and noticeable differences in articulation. Consequently, while training on a single database limits generalizability, simply combining databases is not a straightforward solution. Found results indicate that unless these inherent differences are explicitly accounted for, models will fail to perform well on any new data, regardless of the number of source databases used.

title: Open-Source Rehabilitation of CRS A255 Robotic Arms: Embedded Fuzzy Control and ROS Integration with Simulation Support
authors: Andres Erazo, V Andres Arcentales, N Stalin Caza, Luis Orozco
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents the comprehensive retrofitting of two CRS A255 industrial robotic manipulators through mechanical restoration, control system modernization, and integration with simulation environments. Initially rendered inoperative due to hardware degradation and outdated proprietary electronics, the robots underwent structural repairs, cleaning, and the replacement or repositioning of mechanical components, including DC motors and optical incremental encoders. A modular embedded control architecture was developed using microcontrollers, enabling independent actuation of brakes, encoder signal acquisition, and PWM-based motor control. The system was interfaced with the Robot Operating System (ROS) to facilitate real-time communication and control via the rosserial protocol. A fuzzy logic controller was implemented to manage joint positioning without relying on precise dynamic modeling, enhancing robustness and adaptability. Additionally, a digital twin of the manipulator was selected among V-REP (CoppeliaSim) models, allowing bi-directional synchronization between the virtual model and physical hardware. Experimental results validated improvements in angular control accuracy, system responsiveness, and processing latency, confirming the platform’s effectiveness for research and educational applications in robotics.

title: Predicting Early Corruption Risk in Public Procurement: Ecuador’s Case Study
authors: Mateo Fuertes, Melisa Guerrero, Sthefano Ulloa, Daniel Riofrío, Felipe Grijalva, Pavel Alba, José Vega-Sánchez, Farith Simon, Maria Baldeon-Calisto
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Public procurement accounts for nearly a third of Ecuador’s public spending and is a critical vector for corruption. In response to this challenge, this work presents an earlywarning framework that predicts corruption risk in Ecuador’s Reverse Electronic Auction (REA) processes. Specifically, we extend the Kapak transparency platform by constructing a stagebased dataset ($2020-2023$) of 2,000 REA contracts, integrating 12 binary red-flag indicators and 20 structural features per stage. Corruption risk is operationalized as a four-level label derived from a composite indicator built on quartile thresholds. To address this predictive task, we formulate prediction as a multi-class classification task and benchmark Support Vector Machines, Multilayer Perceptrons, Random Forests, and Gradient Boosting across three decision points: (i) Stage 1: Questions-Answers-Clarifications, (ii) Stage 2: Pending Award, and (iii) Stage 3: Contract Execution. Across all stages, Gradient Boosting consistently ranks first, achieving macro-F1/AUC-ROC scores of 0.60/0.84 in Stage 1, 0.61/0.85 in Stage 2, and 0.79/0.94 in Stage 3, with performance gains confirmed by Wilcoxon signed-rank tests (threshold $\boldsymbol{\lt } \mathbf{0. 0 5}$). Notably, high-risk contracts are the easiest to discern (AUC up to 0.91), while medium-risk levels remain challenging. Furthermore, feature-importance analysis reveals that clarifications with restrictive language, late contract publication, and post-award document changes are among the strongest predictors. Overall, the results demonstrate that meaningful corruption-risk signals are detectable well before contract execution, enabling oversight bodies to allocate investigative resources proactively and enhance procurement integrity in emerging economies.

title: Technology-Driven Multidimensional Evaluation of Learning Outcomes in Higher Education: A Systematic Synthesis
authors: Meta Amalya Dewi, Dina Fitria Murad, Sfenrianto, Harjanto Prabowo
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: This study presents a systematic synthesis of technology-driven approaches for evaluating student learning outcomes (LO) in higher education, with emphasis on cognitive, affective, and behavioral dimensions. By analyzing the integration of big data analytics, digital platforms, and computational models, the research identifies emerging patterns in multidimensional evaluation practices. A Systematic Literature Review (SLR) was conducted using the Kitchenham method, involving 30 peer-reviewed articles published between 2019 and 2025. Studies were assessed based on methodological rigor, theoretical foundation, and relevance to $\mathbf{L O}$ domains. The findings reveal that cognitive outcomes are predominantly measured through quantitative tools, while affective and behavioral aspects are addressed through qualitative and formative assessments. Mixed-methods approaches are most effective in capturing the full spectrum of student achievement. Visual tools such as heatmaps and topic networks were used to illustrate variable relationships and evaluation trends. Notably, only a limited number of studies address $\mathbf{L O}$ evaluation in online and distance learning environments, and these often lack depth in capturing affective engagement and behavioral change. This review contributes a cross-national perspective, highlighting the need for integrative, scalable, and context-aware LO evaluation models that align with outcome-based education and the complexities of digital higher education ecosystems.

title: Developing a Functional Test Stand for Advanced Air Turbine Models
authors: Anastas Yangyozov, Aleksandrina Bankova, Stefan Tenev, Asparuh Atanasov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Advanced in the present paper is the development of a specialized test stand for aerodynamic evaluation of turbines displaying non-standard blade geometries, with the primary objective being the establishment of a reliable experimental environment that facilitates the analysis and verification of their operational characteristics. Several critical subsystems are integrated into the stand, including a mechanical load-bearing structure, an adjustable airflow wind tunnel, an airflow generation system, and high-precision measurement instrumentation. The methodological approach emphasizes the creation of conditions that enable accurate assessment of key performance parameters, including aerodynamic efficiency, energy losses, operational stability across diverse loading regimes, and the impact of blade geometry on the overall turbine dynamics. The resultant experimental data is pivotal for both the validation of numerical models and the optimization of design solutions, ultimately enhancing the efficiency and reliability of aerodynamic turbines for energy generation.

title: A Block-Based Language for CI/CD Authoring
authors: Hugo Da Gião, Rui Pereira, Jácome Cunha
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Continuous Integration and Deployment (CI/CD) pipelines are essential for modern software delivery, yet configuring them remains a challenge due to the complexity of text-based formats like YAML. These configurations are error-prone and require substantial expertise, posing a barrier to novices. In this paper, we introduce PipeBlocks, a block-based CI/CD tool featuring a graphical interface for visually constructing pipelines through modular, drag-and-drop blocks. PipeBlocks seamlessly integrates with GitHub Actions, allowing users to design, validate, and execute pipelines entirely within the tool while maintaining full compatibility with existing YAML workflows. A key innovation is the ability to trigger and monitor pipeline runs directly in PipeBlocks, eliminating context-switching. We evaluated PipeBlocks through a controlled study with 10 participants configuring identical pipelines (build, test, deploy) using both PipeBlocks and YAML editing in GitHub Actions. Using the System Usability Scale (SUS) and NASA-TLX benchmarks, we found that PipeBlocks achieved a statistically significantly higher usability score and a lower cognitive load. The results suggest that block-based approaches can effectively lower CI/CD’s learning curve while maintaining functional completeness, making them particularly valuable for academic settings and early-career developers building CI/CD competencies.

title: Improvement model to reduce defects in airtight buckets: Application of SMED 4.0, TPM and DOE in the plastics sector
authors: Nayeli Huacho Ynga, José Luis Álvarez Arteaga, Victor Villafuerte Taipe
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In the plastics industry, reducing defective parts is essential to ensure quality, efficiency, and competitiveness. This study presents a model to reduce the defective part rate in the sealed pail line by integrating three complementary tools: Total Productive Maintenance (TPM), focused on preventing anomalies in injection molds; Single Minute Exchange of Die (SMED) with an IoT approach, to reduce color changeover time; and Design of Experiments (DOE), to optimize the pigment ratio in the mixing process. The defective part rate was reduced from $9.38 \%$ to $3.50 \%$, demonstrating the model’s effectiveness. The proposal is applicable to other production lines with similar conditions, providing a scalable methodology aligned with Industry $\mathbf{4. 0}$ principles.

title: A High Performance UWB Antenna for Military Communications and Radar Applications
authors: Yazan Mohammad Hyasat, Yanal S. Faouri
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents the design and performance analysis of a novel ultra-wideband microstrip patch antenna meticulously engineered for military communications and radar applications covering the frequency range from 3.63 gigahertz to 22.03 gigahertz. The primary radiating element consists of a rectangular patch with a rounded edge at the top and two identical extensions on either side. The antenna is fed through a simple microstrip line and fabricated on a cost-effective and readily available FR4 substrate with a dielectric constant of 4.4. The antenna demonstrates exceptional impedance matching, with a simulated return loss consistently below ten decibels across its entire operational bandwidth. The antenna exhibits a stable peak realized gain ranging from 2.84 to 9.59 decibels and a high radiation efficiency exceeding 86.38 percent throughout the band. A detailed analysis of the simulated E-plane and H-plane radiation patterns at key resonant frequencies (4.46, 7.68, 10.21, 12.47, 17.04, 19.67, and 21.13 gigahertz) reveals a versatile evolution of directional characteristics, transitioning from broad coverage at lower frequencies to more focused and complex patterns at higher frequencies. This adaptability makes the antenna a promising candidate for diverse military applications, including broadband tactical communications, electronic warfare, surveillance radar, and precision-tracking systems, offering a multifunctional solution for modern military platforms.

title: Considering Metal Structures when Modeling Electromagnetic Fields of a 25 kV Traction Network
authors: Andrey Kryukov, Konstantin Suslov, Ekaterina Voronina, Iliya K. Iliev, Hristo Beloev, Ivan Beloev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study focuses on the formulation of digital models for assessing traction network-generated electromagnetic fields (EMF) in environments containing large metallic portals, specifically overpasses. A key outcome of the modeling is the pronounced distortion of the spatial EMF distribution by large conductive structures, which transforms the field from a plane-parallel regime into a fully three-dimensional one. The underlying numerical approach employs a mesh of finite-length segments to represent the entire system, including aerial and grounded elements. The spatial dimensions of this mesh were deliberately confined to a scale of several hundred meters, a necessary condition for upholding the quasi-stationary field assumption at frequencies up to 2 kHz. The implemented system model included an equivalent power supply generator, a 40 MVA traction substation, and a 10-km double-track section of a 25 kV traction network utilizing a PBSM-95 + MF-100 catenary suspension. Analysis of the simulation data provided the longitudinal profiles of EMF strength amplitudes and their constituent components, followed by the construction of three-dimensional field distribution maps to elucidate the spatial characteristics of the electromagnetic environment. The study results indicate that the presented method successfully incorporates the effect of metal structures in traction network EMF modeling. Its practical application can contribute to the design of enhanced electromagnetic safety protocols.

title: Designing Conversational AI to Support Think-Aloud Practice in Technical Interview Preparation for CS Students
authors: Taufiq Daryanto, Sophia Stil, Xiaohan Ding, Daniel Manesh, Sang Won Lee, Tim Lee, Stephanie Lunn, Sarah Rodriguez, Chris Brown, Eugenia Rho
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: One challenge in technical interviews is the thinkaloud process, where candidates verbalize their thought processes while solving coding tasks. Despite its importance, opportunities for structured practice remain limited. Conversational AI offers potential assistance, but limited research explores user perceptions of its role in think-aloud practice. To address this gap, we conducted a study with 17 participants using an LLM-based technical interview practice tool. Participants valued AI’s role in simulation, feedback, and learning from generated examples. Key design recommendations include promoting social presence in conversational AI for technical interview simulation, providing feedback beyond verbal content analysis, and enabling crowdsourced think-aloud examples through humanAI collaboration. Beyond feature design, we examined broader considerations, including intersectional challenges and potential strategies to address them, how AI-driven interview preparation could promote equitable learning in computing careers, and the need to rethink AI’s role in interview practice by suggesting a research direction that integrates human-AI collaboration.

title: Designing Human-AI Collaboration to Support Learning in Counterspeech Writing
authors: Xiaohan Ding, Kaike Ping, Uma Sushmitha Gunturi, Buse Carik, Sophia Stil, Lance T Wilhelm, Taufiq Daryanto, James Hawdon, Sang Won Lee, Eugenia H Rho
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Online hate speech has become increasingly prevalent on social media, causing harm to individuals and society. While automated content moderation has received considerable attention, user-driven counterspeech remains a less explored yet promising approach. However, many people face difficulties in crafting effective responses. We introduce CounterQuill, a human-AI collaborative system that helps everyday users with writing empathetic counterspeech-not by generating automatic replies, but by educating them through reflection and response. CounterQuill follows a three-stage workflow grounded in computational thinking: (1) a learning session to build understanding of hate speech and counterspeech, (2) a brainstorming session to identify harmful patterns and ideate counterspeech ideas, and (3) a co-writing session that helps users refine their counter responses while preserving personal voice. Through a user study ($\mathbf{N} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{2 0}$), we found that CounterQuill helped participants develop the skills to brainstorm and draft counterspeech with confidence and control throughout the process. Our findings highlight how AI systems can scaffold complex communication tasks through structured, human-centered workflows that educate users on how to recognize, reflect on, and respond to online hate speech.

title: Open Justice and the Challenge of Privacy and Personal Data Protection in Ecuador’s Electronic Case System
authors: Tatiana Saltos-Hidalgo, Alex Fabián Mejía-Sandoval, Erick Sebastián Rodríguez-García, Yesenia Nicole Simbaña-Guala
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Ecuador’s electronic filing platform (SATJE) routinely exposes litigants’ full identifiers and sensitive information, undermining the constitutional guarantees of privacy and personal-data protection. To measure the scale of the problem, we reviewed all 933 constitutional filings lodged in 2023 before Quito’s North Judicial Complex, isolated the 270 petitions granted at first instance, and examined 78 digital case files-treating each judicial tier as a separate analytical unit. We coded every docket, classified disclosures into seven statutory categories, and recorded their anonymization status. Of the 78 evaluable files, 94.9% contained no anonymization whatsoever. Names, identity numbers and sensitive particulars persisted across the record; data concerning disability appeared in 33.3% of cases and information on minors in 25.6%, whereas asset data were rare (2.6%). All instances of anonymization—partial or total-concerned minors only. These findings show that Ecuador’s digital-justice architecture privileges transparency over privacy, leaving personal data perpetually exposed to every online visitor. We argue that a judiciary-wide anonymization protocol, implemented by designated data-protection officers, is now imperative. Default suppression of personal data offers the most viable route to reconcile open-justice ideals with constitutional obligations and to restore public trust in electronic justice.

title: Implementation of a Virtual Networking Laboratory for Corporate Network Simulation Using GNS3
authors: Fernando Caicedo-Altamirano, Silvia Alpúsig-Cuichán, Patricio Villacrés-Cevallos, Bryan Chanataxi Nacimba, Alexis Loachamin-Alvarez, María Guamán-Yanez
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The increasing demand for practical networking skills in telecommunications education is limited by the high cost and operational complexity of physical laboratories. To overcome these barriers, we designed and implemented a fully virtual corporate network laboratory using GNS3 and VMware that accurately replicates a multi-branch enterprise topology with real-world routing, switching, and security protocols. The laboratory integrates Cisco and MikroTik devices with VLAN segmentation, OSPF dynamic routing, and GRE-based VPN tunnels, enabling advanced hands-on training without additional hardware. Comprehensive performance tests confirmed an average OSPF convergence time of 7.2 seconds and a 35% reduction in inter-branch latency compared with OSPF-only routing. Resource consumption remained stable, operating with 3.2 GB of RAM and less than $50 \& \mathrm{CPU}$ utilization on mid-range hardware. These results validate the scalability, reproducibility, and cost-effectiveness of the proposed architecture, offering an estimated USD $\mathbf{1 2, 0 0 0}$ savings compared with an equivalent physical setup. The solution provides a robust and academically rigorous platform for universities and technical institutes to modernize curricula and enhance student readiness for real-world enterprise communication networks.

title: Integrating Machine Learning with Cloud-Native Architecture for AJI Applications: Scalable Attendance and Payroll Solutions
authors: Trimono Trimono, Dwi Arman Prasetya, Mohammad Idhom, Masti Fatchiyah Maharani, Ajeng Puspa Wardani, Muhammad Azkiya Akmal
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in Indonesia continue to face challenges in managing employee attendance and payroll due to reliance on manual systems. This study introduces AJI, a cloud-native application integrated with machine learning to automate and secure attendance and payroll processes. The system is designed with a cloud-native architecture that ensures scalability, security, and cost efficiency. For employee identification, the application employs facial recognition technology using a Siamese Convolutional Neural Network (SCNN). Employee attendance data is directly linked to an automated payroll system that accounts for attendance, overtime, and lateness. The backend infrastructure utilizes Google Cloud services, including Cloud Run, Cloud SQL, and Cloud Storage. The model was trained on 2,800 facial images and achieved a testing accuracy of 98.80\%. Deployment through Cloud Run resulted in an average response time of 1 second for facial verification requests. Compared to similar applications, AJI offers an integrated, automated solution specifically designed for MSMEs, emphasizing data accuracy, operational transparency, and user-friendliness. This research aims to enhance operational efficiency and minimize manual errors in human resource management systems for MSMEs. Future enhancements may include multi-language support and broader application in sectors like healthcare and education.

title: A Bibliometric Analysis of Natural Language Processing in the Study of Human Behavior
authors: Edison F. Meneses Torres, Stefany A. Narváez Sampedro, Paul Sanmartin-Mendoza, Santiago Acurio Maldonado, Erwin J. Sacoto-Cabrera, Mónica Karel Huerta
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Over the past decade, Natural Language Processing (NLP) has emerged as a key tool for understanding human behavior through large-scale textual data. However, the rapid increase in publications has led to fragmentation that makes it difficult to identify clear trends, thematic gaps, and emerging research areas. This situation limits the development of focused studies and hinders interdisciplinary collaboration in fields such as mental health, education, and social media analysis. The aim of this study is to conduct a bibliometric analysis to map the scientific evolution of NLP research applied to human behavior, highlighting key topics, collaboration networks, and future research directions. Following the PRISMA 2020 guidelines, a final corpus of 22 articles from the Scopus database (2010-2024) was analyzed using the Bibliometrix software package for quantitative analysis. The results reveal a steady growth in scientific output, with a thematic concentration in sentiment analysis, digital mental health, and emotion detection. Strong collaboration networks were identified in North America, Europe, and Asia, although low participation from regions in Latin America and Africa was noted. This study provides a comprehensive overview of the current landscape, highlighting research opportunities and the need to develop explainable and ethically auditable models to guide future interdisciplinary work.

title: Innovation and resilience in medical imaging servers: an alternative based on Synology DSM and ARPL on commodity hardware
authors: Fabricio Marcillo Vera, Lucía Begnini Domínguez, Natacha Chamorro Benavides, Jessica Garrido Egas, Daniel Shauri Romero, Pamela Fajardo Vanegas
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents the implementation and performance analysis of a medical imaging server based on Synology DSM and ARPL virtualization deployed on generic hardware within a public hospital setting. Over a continuous six-month evaluation at Dr. Gustavo Domínguez Z Hospital, the system demonstrated high operational reliability with uptime levels consistently ranging from $99.95 \%$ to $99.99 \%$ and an average availability of 99.97 %. Recovery times remained below six minutes even during critical events, and no clinical data loss was recorded. The storage utilization increased from $12.1 \%$ to $18.0 \%$ during the period, reflecting a progressive integration into clinical workflows and strong user adoption. The use of Synology Hybrid RAID contributed to optimal data integrity, achieving $100 \%$ in most months and 99.99 % during isolated events. Comparative analysis with other international implementations confirmed similar or superior performance. The findings support the viability of deploying non-proprietary infrastructures in healthcare environments with limited budgets while maintaining high standards of data resilience and service continuity. The study also encourages replication of this model across other institutions and long-term monitoring to assess performance under critical scenarios such as firmware updates or disaster recovery. The solution demonstrates potential to reduce costs, promote technological sovereignty, and enhance operational efficiency in clinical settings.

title: Cascade Control with Feedforward Compensation: Evaluation of alternatives
authors: Sebastian Vega, Mateo Vasquez-Guevara, Alvaro Prado, Paulo Leica, Gabriela M. Andaluz, Oscar Camacho
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study investigates the effectiveness of cascade control and feedforward compensation in improving system performance in the presence of disturbances and complex dynamics. It aims to evaluate an integrated architecture using a Generalized Model Control (GMC) algorithm as the main controller, with two feedforward configurations. Key contributions include: (i) a practical implementation framework, (ii) analysis of modeling, tuning, nonlinearities, stability, and (iii) guidelines for deploying this control strategy in real-world settings.

title: Deep Learning and Vision-Based Systems for Crime Detection and Prevention in Urban Surveillance
authors: Andrés Herrera, Felipe Grijalva, Daniel Riofrío, José Vega-Sánchez, Ricardo Flores-Moyano
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents the training and implementation of machine learning and computer vision algorithms aimed at the real-time prevention and detection of criminal activity. The proposed approach is motivated by the increasing crime rates in Ecuador and seeks to reduce police response times through the automated analysis of suspicious behaviors in video footage. Deep neural network models were employed, specifically the I3D architecture and a hybrid ISD+ConvLSTM model, capable of identifying anomalous patterns in temporal video sequences. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of these techniques in both anticipating and detecting criminal events, thereby providing a valuable tool for enhancing public safety. This work represents a significant advancement in the application of computer vision to urban environments and offers a practical solution with strong potential for real-world deployment.

title: A Six-Pillar Governance Readiness Framework and Tool for ERP Migration Data Quality
authors: Tirumala Rao Chimpiri
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Data governance plays a central role in ensuring the success of Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) migrations by influencing data quality, regulatory compliance, and overall organizational performance. Despite its importance, many institutions embark on major system transitions without adequately assessing their governance readiness, leading to costly disruptions, data integrity issues, and increased compliance risks. To address this gap, this study proposes a six-pillar data governance framework that integrates key dimensions such as data ownership, stewardship, quality management, security, compliance, and lifecycle control. Complementing the framework, a prototype readiness assessment tool was developed using HTML and Python Flask to evaluate institutional governance maturity levels prior to migration. The tool produces readiness scores and tailored feedback, enabling organizations to identify weaknesses and prioritize improvement areas. Comparative case analyses across higher education, healthcare, and financial sectors reveal common governance deficiencies, including fragmented data ownership and inconsistent quality standards, alongside sector-specific challenges shaped by regulatory demands and legacy infrastructures. By combining conceptual modeling with prototype validation, this research offers a practical and adaptable approach to enhancing governance maturity and reducing migration risks. The findings contribute to both academic and practitioner discussions on digital transformation readiness, offering actionable guidance for achieving sustainable ERP outcomes across diverse institutional contexts.

title: Optimization of Delivery Robot Area Mapping using Object Color Filter Reading Based on Odometry
authors: Faikul Umam, Ach. Dafid, Sri Wahyuni, Hairil Budiarto, Firman Maolana
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The development of robotics technology is increasingly penetrating everyday life, including simple activities such as delivering goods. Activities that are done repeatedly can take up a lot of energy and time. This need drives this research: designing a delivery robot that can move independently, recognize its environment, and intelligently avoid obstacles. The robot developed combines odometry from a rotary encoder sensor to determine position, mechanum wheels to enable flexible movement in all directions, and an omnidirectional camera that reads the color of objects using the HSV color space. The system is equipped with PID control to keep the robot’s movements stable and accurate. The novelty of this work lies in the integration of odometry, PID control, and HSV-based vision into a single, low-cost yet effective solution for small-scale logistics and urban applications. The robot not only moves but also learns to “understand” its path to the destination. Odometry tests show that the robot can reach its destination with a relatively small average error of $\mathbf{1}-\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{\%}$. When tested on a 1360 mm track, the integration of PID control significantly improved movement stability, reducing directional errors to almost zero. Meanwhile, the HSV-based vision system successfully distinguished between green paths, red targets, and white obstacles with consistent accuracy, even in varying lighting conditions. The synergy of these three methods enables the robot to move more smoothly, precisely, and adaptively. Beyond its technical contributions, this research also aligns with Indonesia’s SDGs (SDGs 8, 9, and 11) by enhancing productivity, fostering innovation, and supporting sustainable urban logistic

title: Deep Stacking Ensemble with Stacked LSTM and SVR for Analysis and Forecasting: A Case Study of Rice Price in East Java
authors: Aviolla Terza Damaliana, Sischa Wahyuning Tyas, Amri Muhaimin, Trimono, Shindi Shella May Wara, Mohammad Idhom
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Fluctuating food prices, especially rice is pose a significant challenge in obtaining accurate predictions. Classical models like Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) face limitations in handling non-linear behavior and long-term dependencies in time series. To address these limitations, this study develops and evaluates a forecasting framework by comparing the performance of classical statistical methods, deep learning models, and ensemble techniques. The comparison includes ARIMA as the baseline, alongside Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) models with different architectural configurations (1, 2, and 3 layers) using lag 1 and lag 7, and the proposed Deep Stacking Ensemble Learning model with its meta-learner using Support Vector Regression (SVR). The models performance was assessed on the testing dataset using Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE). The Deep Stacking Ensemble outperforms LSTM and ARIMA, with lag 1 being most robust (MAPE 0.098%) and lag 7 more accurate than ARIMA (MAPE 0.126%). This study concludes that the deep stacking ensemble method improves forecasting accuracy and reliability by integrating multiple models, making it suitable for highly fluctuating time series.

title: SMSHIELD: A Real-Time Smishing Detection in Mobile Messaging Systems using Deep Learning Approach
authors: Annisa Rahmapuri, Rizka Wakhidatus Sholikah, Hafara Firdausi
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The advancement of information and communication technology has improved the efficiency of digital communication, but it has also created opportunities for cybercrimes, such as smishing (SMS phishing). While deep learning approaches have been employed to detect fraudulent messages, most research has been limited to the English language and binary classification (phishing vs. non-phishing). This study develops a phishing message detection system in Indonesian using a multiclass approach that categorizes messages as normal, promotional, or phishing. It employs Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Bidirectional LSTM (Bi-LSTM), and Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) models. The evaluation of the models was conducted using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score metrics, along with confusion matrix analysis. The results indicate that balanced data distribution significantly enhances model performance, particularly in classifying promotional messages. Among the models tested, Bi-LSTM consistently delivered the best performance, achieving accuracy of 0.968, precision of 0.980, recall of 0.970, and F1-score of 0.970. Additionally, this research produced a mobile application capable of detecting potential smishing messages in real-time and providing alerts to the user.

title: Technological development of automotive MSEs in Peru as a catalyst for the Latin American Manufacturing Hub: A model with Machine Learning and DDMRP
authors: Antonio Silva-Bossio, Camila Gadea-Alcantara, Fernando Maradiegue-Tuesta, Fabiola Pinzón-Hoyos
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The MSEs metal-mechanics in Peru are faced with the challenge of delivering the orders on time and complete, becoming a hard challenge to accomplish. In the case of CREATEM S.A.C. is a manufacturing MSE dedicated to the fabrication of replacement parts for motorized vehicles that present a low OTIF of 47.45% very low compared to the standard which is 80%. Currently, the metal-mechanic sector represents a 11% of the manufacturing industry and the MSEs cover a 99.2% of the total companies in Peru. However, the majority of that have problems with adequate inventory control of the raw material. To this end, in order to reduce its economic impact as a solution, a comprehensive DDMRP and Machine Learning model is proposed to forecast the demand and manage the inventory dynamically. After the validation of the model, we obtained an improvement of the OTIF of 79.45%, as well as a reduction in the stock out rate to 8.2%. The proposal proved to be robust to lead time variations and demand peaks thanks to the buffers adjustment. It not only improved CREATEM logistics performance but also contributed strategically to position Peruvian automotive MSEs as a catalysts of the Latin American Hub.

title: Effect of network quality on internet home complaints, queries, and payments
authors: Fernando Uyaguari, Erwin J. Sacoto-Cabrera, Alvaro Uyaguari, Emilio Oyervide, Vanessa Bermeo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In the context of Internet Service Providers (ISP), scientific literature presents, quality models composed of multiple dimensions that influence customer loyalty. The network quality is the most important dimension according to the studies. This study used data from customers whose network quality was upgraded from copper to fiber optic technology between January and April 2019 to measure the effects of the upgrade upon complaints, inquiries and payments. Non-parametric test were used to test hypothesis, the results indicate that the network upgrade has a positive influence on the number of complaints by reducing their quantity. Regarding inquiries, the improvement in network quality doesn’t influence the number of inquiries. The network quality upgrade does influence the number of payments and their value, the network improvement to optical fiber technology increases both the value and the number of payment annually.

title: Cooperation Without Compromise: Securing UAV Collaboration in the Low-Altitude Economy
authors: Bin Liu, Wei Ni, Ren Ping Liu, Hongbo Zhu
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have demonstrated remarkable versatility across industries and are poised to drive low-altitude economy (LAE), where effective cooperation is key to unlocking their full potential. Given the open and interconnected nature of LAE networks, UAV cooperation introduces privacy risks that may undermine trust and collaboration. Protecting sensitive information, such as locations, flight trajectories, and proprietary operational data, is essential to ensure secure and reliable coordination. The disclosure of this information could expose a UAV to attacks or disruptions. This article presents a novel privacy-preserving UAV cooperation framework designed to create a privacy-conscious networking environment and promote collaborative UAV operations for LAE. The framework specifically addresses privacy concerns inherent in collaborative UAV missions by safeguarding origin points, destinations, and trajectories. This is achieved through destination obfuscation and a non-cooperative Bayesian game approach for trajectory planning, wherein each UAV only shares the probabilistic distribution of its potential waypoints at different times. The best response strategy is established to guarantee a Nash equilibrium regarding the trajectories. Simulations demonstrate the framework’s capability to ensure timely UAV arrivals, while preserving trajectory and location privacy. Even under moderate obfuscation the algorithm maintains over 90% of the optimal energy performance, highlighting its resilience to privacy-preserving perturbations.

title: Dynamic Event-Based Adaptive Optimal Enclosure Control for Spacecraft Formation Against Noncooperative Targets
authors: Hongcheng Liu, Peng Yi, Dechao Ran, Lu Cao, Shuang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper investigates the adaptive optimal enclosure control problem for multi-spacecraft systems surrounding a noncooperative target. Based on the orbital dynamics derived from the two-body problem, a manifold-based invariant estimation method is developed to accurately reconstruct the unknown control input of the target. Subsequently, a dynamic model of relative orbital error is established to formulate the enclosure control objective. An adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) approach utilizing a single critic neural network is proposed to approximate the solution of the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman (HJB) equation online. To alleviate onboard computational burdens, an adaptive event-triggered mechanism incorporating a dynamic state regulator (DSR) and an auxiliary threshold modulator (ATM) is designed, which actively adjusts the triggering threshold to balance triggering frequency and control accuracy. Thus, an event-driven weight update law is further introduced, significantly reducing the update rate while maintaining satisfactory approximation performance. The resulting optimal control law ensures precise enclosure formation with guaranteed stability. The uniform ultimate boundedness (UUB) of the closed-loop system is rigorously proven via Lyapunov theory. Numerical simulations validate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed control strategy.

title: Quantum Power Electronics - The Ultimate Path for Optimal Power Conversion?
authors: Sergio Busquets-Monge, Salvador Alepuz, Joan Nicolàs-Apruzzese, Xavier Jordà, Mariana Raya, Álber Filbà-Martínez, Gabriel Garcia-Rojas
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Advances in power electronics play a fundamental role in achieving the technological objectives that society pursues in terms of sustainable use of energy. One promising path to search for notable advances in power electronics is to develop power processing techniques where voltage, current and time are all three broken down into the smallest amounts feasible, in what could be referred to as quantum power electronics. Since the product of voltage, current and time defines electrical energy, breaking them down into the smallest quantities feasible (viable and suitable in the context of the state-of-the-art of power electronics devices and systems) enables processing power through processing small energy quanta. A discussion is provided to justify that this, in principle, could bring substantial benefits in terms of standardization, modularity, scalability, flexibility, versatility, efficiency, power density, reliability, cost, and other performance features at system level. That is, this paper shares a vision of future power electronics systems as built from a single standardized and optimized low-voltage and low-current power semiconductor switch rather than from a number of different switches at different voltage and current ratings. One of the possible paths to implement these power processing techniques is through the use of switching cell arrays, where switching components are not mixed with energy storing components, potentially leading to high levels of integration.

title: A Novel Post-Coded Time-Domain Channel Estimation for Chirp-Based Multicarrier Waveforms
authors: Abdelali Arous, Hamza Haif, Hüseyin Arslan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Chirp-based multicarrier waveforms, notably the generalized version, affine frequency division multiplexing (AFDM) have garnered increased attention recently. Particularly, due to its unique channel representation, the channel estimation (CE) in the affine domain raises major challenges. Therefore, this paper introduces a novel, low-complexity CE technique that exploits the properties of chirp carriers in the post-coded time-domain (PCTD). Initially, based on the explicit input-output relationship in doubly selective channels, the inherent properties of AFDM and their dependency on the refining coefficients are analyzed, revealing the limitations of existing guard-based CE techniques. As such, a comprehensive representation of single and multiple chirp carriers in the PCTD is provided both pre- and post-channel transmission, with a focus on interpreting the effects of delay and Doppler shifts. Building on this analysis, a two-stage CE method is proposed, leveraging the zero-padded PCTD (ZP-PCTD) received signal, effectively decoupling delay and Doppler components with scalable resolution. This method effectively compensates for phase selectivity across carriers while maintaining adaptability through scenario-based frame structures with optimized pilot-to-data ratios. The proposed approach significantly reduces the computational complexity and improves spectral efficiency (SE) by minimizing pilot overhead. Simulation results reflect the superiority of the proposed method over the existing iterative schemes, highlighting its ability to improve the performance of AFDM in practical propagation channels.

title: Perception System Credibility Testing for Automated Vehicles: Bayesian-Based Adaptive Search Method
authors: Wei Hong, Peng Wang, Ruohai Di, Shoucai Jing, Chuchao He, Xiangmo Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: The credibility of the perception system is a linchpin for the safety of Automated Vehicles (AVs). However, existing scenario-based testing approaches often overlook the reliability assessment of the perception system. To address this shortcoming, we propose BAGA, a Bayesian-based adaptive search method for high-value scenarios, which accelerates scenario-based simulations while identifying critical scenarios for the perception system. Concurrently, we design a sensitivity analysis method, BNSobol, based on the naive Bayes network. This method decouples the associations among selected trigger source sets and develops a mutation strategy that aligns with the physical characteristics of the perception system. Furthermore, we construct an objective function that integrates the tolerance boundaries of the credibility indicators. This function calculates the perception system's credibility within scenarios and identifies high-value scenarios. Ultimately, we develop integrated software for evaluating the credibility of the perception system, providing a universal solution for such assessments. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to mainstream scenario generation methods and exhaustive search methods, our proposed method increases efficiency by 77.7% and 143.2%, respectively. It can effectively generate the high-value scenarios required for perception system testing, thereby facilitating the discovery and localization of credibility issues.
