title: HHGSynergy: An Adaptive Heterogeneous Hypergraph Representation Learning Method for Anticancer Drug Synergy Prediction
authors: Jinmiao Song, Yang Meng, Lei Deng, Qimeng Yang, Qiguo Dai, Shengwei Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Compared with monotherapy, combination drug therapy plays a crucial role in clinical treatment. However, the exponential expansion of the drug combination space has rendered traditional exploration methods for synergistic drug combinations inadequate. Recently, numerous efficient and accurate computational approaches have been developed to predict anticancer drug synergy, particularly those leveraging hypergraphs to model the multifaceted relationships between drug combinations and cell lines, which have demonstrated remarkable potential. Nevertheless, existing hypergraph-based methods fail to account for the heterogeneity of anticancer synergy hypergraphs and overlook the underlying similarities among drugs and cell lines, thereby limiting their ability to fully capture the complex interactions between drug combinations and cell lines. To address these limitations, we propose an Adaptive Heterogeneous Hypergraph Representation Learning Method (HHGSynergy) for predicting anticancer drug synergy, enabling more precise identification of synergistic drug combinations. Specifically, our framework first constructs drug/cell line similarity-based synergy hypergraphs based on the foundational anticancer synergy hypergraph, thereby establishing a comprehensive heterogeneous hypergraph. Next, a node importance calculation module is employed to learn both local and global importance weights of nodes, effectively capturing the structural characteristics of the hypergraph. Finally, a type-specific multi-head attention mechanism is utilized to iteratively update node embeddings, adaptively learning the significance of heterogeneous hyperedges. Experimental results demonstrate that HHGSynergy achieves state-of-the-art performance in both classification and regression tasks across diverse experimental scenarios, outperforming existing leading models. Case studies further underscore its potential for discovering novel synergistic drug combinations. The source code and the datasets are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/lasxmy/HHGSynergy</uri>.

title: 2D Relative DoA Estimation in Cellular Networks Using Radio-Frequency Measurements and Machine Learning
authors: Pablo Lupera Morillo, Alvaro Morillo, Paul Enriquez, Ricardo Llugsi, Robin Alvarez Rueda, Darwin Flores-Osorio, Gabriel Palma
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents a novel, learning-based approach for estimating the relative Direction of Arrival (DoA) in real mobile urban environments. Our methodology integrates multiple radio frequency performance metrics and considers the direction of the drive test as a user device moves between cells. Traditional DoA estimation methods, limited by the inherent sparsity of downlink (DL) channel structures in mobile systems, often incur high computational complexity and do not fully leverage available radio frequency measurements. To address these challenges, we propose three relative DoA estimation methods utilizing linear regression equations, neural networks, and a gain-based formula. These methods are designed to be compact and efficient, m aking t hem w ell-suited f or i mplementation on user devices. Experimental results demonstrate that the neural network method achieves superior accuracy in estimating relative DoA compared to other approaches, under both line-of-sight and non-line-of-sight conditions in real outdoor mobile environments. Notably, the neural network model achieved the best RMSE value of $9.7 \%$, underscoring its effectiveness. This approach highlights a promising path for reducing DoA estimation complexity in mobile communication systems.

title: Exploring natural antifungals: the hidden power of native or exotic medicinal plants occurring in Imbabura’s local markets, Ecuador
authors: Shailili M. Moreno M, Maria S. Vergara, Marisabel Condo A, José L. Rodríguez-Villafuerte, Hugo Romero-Saltos
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This review compiles, systematizes, and discusses recent scientific evidence on the antifungal activity of secondary metabolites reported in medicinal plant species, native or exotic, commonly commercialized in the markets of the Imbabura province in Ecuador. After reviewing original articles, a comprehensive account was completed for bioactive compounds as terpenoids, flavonoids, alkaloids, coumarins, saponins, and furanocoumarins that have shown multiple mechanisms of action, including damage to the fungal membrane, inhibition of ergosterol biosynthesis, promotion of reactive oxygen species formation, and blockage of essential metabolic pathways. Quantitative data on minimum inhibitory concentrations, zones of inhibition, minimum fungicidal concentration, and synergies with classical antifungals, are also discussed. The findings reveal that these plant species, which are commonly available in the local markets, are promising sources to produce natural antifungal products in medicine and agriculture. The data also show that some of these species may potentially provide a valuable new source of bioactive compounds for sustainable therapeutic or phytosanitary use. This review represents a reference for future studies related to the isolation, structural elucidation, toxicology studies, and clinical application of these compounds.

title: Public Procurement System Based on Blockchain and Ecuadorian Regulatory Framework
authors: Juan E. Guaranga-Allauca, Alan Tierra-Llanga, Washington Luna-Encalada, Jaqueline Ponce-Pinos, José Morales-Gordon, Ramiro Isa-Jara
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Public procurement in Ecuador continues to face vulnerabilities to corruption and inefficiencyd espite the integration of advanced anti-fraud mechanisms, particularly during document submission and contractor selection. This paper proposes a novel system that integrates blockchain technology with the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) to address these challenges. The hybrid architecture combines a private blockchain-restricted to verified institutional nodes f or managing submissions and contract execution through smart con-tracts-with a public blockchain that allows real-time auditability by external stakeholders. Blockchain ensures cryptographic security and immutable audit trails, while IPFS provides decentralized, scalable, and cost-effective storage beyond blockchain’s intrinsic limitations. The proposed framework is designed to align with Ecuador’s Organic Law of the National Public Procurement System (LOSNCP), particularly Articles 6, 25, and 31, which establish transparency, equity, and efficiency as guiding principles. Technical evaluation through simulations compares Ethereum and Algorand in terms of transaction costs, performance, and energy efficiency, justifying the a doption of Ethereum for its broader maturity. While results confirm the f easibility of the system, limitations remain, as validation relies on simulations rather than pilot deployments, and scalability under real-world conditions requires further study. By combining transparency, security, and regulatory compliance, this work contributes a scalable and innovative model for future e-government procurement systems that prioritize accountability, equity, and public trust.

title: AI in Communication Teaching and Practice: Use, Frequency and Limitations
authors: Vanessa Karina Duque-Rengel, Rosario Puertas-Hidalgo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become one of the most widely adopted technologies in the academic field, generating both opportunities and challenges for students and educational institutions. This research analyzes its application in the training of undergraduate Communication students in Ecuador. It is an exploratory study with a quantitative approach, employing surveys as the data collection technique and an online questionnaire as the instrument, applied through non-probability convenience sampling. The analysis focuses on three variables: (1) Frequency of AI tool usage; (2) Level of difficulty in implementing AI tools in academic contexts; and (3) Identification of the most frequently used AI tools. The results show that $\mathbf{4 5 \%}$ of students use these tools for writing tasks, idea generation, and design, reflecting a functional, albeit unsystematic, integration of these technologies into the teaching-learning process. A neutral perception of the difficulty in integrating and applying AI tools in students’ daily academic life is observed. Finally, the most commonly used AI tools among respondents are ChatGPT, Gemini, and Canva.

title: Performance and Analysis of LFU Cache Replacement Algorithm for NDN Using YANFD
authors: Mahesa Muhammad Firdaus, Leanna Vidya Yovita, Tody Ariefianto Wibowo
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Technology has grown massively in this decade, especially on the network side. One of the developments is NDN, which is a network architecture that is intended to replace IP. However, technological advances always raise some issues. One of these is the efficiency of power usage. According to the Indonesian Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources in 2023, electricity usage had grown from 2022. During that period, the internet became widely used because of the new normal. Responding to that, NDN also has the same issues; considerable power expenditure of $0.023 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{MB}$ is required for DRAM access. Previous research has shown power reduction. It’s still considered insignificant due to caching. This research proposes a comparison of LFU and LRU as cache replacements on the NDN forwarder YANFD. This research comprises four test scenarios. Based on the results, in overall LFU has more efficient result than LRU. LFU shows more than 3, 57% higher cache hit ratio performance. As for QoS, RTT has a lower value of more than $\mathbf{2, 9 8 \%}$ than LRU. Throughput also has higher result, with a range of 3,04% to 19% faster than LRU.

title: MLCAE: A Multi-Layered Configuration for Architectural Elements in Large-Scale Software Applications
authors: Hristo Hristov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The increasing complexity of large-scale software applications, such as ERP, CRM and DMS, requires advanced approaches for organizing and managing architectural elements (AEs) including architectures, architectural patterns, technologies, frameworks, standards, methodologies, etc. This paper introduces MLCAE (Multi-Layered Configuration for Architectural Elements), a novel model for architectural modeling that provides a structured, flexible and scalable way of positioning AEs across multiple layers. MLCAE defines a set of standard layers (Core, Communication, Deployment) and allows for the dynamic creation of non-standard layers (Security, Monitoring, DevOps pipelines, Integration, etc.), depending on project-specific requirements. The model supports role-based placement of AEs (Primary Layer Placement, Secondary Layer Presence, Interface Anchors, Deployment Bindings), indexing mechanisms for managing overlapping AEs across multiple systems and categorization to differentiate between architectural types. Furthermore, MLCAE introduces layer priorities for conflict resolution and architectural packages to group cross-layer AEs. A case study with ERP, CRM, DMS, PLM and SCM demonstrates the practical applicability of MLCAE in enterprise environments, showing improvements in coverage, conflict resolution and integration compared to traditional architectural modeling. The results indicate that MLCAE can serve as a strategic tool for enterprise architecture management and future research directions include AI-assisted classification of AEs and automated visualization dashboards.

title: Mesh Network Monitoring Protocols
authors: Mell Vergara, Lisbeth Chávez, Nahomy Montaño, Wilson Gustavo Chango Sailema
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents a simulation of a physical mesh network using Cisco Packet Tracer, with the objective of analyzing the behavior of Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) in topologies with redundant links. Based on a network composed of several interconnected nodes and switches, the ability of STP to avoid loops, maintain network stability and recover connectivity in the event of simulated failures was tested. During the tests, key aspects such as reconvergence time and packet loss were observed. The results showed that STP, although a classical protocol, is still an effective solution to ensure a stable logical network over a complex physical infrastructure. In addition, this experience strengthened the practical understanding of concepts that are often approached only from theory.

title: Real-Time Network Infrastructure Monitoring: A Zabbix and Telegram Integration Case Study in the Energy Sector (EMELNORTE S.A.)
authors: Darwin Pillo-Guanoluisa, Leandro Bermúdez Herrera, Alexandra Juma Alba, Diego Salgado Báez, Victoria Fray Buestán
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Real-time visibility of core, distribution, and access switches within the headquarters network infrastructure is vital for ensuring operational continuity in the energy sector. This study presents the deployment of a centralized monitoring system using Zabbix at EMELNORTE S.A. main headquarters, guided by the PPDIOO methodology and the FCAPS framework. The solution continuously monitored a set of ten switches, encompassing all hierarchical network layers, under uninterrupted operational conditions. Validation followed a before-and-after approach. After implementation, the average incident response time dropped from 10 to 1 minute due to automated alerting via email and Telegram. The system detected core switch traffic peaks of 1.5 Gbps and periods of interface congestion above 90 percent utilization for over 45 minutes. Sustained RAM utilization of 38.5 percent demonstrated operational stability. These results confirm that the proposed approach enables early anomaly detection and supports proactive, data-driven infrastructure management, enhancing both the reliability and quality of the electrical service at EMELNORTE headquarters.

title: Use of HT-PEMFC Fuel Cells Powered by Methanol Reformate Gas as a Source of Electricity and Heat in an Integrated off-grid Energy System
authors: Magdalena Dudek, Andrzej Raźniak, Bartosz Adamczyk, Mikołaj Zarzycki, Ivan Beloev, Jarosław Markowski, Umar Majeed Sada, Abrar Ahmad, Iliya K. Iliev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This article presents the results of investigating a high-temperature polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (HT-PEMFC) generator supplied with hydrogen from methanol reforming, used as an autonomous source of electricity and heat in a distributed off-grid energy system. The experimental setup employed a 5 kW HT-PEMFC stack operating in parallel with an electrochemical battery pack. Hydrogen was produced in a methanol reforming system directly integrated with the HT-PEMFC stack. The test stand was equipped with an additional external liquid cooling system containing 100% triethylene glycol (TEG). The electricity generator achieved a nominal electrical power of P ≃ 5 kW. Tests showed that the maximum amount of heat extracted from the H3-5000 generator by the TEG-based liquid cooling system was 9.4 MJ/h (corresponding to a thermal output of 2.6 kW). Additionally, heat is removed from the generator via exhaust gas streams from the anode compartment, ventilation air from the interior of the housing, and air from the cathode compartment of the HT-PEMFC fuel cell. The potential thermal output of these gases is approximately 3 kW. These results confirm the feasibility of recovering heat from the HT-PEMFC cell for use in heating technologies, such as providing hot water or heating homes.

title: Deepfake Image Recognition using Unified Hybrid Framework of CNN, Transformer, and Frequency Features
authors: Budi Dwi Satoto, Achmad Yasid Syamsul, Wahyudi Agustiono, Rima Tri Wahyuningrum, Bain Khusnul Khotimah, Suraya Binti Hamid
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Deepfake is a technique for manipulating or creating visual and audio content to appear realistic. A person’s face can be replaced, their voice imitated, or a scene made to appear as if it were real, even though it is actually fake. This technology has positive applications in the film, entertainment, and education industries; however, it also has the potential to be misused to spread disinformation, commit fraud, and disseminate slander. There are serious risks to public trust, including the spread of misleading information, slander, and security vulnerabilities. An integrated hybrid framework combines CNN, Transformer, and Frequency Features in facial recognition. Transformer models global contextual dependencies between facial regions, and Frequency Features to analyse spectral inconsistencies typical in manipulated media. By combining these representations in an ensemble framework, the model can more effectively distinguish real and synthetic faces. This method performs very well in identifying distorted facial features, unusual blink patterns, and irregular frequency artefacts. The evaluation achieved an average accuracy of $92.3 \%$, with an MSE of 0.072, RMSE of 0.268, and MAE of 0.126. Depending on the complexity of the manipulated footage, data trials showed detection performance ranging from 85\% to 98%.

title: Modification of WSM and WPM for Group Decision-Making Considering DMs’ Different Competence Domains
authors: Zornitsa Dimitrova, Vasil Dimitrov, Daniela Borissova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The article addresses group decision-making, considering the differences in competence domains. For the goal, a modification of the Weighted Sum Model and Weighted Product Model methods is formulated. This is realised by associating weight coefficients related to the competence of decision-makers for each criterion separately. In addition, a mechanism for grouping the criteria is proposed, which facilitates the administration of the process and reduces the complexity of the calculations. The changes compared to the classical methods cover both the algorithm and the mathematical formulation of the models. The practical applicability of the proposed modification is demonstrated through a case study on the selection of renewable and sustainable energy technologies like photovoltaic systems, wind turbines, and biogas installations. The goal is for a mixed agricultural enterprise, including agriculture, greenhouse production, and livestock farming, to reduce its carbon footprint and move towards a closed cycle. The obtained results categorically prove the applicability of the proposed modifications.

title: Multilevel Image Thresholding of Transmission Line Insulators: Entropy-Based Performance Evaluation of PSO, NRBO, and WO Algorithms
authors: Nermin Komar, Mirza Batalovic, Medina Kapo, Amila Akagic, Emir Buza
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Timely detection of damaged transmission line insulators prevents greater risks of costly interruptions. Manually monitored inspections are time-consuming and prone to human error, while automated approaches offer faster damage detection. This paper presents multilevel threshold techniques for insulator image segmentation using three metaheuristic algorithms: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Newton-Raphson-based Optimizer (NRBO), and Walrus Optimizer (WO). A comparative analysis of these methods is provided to understand their differences. Two different entropy-based objective functions, Kapur's and Otsu's criteria, are used. Based on the proposed methods, the segmentation accuracy was analyzed with the execution time on the proposed dataset. To observe the difference between the algorithms and the entropy measure, a one-way ANOVA test is provided. The results show that PSO combined with Kapur entropy provides the best compromise between accuracy and time required, making it very suitable for large-scale inspection tasks.

title: The Energy Transition in Japan: Current Situation and Future Prospects
authors: Dimiter Ialnazov, Vladimir Zinoviev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: There is a variety of national pathways to net zero emissions by 2050. Some countries have rapidly expanded the share of renewable energy and phased down fossil fuels, while others like Japan have taken a more cautious approach. In this paper we examine two possible future trajectories of Japan’s energy transition, namely the Japanese government scenario that is already being implemented under the Seventh Strategic Energy Plan and the Renewable Energy Institute (REI) scenario. The former keeps a relatively high level of reliance on fossil fuels, supports the revival of nuclear power, as well as the application of new technologies such as hydrogen/ammonia co-firing and carbon capture and storage. The proponents of the latter argue for a larger expansion of variable renewable energy such as wind and solar combined with an emphasis on energy storage, electricity grid enhancement, and demand response. We evaluate these two scenarios by focusing on their impact on Japan’s climate goals, energy security, and power system costs. While we agree with many of the REI’s criticisms toward the government scenario, we argue that REI’s ambitious targets for solar and wind in 2040 may not be very realistic having in mind the challenges that Japan faces in developing its renewable energy infrastructure.

title: Balises for Precise Positioning in Automated Metro Transport
authors: Svetoslav Tomov, Emiliya Dimitrova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The precise positioning of trains on the line is of crucial importance for automated metro transport. This report examines operational situations with balises as fixed track markers integrated in Sofia Metro Line 3 as part of the signaling system with Grade of Automation GoA3. The principle by which trains determine their own location on the track has been explained and how the precision of calculations increases with the use of balises. Information about the train stopping accuracy at stations, the calibration of train wheels and the procedure for initial train sieving/ localization before leaving the Depot area towards the main line have been provided. The requirements for operating and maintenance personnel are mentioned. Specific cases of failures, their causes and solutions have been examined. A conclusion has been drawn on the general behavior of the balises on this line, recommendations for improvements have been indicated.

title: Analysis of Airflow in an Inlet Duct with an Acoustic Wave-Dispersing Palisade
authors: Jaroslaw Markowski, Pawel Imilkowski, Grzegorz Wieczorkiewicz, Iliya K. Iliev, Krzysztof Jesionek, Anita Zych
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The operation of generator sets in backup power systems, under increasingly strict requirements for reducing noise emissions to the environment, necessitates the use of sound-absorbing barriers in the form of containerized enclosures. The acoustic insulation performance of the enclosure walls depends on the materials used, their sound-attenuation characteristics, and their thickness. A remaining challenge is ensuring appropriate acoustic conditions for the air-supply ducts leading into the enclosure. The use of noise silencers is necessary; however, they introduce flow resistance in the inlet duct. Therefore, a system incorporating a palisade-type arrangement of elements for acoustic wave scattering was proposed, and a numerical analysis of airflow conditions in the inlet duct with the proposed solution was carried out. The analysis was performed with respect to evaluating flow resistance as a parameter directly affecting the energy demand of the fan that forces the airflow through the duct. The results of the conducted analysis are presented in the article.

title: Creative Education in the Age of AI-Driven Networks: Challenges and Opportunities for Intelligent Learning Systems
authors: Denitsa Miteva, Dimitar Grozev, Ivan Beloev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study examines the role of artificial intelligence (AI) in fostering creativity in education. Although the impact of AI on creativity has been widely studied in fields such as computer science and the arts, its influence on creative processes in education remains underexplored. A survey of 127 respondents examined perceptions of the advantages, disadvantages, and risks of using AI to enhance creativity during the learning process. The results show widespread recognition of creativity as an essential component of education, but also reveal a significant discrepancy between this recognized importance and the practical integration of methods to enhance creativity. A SWOT analysis reveals strengths, including the ability of AI to adapt learning experiences to individual learner needs and support new educational models. However, weaknesses and threats stem from insufficient training of educators, ethical concerns about the role of AI in decision-making, and the risk of reducing learners' critical thinking. The study highlights the need for education systems to evolve in parallel with emerging intelligent technologies, i.e. AI should act not simply as a tool, but as an active collaborator in the creative learning process. Ultimately, through thoughtful and ethical integration of AI, education can foster creativity in ways that complement critical thinking and prepare learners for a technology-rich future.

title: Comparative Analysis of Refrigeration Systems in Commercial Display Cabinets Using R134a and R290
authors: Stefan Stoyanov, Ivan Dimchev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of two refrigeration systems designed for a commercial display cabinet using R134a and R290 refrigerants. Both commercial display cabinets are identical, the difference is only in the used refrigerant (and also on some of the components) so the study aims to evaluate their thermodynamic performance, energy efficiency, environmental impact, and regulatory compliance. The two refrigerated display cabinets are manufactured based on refrigeration load calculations and component sizing and selection. The refrigerants are assessed based on key performance indicators such as cooling capacity, coefficient of performance (COP), global warming potential (GWP), total equivalent warming impact (TEWI) and refrigerant charge requirements. R134a is a conventional HFC that has proven its qualities for the selected application, but has a high GWP. In contrast, R290, which is a natural refrigerant with ultra-low GWP, offers higher efficiency but with limited charge due to its flammability. The results of comparative analyses show that R290 provides better performance with a lower environmental impact, which supports its readiness for sustainable use in commercial refrigeration equipment. The article highlights the potential of R290 to replace high-GWP refrigerants but only in the light commercial applications due to its flammability.

title: TraceMate: Collaborating with AI in Test-Driven Programming
authors: Jinmiao Wu, Thomas Selig, Erick Purwanto
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Large programming courses often use test-driven autograding systems (e.g., CodeRunner) for instant feedback, but these usually only show which tests failed without explaining why or how to fix the error. Novice students struggle with such minimal guidance and often resort to trial-and-error. Meanwhile, AI coding assistants (e.g., GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT) can provide hints and code suggestions, but novices may over-trust these outputs and lack the skills to verify them. To solve these issues, we present TraceMate, an IDE plugin that pairs the autograder’s tests with a conversational AI chatbot. TraceMate augments test feedback with context-aware explanations and inline suggestions for code modifications, and immediately validates each AI suggestion on the test suite. This workflow gives actionable hints while ensuring any AI-proposed changes are correct. In a user study with novice programmers, participants using TraceMate solved problems more effectively and reported higher confidence than those using only the autograder. These results suggest that pairing automated tests with an interactive AI assistant can enhance learning in introductory programming courses.

title: Enhancing Fake News Detection through the Fusion of Classical and Advanced Machine Learning Models
authors: Edison F. Naranjo-Espin, Johanna B. Arguero-Tello, Marcela Mosquera, Gabriel A. Lóon-Paredes
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social networks poses a significant c hallenge to p ublic t rust a nd cybersecurity. This study explores a hybrid approach to enhance fake news detection by integrating classical machine learning models, such as Logistic Regression, AdaBoost, and Support Vector Machines (SVM), with advanced techniques like Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT). Textual content is processed using Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) and Global Vectors for Word Representation (GloVe) embeddings to analyze syntax and semantics. Experimental results demonstrate that BERT significantly o utperforms o ther m odels, a chieving an accuracy of $97.36 \%$, precision of $95.01 \%$, recall of $99.89 \%$, and an F1-score of $97.39 \%$, positioning it as the most effective solution. These findings u nderscore t he p otential of combining traditional and modern methodologies to strengthen fake news detection systems, fostering a safer digital environment.

title: DoublyAware: Dual Planning and Policy Awareness for Temporal Difference Learning in Humanoid Locomotion
authors: Khang Nguyen, An T. Le, Jan Peters, Minh Nhat Vu
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Achieving robust robot learning for humanoid locomotion is a fundamental challenge in model-based reinforcement learning (MBRL), where environmental stochasticity and randomness can hinder efficient exploration and learning stability. The environmental, so-called aleatoric, uncertainty can be amplified in high-dimensional action spaces with complex contact dynamics and entangled with epistemic uncertainty in the models during learning phases. In this work, we propose DoublyAware, an uncertainty-aware extension of Temporal Difference Model Predictive Control (TD-MPC) that explicitly decomposes uncertainty into two disjoint, interpretable components, i.e., planning and policy uncertainties. To handle the planning uncertainty, DoublyAware employs conformal prediction to filter candidate trajectories using quantile-calibrated risk bounds, ensuring statistical consistency and robustness against stochastic dynamics. Meanwhile, policy rollouts are leveraged as structured informative priors to support the learning phase with Group-Relative Policy Constraint (GRPC) optimizers, which impose a group-based adaptive trust region in the latent action space. This combination enables the robot agent to prioritize high-confidence, high-reward behavior while maintaining effective, targeted exploration under uncertainty. Evaluated on the HumanoidBench locomotion suite with the Unitree 26-DoF H1-2 humanoid, DoublyAware demonstrates improved sample efficiency, accelerated convergence, and enhanced motion feasibility compared to RL baselines. Our results emphasize the significance of structured uncertainty modeling for data-efficient and reliable decision-making in TD-MPC-based humanoid locomotion learning.

title: MarkingVLM: Vision-Language Model for Few-Shot IC Marking Detection_supp1-3638609.pdf
authors: Yu Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: Integrated circuit (IC) marking detection faces critical “Triple C” challenges: compact marking scales, complex multidirectional layouts, and costly annotation requirements. Traditional models struggle with data scarcity in dynamic manufacturing environments where fine-grained labeled data are expensive and time-consuming to obtain. This work presents MarkingVLM, a specialized vision-language model designed for IC marking detection with exceptional few-shot learning capabilities. MarkingVLM adapts cross-modal understanding from Contrastive Language-Image Pre-training (CLIP) through unique innovations: 1) dual-granularity detection combining patch-level semantic alignment with pixel-level visual decoding; 2) layout mirror module enabling efficient multidirectional text flow recognition through feature-level augmentation; and 3) enhanced prompt engineering with learnable contexts for effective domain adaptation. Extensive experiments across two IC marking datasets with distinct characteristics substantiate superior performance: 94.2% precision and 96.5% recall on Dataset-1, and 89.6% precision with 92.6% recall on the more challenging Dataset-2. Most significantly, MarkingVLM achieves 92.7% precision with 32 training samples and maintains over 80% recall with merely 8 samples, demonstrating notable data efficiency improvement over conventional methods. Results establish a new paradigm for industrial text detection by bridging open-domain vision-language knowledge with specialized manufacturing requirements.

title: Adaptive End-to-End Transceiver Design for NextG Pilot-Free and CP-Free Wireless Systems
authors: Jiaming Cheng, Wei Chen, Bo Ai
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: The advent of artificial intelligence (AI)-native wireless communication is fundamentally reshaping the design paradigm of next-generation (NextG) systems, where intelligent air interfaces are expected to operate adaptively and efficiently in highly dynamic environments. Conventional orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) systems rely heavily on pilots and the cyclic prefix (CP), resulting in significant overhead and reduced spectral efficiency. To address these limitations, we propose an adaptive end-to-end (E2E) transceiver architecture tailored for pilot-free and CP-free wireless systems. The architecture combines AI-driven constellation shaping and a neural receiver through joint training. To enhance robustness against mismatched or time-varying channel conditions, we introduce a lightweight channel adapter (CA) module, which enables rapid adaptation with minimal computational overhead by updating only the CA parameters. Additionally, we present a framework that is scalable to multiple modulation orders within a unified model, significantly reducing model storage requirements. Moreover, to tackle the high peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR) inherent to OFDM, we incorporate constrained E2E training, achieving compliance with PAPR targets without additional transmission overhead. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the proposed framework delivers superior bit error rate (BER), throughput, and resilience across diverse channel scenarios, highlighting its potential for AI-native NextG.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Consumer Information Search: A Review, Synthesis and Propositions
authors: Sivaranjan Murugesan, Bharadhwaj Sivakumaran, Piyush Sharma, Laxminarayanan Ganesan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming how consumers search, interpret, and apply information, presenting both opportunities and challenges for engineering management in designing, managing, and using AI-enabled search systems. Despite substantial research, studies on AI-enabled consumer information search remain fragmented, providing limited integration of insights across technological, behavioral, and managerial perspectives. To address this, we conduct a systematic literature review guided by the PRISMA protocol and grounded theory, identifying four thematic areas: Information Search and AI recommendation, AI conversation, AI anthropomorphism, and AI retrieval, which are structured into a search-theme mapping framework to organize themes across the consumer search stages. The findings under each theme are synthesized to reveal research gaps, derive future research propositions, and highlight managerial implications. This synthesis shows how engineering managers can apply AI recommendation strategies, message framing, anthropomorphic design, modality, cognitive load, and generative AI timing to optimize consumer search, decision making, and engagement. Overall, the study synthesizes fragmented knowledge, advances theoretical understanding, and provides a structured foundation for guiding future research and managerial practice in engineering management.

title: Every Picture Tells a Managerial Story: A Review on Image Analysis Empowering Managerial Decisions
authors: Renzhi Gao, Shujie Liu, Xiangwei Kong, Gang Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Image analysis provides richer, more intuitive, and easily understandable insights, making it an increasingly indispensable tool in business. The exponential growth of image data has inspired management researchers to uncover the stories from image analysis. This study conducts a review of advanced management literature to examine how image analysis empowers managerial decisions. Drawing on information processing theory, we discuss the process of addressing management problems through image analysis from image perception, image encoding, and image-based decision-making. We reveal that image analysis provides novel perspectives, innovative methods, and emerging challenges for management, while also highlighting current research gaps in the application of image analysis within the management field. This study provides foundational guidelines for future explorations and innovations in image analysis for managerial decisions.

title: Graphene Based Dual Band MIMO Antenna for THz Applications
authors: Rakesh N. Tiwari, Prabhakar Singh, Pradeep Kumar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: A compact dual-band 2-port MIMO antenna is proposed using a slotted graphene patch as the radiating element, printed on a polyimide substrate with a partial copper ground plane. Graphene is employed owing to its high electron mobility and tunable conductivity at terahertz frequencies. The antenna occupies a compact footprint of 130 μm × 240 μm × 12.5 μm and exhibits resonances at 0.69 THz and 0.93 THz. High isolation values of 23 dB and 35 dB are achieved at the respective resonant frequencies. An equivalent circuit model is developed, which closely validates the simulated S-parameter results. The antenna demonstrates a realized gain above 4 dBi and total efficiency exceeding 80% across the operating bands. Furthermore, key diversity metrics, including envelope correlation coefficient, diversity gain, channel capacity loss, and total active reflection coefficient, are evaluated to confirm its suitability for MIMO applications. The proposed design, analyzed using CST Microwave Studio, offers a promising solution for emerging THz communication systems.

title: Assessment of Green Hydrogen Production in a Laboratory Environment Using Surplus Photovoltaic Generation and Its Potential Applications
authors: Galo Padrón, Estefanía Pesántez, Danny Ochoa-Correa
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study evaluates the use of surplus photovoltaic energy for green hydrogen production through water electrolysis, followed by storage in compressed tanks and reconversion into electricity with a proton exchange membrane fuel cell, completing a closed “Power to Power” cycle. The approach combines experimental operation in a laboratory microgrid with a techno-economic assessment, including subsystem characterization, round-trip efficiency, and the levelized cost of hydrogen. Quantitative results show an annual output of approximately 447.49 kg of hydrogen, a round-trip efficiency near $31 \%$, and a production cost of about 68.79 USD/kg. Beyond energy storage, the study includes a concise appraisal of fuel cell mobility applications, showing the potential use of the produced hydrogen for institutional transport within the laboratory context.

title: Classification of Evapotranspiration using the Weather Forecasting Model and Self-Organizing Map Learning
authors: Carlos Flores, José Vega-Sánchez, Felipe Grijalva, Roberto Andrade, Pavel Alba, Daniel Riofrío
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The accurate estimation of evapotranspiration (ETo) is crucial for efficient irrigation management and the sustainable administration of water resources. One of the most widely used approaches for simulating atmospheric variables is the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model, which has proven effective in both climate research and numerical weather prediction. In this work, outputs from the WRF model are integrated with a Self-Organizing Map (SOM), an unsupervised neural network technique in the field of Machine Learning, to create a robust framework for classifying spatial patterns of evapotranspiration. Moreover, to optimize the processing of large volumes of simulated meteorological data, we propose the use of the Somoclu library, an efficient implementation of SOM that significantly accelerates training while preserving the topological structure of high-resolution data. Specifically, the proposed approach is applied to classify climatic patterns associated with ETo in Ecuador’s Amazon and Andean regions. The results reveal both stable and dynamic spatial groupings of ETo, providing strategic information that can significantly contribute to improved irrigation practices and water resource planning.

title: Extension of the Hill Cipher via Rhotrices and Heart-Oriented Multiplication with MS Excel Implementations for R3 and R5 Cases
authors: Adriana Borodzhieva
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents a variant of the Hill cipher that replaces ordinary matrix operations with rhotrix algebra using heart-oriented multiplication. We review basic properties of rhotrices, define invertibility under heart-oriented multiplication, and describe a simple encryption-decryption scheme in which one rhotrix serves as the encryption key and its inverse as the decryption key. A numerical mapping for letters and a complete algorithmic description are given, together with a worked example. We then describe practical implementations of the method for rhotrix orders R3 and R5 using Microsoft Excel worksheets intended for classroom use in the Telecommunication Security course. The MS Excel workbooks demonstrate key generation, encryption, decryption, and validation steps to support hands-on learning and assessment.

title: Design of a Lossy FDNC-Based Chua's Diode Utilizing VDTA for Chaotic Oscillator
authors: Pelin Doğan Sekreter, Atilla Uygur
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel implementation of Chua’s oscillator by employing a lossy frequency-dependent negative conductor (FDNC) as the nonlinear component, namely the Chua diode, in the Chua circuit. The literature indicates that frequency-dependent negative resistor/conductor (FDNR/FDNC) have predominantly served as passive or supplementary components, rather than as direct substitutes for the Chua diode. A Voltage Differencing Transconductance Amplifier (VDTA) based lossy FDNC structure is proposed and simulated in the LTspice environment with the commercially available MAX435 macro model. The designed circuit exhibits a dominant operating frequency of 45 kHz, and the simulation results demonstrate that different types of attractors (limit cycle, double scroll) can be obtained depending on the value of resistor R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">B</inf>.

title: Information Entropy-Enhanced CNN-LSTM Model for Detecting Electromagnetic Information Leakage
authors: Yiqi Yan, Xingye Chen, Fei Dai, Yiyun Hu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Electromagnetic information leakage detection seeks to identify security vulnerabilities in Information Technology Equipment. This process typically requires prior knowledge of the device's operational mechanisms, which can make detection challenging. Thus, this paper proposes a method for detecting electromagnetic information leakage that integrates information entropy, attention mechanisms, and a CNN-LSTM architecture. Time-domain signals of electromagnetic leakage are obtained through on-site measurements and used as the dataset. Information entropy features of these signals are computed to improve data representation. Subsequently, a CNN-LSTM model with an attention mechanism is applied for feature extraction, followed by Softmax classification for red-black signal classification. Finally, the confusion matrix was used to evaluate the model's performance, showing that the model achieves high accuracy in classifying and detecting electromagnetic information leakage from computer VGA cables.

title: Practical Approach for Effective Project Management and Organization in Machine-building and Feeding System Projects
authors: Penko Mitev, Yordan Stoyanov, Atanasi Tashev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper suggests a practical approach for effective project management and organization of machine-building projects. In today’s dynamic world, automation of processes takes an important role. More advanced technologies, new machines and utilities are integrated on daily basis in various production facilities with the sole purpose of automating industrial processes. The main aspects of automation are increase of quality, reduction of production costs, optimization of personnel resources and reduction of non-conforming parts. The approach follows up the process of development of machine-building projects from the point of view of the machine-builder as well as the customer. There are different tasks and processes to be followed in order to complete with a successful project, in time. Finishing projects in time is critical due to the fact industrial processes are dynamic and influenced by various factors. Each delay may lead to greater problems with logistics chains, customers, suppliers, etc.

title: Design, Simulation, and Implementation of a Three-Phase Inverter with SPWM Modulation Based on ESP32
authors: Diego Zarie, Ciro Larco
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This article presents the design, simulation, and construction of a low-power three-phase inverter using sinusoidal pulse-width modulation (SPWM), implemented with a low-cost microcontroller, the ESP32. The paper begins with an introduction to inverters and a theoretical framework covering the most relevant concepts. It then proceeds with the design and simulation of the inverter, carried out in MATLAB/Simulink using the Electrical Foundation Library from Simscape.The subsequent sections describe the structures and devices used in the construction of the three-phase inverter, including the power stage based on IGBTs, the LC filter, the selected resistive load, and the SPWM control signals generated by the ESP32 using the Arduino IDE platform. As part of the construction phase and essential for the inverter’s operation, the implementation of the IR2110 gate drivers for the IGBTs is detailed, with each circuit including the component values used. Finally, the fabricated printed circuit boards and the experimental results obtained from the developed inverter are presented.

title: Hybrid EfficientNetB0 and MobileNetV2 Feature Fusion by KNN Classifier for Maize Disease Classification
authors: Anggraini Puspita Sari, Firza Prima Aditiawan, Muhammad Muharrom Al Haromainy, Shintyadhita Wirawan Putri, Hafiyan Fazagi Adnanto, Muh. Irsyad Dwi Kurniawan
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: One of Indonesia’s three primary food commodities is maize. In the Madura region, maize is a key source of food and animal feed. However, its productivity is often hampered by pests, resulting in reduced harvest yields. This paper suggests a hybrid architecture that combines deep features taken from MobileNetV2 and EfficientNetB0, two convolutional neural networks (CNNs) that have already been trained. Dataset consist of 4768 training images and 1191 testing images across six classes are two healthy classes and four sick classes which features were taken from a combined dataset of maize leaf and maize stalk images that was obtained from Kaggle and divided into training and testing subsets in an 80:20 ratio. The K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) classifier was used to assess the characteristics. According to experimental data, hybrid CNN had the greatest test accuracy of 98.57%, but MobileNetV2 and EfficientNetB0 with only one feature had accuracies of 95.89% and 96.64%, respectively. KNN achieved the best balance between accuracy and computational cost, and the proposed feature fusion improved discriminative power. The pipeline shows strong potential for automated maize disease detection and may benefit from a larger dataset and end-to-end fine-tuning.

title: Techniques of Machine Learning to Eliminate Meteorological Dependencies in Solar Power Forecasting in Ecuador: Systematic Review
authors: Jaime Nasimba Quinatoa, José García López, Luis Ortiz Jiménez, Daniel García Tapia, Ximena Quintana López, Hernán Abad Hidalgo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The review, conducted following the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and MetaAnalyses) methodology, synthesizes evidence on data-driven approaches such as convolutional neural networks (CNN), hybrid deep learning models, and federated learning frameworks applied to satellite or raster-based irradiance data. This systematic review explores recent advances in machine learning techniques aimed at eliminating meteorological data dependency in solar power forecasting, with a special focus on Ecuador. The review, conducted following the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and MetaAnalyses) methodology, synthesizes evidence on data-driven approaches such as convolutional neural networks (CNN), hybrid deep learning models, and federated learning frameworks applied to satellite or raster-based irradiance data. The review synthesizes evidence on data-driven approaches such as convolutional neural networks (CNN), hybrid deep learning models, and federated learning frameworks applied to satellite or raster-based irradiance data. Key findings reveal that models integrating spatiotemporal data and geographic information systems (GIS) can maintain high forecasting accuracy even in the absence of traditional weather datasets. Nonetheless, significant gaps remain regarding large-scale validation, generalization capacity, and deployment in datascarce regions like Ecuador. The development of such models could significantly support decentralized solar energy planning and equitable energy transitions in Ecuador and beyond.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Gastronomic Tourism: A New Frontier for Culinary Experiences
authors: Pablo Alejandro Quezada-Sarmiento, Patricia Marisol Chango- Cañaveral, Aracelly Fernanda Núñez-Naranj
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become a key driver of innovation in the gastronomic tourism industry, significantly transforming traveler experiences and optimizing business operations. In customer service, AIpowered tools such as chatbots, virtual assistants, and intelligent video call systems-fueled by Natural Language Processing (NLP) and machine learning-offer fast, accurate, and tailored responses that enhance user satisfaction and reduce wait times. From a security and risk management perspective, AI enhances surveillance systems at gastronomic destinations by analyzing real-time data from sensors and cameras. This capability supports early threat detection, the identification of suspicious behaviors, and the implementation of preventive measures, ensuring safer environments for tourists. Moreover, AI enables hyperpersonalized travel experiences through the analysis of large datasets. Predictive analytics and advanced market segmentation allow businesses to provide highly targeted culinary recommendations based on travelers’ preferences and behavioral patterns. This strengthens customer loyalty and competitive differentiation. AI not only streamlines operational efficiency within gastronomic tourism but also elevates the quality, personalization, and safety of the services provided. As its adoption continues to grow, AI represents a strategic opportunity to enhance sustainability and innovation in the sector, positioning itself as a cornerstone of modern tourism development.

title: Enhancing Perceptron Constancy for Real-world Dynamic Hand Gesture Authentication
authors: Yufeng Zhang, Xilai Wang, Wenwei Song, Wenxiong Kang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Dynamic hand gesture authentication (DHGA) has emerged as a promising biometric technology, offering enhanced theoretical security over conventional unimodal systems by combining both physiological and behavioral characteristics. Existing DHGA research predominantly focuses on controlled lab conditions, therefore showing low generalizability to uncontrolled application conditions. To bridge this gap, we propose a novel Skeleton-assistant Standardization and Authentication Framework (SSAF) that incorporates a generic data preprocessing method before authentication. First, we introduce a Geometry- Environment Standardization (GE-Stan) method to standardize five primary geometric and environmental factors inducing data distribution discrepancy, significantly improving robustness across different sessions and scenarios. Notably, the GE-Stan method can be applied to most existing algorithms and brings substantial improvement. Second, we design an Appearance and Motion Network (AM-Net) to fully leverage standardized video and skeleton data. It decouples appearance and motion features using specialized representation and processing strategies. Therefore, our SSAF achieves a flexible balance between accuracy and efficiency, enabling up to 3.6× efficiency boost with only minor accuracy trade-offs. Finally, to support real-world evaluation, we also contribute a new challenging dataset, SCUT-RealDHGA, captured under uncontrolled practical conditions with diverse backgrounds and illuminations. Extensive experiments across three DHGA datasets demonstrate that SSAF outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy, efficiency, and robustness. The code and dataset are available at https://github.com/SCUTBIP-Lab/SSAF.

title: Efficient Direct Instantaneous Torque Control Strategy for Switched Reluctance Starter/Generator
authors: Shoujun Song, Tiangyang He, Qingkun Yang, Wenrui Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: In the starter/generator system of switched reluctance motor (SRM), excessive torque ripple during the motor starting process can adversely affect the aircraft engine. In addition, the heating problem of the motor can also reduce the reliability of the system. To address the issue of difficulty in obtaining motor characteristics, this article proposes a torque estimation method based on piecewise Lagrange-Fourier joint interpolation, which accurately characterizes magnetic flux and torque characteristics with only a small amount of magnetic chain data. To solve the problem of discrete control in the traditional direct torque control strategy’s torque hysteresis control method, a pulse width modulation control method is introduced. Based on the characteristics of torque generation, an efficient duty cycle strategy is established, improving motor efficiency and ultimately achieving efficient and precise control of the instantaneous torque of SRM.

title: A Spatio-Spectral-Temporal Progressive Algorithm for Infrared Tiny Target Detection in Cluttered Scenes
authors: Jiacheng Wang, Feng Pan, Xinheng Han, Xiuli Xin, Jielei Xu, Haoyuan Zhang, Weixing Li, Ji Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Infrared tiny target detection is of great value in fields such as military reconnaissance and security early warning but faces challenges including low signal-to-noise ratio, performance-efficiency trade-offs, and detection-false alarm compromises in complex dynamic scenarios. To solve these questions, we propose a novel Spatio-Spectral-Temporal Progressive (SSTP) Algorithm, integrating spatial, spectral and temporal features for infrared tiny target detection in cluttered scenes. First, it adopts anisotropic gradient difference detection algorithm to construct a spatial candidate target set based on the anisotropic radiation characteristics of target neighborhoods. Then, we use the isolation penalty adaptive clustering algorithm to obtain boundaries via outlier-enhanced clustering, and design a multilateral context filling algorithm to generate suspected regions and fill internal boundary information. Additionally, we develop an adaptive nonlinear geometric filter for point screening using nonlinear structural features, apply a multi-scale wavelet energy filter to capture high-frequency features, and utilize a target-background local difference measurement algorithm to extract regional independence for screening. Based on the proposed single frame detection method, a multi-dimensional feature fusion-based dynamic target tracking algorithm is employed to extract moving targets. Experiments show that on multi-frame datasets DSAT and single-frame datasets SIRST, the proposed method significantly outperforms mainstream algorithms, achieving detection rates of 98.75% and 98.23% as well as false alarm rates of 2.56 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup> and 10.86 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup>, respectively. The algorithm not only performs well in multi frame detection, but also has good performance in single frame detection. It thus provides a solution with high robustness and real-time performance for infrared early warning systems in complex environments.
