title: Framework for Cybersecurity Audit in Non-Profit Organizations: A Preliminary Investigation through Intelligent Minimalism
authors: Yordan Terziev, Velizar Shalamanov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Non-profit organizations find themselves in what researchers have termed a "cyber-poor, target-rich" environment – they handle increasingly sensitive donor and beneficiary data yet chronically underinvest in cybersecurity due to resource constraints. Recent evidence from the UK suggests that nearly one third of charities encountered cyber incidents in 2024. At the global level, close to two thirds of nonprofits continue to operate without documented incidentresponse policies. This combination of high exposure and limited preparedness places the sector in a distinctly vulnerable position. The study investigates whether cybersecurity audits— long associated with enterprise risk management and government oversight—can be adapted into practical resilience instruments for non-profits that typically lack comparable resources. Our approach draws on established frameworks, including the NIST Cybersecurity Framework, ISO/IEC 27001 and 27005, the CIS Controls, and the IASME Cyber Assurance standard. From these sources we developed a methodology grounded in the principle of intelligent minimalism: a focus on a small set of high-impact controls that organizations are capable of sustaining rather than extensive checklists that often remain aspirational. Feasibility was examined through a sixmonth case study with the Bulgarian NGO Association for Democratic Education "FAR", complemented by two comparative analyses. Early findings suggest that streamlined audit practices can raise awareness, introduce structured processes, and improve resilience without overwhelming organizational capacity. While the evidence remains preliminary, the results point to the potential of tailored audits as a pragmatic means of strengthening non-profit cybersecurity, meriting further validation across more diverse contexts.

title: Defect Reduction in Textile Manufacturing: A Review
authors: Ángeles Solís-Solís, Sebastián Villacís-Capuz, Marco Centeno-Alarcón, Fátima Avilés-Castillo, Jorge Buele
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The textile industry faces continuous challenges in reducing defects during manufacturing, as quality inconsistencies can lead to financial losses, reduced efficiency, and diminished consumer confidence. Addressing this issue requires a combination of methodological and technological approaches that optimize production while minimizing waste. This review examines various strategies for defect reduction, focusing on process improvement methodologies, predictive technologies, and sustainable practices. A systematic analysis of 12 studies highlights the effectiveness of structured quality management approaches in identifying and eliminating defect sources. Additionally, predictive models based on artificial intelligence have demonstrated significant potential in real-time defect detection and prevention, improving overall product quality. However, challenges such as machinery rigidity and the high variability of textile products complicate the implementation of these strategies. Sustainable manufacturing practices and specialized workforce training have also been identified as key factors in enhancing defect management, as they contribute to resource conservation, waste reduction, and improved working conditions. The findings suggest that a comprehensive approach, integrating advanced process optimization techniques, predictive analytics, and sustainable production methods, is essential for improving efficiency and quality in textile manufacturing. This integration not only reduces defects but also strengthens competitiveness in an industry increasingly driven by quality, sustainability, and technological innovation. The OSF registration can be accessed at: https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/NAMWY.

title: From Presence to Profit: Assessing Digital Adoption and Sales Performance in Ecuadorian MSMEs
authors: Sixto Raúl Manosalvas Sánchez
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Digital tools are increasingly essential for MSMEs seeking to remain competitive in globalized markets. However, in Ecuador’s Zone 1, most MSMEs face persistent challenges in transforming digital presence into sales and operational efficiency. This study investigates digital adoption patterns and commercial outcomes among MSMEs in this region. A structured survey of $\mathbf{3 7 7}$ MSMEs across six cities was conducted using stratified sampling. The dataset was analyzed through descriptive statistics, Chi-square testing, and segmentation analysis. The objective was to evaluate how internet-based tools-such as social media platforms, CRM systems, and e-commerce applications-translate into perceived competitiveness and measurable digital sales. The results revealed a $71.6 \%$ adoption rate of digital tools, yet only $11.1 \%$ of businesses reported generating more than $25 \%$ of their sales via digital channels. Moreover, over $60 \%$ of firms had invested less than ${\$}$100 in such tools. Despite limited investment, 95.6% of adopters reported improvements in competitiveness. This work contributes to the development of digital maturity models for MSMEs and supports targeted policy and training programs. By identifying the technological and strategic barriers that hinder monetization, the study enables more effective interventions in digital capacity building, platform integration, and commercial scalability.

title: Proactive Cloud Sizing Automation for Platform-as-a-Service using Historical Workload Analysis
authors: Muhammad Herwindra Berlian, Ridi Ferdiana, Guntur Dharma Putra
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The primary challenge in the context of Platform as a Service (PaaS) environments is to allocate resources efficiently so that application performance remains stable under dynamic workloads. This study proposes an automated cloud sizing system that leverages historical workload analysis and integrates multiple forecasting strategies, including LSTM, ARIMA, Prophet, and a lightweight rule-based approach. The system evaluates average, maximum, and trend values of CPU, memory, and DTU usage against predefined thresholds to generate proactive pre-runtime recommendations. A prototype was implemented using the Flask framework, integrated with Azure Monitor and Azure Automation for automatic execution of plan adjustments. The experiments demonstrate that the rulebased method achieved the lowest error for CPU prediction (Test RMSE $=3.96$), while LSTM performed best for memory usage forecasting (Test RMSE $=4.97$). For Azure SQL (DTU), LSTM achieved the lowest error among the compared models. Compared to the baseline configuration, the system reduced costs by $14.25 \%$, maintained resource efficiency, and recommended SKU adjustments that balanced cost savings with workload stability. The contribution of this study is a proactive and interpretable cloud sizing framework for PaaS that integrates multiple forecasting models with automation, and is validated through comparative experiments across rule-based, statistical, and deep learning approaches.

title: Improvement of Direct-Sequence Spread Spectrum for LPWAN Satellite Communication
authors: Lalu Delsi Samsumar, Puput Dani Prasetyo Adi, Supardianto, Erfan Wahyudi, Zaenudin, Badie Uddin
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Low Power Wide Area Network (LPWAN) satellite communication has an emergency feature that offers hope for future IoT communication systems,as it is certain to avoid problems and obstacles or barriers that occur,such as obstacles and limited distance in terrestrial-based LPWAN telecommunications. Resilience in the transmission process is determined by signal strength over a wide bandwidth,little interference that causes signal attenuation,and also allows communication using batteries and small transmission power,as well as superior security systems that can face the challenges of very long distances and also overcome high signal attenuation. As well as a communication system that can be effectively used in the process of transmitting data in active conditions,with a low signal-noise ratio (SNR) indicator and a Receive Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) that remains stable. So,using DSSS (Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum) in the future will have a significant impact on the attenuation of the signal that occurs. From the results of the method comparison,Processing Gain (dB) using Traditional DSSS is 21 dB,while using DSSS Improvement for LPWAN can increase to $\mathbf{2 1 ~ d B}$.

title: AgentPbD: Interactive Agentic Workflow Generation from User Demonstration on Web Browsers
authors: Jiawen Li, Zheng Ning, Yuan Tian, Toby Jia-Jun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Programming by Demonstration (PbD) enables users to automate tasks through examples, but traditional systems generate low-level scripts that are hard to generalize or reuse. Recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) offer the potential to infer higher-level task structures, but rely on ambiguous natural language input. We present AgentPbD, a system that synthesizes task-level agentic workflows from a single user demonstration. By capturing browser actions and contextual metadata, AgentPbD automatically infers user goals and intentions, transforming user demonstrations into an editable, modular LLM agent workflow, and displays it on the browser extension interface. Users can further review and modify the workflow through visual programming. We demonstrate how AgentPbD bridges PbD and LLM planning, enabling interpretable and generalizable automation of complex web tasks.

title: Hazel Deriver: A Live Editor for Constructing Rule-Based Derivations
authors: Zhiyao Zhong, Cyrus Omar
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Students in programming languages and formal logic courses often struggle with constructing rule-based derivation trees due to the complexity of applying inference rules, the lack of immediate feedback, and the manual effort required for handwritten proofs. We present Hazel Deriver, a live, webbased editor designed to scaffold derivation construction through multiple layers of support. Built on the Hazel live programming environment, it provides a structured, interactive experience that encourages iterative exploration and real-time feedback. A preliminary user study with 7 former students suggests that Hazel Deriver reduces the perceived difficulty of derivation tasks while improving conceptual understanding and engagement. We discuss the design of its layered scaffolding features and raise questions about balancing system guidance with learner autonomy.

title: Chaos-Driven Encryption: A Lorenz and ElGamal Hybrid Model for Secure Communication
authors: Mateo García, Gustavo Salazar-Chacón
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Cryptography is a cornerstone of information security, nowadays traditional algorithms face growing challenges. The integration of chaotic systems introduces a novel paradigm grounded in deterministic yet unpredictable dynamics. This paper presents a hybrid symmetric encryption scheme that combines Lorenz attractor as a chaotic key generator, ElGamal algorithm for symmetric operations, and BASE-85 encoding for efficient character-level data transport. The proposed algorithm, named “Joe Cipher”, leverages the extreme sensitivity to initial conditions inherent in chaotic systems to generate high-entropy pseudo-random sequences, enhancing cryptographic strength. In practical environments, the main limitations are the high computational cost required to solve the system during the encryption and decryption processes, as well as the increase in ciphertext length relative to the input size. Experimental results show that Joe Cipher Experimental a Shannon entropy of 5.49 which is close to the theoretical maximum Base-85 alphabet; a strong relation between execution time and input length and exhibits high computational cost with CPU usage approaching 99% during decryption.

title: Methodology for the Distribution of Control Logic among Multiple Controllers
authors: Yuliana Chicay, Josue Zumba, Yadira Bravo, Silvana Gamboa
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This article presents a methodology for distributing control logic among networked programmable logic controllers (PLCs) using an industrial network for data exchange. The proposed design is based on cause-effect analysis, Karnaugh maps, and a twelve-step procedure to distribute logic functions optimally. A grain milling process was emulated to validate the proposed methodology. Results demonstrate improvements in scalability, maintainability, and logical distribution compared to centralized architectures. This approach supports the development of prototypes and scalable control solutions aligned with decentralization and modularity principles, promoting their replication in other industrial environments.

title: Study of WDM channel allocation on C and L bands in high-bitrate demand scenarios
authors: Marco V. Vasquez Chavez, German V. Arevalo
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) leads to the usage of available frequency bands that generate lower losses when transmitting data through long distances, as C and L bands. This paper analyzes WDM usage to allow high density channel assignation improving fiber optics media usage for WAN communications, including the analysis of how transmission variables, such as traffic speed and channel-to-channel spacing, affect the quality of the transmitted data. It was performed a comparison of different wavelength-allocation scenarios, leading to state the best data transmission setups that support actual and potentially future high-bandwidth demands throughout long distance optical networks, optimizing physical media usage and keeping a low bit error rate in the data transmission. Results show that it is possible to transmit at high bit rates in WDM optical fiber systems with a simple intensity modulation technique, up to the limit when the increase of bitrate causes a significant overlapping in the channels’ spectrum. For a $10 \mathrm{~Gb} / \mathrm{s}$ perchannel WDM system, when the inter-channel spacing is 100 GHz, the penalty of increasing from 5 to 25 channels is negligible but for a 50 GHz and 25 GHz separation, the penalty increases to 0.25 dB and 2 dB. For a $25 \mathrm{~Gb} / \mathrm{s}$ perchannel WDM system, there is a floor BER of $\mathbf{1 0 - 5}$ when the channels separation is 50 GHz, and for a $40 \mathrm{~Gb} / \mathrm{s}$ perchannel system it is feasible to achieve results only with a spacing of $\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ G H z}$.

title: A Novel Cross-Layer Resilient Control Approach of Data-Based Switched Systems With Time Delay Induced by DoS Attacks
authors: Peilin Jia, Jie Lian, Wanchen Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems
abstract: This paper investigates the cross-layer resilient control problem of networked switched systems under DoS attacks. In the cyber layer, considering the sequential decision-making process and incomplete information, a Bayesian Stackelberg game based on information entropy is utilized to model the interaction between two players, where the defender is the leader while the attacker acts as the follower. On this basis, the existence and the uniqueness of the equilibrium are rigorously proven, and an algorithm is proposed to identify this equilibrium. The energy allocations of both players based on the equilibrium determines the data transmission delay of the physical layer. To deal with the impact of DoS-induced time delays, the state augmentation approach is employed to reformulate the original system into a delay-free form. An adaptive dynamic programming approach incorporating the mixed switching law is proposed to ensure both the stability and optimal performance. Then a weight related to the optimized performance is incorporated into the defender's cost function to bridge physical and cyber layers. Finally, an industrial simulation is conducted to verify the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method.

title: Paired Channel Enhanced Sign-Aware Graph Recommendation
authors: Haiteng Wang, Zhida Qin, Yacheng Li, Tianyu Huang, Gangyi Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Graph-based recommendation systems have excelled in modeling user–item interactions, but most focus solely on positive feedback, overlooking the critical role of negative feedback in capturing comprehensive user preferences. Signed graphs, which incorporate both positive and negative interactions, offer a promising approach but face challenges due to the oversimplification of balance theory and the limitations of conventional graph neural networks (GNNs) in processing negative signals. To address these issues, we propose paired channel enhanced sign-aware graph recommendation (PCSRec), a novel framework that holistically integrates positive and negative feedback. PCSRec introduces a path-enhanced embedding module that leverages a learnable path-encoding matrix to capture indirect structural patterns, overcoming the limitations of balance theory. Additionally, it employs a paired channel filtering mechanism with spectral low-pass and high-pass filters to model similarity from positive feedback and dissimilarity from negative feedback, respectively. A dual-loss optimization strategy, combining contrastive and Bayesian personalized ranking (BPR) losses, further refines discriminative representations. Extensive experiments on four real-world datasets demonstrate that PCSRec outperforms both unsigned and signed graph-based baselines, achieving state-of-the-art recommendation performance. Ablation studies and visualizations confirm the effectiveness of its components in improving embedding quality and recommendation accuracy.

title: Operating-Mode-Oriented Vibration Collaborative Suppression for a Permanent Magnet Brushless Motor from Perspectives of Different Vibration Sources
authors: Jiamin Bai, Xiaoyong Zhu, Zixuan Xiang, Li Quan, Tengfei Song, Ruicheng Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: In this paper, an operating-mode-oriented collaborative vibration suppression methodology is proposed to suppress the vibration of permanent magnet brushless (PMBL) motors under whole open throttle (WOT) condition driven. The WOT is naturally divided into two operating modes: maximum torque per ampere at low speed and flux weakening at high speed. Then, by constructing the correlation between the key radial electromagnetic force harmonics and the d-axis demagnetization current, it was clarified that the dominant vibration sources of the two operating modes are the electromagnetic force carrier harmonics force and (0,6fe), (0,12fe) electromagnetic force harmonics, respectively. For an extensive investigation, a 48-slot, 8-pole PMBL motor is chosen as a research example. Then, the vibration suppression methods of key harmonics reduction and carrier harmonics energy shifting are proposed. Next, the performances of the optimal PMBL motors are simulated to validate the proposed methodology. Finally, a prototype is fabricated and experimented. Both simulated and test results are presented to verify the validity of the theoretical analysis and design methodology.

title: Explainability in Software Architectural Decisions: The ADR-E Framework and Empirical Evaluation
authors: Ricardo Gacitúa, Javier Pereira, Michael Klafft
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: As software systems increase in scale and complexity, architectural decisions must be transparent, traceable, and understandable to diverse stakeholders. However, traditional documentation approaches—such as standard Architectural Decision Records (ADRs)—often lack the structured rationale and contextual detail necessary to support informed analysis and long-term architectural stewardship. This paper presents the Software Architecture Explainability Framework (SAEF), a structured approach for enabling explainable architectural decision-making. Central to the framework is the Explainable Architectural Decision Record (ADR-E), which extends traditional ADRs with explicit rationale, structured stakeholder-oriented explanations, rejected alternatives, and traceability links grounded in explainability principles inspired by AI. SAEF was evaluated through two industrial case studies: the selection of Azure Kubernetes Service for container orchestration and the adoption of an enterprise-grade observability platform. Using a mixed-methods design combining workshops, scenario-based simulations, surveys, interviews, and operational metrics, the study found that ADR-E substantially improved transparency, traceability, and stakeholder alignment. Both cases reported a 30% reduction in mean time to resolution (MTTR) and transparency scores above 4.6/5. Overall, SAEF provides a practical and theoretically grounded foundation for explainable architectural decision-making. Future work will focus on tool support, graphical notations, and longitudinal assessments to enhance adoption and scalability.

title: Optimizing CNN-Based Video Summarization With Digital Twin Framework for Adaptive Probability Thresholding
authors: Rachit Adhvaryu, Munindra Lunagaria, Ambresh Bhadrashetty, Sudhir Anakal, Deepak Gupta, Rubal Jeet, Tejas Chauhan, Dipesh Kamdar, Aditi Sharma
publish: IEEE Communications Standards Magazine
abstract: The rapid growth of video data necessitates efficient summarization techniques to extract critical insights while minimizing computational overhead. This study investigates three pre-trained CNN models—AlexNet (61 M parameters), GoogLeNet (6.8M), and SqueezeNet (1.24M)—with respective inference speeds of 23.8 ms/frame, 18.4 ms/frame, and 12.6 ms/frame. These computational differences significantly affect real-time summarization performance. A probability-driven thresholding mechanism was introduced to optimize object detection, effectively reducing false positives and enhancing classification accuracy. Among the models, GoogLeNet achieved the best trade-off between accuracy (98.96%) and computational efficiency, while AlexNet attained the highest detection accuracy (99.12%) but exhibited a higher false detection rate (5.6%). SqueezeNet, though lightweight and resource-efficient, reached an accuracy of 94.26% but faced limitations in fine-grained recognition tasks. Probability versus correct detection analysis indicated that a threshold of 0.7 maximized accuracy while reducing misclassifications. The proposed adaptive thresholding framework demonstrates strong applicability in real-world scenarios such as wildlife monitoring, intelligent surveillance, and IoT-enabled video analytics. By bridging CNN-based architectures with scalable IoT-driven solutions, this research advances the development of robust, accurate, and efficient video summarization systems for next-generation intelligent environments.

title: Potential Role of Deep Learning in Operational Radar Rainfall Mapping: Rationale and Demonstration Studies
authors: Haonan Chen
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Although polarimetric weather radar measurements provide rich information about precipitation, traditional approaches of using them can only extract part of the information due to limitations of the applied analytical tools. The performance of conventional radar rainfall estimation algorithms, such as the radar reflectivity (Z) and rain rate (R) relations, is highly dependent on the local raindrop size distributions that vary in different precipitation regimes. This article revisits the surface rainfall mapping problem using operational radar observations, but from a deep learning perspective. For demonstration, a machine learning model driven by a convolutional neural network and a vision transformer is designed to estimate surface rainfall using multiparameter multidimensional observations from the U.S. Weather Surveillance Radar - 1988 Doppler (WSR-88D). Results from the deep learning model are compared with rainfall estimates from the operational polarimetric radar algorithms implemented by the WSR-88D and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) multi-radar multi-sensor (MRMS) system, which indicates the great potential of deep learning for operational applications.

title: SMAUG: Semantic-Enhanced Mobile App Usage Data Generation With LLM
authors: Zihan Huang, Tong Li, Yong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Services Computing
abstract: Mobile app usage data reveal user behavioral characteristics and is crucial for mobile operators for network service optimization, but its data collection is pricey and presents privacy concerns. Data synthesis, fortunately, can tackle this barrier by generating diverse and representative artificial datasets that resemble real-world data. In this paper, we propose SMAUG, a diffusion model-based generative model with large language models (LLMs) designed to generate personalized app usage data based on mobile users' mobility trajectories. To address the data inaccuracy issue brought by the sparsity nature of mobile app usage behavior, SMAUG decomposes the generation process and adopts a hierarchical structure framework to gradually refine the generation from the session level to the specific app level. By encoding spatio-temporal context and applying an attention mechanism, SMAUG effectively represents personalized user representations. Moreover, aiming to extensively explore the semantic information in app usage sessions, SMAUG incorporates LLMs to gain deeper insight into user behavior characteristics revealed in sessions, and also exploits a curriculum representation learning approach based on contrastive learning, exploring session characteristics from elementary to profound. Experiments on two real-world datasets show that SMAUG outperforms existing generative baseline approaches by over 25% under the metrics of RMSE, MAE, CRPS, JSD, M-TV, and Spearmanr. The model has also been successfully deployed to assist network service simulation, demonstrating their suitability for downstream tasks in real-world systems.

title: Robust and Fair Federated Learning Based on Model-Agnostic Shapley Value_supp1-3630314.pdf
authors: Jia Hu
publish: N/A
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a promising framework for privacy-preserving machine learning. FL enables distributed data owners (clients) to collaboratively train a global model without sharing their local data with a central server. However, FL is inherently vulnerable to free-rider and poisoning attacks, where free riders dissimulate their participation of training by sending counterfeit yet harmless model updates to the central server, while adversarial clients send poisonous model updates to the server to degrade the global model performance. Their distinctive attacking patterns make the simultaneous defense against both attacks very challenging. To address this challenge, we propose a novel model-agnostic Shapley value-based robust and fair federated learning method (SVRFL), which models FL as a cooperative game and leverages Shapley values of model updates to defend against free riders and adversarial clients. Specifically, a client reputation score and a model utility score are computed using the Shapley value. Based on these scores, we ensure the basic fairness within FL by identifying and eliminating free riders, and realize adversarial robustness through discarding poisonous model updates, with theoretical convergence guaranteed. Extensive experiments show that SVRFL can detect typical free-rider attacks with up to full precision and is resistant to poisoning attacks launched by adversarial clients.

title: Lessons Learned from the euROBIN Manipulation Skill Versatility Challenge at IROS 2024_supp3-3648290.mp4
authors: Chaoyang Song
publish: N/A
abstract: Robotic automation in high-mix, low-volume settings often relies on structured workcells where fixtures, workpieces, and procedures are well defined, but tasks must be reconfigured quickly across variants. This paper presents the Design and Learning Research Group's solution to the euROBIN Manipulation Skill Versatility Challenge (MSVC) at IROS 2024, in which a standardized electronic task board is operated through a fixed sequence of subtasks. We deliberately adopt a simple, industry-style implementation: each subtask is taught by recording an open-loop Tool Center Point (TCP) and gripper trajectory in the task-board frame, a wrist-mounted depth camera is used once per run to localize the board and a few key features, and a web dashboard exposes the resulting motion primitives as reusable code blocks that can be reordered and reparameterized. With this pipeline, our system completes the benchmark in 28.2 s in the lab (37.2 s on-site), compared to a human baseline of 16.3 s and an average of 83.5 s for previous teams, closing a large part of the performance gap without advanced learning or feedback control. We further demonstrate limited skill transfer by retargeting the same subtask library to a smoke-detector battery replacement scenario required by the competition. Finally, we release our implementation as open source and discuss how competition design and benchmark structure influence the balance between simple engineered solutions and richer sensing and learning.

title: Polarization-Multiplexed Metasurface for Dynamic Reconfiguration Between Orbital Angular Momentum and Focusing Beams
authors: Xiaoxuan Guo, Yang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: A dynamically reconfigurable metasurface is proposed to switch between a focusing beam and an orbital angular momentum (OAM) beam via <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$X$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-polarization (XP) to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$Y$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-polarization (YP) conversion. The metasurface comprises dual-linear-polarization, multilayer unit cells (UCs) with 3-bit phase resolution, exhibiting high transmission amplitude and a wide range of transmission phase shifts. To validate the feasibility of the proposed approach, a Fermi feed and two metasurface prototypes were fabricated using printed circuit board (PCB) technology for measurement. The measured results show good agreement with simulations, demonstrating that the proposed design method can not only achieve dynamic switching between OAM beams and focusing beams but also enable dynamic switching between OAM beams with different topological charges. The demonstrated metasurface holds potential for application in intelligent dynamic scenarios such as autonomous vehicles and drone swarms.

title: A Learning-Enhanced Robust Adaptive Fading Extended/Error-State Kalman Filter for Integrated IMU-UWB Indoor Localization Under NLOS Reception
authors: Mengxia He, S. C. Chan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Indoor localization using ultra- wideband (UWB) technology has received much attention due to its ability to provide decimeter accuracy and low-cost/low-power implementation. However, challenges such as non-line-of-sight (NLOS) propagation caused by ubiquitous obstacles, and systematic bias in off-the-shelf/low-cost UWB modules severely impair the accuracy of UWB measurements, resulting in reduced positioning accuracy and reliability. This paper develops a learning-enhanced robust adaptive fading extended/error-state Kalman filter (LRAF-E(S)KF) algorithm for UWB-based localization systems in complex indoor environments. Firstly, mismatches in the state and measurement noise covariance matrices, commonly found in conventional EKF, are adaptively mitigated by fading factors estimated from a linear KF. This improves positioning accuracy in dynamic environments without any excessive tuning. Then, a robust NLOS detector based on robust statistics is proposed to identify and suppress NLOS-contaminated UWB measurements. Finally, an extreme learning machine (ELM-) based network is developed for correcting large estimation errors in the vertical direction caused by systematic bias in UWB measurements. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is evaluated using two real-world datasets collected in real-time in indoor environments. Results show that the proposed algorithm significantly improves positioning accuracy over the original E(S)KF algorithm and outperforms state-of-the-art approaches under both “Only UWB” and “inertial measurement unit (IMU)-UWB” settings.

title: A High-Order Coupling HTS Dual-Band Bandpass Filter Based on CQ Units Designed by Employing Direct Synthesis and Optimization Technique
authors: Liguo Zhou, Jiang Jiang, Daiyao Zhang, Xilong Lu, Yiqiuzi Shen, Bin Xia, Qibin Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Based on the linear high-order coupling topology, a direct synthesis and optimization technique (DS-OT) has been proposed to generate prototype functions tailored to the design specifications of multiband filters. This method can rapidly extract the coupling matrix of multiband filters, which can exhibit either equal-ripple response within the passbands, equal bandwidth response, or both simultaneously. Building on this, a method for extracting dual-band bandpass filter prototype functions with equal-ripple transmission functions between two subpassbands based on an iterative optimization approach is proposed. In addition, a dual-band filter (DBF) topology of a parallel resonator based on a single-cascaded quadruplet (PBCQ) is proposed. This structure features structural symmetry, a simple design, and the ability to achieve equal-ripple reflection functions within the subpassbands and equal-ripple transmission functions between the two subpassbands. Furthermore, it can be extended for use in multiband filter design. Fully leveraging the advantage of low insertion loss (IL) in high-order coupled filter design using high-temperature superconducting (HTS) materials, a 12th-order HTS DBF was designed and fabricated based on the aforementioned theory and topology. The filter function response exhibits three pairs of symmetric real transmission zeros (TZs), achieving equal-ripple responses both within the subpassbands and between them. Overall, the measured frequency response characteristics demonstrate excellent passband and stopband performance, closely aligning with the results obtained from full-wave analysis and theoretical analysis.

title: A Survey on Methods to Detect Pilot Contamination Attack against Physical Layer Authentication
authors: Dimitriya Mihaylova, Stefano Tomasin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: A promising strategy to authenticate users’ identity in next generation wireless systems is by physical layer authentication (PLA) techniques. One way to accomplish authentication at the physical layer relies on comparison of the currently estimated instantaneous channel features, such as amplitude or frequency response, and those obtained during training: a hypothesis testing is applied whose optimal results are subject to the choice of the threshold value used in the comparison. By initiating pilot contamination attack (PCA) against the process of channel estimation, a non-authenticated user can corrupt the channel state information-based PLA mechanism. This way, identification fails and the intruder improves its substitution and impersonation capabilities. To secure the system against such types of malicious intervention, the methods to detect and counteract pilot contamination against PLA must be extensively studied. In this paper, an overview of several most significant methods related to PCA detection is presented together with an analysis of their characteristics.

title: Circularly Polarized Slotted Ring Antenna for Modern Wireless Communications
authors: Lujain F. Al-Hunity, Raneem A. Al-Mashni, Yanal S. Faouri
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: A compact circularly polarized (CP) antenna is presented with overall dimensions of 40 mm × 40 mm × 1.6 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, designed on an FR4 substrate. The antenna can switch between right-hand circular polarization (RHCP) and left-hand circular polarization (LHCP) depending on the biasing state of the integrated diode. The antenna operates effectively within the 5.4–6 GHz band, ensuring reliable CP performance across the designated frequency range. This reconfigurability provides enhanced flexibility for modern wireless communication systems that require polarization diversity to mitigate multipath fading and improve link reliability (LR). The proposed design achieves stable performance while maintaining a simple and low-cost structure, making it suitable for integration into next-generation communication and sensing applications.

title: From Tool to Partner: Exploring the Roles of Embodiment on AI Agent in Pair Programming
authors: Xiaoran Yang, Yang Zhan, Noboru Matsuda, Qiao Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Pair programming with AI often faces challenges in productive communication and engagement. Integrating embodiment offers a promising solution by making AI a more engaging and context-aware programming partner. To explore how embodied AI agent supports programming learning and affects user experiences, we designed a virtual reality (VR) programming environment with Wizard-of-Oz-controlled AI agents. Our study collected data from 18 participants through knowledge acquisition assessments and interviews. The results showed that embodiment improved engagement, enhanced communication efficiency, and offered emotional support. Specifically, the incorporation of embodied actions allows users to perceive the AI agent as a “programming partner” and introduces many interactions that resemble those shared with real-life partners. However, the effectiveness of embodied actions in supporting users with programming tasks depends on the timing and accuracy of those actions. This study reveals the potential of embodied AI agents in advancing programming education and provides valuable design insights for creating more intuitive and supportive AI programming partners.

title: Wearable Pressure Sensor System for Measuring Kick Reaction Time and Impact Force in Taekwondo
authors: Elías Nicolas Chato Cantos, Juan Jose Rivera Zamora, Ana Cecilia Villa-Parra, Pablo Fernando Cevallos Larrea, Mario Germán Álvarez Álvarez
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents the design and evaluation of an affordable wearable device created to measure reaction time and impact force during kicking actions in Taekwondo to support the evaluation of athletic performance under varying visual stimulus conditions. The prototype consists of an array of force sensors integrated into a wearable chest protector and a visual stimulus module based on light emitting diodes (LEDs) indicators. Reaction time was calculated from the onset of the visual stimulus to the moment of impact, whereas impact force was estimated based on the voltage response of the force sensors. Impact force estimation was achieved through linear regression modeling, reaching $70 \%$ accuracy. The system was validated through preliminary tests with Taekwondo athletes under sequential and randomized visual stimulus protocols. Results revealed measurable differences in performance under different conditions.

title: Development of On-Board Navigation Software with an Interactive Interface for High-Precision Flight Trajectory Control
authors: Yerkebulan Nurgizat, Arman Uzbekbayev, Kuanysh Alipbayev, Gani Sergazin, Nursultan Zhetenbayev, Aidos Sultan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: A software-centric on-board navigation and trajectory-control framework is presented, integrating satellite positioning, inertial sensing, Kalman filtering, and aerodynamic surface actuation within a modular architecture. A ground control station with an interactive interface (PyQt5) supports real-time monitoring, parameter tuning, and trajectory replanning. In hardware-in-the-loop simulations and bench tests, the system maintains stable performance during short GNSS interruptions (up to 5 s) and reduces dispersion (CEP proxy) from 30-40 m to 3-10 m on a legacy unguided platform surrogate under representative wind disturbances. Open architecture facilitates scalability, reproducibility, and non-weaponized research use in aerospace navigation and control.

title: Recognition Methods for Complex Characters in Images from Manuscripts of the 17th-18th Centuries
authors: Viktor Tailakov, Tatyana Golubeva, Dmitry Demidov, Ivan Beloev, Elena Tyshenko, Teodor Iliev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The software development for recognition of complex characters in images from manuscripts is considered in this paper. The research focuses on processing issues of musical notations from ancient Russian manuscripts (17th-18th centuries) based on state-of-the-art ML methods like CNNs, DNNs etc. The existing segmentation and classification methods for recognition of hook and banner characters are analyzed. The model for the automated classification of these characters and the algorithms for generating digital, editable copies of ancient manuscripts are described in this study. The software implementation and testing results are discussed.

title: Hardware Unit for Monitoring the Behaviour of a Bee Colony
authors: Dimitar Avramov, Ivaylo Penev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Bee behaviour monitoring systems typically consist of three main components: a power supply, hardware, and software. This paper focuses on the hardware component, which includes sensors and a computing device. Temperature, humidity, light, and air quality sensors are placed inside the beehive, while a weight sensor and an additional temperature and humidity sensor are installed outside. The selected microcontroller is the NodeMCU 8266. The assembled module has been deployed in a real-world operating environment.

title: Analysis of the Environmental Impact of the Use of Electric Generators in the 2024 Energy Crisis in the Canton of Cuenca
authors: Ginger Adriana Gonzalez Nieves Grupo, Diego Patricio Rivera Guachichulca, Néstor Diego Rivera Campoverde, Andrea Karina Bermeo Naula, Diana Patricia Moya Loaiza
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The 2024 energy crisis in Ecuador, driven by severe drought conditions, significantly impacted hydroelectric power generation, leading to prolonged blackouts in urban areas such as Cuenca. In response, the widespread use of electric generators increased considerably, raising concerns about their environmental and health impacts. This study presents a novel methodology to estimate pollutant emissions (specifically CO2, $\mathrm{CO}, \mathrm{HC}$, and $\mathrm{NO}_{\mathrm{x}}$) based solely on environmental noise levels. A stratified sample of 248 generators was measured across different urban zones using a sound level meter and a gas analyzer, following Ecuadorian regulations. Three machine learning models (linear regression, decision tree, and neural network) were trained to predict emissions from noise data. The decision tree model showed the best predictive capacity, with a maximum $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ of $\mathbf{0. 6 6}$ for $\mathbf{C O}_{\mathbf{2}}$, a value that, while moderate, is considered acceptable in environmental estimation involving a single predictor variable. The trained model was then applied to a broader dataset of 710 generators to estimate total emissions during 691 hours of power outages recorded over 89 days. The results revealed the emission of 428 tons of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}, 14.91$ tons of $\mathrm{CO}, 0.72$ tons of HC, and 7.6 tons of $\mathrm{NO}_{\mathrm{x}}$. In parallel, noise levels exceeded local regulatory limits, particularly in central and residential areas, indicating significant public health implications. The study supports the implementation of regulatory strategies, improvements in generator technology, and a shift towards cleaner energy sources in emergency contexts.

title: Deep Learning-Based Classification of Madura Batik Motifs Using Transfer Learning Approach
authors: Eva Yulia Puspaningrum, Eka Prakarsa Mandyartha, Fawwaz Ali Akbar, Yudhistira Nanda Kumala, Attiqor Rozi, Suwito
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Batik has been officially recognized by UNESCO as an element of Indonesia’s intangible cultural heritage. Across the Indonesian archipelago, each region is distinguished by unique batik motifs, with Madura Batik standing out due to its characteristic patterns that differ from those of other regions. As a cultural heritage, Madura Batik faces significant challenges in the identification and documentation of its motifs, particularly for preservation among younger generations. In this study, a transfer learning approach was employed, utilizing MobileNetV2 pretrained on ImageNet as the backbone architecture, supplemented with several fully connected layers. The dataset comprised images of Madura Batik and NonMadura Batik, with augmentation techniques applied to address dataset limitations. The proposed architecture achieved an accuracy of 96.37%, demonstrating its effectiveness in batik pattern recognition. The contribution of this research is twofold: the provision of a valuable dataset and the advancement of cultural heritage preservation through computational recognition of batik motifs. This work offers potential applications in both educational contexts and the commercial batik industry. Furthermore, to ensure accessibility and practical implementation, a user-friendly web-based interface was developed, enabling the system to be utilized by a broader audience.

title: Bridging Natural Language and SQL with an LLM-Powered Visual Interface
authors: Supriya Kottam
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: In many organizations, business analysts and decisionmakers frequently need to query structured data to extract insights, generate reports, or monitor key metrics. While the data itself is readily available in enterprise databases, accessing it often requires writing Structured Query Language (SQL) - a task that remains challenging for users without formal technical training. As a result, these users typically rely on data engineers or analysts to manually translate their questions into SQL, creating delays, bottlenecks, and communication gaps.

title: The Use of Precedence Networks for Cement Plant Outages
authors: James Lindsey, Bernie Sherin
publish: 2023 IEEE-IAS/PCA Cement Industry Conference (IAS/PCA)
abstract: A case study detailing the use of a precedence network to overcome some of the challenges associated with shifting start dates, fluctuating work scopes, contractor coordination, and parts delays during a cement plant outage. Sixteen days before the scheduled start of the outage the sequential failure of two critical bucket elevators necessitated twice changing the start date, altering the work scope, and altering the coordination of all contractors and materials. This paper will detail how the precedence network (also known as a Critical Path Network) allowed plant leadership to manage these issues and execute a safe, successful outage.

title: Parameter Determination for the Double-Layer Capacitor (DLC) Characterization of the Supercapacitor in the Microgrid Laboratory at the University of Cuenca
authors: Andrés Martínez, Ciro Larco
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Supercapacitors are key devices in modern energy storage applications, particularly in backup systems, electric vehicles, and microgrids, due to their high-power density and long service life. This work presents the identification of parameters for two equivalent circuit models applied to a supercapacitor bank with over a decade of usage. The first model, based on the structure proposed by the manufacturer, fails to accurately reproduce the terminal voltage evolution, even after numerical parameter adjustment, revealing its limitation in representing the actual behavior of the aged bank. The second model, based on Zubieta’s proposal, incorporates the nonlinear dependence of capacitance on voltage and was obtained through simulation in Simulink using the output of the manufacturer’s model as a reference. However, it also required numerical tuning, which yielded significantly different parameters consistent with an advanced aging state of the device. The results suggest a loss of conduction capability, a reduction in total capacitance, an increase in leakage resistance, and a slower dynamic response, considering that the bank is approaching the end of its useful life.

title: Diagnosing Logistics Companies Using Digital Tools: A Descriptive Analysis of Machine Learning Approaches and their Impact on Professional Practice
authors: Rudy López, Michelle Tolozano, Vivian Antúnez, Mario Guzmán, Dayse Cabrera, Luis F. Ugarte
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The digital transformation of the logistics companies has shifted from being an optional strategy to becoming a competitive necessity. This paper provides a descriptive analysis of how the implementation of Machine Learning (ML) tools is reshaping the operations of distribution and warehousing companies. Beyond operational improvements, the study explores the broader social, economic, and professional implications of digital adoption in logistics. The findings, drawn from a review and verification of recent studies, indicate that machine learning enables inventory optimization, failure prediction, and enhanced planning processes. These advances contribute not only to greater operational efficiency but also support the transition toward more sustainable and resilient logistics practices.

title: Evaluation of a Telemedicine Tool for the Training of Rotating Interns
authors: Constanza Andrea Isla Quezada, Judith Francisco-Pérez, Ana Garcia Mingo, Paula de Corral San Martín
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Background: Telemedicine improves access to healthcare in underserved rural areas. However, its academic use for training healthcare professionals remains under-explored. The Cayapas Telemedicine Platform was designed to facilitate asynchronous consultations and improve communication between students and new professionals, with tutors and specialists. Objective: To validate the usability and perceived educational value of the Cayapas Telemedicine Platform through its implementation with rotating medical and nursing interns. Methods: A sequential mixed-methods study was conducted with 26 participants (23 medical and nursing interns and 3 tutors). Semi-structured interviews explored user needs and satisfaction, while quantitative data were collected using two instruments: the System Usability Scale (SUS) and a communication assessment scale. Results: The platform’s usability was rated as “marginal” (mean SUS score: $61.1 \pm 13.8$). According to the communication scale, 56% of users agreed or strongly agreed that the tool improved interaction between students and tutors. Qualitative findings highlighted needs related to functionality, accessibility, interface design, and technical support. Participants suggested improvements in response times, notification systems, artificial intelligence integration, profession-specific profiles, and digital health training. Conclusions: Although the Cayapas platform shows potential as a support tool for rural clinical training, improvements in its usability and relevance are needed to facilitate its future implementation in rural contexts.

title: A Multi-Method Sensitivity Framework for LCOE Under Uncertainty: Combining Monte Carlo, Pareto Frontier, and Contour Maps
authors: Diego Arias-Cazco, Paul Masache, Geovanny Pardo-Salazar, Luis Cruz-Panchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents an integrated methodology for sensitivity analysis of the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE), combining multi-objective optimization techniques, stochastic Monte Carlo simulations, and the subsequent application of Contour Maps as a complementary tool for result validation and comparison. Given that several variables involved in the LCOE calculation are subject to uncertainty, the traditional ceteris paribus assumption is replaced with a Monte Carlo-based approach, introducing randomness into the input variables not included as objective functions in the optimization problem. This allows the generation of multiple Pareto fronts that capture the sensitivity of the LCOE to such uncertainties. To enhance computational efficiency throughout the iterative process, parallel processing is employed. The results are further enriched through contour mapping, which complements the analysis and facilitates visual interpretation. The methodology is validated through case studies, demonstrating its capability to explore a broad solution space, reduce risk exposure, and support more robust decision-making in energy planning under uncertainty.

title: Content-Based Recommendation System for Building Materials using IndoBERT and Word2Vec
authors: Sugiarto Sugiarto, Wahyu Melinda Permanasari, Irma Dwi Kusuma, Laqma Dica Fitrani, Agussalim, I Gede Susrama Mas Diyasa
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: This study discusses the development of a building material product recommendation system based on ContentBased Filtering (CBF) by comparing two text representation approaches IndoBERT and Word2Vec. Data was collected through web scraping from the Mitra10 marketplace website, including product name, description, price, and physical dimensions. After preprocessing, the data were classified based on material categories. Each product description was then converted into a vector representation using the IndoBERT and Word2Vec models. Cosine similarity was used to measure the similarity between products and generate relevant recommendations. The evaluation was conducted by product category using Precision@10, Recall@10, and F1-Score@10 metrics. The results show that the IndoBERT model outperformed Word2Vec, achieving an F1-Score of 0.914 compared to 0.532. The system was then integrated into a web interface using Streamlit, which not only provides product recommendations but also calculates material requirements and cost estimates based on the user’s house size. This study demonstrates that transformer-based semantic representations can significantly enhance the quality of recommendation systems in the context of building materials.

title: CNN Architectures for Multi-Crop Leaf Disease Classification Using a Merged Dataset
authors: Richard Dean Tanjaya, Grace Esther Simanjuntak, Wilson Pranajaya Tunggala, Dave Christian Thio, Mahmud Isnan, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Global food security continues to be threatened by crop diseases that cause annual losses of over USD 220 billion. Image-based recognition of plant diseases has been studied extensively, but many existing works rely on single-species datasets, which limit the ability of models to generalize to more varied field conditions. In this study, we combine two publicly available Bangladeshi leaf image collections into a dataset of more than 15,000 images covering five crop species and eight disease categories. Using this dataset, we fine-tune and compare five pre-trained convolutional neural networks under identical conditions: VGG16, EfficientNetV2, ResNet50, Xception, and InceptionV3. VGG16 produces the most consistent results, with $99.29 \%$ accuracy, $99.31 \%$ precision, $99.29 \%$ recall, and a $99.29 \%$ F1-score. While improvements over prior results are modest, the study contributes a more diverse benchmark and a systematic comparison of commonly used architectures, which may help guide the development of practical tools for plant disease detection.

title: Optimizing E-Commerce User Experiences: Investigating Chatbot Effectiveness and Behavioral Intention Through the Technology Acceptance Model
authors: Shakila Humaira, Sakira Maura Najwa, Adele B L Mailangkay
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has significantly changed customer interactions in e-commerce, particularly through the use of chatbots. These tools enhance the user experience by providing quick responses and handling customer service effectively. This study analyzes the factors that influence Indonesian users’ behavioral intentions toward chatbots by expanding the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) to include personal motivation as an intermediary variable. An online survey was used to collect data from 160 e-commerce users, and analysis was conducted using a Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) approach. Results show that perceived usefulness has a significant impact on personal motivation, which in turn influences behavioral intention. Additionally, perceived ease of use has a significant impact and shapes user attitudes, which in turn influence behavioral intention. These findings highlight the importance of creating useful and user-friendly chatbots while also encouraging user motivation and positive attitudes. This study makes a significant contribution by addressing the limitations of previous studies related to chatbot adoption in emerging markets, while also providing practical insights for strengthening customer service strategies in Indonesian e-commerce.

title: A Centralized-Distributed Hybrid Control Scheme for Voltage Control in Active Distribution Networks With High Renewable Penetration
authors: Mudaser Rahman Dar, Sanjib Ganguly
publish: IEEE Systems Journal
abstract: This article presents a hierarchical voltage control framework based on multitimescale model predictive control (MPC) for ADNs, with high penetration of photovoltaic systems and electric vehicles. The proposed scheme utilizes a hybrid control architecture, wherein OLTC is controlled at the first stage using MPC, leveraging sparse measurement and communication-based centralized control scheme. Inverter-driven control devices (IDCDs) are operated on a faster timescale, utilizing MPC-based distributed coordination. To enhance operational efficiency, a community detection algorithm based on network modularity is utilized for network clustering. A modified modularity metric incorporating the diameter of the cluster, in addition to the average voltage sensitivity and device regulation capacity, is utilized for improved network partitioning. A decomposition coordination control model is used for distributed control of IDCDs, utilizing the alternating-direction method of multipliers, with reduced communication overhead. The scalability and coordination capability of the presented model are validated on the 33-bus network and the IEEE 123-bus network.

title: On minimax empirical Bayes predictive densities
authors: Éric Marchand, William E. Strawderman
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: For estimating the density of Y |μ ∼ Nd(μ, νId) based on X|μ ∼ Nd(μ, σ2X Id) with known ν, σ2X, we consider the class P of “extended plug-in” predictive densities q ∼ Nd(μ, νId). For a given prior density π for μ and Kullback-Leibler loss, we investigate the optimal choice qeb,π obtained by minimizing the expected posterior loss among q ∈ P, as initially proposed by Okudo and Komaki [21]. With qeb,π having a simple form and a appealing alternative to the exact Bayesian predictive density, we investigate its Kullback-Leibler risk performance. Our main finding consists, for d ≥ 3 and a given superharmonic prior density π, in the determination of a lower cut-off point ν such that qeb,π dominates the benchmark minimum risk and minimax predictive density for ν ≥ ν. Specific analyses are carried out and our results are illustrated for a pseudo-Bayes marginal density and a subclass of Strawderman prior densities.

title: AoI-Driven Cooperative Energy Transfer and Data Collection for Multi-UAV Low-Altitude Economy Networks
authors: Huimin Hu, Haizhou Tang, Ruichen Zhang, Fan Jiang, Chau Yuen, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: With the rapid growth of the low-altitude economy (LAE), uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) have become essential for efficient wireless power transfer (WPT) and data collection due to their flexible deployment. In time-sensitive LAE scenarios, maintaining data freshness is critical yet highly challenging, which highlights the age of information (AoI) as a key performance metric. Single-UAV systems suffer from limited endurance and inefficient scheduling, while existing multi-UAV frameworks often neglect the heterogeneous energy demands of ground devices (GDs) and the tight coupling among scheduling, power control, bandwidth allocation, and trajectory planning. These limitations lead to inefficient resource utilization and suboptimal AoI performance in large-scale networks. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a cooperative multi-UAV framework aiming at minimizing the average AoI. Specifically, we introduce a structured joint optimization scheme termed TRUT, comprising three stages: (i) Task location (TL) clustering and GD association via elbow-rule K-means, (ii) Resource scheduling using a genetic algorithm (GA) integrated with closed-form bandwidth allocation, and (iii) UAV trajectory optimization using an improved butterfly optimization algorithm (BOA). Simulation results confirm that our proposed TRUT significantly reduces the average AoI compared to benchmark schemes.

title: Heterogeneous Multirobot Team: Maritime Inspection and Intervention in Global Navigation Satellite System-Denied Scenarios_supp1-3639792.mp4
authors: Barbara Arbanas Ferreira
publish: N/A
abstract: Autonomous robotic systems play an increasingly important role in overcoming complex maritime challenges, where the environment requires high adaptability, robustness, and precision. Marsupial robotic systems, combining aerial systems and surface vessels, offer a powerful solution for coordinated missions in Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS)-denied scenarios, leveraging the unique capabilities of each robot to form a versatile team. This article presents a system integrating advanced sensor fusion, localization, mission planning, and communication to enable seamless collaboration between unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and autonomous surface vehicles (ASVs). The focus is on optimizing the vehicles’ interaction to efficiently locate, retrieve, and transport objects from a target vessel in an adverse sea environment. This article provides a complete system overview, including the hardware setup, algorithms used, implementation details, and field trial results. The results analysis demonstrates the advanced capabilities of the developed ASV‒UAV system in complex real-world maritime operations, underscoring its potential for coordinated multirobot tasks in environments where traditional navigation systems are unavailable. Notably, this system was developed by the team that secured first place in the Mohamed Bin Zayed International Robotic Challenge (MBZIRC), proving its excellence in challenging conditions.
