title: Short-Term Active Power Forecasting in a Photovoltaic Plant Using TiDE and LSTM Models
authors: César Andrés Mejía, Julio César Pérez, Patricio Pesántez, Carlos Gallardo, Marcelo Pozo, Oscar Camacho
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents a deep learning approach for short-term forecasting of active power in photovoltaic (PV) plants operating within islanded microgrids. Three forecasting schemes were implemented in Python using the Darts library: a baseline Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network, a Time-series Dense Encoder (TiDE) model without covariates, and a TiDE variant with exogenous inputs (solar irradiance, ambient temperature, and reactive power). Models were trained on hourly data from a 952 kW PV system on Isabela Island (Ecuador) using 2022 records. The forecasting horizon was 28 days, produced as two consecutive 336 -hour windows (14 days each). Performance was assessed with Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Mean Squared Error (MSE). The TiDE model without covariates matched the LSTM baseline in MAE while reducing MSE by $\mathbf{1 9. 4 \%}$. Including covariates did not improve accuracy but substantially decreased the number of training epochs, indicating faster convergence. These findings demonstrate that TiDE achieves competitive accuracy with lower computational cost, thereby supporting more efficient dispatch strategies in islanded and resource-constrained microgrids.

title: Reducing grid dependence in a university building: Design and feasibility of grid-connected renewable energy systems
authors: Ruben Hidalgo-León, Scarleth Vasconcelos, Miguel Torres, Jaqueline Litardo, Julio Barzola, Jorge Vega, Viviana Villavicencio, Pritpal Singh, Guillermo Soriano
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents the simulation, optimization, and techno-economic assessment of two grid-connected energy systems designed to reduce grid dependence in a university building. These systems integrate PV modules, fuel cells (FCs), H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> tank, electrolyzer, and the grid. The PV/Grid system was modeled with PV array sizes from 50 to 800 kWp, whereas the PV/Grid/FC system used sizes from 100 to 800 kW. The Renewable Fraction (RF) was the indicator used to measure grid dependence across the 17 simulated scenarios. Both systems were modeled, simulated, and optimized using Homer Pro software. Results show that the PV/Grid system with a 400 kWp PV achieved an RF of 63.8%, Net Present Cost (NPC) of USD 632,628, and Cost of Energy (COE) of USD $0.0854 / \mathrm{kWh}$. Although four other scenarios achieved higher RF values, they involved greater electricity exports to the grid without any economic return for the building administration, following applicable local electrical regulations. Similarly, among the PV/Grid/FC scenarios, the system with a 600 kWp PV achieved an RF of 78.9%, NPC of USD 1,593,881.97, and COE of USD $0.238 / \mathrm{kWh}$. Besides, results indicate that scenarios incorporating the PV/Grid/FC system exhibit lower grid dependence, as both imported and exported electricity are significantly reduced compared to PV/Grid scenarios with the same $\mathbf{P V}$ array size. A significant cost gap was observed between the conventional PV/Grid scenarios and those incorporating FCs.

title: Fuzzy Collaborative Urban Planning Recommendation System and Stakeholder Management
authors: Emanuel G. Muñoz, Genesis Alcívar, Jandre Bazurto Vinces, Jaime Meza
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Rapid urban growth and sustainability challenges demand innovative planning approaches, as traditional methods fail to address uncertainty and conflicts among stakeholders with competing interests. This paper proposes a hybrid recommendation system that combines fuzzy logic, collaborative intelligence, and digital twins to transform subjective preferences into optimal urban plans, thereby bridging the gaps left by static tools such as GIS and AHP. Methodologically, we employ a mixed-method Action Design Research framework with advanced techniques-Monte Carlo simulations, Fuzzy C-Means clustering, and Bayesian MCMC models (for XAI-validated through real-world case studies (Quito, Portoviejo) involving key stakeholders (municipalities, universities, citizens). Results demonstrate robust predictive performance (RandomForest: MSE $=1.027, \mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=\mathbf{0. 4 6}$) and uncertainty quantification ($\sigma=1.4 \pm 0.1$), enabling decisionmaking through interactive 3D dashboards and public policy simulations. Our findings highlight the potential of emerging computing paradigms (IoT, LLMs) to scale the system, with future research directions in feedback automation and agri-food supply chain modeling. This framework advances adaptive urban planning by integrating technical rigor with inclusive participation.

title: Modeling a PV System Connected to the Grid using Optimal Direct Power Control (ODPC) with ATP-EMTP and ATPDraw
authors: Jose M. Aller, Gabriel S. Orellana
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This work presents the modeling of a photovoltaic (PV) system connected to the electrical grid using an inverter that employs Optimal Direct Power Control (ODPC). The simulation is conducted in ATP-EMTP, utilizing its graphical environment, ATPDraw. The model includes the photovoltaic panel, a DCDC controller activated by a maximum power point tracking algorithm (MPPT) based on the Perturb and Observe (P&O) technique, and a three-phase inverter connected to the grid that utilizes Direct Power Control (DPC). This technique allows for the adjustment of active and reactive power setpoints to inject the maximum available power from the photovoltaic panel into the electrical grid, according to the instantaneous levels of irradiation and temperature. The developed model is useful for the design of grid-connected photovoltaic systems and demonstrates the advantages of DPC in optimizing the delivered energy and its synchronization capabilities.

title: Development of a Feeding System for Part Vetka
authors: Penko Mitev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This paper presents the process of development, production and experimental research of a feeding system for custom parts, referred to as "Vetka". The parts are intended to be used in sealing systems for transportation purposes, especially on airports ensuring that suitcases have not been open by authorized or non-authorized third-parties. The products are tightened by the users themselves once they have packed their luggage. Each product has a unique serial number and once secured, it could not be opened without being destroyed. Shown in the paper is a drawing of the part in three dimensions. A key highlight and main challenge of this study is the part’s complexity. The part is long, elastic, and made of plastic, which leads to multiple quality issues such as bending and other defects typical for automatic feeding. This unstable and flexible shape of the parts is directly related to the way they are packed and stored, before loading to the system. The purpose of this paper is to describe the development and production of two distinct system variants designed to overcome the identified quality challenges and to present productivity experiments on the final design. Polymer single components are generally causing more issues with part feeding. The realized systems are the main result, together with the productivity analysis and comparison. Among the methods for analysis is a popular methodology for assessment of the degree of suitability for automatic feeding of parts. Though too theoretical and a bit old-fashioned, it provides a good reference point for assessment of parts.

title: Model to Increase On-Time Delivery Using Predictive Maintenance 4.0, SMED, and SLP With Digital Support in a Metalworking Company
authors: Carlos Cardozo-Espinoza, Josemaria Carrion-Ninasque, Carlos Maceda-Cerdán, Giovanna Trillo-Rivera
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study analyzed order delivery delays that negatively impacted the On-Time Delivery (OTD) indicator, crucial for maintaining competitiveness in a company in the metalworking sector. The analysis identified a 17.91% technical gap in OTD, with the company’s current performance at 67.09% compared to the industry average of 85%. This delay incurs an annual economic impact of S/. 352,167.48, representing 10.87% of the company’s annual revenue. The study detailed that 79.77% of downtime is caused by machinery downtime, prolonged setup times, and unnecessary routes. To address these inefficiencies, techniques such as Predictive Maintenance 4.0 to optimize machinery, SMED to reduce setup times, and SLP with digital support to improve route efficiency were implemented. With these improvements, validated through simulation in Arena software, the company was able to increase its OTD by 25.09%, reduce machine downtime by 47.87%, setup times by 39.99%, and distance traveled by 36.56%, according to the performance indicators defined for each root cause. These results helped close the identified gap and demonstrate the effectiveness of the tools implemented in the metalworking sector.

title: Analysis of the Low Waste Recycling Rate in a District of Lima, Peru through Supply Chain Management and Integrated Waste Management
authors: Daniela Peña-Buleje, Alvaro Espinoza-Ramos, Iliana Araceli Macassi Jauregui, José C. Alvarez, Orkun Yildiz
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Poor urban solid waste management is one of the main environmental challenges in Latin America. The district of Los Olivos, located in Lima, Peru, faces a worrying situation: a low recycling rate of 1.79%, even though more than 70% of the waste is potentially recoverable. This represents a growing threat to the environment, public health, and economic sustainability. Analyzing the causes, we identified a lack of awareness campaigns, a lack of infrastructure such as recycling containers or stations, irregular collection, and below-average salaries for recyclers. The analysis was carried out through a methodological approach based on a literature review, collection of official data from institutions, and comparison with success stories from other countries. Therefore, based on the principles of Circular Economy and Sustainability, an innovative proposal is proposed that integrates Supply Chain Management and Integrated Waste Management. This approach seeks to optimize waste collection and processing through adequate logistics and raise environmental awareness among citizens. The goals are to increase recycling rates and reduce environmental impact, contributing to a more sustainable and efficient waste management system.

title: Analysing Internet of Things and Cybersecurity Impact in the Namibia Mining Industry
authors: Suama L. Hamunyela, Hiatsita Shipupeni Shinana, Iyaloo Wainganjo, Ambrose A. Azeta
publish: 2025 Cybersecurity4D (C4D)
abstract: Namibia has experienced significant digital advancements in recent years, embracing digital transformation to drive innovation, enhance competitiveness, improve the standard of living and secure the cyberspace. The evolution of the Internet of Things (IoT) has transformed human existence and working conditions, particularly within enterprises, by reducing human intervention, thereby increasing efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Despite these benefits, IoT introduces cybersecurity risks that can be exploited by cybercriminals. This study examines IoT and cybersecurity impact in the Namibian mining industry. A qualitative approach was adopted, with data collected through semi-structured interviews with eight mining personnel. Thematic analysis was used to analyse the findings, and four key themes were revealed as follows: IoT deployment in the mining sector, risks and vulnerabilities of IoT devices, challenges posed by cyber-attacks, and cybersecurity strategies for IoT in mining operations. Findings identified IoT devices such as voice hubs, smart TVs, smartwatches, automation systems, and smart lighting as commonly used in the mining industry. The findings also, highlighted key threats including physical tampering, firmware manipulation, and vulnerability exploitation, with challenges ranging from financial losses to reputational damage and risks to individual safety. The study concluded that there is a need for cohesive strategies to improve IoT cybersecurity which must include education and training, contractual agreements, and adherence to policy standards.

title: Application of neural networks to estimate the emission of polluting gases in relation to the gasoline consumption of light vehicles circulating in Metropolitan Lima, Peru
authors: Alessandra Meza, Juan Vargas Machuca, Julio Cuisano
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study proposes a predictive model to estimate emissions (HC, NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf>, CO, and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) from light-duty gasoline vehicles in Lima, Peru, based on real-world 2022 consumption data. Unlike previous studies relying on standardized models or external datasets, this work incorporates actual vehicle performance and disaggregates results by body type. Neural networks demonstrated strong generalization, achieving a correlation of $R^{2} =0.85$ for CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, while Random Forest slightly outperformed for $\mathrm{HC}, \mathrm{NO}_{x}$, and CO. The proposed framework offers a scalable, data-driven tool to enhance urban emission inventories and support air quality policy in Latin American cities.

title: Design of Website-Based Subcontractor Performance Report Information System with Design Thinking Method
authors: Nur Alim Mubarok, Muhammad Chorihuddin, Andar Sulistiana, Riyan Leandros
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: PT Pamapersada Nusantara (PAMA) is a mining contractor that collaborates with subcontractors to manage small equipment. A key challenge in this partnership is ensuring optimal Physical Availability of equipment, a critical metric for evaluating subcontractor performance. Currently, performance reporting is manual, unintegrated, and prone to inefficiencies and data inaccuracies. This study aims to design the Subcontractor Performance Report (SUPER) information system using the design thinking method, consisting of five stages: empathize, define, ideate, prototype, and test. Observations and interviews revealed several pain points, including delayed reporting, inconsistent formats among subcontractors, and limited access to real-time data. In response, a SUPER prototype was developed using Figma, featuring a unit population dashboard, Hour Meter data integration, periodic service and inspection monitoring, KPI visualization, and unit breakdown tracking. Usability testing with five users assessed effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction. All users successfully completed the tasks, with an average completion speed of 0.427 goals/ sec, indicating fast and consistent performance. The System Usability Scale scored 76, placing it in the acceptable range. These results demonstrate that the SUPER prototype meets user needs and provides tangible benefits to PAMA, including improved operational efficiency, reduced reporting errors, and faster data-driven decision-making, while supporting SDG 9 through innovation and digital transformation in mining.

title: AI Chatbot Adoption in Programming Education: An Extended TAM2 with Cybersecurity and Academic Expectations
authors: Radiana De Salma, Rio Guntur Utomo, Ayu Qatrunnada Istiqfarri
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: The rapid rise of Artificial Intelligence chatbots in programming education offers both pedagogical opportunities and cybersecurity challenges. This study examines Indonesian STEM students’ acceptance of AI chatbots through an extended Technology Acceptance Model 2 (TAM2), which is used for programming learning with academic motivation while security issues are a concern. TAM2 was selected for its incorporation of output quality, where critical in programming where students evaluate AI-generated code accuracy, and its parsimonious framework directly linking perceived usefulness and ease of use to behavioral intention. Four contextual factors were integrated: Perceived Cybersecurity Risk (PCR), Expected Academic Achievement (EAA), Output Quality (Q), and SelfEfficacy (SE). Using PLS-SEM on 400 valid responses from six regions in Indonesia, findings show that Perceived Usefulness and Expected Academic Achievement are the strongest predictors of intention to use, while Self-Efficacy drives ease of use. PCR revealed a dual effect: reducing adoption intention yet unexpectedly increasing perceived usefulness, indicating security-conscious students apply more sophisticated evaluation frameworks. The model explained 51.7% of variance in intention and 52.4% in usefulness. Findings reveal that programming students adopt AI chatbots through pragmatic, outcome-oriented perspectives prioritizing demonstrable academic benefits, contributing to technology acceptance theory by exposing complex risk-benefit tradeoffs in high-cognition learning environments.

title: Minimizing Packaging Boxes in Online Retail Fulfillment Using Multi-Strategy Heuristics and Extreme-Point Based 3D Bin Packing
authors: Widiq Waskito Adimukti, Samuel Ady Sanjaya
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: The rapid expansion of online retail has created challenges in packaging efficiency, where inappropriate box selection and item placement lead to higher logistics costs, wasted space, and reduced sustainability. This study aims to minimize the number of boxes used per order while improving space utilization by formulating the problem as a 3D Bin Packing Problem (3D-BPP). To address this objective, three heuristic approaches are evaluated the Greedy Heuristic (GH), Multi-Strategy Heuristic (MSH), and Extreme-Point (EP) methods. Using real operational data of up to $\mathbf{1 0, 0 0 0}$ historical orders, the framework assesses each method’s trade-offs in box utilization, space efficiency, and computational performance. Experimental results show that the EP method achieves the lowest box usage and stable runtime performance, reducing box requirements by more than $65 \%$ compared to GH while maintaining comparable air-gap efficiency. MSH provides competitive compactness through iterative refinements but produces slightly higher air gaps due to its adaptive search process. The study also reveals that persistent air gaps largely stem from limitations in the company’s box catalog, suggesting the need for catalog redesign to better match item dimensions. These findings highlight the importance of integrating box catalog optimization with algorithmic design. The proposed framework provides a comprehensive empirical benchmark and practical guidance for developing data-driven, cost-efficient, and packaging strategies in high-volume fulfillment operations.

title: Main Electrical Requirements and Their Implementations to Achieve the Decarbonation of The Cement Plants
authors: Xavier d’Hubert, Joe Riley
publish: 2023 IEEE-IAS/PCA Cement Industry Conference (IAS/PCA)
abstract: This paper continues to explore the journey toward decarbonation of the cement industry, at the plant level, from the point of view of the additional energy requirement that will be required and how projects might be handled by external companies. It references to previously written articles and presentation:•Microgrid for Cement Plants - based on IEEE PCA 2019 St Louis – May 2019•Microgrid for Cement Plants, the Hydrogen parameter - IEEE PCA 2021 virtual - May 2021•The (In)direct Electrification of the Cement Industry: The Contribution of Waste Heat Recovery Projects. – IEEE PCA 2022 – Las Vegas May 2022We look – through their sustainability reports - at the global strategy of some major cement groups and how many of them are extending their businesses both vertically and horizontally. However, the focus is on the practical ways these cement companies will realize their carbon neutrality objectives by 2050, following the guidelines and announcements of the trade organization such as the PCA, Cembureau, FICEM, GCCA, … In other words, translating lofty goals into actual projects, especially those "lower hanging fruit" to be realized by 2030.We review the massive future electricity demand for a cement plant to decarbonize, from the oxy-combustion route that would require an ASU air separation unit, to the hydrogen route that would require electrolyzers, to the various carbon capture technologies themselves, including CO2 purification compression, liquefaction, but primarily to the "carbon capture flue gas readiness" that will require new APC investment to allow and optimize carbon capture projects to actually be realized.As a result of all those none-core up-coming requirements, the amount of resources, expertise, time, CAPEX to be needed is such that it is likely that third-party companies the so-called EaaS [Energy as a Service] or Decarbonation [DaaS] or Resilience aaS [RaaS] or even Environmental Compliance [ECaaS] will actually execute those projects. Some current and past projects will be used to illustrate this trend.

title: Urban Vehicle Emission Modeling using Machine Learning with OBD/GPS Data and comparison with IVE and EURO 6 Standards
authors: Daniel Israel Ortega Rodas, Blanca Del Valle Arenas-Ramírez, Diego Patricio Rivera Guachichulca, Néstor Diego Rivera Campoverde
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This research focuses on modeling urban vehicle emissions using machine learning techniques applied to OBD and GPS data, aiming to overcome the limitations of traditional models such as IVE and EURO 6 standards. The implemented methodology included collecting emissions, GPS, and OBD data under real-world driving conditions along two Real Driving Emissions routes in Cuenca, Ecuador. A machine learning model was trained using data from the first route, followed by validation using data from the second route. The results were encouraging: the OBD-based model achieved a coefficient of determination ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$) of $\mathbf{0. 9 4 7}$ for $\mathbf{C O}_{\mathbf{2}}, \mathbf{0. 9 3 1}$ for $\mathbf{C O}$, and $\mathbf{0. 9 2 8}$ for $\mathrm{NO}_{\mathrm{x}}$, demonstrating high predictive accuracy compared to direct measurements obtained using a PEMS system. Meanwhile, the GPS based model, which estimated dynamic variables such as longitudinal acceleration and road gradient, achieved $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ values of $\mathbf{0. 9 1 6}$ for $\mathbf{C O}_{\mathbf{2}}, \mathbf{0. 8 9 5}$ for $\mathbf{C O}$, and $\mathbf{0. 8 9 1}$ for $\mathrm{NO}_{\mathrm{x}}$. The emission factors estimated by the OBD model were $\mathbf{1 7 1. 6 g} \boldsymbol{g} / \mathbf{k m}$ for $\mathbf{C O}_{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{1. 5 8 ~ g} / \mathbf{k m}$ for $\mathbf{C O}$, and $\mathbf{0. 2 3 ~ g} / \mathbf{k m}$ for $\mathbf{N O}_{\mathbf{x}}$, with absolute deviations of less than 6% compared to field measurements. The GPS model provided similar emission factors: $\mathbf{1 7 6. 2 ~ g} / \mathbf{k m}$ for $\mathbf{C O}_{\mathbf{2}}, \mathbf{1. 7 1 ~ g} / \mathbf{k m}$ for CO, and $\mathbf{0. 2 6 ~ g} / \mathbf{k m}$ for $\mathrm{NO}_{\mathrm{x}}$ further confirming the robustness of both methodologies. These results not only validate the accuracy of the models but also highlight their relevance in estimating emissions in urban contexts, adapting to the specific topography and climate conditions of Cuenca. As such, their use is recommended for developing emission inventories and designing more suitable urban mobility policies, instead of relying on international models such as IVE, which often overestimate emissions under local conditions especially in areas with unique altitudes and driving patterns.

title: Probabilistic Cyber Threat Modelling for Remote Commands of System Integrity Protection Scheme
authors: Monazzah Ebrahimi Gardeshi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: System Integrity Protection Schemes (SIPS) mitigate operational challenges in power systems but increase the risk of cyber-attacks. Previous works in the literature primarily focus on improving security within the SIPS perimeter. However, research on SIPS commands to remote sites remains limited. Furthermore, current studies overlook the distributional ambiguity of cyber-attacks, limiting the ability to assess risk comprehensively. To address this gap, this paper proposes a STRIDE-based threat modelling framework that leverages the Wasserstein metric to characterise variability in the probabilistic impacts of cyber threats. Based on the probabilistic impacts, this paper introduces the threat exposure scores for ranking the vulnerable elements within a cyber-physical system (CPS) and the threat categories. The proposed framework is applied when SIPS sends commands to offshore wind farms to limit their generation after the failure of the transmission line. We decomposed the system into 27 critical components in cyber layer modelling and defined 205 attack vectors. We used the IEEE 24 bus test system to model power system response to cyber-attacks. Threat exposure scores are computed based on probabilistic impacts, attack persistence, and attack sophistication, considering a 5% acceptable ambiguity in the attack characterisation. Simulation results of attack vectors reveal that Elevation of Privilege and Information Disclosure are the most critical threats capable of halting SIPS commands to offshore wind farms. The proposed approach for characterising the probabilistic impacts of cyber threats can be used for different types of SIPS and other power system architectures, providing a practical tool for threat assessment in complex CPS.

title: A Multidimensional Approach to Assessing the Progress of IT's Success in the Process of Digitalization
authors: Daniela Borissova, Zornitsa Dimitrova, Radoslav Yoshinov, Magdalena Garvanova, Ivan Garvanov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Digital transformation not only improves workplace efficiency and customer satisfaction but also plays a key role in ensuring a sustainable future. IT success is of utmost importance, as it is related to various aspects of a company’s activities. Successful IT strategies allow businesses to innovate by using new technologies, which contribute to adapting to changing market conditions. That is why the article analyses five groups of indicators by which the success or failure of the IT used can be assessed. These indicators are integrated into a proposed measure that determines a generalized index of IT success. The results of the tests conducted in a medium-sized IT company unequivocally prove the applicability of the proposed approach to assessing IT success. The described results can be helpful for managers and consultants in preparing various reports and assessments related to digital transformation.

title: Bidirectional Step-Down/Step-Up DC/DC Converter with Two Selectable Energy Sources – Computer Investigation
authors: Hristo Antchev, Dimitar Borisov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The article discusses a bidirectional step-down/step-up converter of direct current to direct current (DC/DC) with the ability to operate from several energy storage elements. A characteristic feature is the inclusion of additional transistors to these elements, which are controlled by an appropriate algorithm. The goal is to be able to select both the element from which energy will be consumed and the element to which energy will be returned. The studies was done through computer simulation in different modes. The simulation schemes containing the main elements of the control and regulation system are presented. The necessary feedback loops are provided for stabilizing certain variables. The results of the computer simulation when operating with two elements - an ultracapacitor and a rechargeable battery are presented.

title: Comparison of Geoinformatics Tools for Hydrological Modeling of Floods
authors: Marian Dobransky, Kristian Micko, Pavol Purcz
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This study evaluates geoinformatic tools for hydrological modeling of floods, with a focus on advancements in digital terrain modeling (DTM), hydrodynamic simulation, and the integration of artificial intelligence. Utilizing data from the Hornad River in Slovakia, the research highlights the role of high-resolution geodetic surveys and remote sensing technologies, including multispectral cameras and LiDAR, in enhancing flood risk assessment. Key methodologies include the generation of bathymetric models, roughness maps, and integration with hydrodynamic software such as HEC-RAS versions 6.5 and the new RAS 2025 Alpha. The findings emphasize the improvements in computational efficiency and accuracy enabled by the new mesh generation capabilities of RAS 2025, reducing preprocessing time and handling high-resolution geodetic data effectively. Comparative analyses demonstrate similar modeling outcomes between the new and previous versions, despite the simplified calibration. The study also explores the application of neural networks for roughness mapping, utilizing Land Cover Segmentation models to refine hydrological inputs. While the results validate the feasibility of using RAS 2025 for advanced flood modeling, limitations due to the lack of calibrated historical flood data are noted.

title: Dynamite: Real-Time Debriefing Slide Authoring through AI-Enhanced Multimodal Interaction
authors: Panayu Keelawat, David Barron, Kaushik Narasimhan, Daniel Manesh, Xiaohang Tang, Xi Chen, Sang Won Lee, Yan Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Facilitating class-wide debriefings after small-group discussions is a common strategy in ethics education. Instructor interviews revealed that effective debriefings should highlight frequently discussed themes and surface underrepresented viewpoints, making accurate representations of insight occurrence essential. Yet authoring presentations in real time is cognitively overwhelming due to the volume of data and tight time constraints. We present Dynamite, an AI-assisted system that enables semantic updates to instructor-authored slides during live classroom discussions. These updates are powered by semantic data binding, which links slide content to evolving discussion data, and semantic suggestions, which offer revision options aligned with pedagogical goals. In a within-subject in-lab study with 12 participants, Dynamite outperformed a text-based AI baseline in content accuracy and quality. Participants used voice and sketch input to quickly organize semantic blocks, then applied suggestions to accelerate refinement as data stabilized.

title: Systematic Mapping of Mobile Technologies for the Promotion of Local Tourism
authors: Juan Sebastian Lemus Jacome, Kevin Hernando Lobo Ortiz, Yesenia Aréniz Arévalo, Dewar Rico-Bautista
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This article presents a systematic mapping study of mobile technologies adopted in local tourism, with emphasis on Ocaña, Colombia. Forty-four primary studies from 20152024 were reviewed to find trends, strategies, limitations, and integration of culture. Findings reveal that geolocation, interactive maps, and augmented reality are the most common technologies, and diverse strategies reflect opportunities and limitations to promote local tourism. The research contribution is to provide an evidence-based review that informs future technological solutions toward sustainable tourism development.

title: Social Incentive and Solution Reliability: Evidence from Crowdsourcing Competitions
authors: Fan Zhang, Shan Liu, Baojun Gao, Qing Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Crowdsourcing competitions are increasingly used by firms to tackle internal R&D tasks; however, the reliability of solutions generated through these competitions remains underexplored. This study examines how social incentives influence solution reliability in such contests. Drawing on the attention-based view (ABV) and the exploration-exploitation (E- E) framework, we frame social incentives as attentional cues that redirect participants' focus toward socially visible performance metrics. This shift in attention can disrupt the balance between optimizing explicit performance and maintaining implicit reliability. To test this hypothesis, we leverage a natural experiment on a machine learning contest platform, where the introduction of a “following” feature generated exogenous variation in users' exposure to social incentives. Our empirical results indicate that this feature negatively affects solution reliability. The robustness of this finding is confirmed through multiple checks, including assessments of parallel trends, placebo tests, difference-in-difference-in-differences models, regression discontinuity in time analyses, and instrumental variables. Further analyses reveal that participants who gained followers or followed others submitted more solutions; however, these submissions were less reliable. Notably, high competition intensity mitigated this negative effect. This study contributes to the engineering management literature by addressing a crucial but understudied aspect of crowdsourced R&D projects: solution reliability. By integrating the E-E framework with ABV, it also advances research on open innovation by framing reliability as an attentional outcome shaped by social incentives rather than as a purely technical attribute. Overall, the findings reveal an unintended consequence of social incentives and provide actionable guidance for managers overseeing crowdsourced R&D initiatives.

title: Optimizing the p- Type Conductivity of Sub-10-nm NiO x Films, for Improved Device Characteristics, Ultra-Low Gate Leakage and High Threshold-Voltage Shift of Oxide-Gated GaN/AlGaN HEMTs
authors: Pinki Pal, Umang Singh, Swagata Bhunia, Apurba Laha, Suddhasatta Mahapatra
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: The inclusion of a p-type conducting nickel-oxide (NiO ${}_{x}\text {)}$ layer in the gate-stack is a promising method to induce large positive threshold-voltage (V Th) shift in as-fabricated depletion-mode (D-mode) GaN/AlGaN high-electron-mobility transistors (HEMTs). The inclusion of relatively thick NiO x layers in the gate-stack, in combination with either gate recession, or use of thin AlGaN top-barrier layers, has also enabled enhancement-mode (E-mode) operation in some cases. In this work, we demonstrate that a large threshold-voltage shift can be obtained even with a sub-10-nm-thick NiO x layer, provided the deposition parameters are carefully optimized for a high p-type conductivity of the oxide. In comparison to previous reports, we demonstrate that the use of a thin NiO x layer, and a sufficiently thick AlGaN top-barrier layer, allows significant improvement of almost all performance metrics of the resultant oxide-gated HEMTs. Albeit that the NiO x layer used in this work is the thinnest reported so far, we also measured the lowest gate-leakage current density. Additionally, both the threshold voltage and the gate-leakage current are observed to be fairly insensitive to a rise in the operating temperature, up to 473 K. Therefore, these results bode extremely well for the realization of E-mode GaN/AlGaN HEMTs, without thinning of the top-barrier layer, and thereby compromising the device characteristics.

title: Cooperative Stochastic MPC Under Hard Input Constraints and Event-Triggered Communication
authors: Irene Perez-Salesa, Dimos V. Dimarogonas, Carlos Sagüés, Rodrigo Aldana-López
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems
abstract: In this work, we develop a new distributed output- feedback stochastic model predictive control (SMPC) proposal for a plant that is cooperatively regulated by a set of actuator nodes. Contrary to most approaches, we consider hard constraints on the actuators, and we appropriately tighten the constraints to ensure recursive feasibility with a given probability, despite the stochastic noise present in the system. To lighten the communication load, the constraint design is performed offline and an event-triggering mechanism is included, so that the nodes only need to transmit their local state estimates to neighbors at event instants during online execution. We prove constraint satisfaction and stability of our proposal, and we include simulation results showing that similar control performance to the centralized case can be achieved by our distributed SMPC with reduced communication.

title: A Unified Convergence Analysis of Decentralized Federated Learning at the Edge
authors: Chengyan Jiang, Jiamin Fan, Talal Halabi, Israat Haque
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) reshapes the AI model training paradigm by enabling privacy-preserving collaborative learning, where models are trained across distributed clients without sharing raw data, but only model parameters or updates. This learning can be centralized or distributed. Centralized FL (CFL) may suffer from latency and lack of robustness due to the reliance on a coordinating server for model convergence. On the other hand, Decentralized Federated Learning (DFL) enables direct collaboration among participating devices without relying on a central server. Each device can independently connect to other devices and share model parameters. In such collaborative training paradigm, model convergence in the presence of various deployment topologies, AI model types, Non-IID data distribution, and training strategies demands systematic analysis to realize their practical deployment in critical applications such as intelligent transportation, smart factories, and real-time surveillance. Some works have attempted to conduct only partial analysis and completely neglected incorporating Non-IID data distribution, a critical factor in practical deployment of DFL in mentioned applications. This work conducts a systematic analysis on the convergence of DFL considering a wide range of AI models (e.g., classical, deep neural networks, and Large Language Models), network topologies (e.g., linear, ring, star, and mesh), training strategies (e.g., continuous and aggregate), and degree of Non-IID data distributions. The analysis includes both mathematical formulations and their implementation and evaluation using real-world data. The results confirm that the convergence rate of the models is inversely proportional to the degree of Non-IID data distribution. Moreover, judicial selection of network topologies and training strategies can aid in this convergence process for the practical edge deployment of DFL.

title: Leveraging Simultaneous Usage of Edge GPU Hardware Engines for Video Face Detection and Recognition
authors: Asma Baobaid, Mahmoud Meribout
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computing
abstract: Video face detection and recognition in public places at the edge is required in several applications, such as security reinforcement and contactless access to authorized venues. This paper aims to maximize the simultaneous usage of hardware engines available in edge GPUs nowadays by leveraging the concurrency and pipelining of tasks required for face detection and recognition. This also includes the video decoding task, which is required in most face monitoring applications as the video streams are usually carried via Gbps Ethernet network. This constitutes an improvement over previous works where the tasks are usually allocated to a single engine due to the lack of a unified and automated framework that simultaneously explores all hardware engines. In addition, previously, the input faces were usually embedded in still images or within raw video streams that overlook the burst delay caused by the decoding stage. The results on real-life video streams suggest that simultaneously using all the hardware engines available in the recent NVIDIA edge Orin GPU, higher throughput, and a slight saving of GPU engine power consumption of around 300 mW, accounting for around 5%, have been achieved while satisfying the real-time performance constraint. The performance gets even higher by considering several video streams simultaneously. Further performance improvement could have been obtained if the number of shuffle layers that were created by the TensorRT framework for the face recognition task was lower. Thus, the paper suggests some hardware improvements to the existing edge GPU processors to enhance their performance even higher.

title: A Thermal and System Analysis of SoC-Memory 3D Stacking using Massive Orthogonal Stacking Assembly
authors: Hung-Chih Huang, Masaya Kawano, Yuki Mitarai, Mototsugu Hamada, Atsutake Kosuge
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: A novel chip stacking method with low thermal resistance for 3D integration of a large number of memory chips and processor chips is proposed, namely Massive Orthogonal Stacking Assembly of IC (MOSAIC) technology. Through thermal resistance analysis, it is possible to achieve a high effective thermal conductivity of 0.88 W/(cm·K) and low operational temperature with 60 chips stacked on a GPU. This represents three times the number of chips compared to conventional parallel chip stacking. While MOSAIC exhibits good heat dissipation capability, there is a strong trade-off between heat dissipation capability and system performance. To gain a systematic understanding of the MOSAIC system, a thermal model analysis is developed. This provides designers with an optimal solution for MOSAIC design that satisfies both good heat dissipation capability and SoC performance.

title: A Stochastic Geometric Analysis on Multi-Cell Pinching-Antenna Systems Under Blockage Effect
authors: Yanshi Sun, Zhiguo Ding, George K. Karagiannidis
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Recently, the study on pinching-antenna technique has attracted significant attention. However, most relevant literature focuses on a single-cell scenario, where the effect from the interfering pinching-antennas on waveguides connected to spatially distributed base stations (BSs) was ignored. To fulfill this knowledge gap, this letter aims to provide an analytical framework on performance evaluation for multi-cell pinching-antenna systems where spatially distributed waveguides which are connected to different BSs are considered. In particular, tools from stochastic geometry is applied for system modeling. The expression for the outage probability is obtained. Simulation results are provided to verify the accuracy of the analysis and demonstrate the superior performance of pinching-antenna system compared to fixed-antenna systems.

title: Reliability Study of AlInGaAs Strained Multi Quantum Well O-band Laser Source
authors: Horacio I. Cantú, Antonio Samarelli, Iain Eddie
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: The reliability of a ridge waveguide AlInGaAs strained O-band InP laser design is characterized by means of 10 khrs of accelerated life test. Multiple stress conditions are used to estimate the device wear-out activation energy and bias current exponential factor using the Eyring equation. Time to failure for each stressed device is obtained from the parametric accelerated life test data. The laser operation bias current degradation is used to extract failure distributions. These distributions agree well with lognormal fits and are used to calculate the wear-out activation energy and bias current exponential factor. An activation energy and an exponential factor above 1.5 eV and 3, respectively, are obtained from operation bias current degradation analysis. Based on five stress conditions calculated acceleration factors, single digit failures in time are expected after 10 years of continuous operation.

title: Polarization Controlled Dual-Polarized MIMO Antenna With Enhanced Isolation for Full-Duplex WBANs
authors: Ajeet Thakur, Ashwani Sharma, Ignacio J. Garcia Zuazola
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A polarization controlled dual-polarized multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) antenna with enhanced isolation for full-duplex wireless body area network (WBAN) in the 5.8 GHz industrial, scientific, and medical (ISM) band is proposed. The advanced polarization control of each antenna element comprising the MIMO antenna is realized by embedding tailored T-shaped strips within the transversal slots of a main diagonal cut in the ground plane, which effectively steer the surface currents to a favorable direction to achieve the desired polarization with enhanced isolation. By slotting the twin circular patch radiating elements and incorporating twin capacitively coupled stepped elements adjacent to their feeding terminals, the proposed low-profile design realizes good impedance matching, return loss, and bandwidth. Experimental results demonstrate isolation greater than 5 dB compared with existing designs, and we report inter-port isolation that exceeds 33 dB for the 150 MHz bandwidth, with a peak isolation of approximately 67 dB. As a result, the proposed antenna exhibits low envelope correlation coefficient (ECC), high diversity gain (DG), and acceptable total active reflection coefficient (TARC) and channel capacity loss (CCL). A prototype antenna was tested under structural deformation by bending it along a -45∘ direction, with a simulated specific absorption rate (SAR) of 0.258 W/kg on a human phantom, thereby validating the antenna’s compliance with safety standards. The findings of this study demonstrate that the proposed design effectively addresses critical challenges in full-duplex WBAN antennas by enhancing port isolation, minimizing mutual coupling, and advancing polarization control, while maintaining a low-profile and low-complexity feeding network structure.

title: A Self-Alignment Method for Vehicle-Mounted MEMS IMU
authors: Lingtong Zhong, Xiaosu Xu, Yiqing Yao, Tao Zhang
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: To address the challenges of initial heading alignment for the conventional vehicle-mounted microelectromechanical system (MEMS) inertial measurement unit (IMU) in satellite-denied and magnetically disturbed environments, this article proposes a novel iterative self-alignment method that eliminates the reliance on precision rotating mechanisms. First, based on observability analysis, a flexible stop-turn-stop strategy is designed for self-alignment. By reusing data to maintain virtual rotation, the alignment time is significantly reduced. Second, an online iterative progressive compensation method for IMU bias is developed, allowing zero-velocity and zero-angular-rate corrections during vehicle stationarity. This enables autonomous bias compensation without external assistance. Finally, the proposed algorithm is validated through simulations, turntable experiments, and vehicle tests. The results demonstrate the effectiveness and reliability of the method, achieving a breakthrough in heading self-alignment for conventional medium- to high-grade MEMS IMUs and providing a new solution for its application in complex environments.
