title: An Ensemble Forecasting Approach for Dynamic Allocation in Collective Self-Consumption Schemes
authors: Joan Tomàs Villalonga-Palou, Javier Serano González, Jesús Manuel Riquelme Santos, Antonio Maia de Jesus Chaves Neto
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Collective self-consumption schemes usually require dynamic sharing coefficients—hourly allocation ratios per customer—to be submitted during the month preceding settlement. This makes reliable month-ahead, hour-by-hour demand forecasts essential. This paper proposes a practical framework to generate such forecasts from historical data and to derive allocation coefficients compliant with the submission requirement. Several persistence-based predictors are used to capture recent individual-load behavior, and their outputs are combined through an ensemble that learns data-driven weights from past errors with the aim of improving upon the individual predictors. The approach is evaluated on real hourly data for 15 residential customers, showing a satisfactory performance of the proposed method compared with the individual predictors and results that are acceptably close to a theoretical baseline in which loads are assumed to be known in advance.

title: Decision Making System for Image Filtering Algorithms Based on MCDM and Artificial Intelligent
authors: Georgi Mihalev, Elena Monova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The article examines the problem of selecting an image filtering algorithm in machine vision systems. By defining appropriate criteria that most significantly affect the efficiency of the implemented algorithms and applying a method based on MCDM and artificial intelligence, the task of optimal selection through a generalized utility function is solved. The considered algorithms are implemented and applied to a test image in a MATLAB environment. Some basic functional dependencies related to MCDM are presented. The obtained results are shown graphically, with the use of AI playing a positive role by eliminating the subjective factor in determining the objective function while maintaining a high degree of significance among the opinions.

title: A Type Language for Blockly
authors: Robin Stunic, Friedrich Steimann
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Google’s Blockly library provides rudimentary support for types that constrain how blocks can be connected to form larger fragments. We argue that Blockly’s current type language does not reach beyond the level of context-freeness, and show how this can be changed — in a non-disruptive way — by adopting elements from attribute grammar and constraint-based typing. We demonstrate the generality of our approach by applying it to different languages, and describe our implementation and integration into Blockly.

title: Affordances of Sketched Notations for Multimodal UI Design and Development Tools
authors: Sam H. Ross, Yunseo Lee, Coco K. Lee, Jayne Everson, R. Benjamin Shapiro
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Multimodal UI design and development tools that interpret sketches or natural language descriptions of UIs inherently have notations: the inputs they can understand. In AI-based systems, notations are implicitly defined by the data used to train these systems. In order to create usable and intuitive notations for interactive design systems, we must regard, design, and evaluate these training datasets as notation specifications. To better understand the design space of notational possibilities for future design tools, we use the Cognitive Dimensions of Notations framework to analyze two possible notations for UI sketching. The first notation is the sketching rules for an existing UI sketch dataset, and the second notation is the set of sketches generated by participants in this study, where individuals sketched UIs without imposed representational rules. We imagine two systems, FixedSketch and FlexiSketch, built with each notation respectively, in order to understand the differential affordances of, and potential design requirements for, systems. We find that participants’ sketches were composed of element-level notations that are ambiguous in isolation but are interpretable in context within whole designs. For many cognitive dimensions, the FlexiSketch notation supports greater intuitive creative expression and affords lower cognitive effort than the FixedSketch notation, but cannot be supported with prevailing, element-based approaches to UI sketch recognition. We argue that for future multimodal design tools to be truly human-centered, they must adopt contemporary AI methods, including transformer-based and human-in-the-loop, reinforcement learning techniques to understand users’ context-rich expressive notations and corrections.

title: Comparative Analysis of Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Welded Joints in HSLA Steels ASTM A1011 and ASTM A500: Implications for Legal Liability and Regulatory Compliance
authors: Welligton Vladimir Poveda Almeida, Oswaldo Javier Alajo Chicaiza, María Belén Paredes Robalino, Alejandra Marlene Lascano Moreta
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study presents a comparative analysis of the microstructure and mechanical properties of welded joints in HSLA steels ASTM A1011 Gr 50 and ASTM A500 Gr C. The research evaluates whether ASTM A1011, with its superior mechanical properties and corrosion resistance, constitutes a viable alternative to ASTM A500 Gr C, a material commonly employed in the manufacture of bus bodies in Ecuador, which are characterized by being robust and heavy. The study focuses on two specific welding processes applied to a representative joint configuration, selected from a section of the metallic structure of domestically manufactured bus bodies. The extracted samples were subjected to tensile strength, ductility, toughness, microstructural, and hardness tests to determine the properties influencing joint performance. The findings reveal significant differences in the mechanical properties of welded joints between the base materials. Microstructural analysis shows an increase in carbon content within the fusion zone of the welded joints, mainly due to metallic inclusion from the filler wire used. Furthermore, the results are correlated with the requirements established by the applicable ASTM standards and the legal implications associated with the fabrication of welded structures under Ecuadorian regulations.

title: Development of an Autonomous and Adaptive Wheelchair for Navigating Urban Sidewalks
authors: Galo Alexander Guerrero Encalada, Mathews Castillo Guerrero, Pablo Salamea Cordero
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: In urban sectors such as Cuenca, Ecuador, people with motor disabilities face significant architectural barriers such as elevated sidewalks, lack of ramps and surface irregularities. In response to this problem, an intelligent and autonomous electric wheelchair is proposed, capable of detecting, analyzing and overcoming sidewalks of up to 20 cm without external assistance. The system incorporates RGB-D cameras, sensors such as accelerometers, gyroscopes and ultrasonics, and deep learning algorithms managed by a Raspberry Pi embedded unit for real-time autonomous navigation. Its design includes a scissor-type front lifting mechanism or articulated arm to safely traverse urban curbs and slopes, with a strong and lightweight structure made of 6061-T6 aluminum and carbon fiber reinforced polymers. In addition, low-consumption brushless motors (BLDC) and lithium-ion batteries are used to ensure extended autonomy in complex urban environments. This proposal represents a technological and social advance towards more inclusive cities, aligning with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG 10 and 11). The system was validated through machine learning-based torque predictions and classical physics models, showing up to 15% higher accuracy in dynamic conditions. Additionally, simulations with users of different body masses (60–100 kg) confirmed safe and adaptive performance, reinforcing the robustness of the proposed design compared to existing commercial solutions.

title: Implementation and validation of a clinical decision support system for quantifying plantar contact areas in podiatry
authors: Juan José Narváez Zambrano, Daniel Alberto Andrade Rivera, Patricio Fernado Urgiles Ortíz
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The present study demonstrates the MV 7000 digital podoscope’s effectiveness in precisely analyzing foot prints using advanced image processing technologies. The system uses an algorithm that combines adaptive shading, Gaussian filtering, and morphological operations to optimize segmentation, with a notable innovation to the previous work: the dynamic threshold control that automatically adjusts parameters to maximize contrast. The results of validation against ImageJ (reference standard) showed a 95% concordance with an average error of 3.49%, within the clinically acceptable margin (5%). The metric calibration achieves a spatial resolution of $14.15009 \mathrm{px} / \mathrm{cm}$, guaranteeing accuracy in measurements. The analysis of 50 plantar images confirms the robustness of the system in contour detection and calculation areas, supported by a strong statistical correlation $(r=0.990, R 2=0.979)$. These results validate the reliability of the MV 7000 for possible clinical applications, including quantification of pressure areas and morphological analysis, with potential to implement convolutional neural networks (CNN) in future developments for automated classification of pathological patterns.

title: Ontology-driven Feature Engineering For Machine Learning
authors: Daniela Jiménez, Ricardo Flores-Moyano, Noel Pérez, Diego Benítez, José Vega-Sánchez
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study proposes an ontology based feature engineering methodology to enhance the performance and interpretability of machine learning models. By developing an educational ontology structured around a student performance dataset, semantic structures were integrated into the processing pipeline to conceptually group and justify data attributes. Different models were implemented and compared across three tasks: final g rade p rediction, a cademic p erformance classification, and anomaly detection, contrasting traditional approaches with ontology-enhanced versions. While statistical models outperformed the quantitative metrics, the ontology-driven models proved competitive, more structured, and offered greater traceability. This study highlights the potential of ontologies as a complementary tool for machine learning, particularly in contexts where knowledge sustainability is crucial. This project establishes a foundation for further applications in educational domains and other areas involving high semantic complexity.

title: Transformer Model Benchmarking for DomainSpecific NLP: Insights from Cultural Heritage and History Texts
authors: Tri Lathif Mardi Suryanto, Aji Prasetya Wibawa, Hariyono, Andrew Nafalski
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Although Transformer-based technologies have pioneered the advancement of Natural Language Processing (NLP), the evaluation of such technologies in specific niche fields is notably lacking. The purpose of this research is to evaluate the BERT-base, DistilBERT, RoBERTa-base, RoBerta-large, and ALBERT-BASE V2 models in relation to the peculiarities of the language and the context of the cultural and historical texts. F1, recall, precision, BERTScore, and F1, BERTScore metrics proved the highest results to be BERT-base (F1 0.915, BERTScore 0.897), confirming statistical significance with Bootstrap Resampling and McNemar’s Test. In the relation of domain specific interpretative weaknesses, it was found that RoBERT did the best, with sarcasm proving to be problematic for BERT and long narratives for DistilBERT. There is little previous research on benchmarking Transformers for cultural heritage, and this research sheds light on the area, providing a balance between the accuracy and the needed computational resources. This research aims to deepen the understanding and to implement the storing and the explanation of the historical and cultural knowledge.

title: From Simulation to Reality: A Digital Twin Implementation of a 4-DOF Robotic Manipulator
authors: Bryan S. Guevara, José Varela-Aldás, Viviana Moya, Angéelica Veróonica Quito Carrióon, Marcelo Ortiz
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive and reproducible workflow for the development of a digital twin of a 4-degree-of-freedom (4-DOF) robotic manipulator, designed in the context of an online educational course. The process begins with the creation of a computer-aided design (CAD) model of the robot, which is then exported to the Unified Robot Description Format (URDF) for integration into a simulation environment. A classical kinematic controller is implemented to perform Cartesian trajectory tracking, demonstrating the interaction between robot geometry and motion control. The proposed methodology emphasizes modularity, accessibility, and educational value, enabling students and researchers to simulate and validate robotic behaviors without requiring physical hardware. All resources, including 3D models, code, and course materials, are openly available in a public GitHub repository to encourage replication and further development. This work provides an accessible foundation for hands-on robotics education and reproducible research.

title: A Comparative Study of Deep Learning Approaches for Apple Leaf Disease Classification
authors: Brian Marcellino, Nasywa Hilmi Cahyono, M. Aldiki Febriantono
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Apple production is declining due to diseases, particularly those affecting the leaves. These diseases spread rapidly, making accurate identification crucial for early control. This study compares the performance of four deep learning classification models for classifying apple leaf diseases. The datasets used are from three publicly available datasets that consist of different leaf conditions, diseased and healthy. The results of the experiment demonstrated that InceptionV3 achieved the best results across all datasets. The InceptionV3 had 98.89% accuracy on Apple Leaf Disease Symptoms dataset and 96.67% accuracy on the AppleLeaf9 dataset as well as 82.08% on the Kashmir dataset. Contrastively, InceptionV3 achieved the best accuracy ($82.08 \%$) with the Kashmir dataset compared to other models, ResNet50 at $80.00 \%$, EfficientNetB0 at $73.96 \%$, and MobileNetV2 at $66.04 \%$. Although the InceptionV3 is highly accurate, the computational power required for training is high, making it a challenge to consider especially if running on a less capable device. All datasets are publicly available, links are provided in the paper to support reproducibility. These findings provide a rigorous baseline and practical guidance for selecting architectures for orchard scale monitoring and motivate future work on lightweight models.

title: Minimizing E-commerce Order Cancellation Cost Using Shap-based Explainable XGBoost
authors: Angelin, Samuel Ady Sanjaya
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: E-commerce has experienced rapid growth in recent years, offering convenience and accessibility to millions of consumers worldwide. However, this growth also brings operational challenges for businesses, among which order cancellations have emerged as a significant concern. Cancellations not only disrupt logistics and inventory management but also increase operational costs and reduce customer trust, affecting overall business performance. This study proposes a framework for predicting and explaining order cancellations in e-commerce by combining machine learning with Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) techniques. A dataset of 6,372,704 unique orders was used, incorporating order-related, customer-related, and operational features. Three machine learning algorithms, XGBoost, Random Forest, and Logistic Regression, were evaluated using metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC AUC score. The evaluation shows that XGBoost achieved the best performance, slightly outperforming Random Forest. Meanwhile, Logistic Regression performed poorly, particularly in terms of the precision score. SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations) was then applied to interpret the XGBoost model, revealing that the most influential features vary across different sales groups. For high-value orders, quantity and payment method had the strongest influence, while payment method was also most significant in medium-value orders, and voucher usage had the most effect in low-value orders. These findings demonstrate that explainable AI can help to make targeted interventions to minimize order cancellation costs.

title: A Paradigm for the Application of Generative Machines in the Educational Domain in the Context of Bloom's Revised Taxonomy
authors: Valentin Atanasov, Aneliya Ivanova
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The development of a modern paradigm for the use of cognitive and, in particular, generative machines (GM) in the field of education and the learning process raises several fundamental questions for discussion in the community of educators across the entire disciplinary spectrum. On the one hand, the existence of different understandings of the essence of such a paradigm builds the thesis for the formation of its following categories: GM-driven, in which the learner is considered a recipient; GM-supported, in which the learner is regarded as a collaborator; and GM-empowered, in which the learner is viewed as a leader. On the other hand, its distinctive features are personalized learning, the mentoring role of teachers in the learning process, and the high complexity of the learning applications. The need for a regulated application of this paradigm in the learning process requires the use of a working framework with predefined categories, forming a functionally complete system "learning process" — "pedagogical goal", and the revised Bloom's taxonomy is considered a suitable tool for this purpose.

title: Self-generation of industrial energy in Ecuador Regulatory, technical, and strategic perspectives for the energy transition.
authors: Guamán-Pozo Jessica Michelle, Cuji Cuji Cristian Cristobal, Calderón-Ordóñez Fernando Javier, Segura Muñoz Félix de Jesús
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study developed a technical and legal methodology to evaluate the potential for self-generation of electricity in Ecuador, using electricity consumption data by sectors from 2018 to 2023. Through a quantitative analysis, linear trends were projected until 2026, highlighting that the residential sector will reach an estimated consumption of ~8996 GWh (38.3%), followed by the industrial sector with ~6439 GWh (27.4%) and the commercial sector with ~4066 GWh (17.3%). However, although the industrial sector represents a high percentage of consumption, its growth has been negative, so commerce and public lighting emerge as priority candidates to initiate self-generation processes due to their stability and growth. Technical, legal and social criteria are incorporated, establishing a structured methodological process: review of the legal framework, technical analysis, consumption forecasts, visualization, interpretation of results and decision-making. These findings allow guiding differentiated public policies and promoting energy planning consistent with the national energy transition.

title: Hybrid Intelligence as a Tool for Managing Sustainable Innovations in Industrial and Energy Systems
authors: Petya D. Georgieva, Siyka Demirova, Kostadin Markov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The report examines the application of hybrid intelligence as a combination of artificial intelligence and human expertise for driving sustainable innovation in industrial and energy systems. The study aims to demonstrate the potential of HI to reduce the energy consumption, carbon emissions, and production costs in line with global goals for sustainable development and climate neutrality. The methodology includes a mixed approach: quantitative data analysis (Bulgaria, EU, global), mathematical modelling and a simulation of a 30-day production process. The results show an average 15% reduction in energy, 10% in emissions and 11% in costs, with the effect being most significant for enterprises with large production volumes. Although the practical implementation uses deterministic Excel simulation with percentage calculations, these methods serve as simplified analogues of artificial intelligence techniques. The simulation validates the conceptual assumptions and provides a statistical baseline for the future integration of advanced AI methods such as regression forecasting, neural networks, and optimisation algorithms.

title: The Prompt–Refactor–Verify (PRV) Cycle: A Human-Centered Framework for AI-Assisted Programming
authors: Nikolay Yanev, Iglika Getova, Elizabet Mihaylova, Iva Kostadinova, Milena Bankovska, Georgi Dimitrov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The widespread adoption of large language models (LLMs) in software development has given rise to vibe coding—a practice in which developers rely on conversational prompts to generate and refine code. While this approach accelerates prototyping and lowers barriers to entry, it also introduces risks including frequent and unstable code changes, reduced readability, and a lack of accountability. To address these challenges, this paper proposes the Prompt–Refactor– Verify (PRV) cycle, a lean, human-centered framework that adapts prompt engineering techniques to AI-assisted programming.

title: Application of the Ant Colony Optimization algorithm (ACO) in urban route optimization: an in silico case study
authors: Fabricio Marcillo Vera, Anderson Meza Vizuete, Argel Velez Villagomez, Sebastián Toscano Araque, Kenneth Cevallos Cedeño, Andy Alava Gomez, Andy Roldan Posligua
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study examined how the Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) algorithm could be used to improve urban route planning, using a simulation based on the classic Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP). Four city locations were represented using Cartesian coordinates, and the distances between them were calculated with the Euclidean formula. The experiment was conducted in Python 3.13.0, applying NetworkX and Matplotlib for modeling and visualization. The ACO algorithm was configured with four ants and ten iterations, using standard parameters such as pheromone importance, evaporation rate, and heuristic influence. The results showed that the ants generated distinct routes. The most efficient path—C4, C3, C1, C2, C4—was identified early in the process, with a total length of 241.45 km. The variability in the solutions highlighted ACO’s ability to explore multiple possibilities within the search space. Compared to other heuristic techniques like Genetic Algorithms, Tabu Search, or Simulated Annealing, ACO showed a more flexible and stable performance, particularly in dynamic urban environments. These qualities suggest that ACO could be a valuable approach for tackling routing problems in cities, especially when conditions such as traffic or delivery constraints are in constant change. While results were promising, future research is encouraged to evaluate ACO in more complex urban scenarios and explore how tuning its parameters might enhance its performance in real-world applications.

title: Benchmarking Web Security for Countries in the Black Sea Region
authors: Ana Țurcan, Dumitru Ciorbă
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The Black Sea region combines high geopolitical sensitivity with uneven digital maturity. We benchmark countries by jointly analyzing national-level posture (ITU GCI), government implementation capacity (NCSI), and digital readiness (NRI), together with an application-level Web Security Index (WSI) computed from HTTP security headers of the top 1,000 user-visited websites per country. WSI is defined on a 0–150 scale (50 points each for Content Security—CS, Cross-Location Security—CLS, and Network & Protocol Security—NPS); in our 2024/2025 snapshot, the highest observed country score is ~120, reflecting gaps primarily in CLS policies. We (i) make our WSI reproducible via a transparent rubric and collection pipeline, (ii) quantify where policy-level indices align—or diverge—from practical web hardening, and (iii) provide country-specific recommendations. Results show a consistent regional gap in CLS, partial alignment between GCI/NCSI and NPS, and multiple policy–practice mismatches around CSP adoption. We discuss limitations and directions for follow-up comparative studies.

title: The Application of Big Data Analytics in the Retail Sector: A Comparative Study of European Union Member States
authors: Simeonka Petrova, Zoya Ivanova, Elena Valcheva
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: This article aims to empirically assess the application of Big Data analytics by retail enterprises across the 27 EU member states, building on systematized conceptual reasoning and employing econometric methods. A total of eight indicators have been selected as factor variables, characterizing the digital level of application of Big Data analytics in the surveyed enterprises in 2023, while the outcome variable is "enterprises in the retail sector with e-commerce sales". The study is based on data published by Eurostat. The methodological framework of the study encompasses the application of cluster analysis and the method of linear regression and correlation, implemented using SPSS Statistics and Microsoft Excel. The obtained research results reveal the formation, at the European level, of segments of retail sector enterprises with both similar and differing capacities to apply Big Data analytics in their business activities. The established positive correlation supports the conclusion that this type of analysis positively influences the growth of the assessed economic sector.

title: Spice Modeling of CA100 Rechargeable Lithium Iron Phosphate Battery for Opel Corsa Converted Electric Vehicle
authors: Dobroslav Dankov, Strahil Sabev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The successful conversion of cars from internal combustion engines to electric motors involves the preliminary selection of a battery and battery management system (BMS). The publication offers a Spice model of the CA100 LiFePO4 battery for modeling the battery's performance during the conversion of an Opel Corsa vehicle in order to determine the SOC at different discharge currents and operating temperatures.

title: Codigen: Enhancing Personalized Programming Education with Visual Authoring and LLMs
authors: Mohamed Ez-Zaouia, Yazid Boumarafi
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC)
abstract: Computer programming is an essential skill for the 21st-century workforce. However, mastering programming is challenging, especially for beginners. Recently, digital tools have become popular in supporting programming education. However, creating engaging programming materials remains difficult due to the many factors that need consideration. We introduce Codigen, an interactive tool powered by large language models (LLMs) that integrates visual authoring and prompt engineering to support programming education with various learning strategies. A user study with 29 participants showed that Codigen can assist teachers in generating quality programming materials. Statistical analysis showed that Codigen supports learners’ confidence and learning outcomes in programming. The perceived utility and engagement with the tool were also statistically significant. We discuss our findings to guide the design and use of LLM-powered authoring tools for educational purposes.

title: A Conceptual Framework for Integrating IoT, Artificial Intelligence and Blockchain in Smart Agriculture
authors: Avni Rustemi, Florim Idrizi, Ejup Rustemi, Hirijete Idrizi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The digitalization of agricultural processes requires the commitment and implementation of contemporary technologies such as the Internet of Things (IoT), Blockchain technology (BT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) in order to address the current challenges that different countries are facing, both in terms of productivity and safety of agricultural processes. Smart agriculture (SA) offers many solutions in terms of increasing productivity, implementing intelligent methods for cultivating agricultural products, rational use of resources and creating a safer agricultural chain. Real-time monitoring through IoT sensors, secure connection and communication between devices through BT, and the creation of long-term strategy through intelligent algorithms and machine learning are the main goals of SA, among others. Through the paper, we will attempt to provide a description of current developments in SA, the advantages and disadvantages in the context of practical implementations, as well as the proposal of a conceptual framework for the integration of IoT, AI and BT in smart agriculture.

title: Hybrid Heuristic Method for Optimal Transmission Switching with Greedy Pre-Filtering
authors: Viktor Tailakov, Tatyana Golubeva, Yaroslav Napadailo, Ivan Beloev, Teodor Iliev
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Optimal Transmission Switching (OTS) is a method of optimising the operation of power systems by selectively disconnecting transmission lines in order to minimise costs while ensuring that the solution remains feasible. Traditional MILP-based methods are computationally expensive when applied to large-scale networks. This paper therefore proposes a hybrid heuristic method involving greedy pre-filtering, whereby the MILP problem is replaced by a series of linear programming (LP) problems. The method begins by solving an optimal power flow (OPF) problem under the assumption that all lines are connected. This is followed by the iterative disconnection of lines with low utilisation, with solution feasibility being checked at each step using LP. This approach reduces the computational burden by transforming the problem into a series of LP tasks and avoids the exponential complexity of the branch-and-bound method. Experiments on IEEE test systems with 3, 14 and 30 nodes demonstrate that the proposed heuristic achieves near-optimal solutions while reducing computation time by 50–80% for systems with over 100 nodes, as confirmed by literature on heuristic OTS methods. This method is suitable for real-time decision support systems (DSS) and can be extended using machine learning techniques to predict which lines to disconnect, making it a practical tool for managing operational power systems.

title: Study of Combined Heat and Power Integrated Carbon Capture and Compression at an Existing Cement Manufacturing Facility
authors: Wayuta Srisang, Brent Jacobs, Yuewu Feng, Puttipong Tantikhajorngosol, Doug Daverne, Conway Nelson
publish: 2023 IEEE-IAS/PCA Cement Industry Conference (IAS/PCA)
abstract: As countries and organizations establish net zero targets and pathways to achieve these targets, the role of carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCS/CCUS) is widely recognized. The role of CCS is particularly important in the cement industry where over half of the CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions are inherent to the cement manufacturing process and, therefore, need to be mitigated by CCS or other means.A feasibility study was completed for an existing cement manufacturing facility in Western Canada; the so-called CCS Feasibility Study. The study uncovered a number of innovations that can be applied to reduce the overall risk profile of the project from an economic and reliability perspective. This paper will share the results of evaluating options for a combined heat and power (CHP) plant to supply energy to the CCS facility. Several CHP options were evaluated, and a combustion turbine selection was recommended. The addition of CHP can increase the project NPV by running consistently and providing power to the grid when the cement plant isn’t running.

title: Improving Dysarthria Assessment Through Voice Conversion in Low-Resource Settings
authors: Emily Chimbo, Felipe Grijalva, Karen Rosero
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: The development of automatic dysarthria assessment systems is often limited by the scarcity of labeled pathological speech, particularly in low-resource clinical environments. In this work, we explore the use of generative voice conversion to address this bottleneck. We propose a pipeline based on speech enhancement and voice conversion to transfer dysarthric vocal traits onto healthy utterances to generate realistic pathological speech. A total of 4,082 synthetic samples were generated and enhanced to improve quality while preserving pathological prosody. A dual-branch CNN trained under four experimental setups showed that combining real and synthetic data improved the classification accuracy from $\mathbf{7 7. 5 2 \%}$ to $\mathbf{9 8. 3 6 \%}$, while using only enhanced synthetic data reached 97.10%. These results support the use of voice conversion to expand clinical datasets and reduce dependence on real patient recordings.

title: IntelliGrow: Image processing with IoT alert for pests and diseases classification in chili plant
authors: Jardel Mckenzy Melvin, Danial Md Nor, Fahmy Rinanda Saputri, King Lee Chua, Abdel Rahman Al Ali, Fahad Saleh M Abdallah
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Smart Cities, Automation &amp; Intelligent Computing Systems (ICON-SONICS)
abstract: Pest and disease outbreaks in chili cultivation remain significant challenges for farmers. Traditional manual inspection methods are slow, inconsistent and labor-intensive, often resulting in reduced crop yields and economic losses. This study presents IntelliGrow, a smart system integrating image processing, deep learning, and Internet of Things(IoT) technologies to detect and classify chili plant diseases in real time. A deep learning model based on Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), developed with TensorFlow, classifies chili leaf conditions into Anthracnose, Aphid Infestation, Powdery Mildew, and Healthy categories. The system integrates a Raspberry Pi with a webcam, LEDs, and a buzzer to enable real-time image capture, classification, and alert notifications. Detection results are stored in a MySQL database and displayed through a web application built using HTML, CSS, JavaScript, PhpMyAdmin, and XAMPP. Testing showed high classification accuracy, with $100 \%$ for Anthracnose, $98.92 \%$ for Healthy plants, $83.60 \%$ for Powdery Mildew, and $59.56 \%$ for Aphid Infestation. The system supports both scheduled and manual detection for real-time monitoring and alerts, offering a reliable and low-cost solution for early pest and disease detection in smart agriculture.

title: Research on the Influence of Air Temperature and Physiological Work Mode on the Efficiency of Occupational Safety in the Sewing Industry
authors: Vasil Chobanov
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to establish how significant the influence of air temperature and the physiological regime of work and rest, separately and jointly, is on the effective-ness of occupational safety in sewing companies. Considering the significant influence of these parameters on the health of employees, the morbidity of workers was chosen as a criterion for the effectiveness of occupational safety. The research was carried out for one of the main areas in a garment factory of a sewing company - the area for moisture-heat treatment. To increase the efficiency in ensuring safe working conditions, the air temperature is constantly recorded over time, using a computer-integrated measurement system. The studies were carried out for two periods - cold and warm periods of the year. Using the methods of two-factor analysis of variance, the influence, separately and jointly, of air temperature and the physiological regime of work and rest on the morbidity of workers is established. The results obtained create conditions for making quick and accurate decisions to increase the efficiency of processes for ensuring occupational safety as well as for their mathematical modeling.

title: Topics Model in Political Communication on Social Media for NTB Governor Election
authors: Mohammad Taufan Asri Zaen, Lalu Mutawalli, Muhammad Fauzi Zulkarnaen, Maulana Ashari, Ahmad Tantoni
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: This study presents a computational analysis of political discourse in the 2024 West Nusa Tenggara (NTB) gubernatorial election using advanced topic modeling techniques. Leveraging Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), Nonnegative Matrix Factorization (NMF), and Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT), we examine social media content associated with three major candidate pairs: Rohmi-Firin, Zul-Uhel, and Iqbal-Dinda. Data was acquired via automated web scraping and official Instagram APIs, encompassing posts, comments, and engagement metrics. The objective is to identify dominant semantic patterns and temporal shifts in political communication across digital platforms. Experimental results reveal distinct thematic distributions among candidates, with recurring topics including community engagement, youth empowerment, education, and local economic development. Coherence scores across models validate the effectiveness of topic modeling in capturing latent structures within unstructured textual data. This research contributes to the intersection of natural language processing and computational social science by demonstrating scalable methods for extracting insights from large-scale political data. The findings underscore the utility of machine learning in decoding public sentiment and campaign strategies, offering implications for the development of AI-driven political analytics systems.

title: A Strategic Management Model for Renewable Energy SMEs in the Context of Ecuador’s Energy Matrix Transformation
authors: Franklin E. Pacheco
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This study proposes a strategic management model tailored to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Ecuador’s renewable energy sector, within the broader context of the country’s shift in its energy matrix. The lack of adaptive management tools aligned with public policy frameworks represents a major barrier to SME development in this emerging sector. Through a mixed-methods approach—including document analysis, surveys of potential end users, and interviews with SME representatives—this research diagnoses internal and external challenges affecting these firms. The proposed model integrates strategic planning with the Balanced Scorecard framework, aligning critical success factors, value propositions, and performance indicators. The resulting strategic map and dashboard serve as a practical guide for SMEs aiming to increase competitiveness and policy alignment in a rapidly evolving industry.

title: A Real-Time UAV Surveillance System with Fine-Tuned YOLO Models: Comparative Analysis of Vehicle and Pedestrian Detection
authors: Darwin Macas-Poma, Alan Tierra-Llanga, Washington Luna-Encalada, José Morales-Gordon, Jorge Hernández-Ambato, Ramiro Isa-Jara
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Object detection for vehicles and people in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) applications is crucial in various fields s uch a s ecurity a nd s urveillance, t raffic management, smart mobility, logistics and warehousing, among others. This work presents a detailed comparison of YOLO models, fine-tuned on VisDrone, under various environmental, density, weather, and lighting conditions, considering the Mean Average Precision (mAP) and inference speed. To achieve these results, the study begins with a “baseline” YOLO network determined through a literature review for model selection. Subsequently, recent versions of the network and variations introduced through fine-tuning a rec onsidered. F inally, a $n A I$ a rchitecture model with an optimal balance between accuracy and inference speed is proposed, which is integrated into a real-time vehicle and person detection system for live transmission from a UAV in flight, monitored and operated through a ground-based computer interface.

title: Model to Increase Inventory Turnover in a Vehicle Dealership Through Economic Order Quantity, Winters Forecasting, Warehouse Management and Material Planning with a Sustainable Approach
authors: Delgado Silva, Daniel Alberto, Ramírez Pérez, Oshiro Akyhito, Saenz Moron, Martín, Straujuma, Anita
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: Low inventory turnover in vehicle dealerships represents a critical issue that generates high operating costs due to prolonged storage, unit depreciation, and missed business opportunities. This scenario worsens with the emerging demands of the automotive market, such as the transition to electric vehicles, which require more agile, efficient, and sustainable inventory management. While previous efforts have focused on traditional inventory control techniques, these are insufficient in complex environments where traceability and digital planning are decisive. In this context, the present study aims to develop an improvement model to increase inventory turnover through the integration of tools such as Economic Order Quantity (EOQ), Winters forecasting, a Warehouse Management System (WMS), and Material Requirements Planning (MRP), under the Industry 4.0 and sustainability approach. The proposal seeks to systematize vehicle-level data, optimize inventory availability, and ensure efficient communication regarding the status and location of units. The model was validated in a real dealership through performance indicators, achieving an $85 \%$ increase in turnover, a $13 \%$ reduction in unplanned purchases, a $5 \%$ decrease in unregistered vehicles, and a $5 \%$ reduction in delivery delays due to stockouts. It is concluded that integrating emerging technologies with traditional methodologies significantly improves operational efficiency, offering a scalable and adaptable solution for other sectors with high inventory turnover.

title: Collaborator Selection and Paths to Enhance Exploratory Innovation: Should Inventor Collaboration Seek Common Ground or Preserve Differences?
authors: Ke-Chiun Chang, Xiaoran Sun, Xinyi Xiong, Shuyu Zhang, Yen-Chun Lai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: We investigate why inventors choose specific collaborators and how different collaboration patterns shape the relationship between network stability and exploratory innovation in interdisciplinary contexts. Using nano-energy patents (1998-2021) from the Derwent World Patent Index, we find that collaboration network stability hinders exploratory innovation, and this effect is moderated by assortativity. We classify collaborations into two types based on inventors' assortativity and network location: high assortativity collaboration, where core (peripheral) inventors work with others in similar locations, and low assortativity collaboration, where inventors collaborate across different network locations. We further examine how these collaborations influence the impact mechanism, challenging the conventional assumption of core-core collaboration. Robustness tests, including narrowed sample windows and alternative variable measures, confirm the consistency of results. Our findings provide nuanced insights into how partner selection and collaboration structures affect exploratory innovation, offering practical guidance for managers seeking to design effective collaboration strategies in technology-driven and interdisciplinary organizations. Managerial Relevance Statement-This study offers actionable insights for managers tasked with organizing and leading innovation teams in dynamic interdisciplinary environments. Our finding that network stability impedes exploratory innovation underscores the importance of reconsidering collaborator selection. Managers should carefully balance the benefits of predictable, stable networks with the need for fresh perspectives. Notably, individual inventor collaborative preferences—the tendency to collaborate with similar peers (assortativity)—should also be closely monitored. As the effects of these preferences vary depending on an inventor's position within the network, organizations should promote cross-boundary collaboration, particularly between core and peripheral members. Such collaboration fosters the exchange of heterogeneous ideas and mitigates cognitive inertia. By aligning collaboration preferences with strategic network locations, organizations can sustain exploratory innovation and remain competitive in rapidly evolving technological landscapes. This study also contributes to the following SDGs: SDG 7, SDG 17.

title: Low-Resource FPGA Implementation of DWPT for Power Quality Indices Estimation Using MAC-Based Wavelet Filters
authors: Vinay K. Tiwari, D. Prakash Reddy, Sachin K. Jain
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This work presents the design and implementation of a Multiply-Accumulate Discrete Wavelet Packet Transform (MAC-DWPT) architecture for estimating power quality indices on a Field-programmable gate array. In conventional DWPT, increasing the wavelet filter order improves power quality indices estimation accuracy by reducing spectral leakage, but it also increases hardware usage, lowers operating frequency, and raises power consumption. The proposed MAC-DWPT overcomes these limitations by maintaining nearly constant resource utilization, operating frequency, and power consumption regardless of the wavelet filter order. For the proposed MAC-DWPT architecture (using the Daubechies mother wavelet, db8) implemented on a Xilinx Artix-7 FPGA AC701 board, Look-Up Table (LUT) utilization is reduced from 54.12% to 42.63%, Flip-Flop (FF) utilization from 15.41% to 10.57%, and DSP slice utilization from 96.39% to 39.59%, compared to the conventional DWPT. In addition, total on-chip power consumption is reduced by approximately 52.08%, while the design maintains an operating frequency of about 130 MHz, independent of the wavelet filter order.

title: Fault Diagnosis Method for Single-Phase-to-Ground Faults Based on Phase-to-Phase Current Fault Components in Distribution Networks
authors: Jiawei Yuan, Xiaojian Dong, Lifeng Xing, Xuan Dong, Jun Liu, Zaibin Jiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: Accurate diagnosis of single-phase-to-ground (SPG) faults in distribution networks is essential for rapid fault isolation and reduced power interruptions. Existing approaches often address only one aspect of fault diagnosis, suffering from low reliability, heavy communication requirements, and high investment costs. To overcome these challenges, this paper presents a comprehensive fault diagnosis method based on phase-to-phase current fault components (PPCFC). The fault characteristics of PPCFCs are firstly analyzed on both the substation and feeder sides, taking into account the practical configuration of current detection devices. The results show that, in faulty feeders and sections, the fault-phase-related PPCFCs are significantly larger than the healthy-phase-related ones, while in healthy feeders and sound sections, all three PPCFCs remain close to zero. The PPCFCs are then calculated with consideration of possible triggering delays under high impedance faults, and their amplitude features are extracted. Based on this analysis, a fault phase and faulty feeder identification method is developed using PPCFCs from a single feeder at the substation side. In addition, a distributed location strategy is proposed, which employs local indicators to accurately determine the fault section via simple binary communication. Extensive experiments confirm its effectiveness and practicality.

title: State-Triggered Fault-Tolerant Control Strategy for Performance Recovery in Nonlinear Interconnected Systems
authors: Weiwei Sun, Lusong Ding, Xinyu Lv, You Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article develops the performance recovery-based state-triggered fault-tolerant control (FTC) strategy for nonlinear interconnected systems (NISs). Under discontinuous state transmission, a novel set of event-triggered chainlike filters is introduced to reconstruct the error coordinate transformation, effectively addressing the challenge of state-triggered nondifferentiability. Then, a dynamic redundancy fault-tolerant control method is presented, which is tailored to constrain full errors and ensure prescribed performance, even in the face of actuator faults. It is capable of handling different types of faults, including moderate faults and extreme faults, and explicitly takes deferred actuator switching into account. By exploiting the performance function, the exceeding errors can be recovered into the safe constraints even after complete actuator failure. Besides, the globally uniformly ultimately bounded of closed-loop signals is realized without dependence on any unknown initial conditions. Finally, the validity of the proposed method is confirmed by a practical example.

title: Semantic Covert Communication: Concealing Sensitive Image Information via Covertness-Oriented Artificial Noise
authors: Chengyu Yin, Yiliang Liu, Zhou Su
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: This paper investigates covert transmission in semantic communication systems, with a particular focus on protecting sensitive information embedded in images. While current research on semantic secure communication emphasizes semantic confidentiality, it often overlooks the covertness of semantic content. To bridge this gap, we propose a semantic covert communication scheme comprising a semantic covert artificial noise module and a deep learning module. The semantic covert artificial noise module ensures that the covertness-oriented artificial noise (CoAN) lies within the null space of the legitimate user’s channel, so that it perturbs only the eavesdropper while preserving the legitimate user’s ability to recover semantic information. The deep learning module is designed to distinguish sensitive content from the background in an image. Furthermore, the semantic covert communication neural network is trained using a customized information-bottleneck–inspired loss function that simultaneously enhances the semantic expressiveness of the representation observed by the legitimate user and improves the semantic representational capability of the CoAN at the eavesdropper, thereby inducing the eavesdropper to misinterpret the transmitted information as background. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme conceals sensitive information from the eavesdropper’s perspective while maintaining high-fidelity semantic recovery for the legitimate user.

title: From Time Series to Images: A GAF-ResNet-LSTM Framework for Asset Selection and Portfolio Optimization
authors: Neha Solanki, Manoj Jha
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Financial market forecasting in portfolio formation has increasingly drawn interest within machine learning due to its complex temporal dynamics and high volatility. While Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) have demonstrated efficacy in image-based tasks, their direct application to time series data remains limited. To address this, we propose a prediction-based portfolio optimization framework that converts stock price sequences into Gramian Angular Field (GAF) images, enabling spatial feature extraction via a ResNet. Temporal dependencies are captured using a LSTM encoder, forming a hybrid GAF + ResNet-LSTM model. To be specific, this paper first applies these prediction models for asset preselection before portfolio construction. Then, this paper incorporates their predictive results in advancing nested clustered optimization (NCO) method, which clusters assets based on predictive confidence and allocates weights using intra-cluster optimization. In order to balance calibration and classification, Training employs walk-forward validation and a composite loss combining mean squared error and directional accuracy. The empirical study is conducted on a dataset comprising 25 stocks from the National Stock Exchange of India, spanning January 2014 to January 2024, including periods of market disruption such as the COVID-19 crash. Thus the sample makes it possible to catch subtle market shift for model execution. Moreover, we compared the performance of the proposed model against equally weighted and mean-variance portfolios to underscore the advantages of the NCO model. The proposed model achieves a 21.05% annual return with a Sharpe ratio of 1.31, outperforming benchmark architectures. Empirical results demonstrate that the proposed technique significantly outperforms the benchmark portfolios, particularly for investors with a high risk-return preference. Statistical significance is further corroborated by t-tests. Based on these findings, we advocate the integration of our comprehensive portfolio optimization model into investment decision-making processes.

title: Digital Transformation, CEO Career Concerns, and Enterprise Green Mergers and Acquisitions_supp1-3647692.docx
authors: Lei Zhao
publish: N/A
abstract: Green transformation has become a global consensus, but enterprises often treat it as a symbolic strategy rather than a substantive commitment. While existing studies have examined how internal capabilities and external pressures influence enterprise green actions, few have explored how digital transformation enables external green strategies such as green mergers and acquisitions (M&A), or how CEO career concerns shape such decisions. This study examines the impact of digital transformation on green M&A among Chinese A-share listed enterprises from 2010 to 2023, with an in-depth analysis of the moderating role of CEO career concerns in this process. The results show that digital transformation significantly promotes green M&A, particularly when CEOs face external and prospective concerns, whereas internal career concerns weaken this effect. Heterogeneity analysis reveals that the digital–green relationship varies by CEO characteristics, industry type, and enterprise characteristics. The study enriches the understanding of sustainable strategic decision-making mechanisms in engineering management. It offers enterprises guidance on aligning incentives to promote the synergy between digital transformation and green transition.

title: Cascade PID—FOPID Control with Single Sensor: Application to the EPC Educational Plant
authors: Luis Caiza, Diego S. Benitez, Oscar Camacho
publish: 2025 IEEE Ninth Ecuador Technical Chapters Meeting (ETCM)
abstract: This paper presents a modified cascade control structure using a single sensor applied to the EPC Educational Plant. It maintains the hierarchical design of cascade control, with an outer-loop controller overseeing the main process variable and an inner-loop control action derived rather than directly measured. The method simplifies setup and reduces instrumentation costs, making it ideal for educational environments and cost-sensitive industrial applications where frequent disturbances reduce the performance of basic feedback controllers.

title: A Random Forest and SMOTE (RFS) Approach for Stroke Prediction on Imbalanced Medical Data
authors: Achmad Jauhari, Fifin Ayu Mufarroha, Devie Rosa Anamisa, Amelia Nur Septiyasari
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th Information Technology International Seminar (ITIS)
abstract: Stroke is a very serious global health problem, and accurate early detection is necessary to minimize its burden. A stroke prediction model integrating the Random Forest (RF) with the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) is introduced here for solving the class imbalance in medical data. The data, collected from Bangladesh, contains 5,110 samples and 11 features with only 249 stroke cases. To ensure data quality, a strong preprocessing pipeline was followed that involved data selection, encoding for categorical features, KNN Imputer imputation for missing values, removal of outliers using the Interquartile Range (IQR) method, and min-max normalization. SMOTE was then applied to balance data. The current work is combination of SMOTE-based resampling and RF classification, made possible by intensive preprocessing and Gain Ratio-based feature selection. It improves both data representation and prediction. Experimental results show that the model suggested employing SMOTE ($k=5$) and achieved 95% accuracy, with 829 True Positives (TP), 59 False Positives (FP), 786 True Negatives (TN), and 19 False Negatives (FN). These findings highlight the strength of integrating oversampling and ensemble learning for predicting health tasks. This work provides fresh understanding of handling imbalanced health data. Future research could extend this approach and explore other sampling methods, more advanced feature selection techniques, and hyperparameter adjustment

title: Integrated Threat Intelligence and Event Correlation with Wazuh, Suricata, and MISP
authors: Manos Vasilakis, Manolis Tampouratzis, Athanasios Dimitriadis
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: Modern cyber threats are becoming increasingly sophisticated, requiring complicated defense techniques to be able to detect them, making traditional defense methods inadequate. This research presents an automated architecture with open source solutions, integrating a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system based on Wazuh that executes correlation rules and matches correlations from Suricata alerts and the lists of the MISP for confirmed threats, Suricata, a high-performance Intrusion Detection System (IDS) designed for network detection and malicious pattern detection, and a Malware Information Sharing Platform (MISP), which is continuously enriched by the updated URLhaus database of indicators of compromise (IoCs), which contains datasets with malicious URLs and receives data from MISP through an automated continuous flow. Automated Python scripts have been created to run via cron jobs and their purpose is to extract IoCs by connecting to the MISP API and then converting them into Suricata rules. The proposed integration improves event correlation and accurately detects all malicious IoCs in the specific database, leading to a more efficient detection of known threats.

title: Intelligent Fault Diagnosis of Induction Motor Bearings Using SVM Algorithm for Predictive Maintenance Industrial Applications
authors: Vasileios I. Vlachou, Theoklitos S. Karakatsanis, Dimitrios E. Efstathiou, Stavros D. Vologiannidis, Agisilaos E. Efraimidis, Eftychios I. Vlachou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communications, Information, Electronic and Energy Systems (CIEES)
abstract: In most industrial applications, induction motors (IMs) are fundamental to the automation, generation and transfer of energy, making them a reliable and economical choice. Their continuous operation causes significant stresses on electrical and mechanical parts of the system. Bearings are one of the key mechanical components that play a critical role in shaft motion, offering reduced friction and smooth rotation under various load conditions. Recent research studies have shown that bearing faults occupy the highest percentage of failures in IM. In recent years, the evolution of the Internet of Things (IoT) and artificial intelligence systems have contributed to the development of predictive maintenance methods to monitor, assess and diagnose potential future failures. The present study focuses on the creation of an experimental setup that includes an IM and its corresponding control system to collect real time vibration measurements. Our experiments were based on the six different operating states of the bearing in healthy operation and under fault conditions. The proposed methodology includes statistical analysis of the data and development of a machine learning algorithm based on Support Vector Machine (SVM) technique for classification and automatic diagnosis of the bearing condition.
